We started with the Salmon Crudo, English Pea Sformatino (one of my personal faves), Anchovies, Grilled Calimari and the famous Spaghetti.

Entrees included the Liberty Duck, Mint Tagliatelle and Ricotta-stuffed pasta and short-rib-stuffed pasta.  

Dessert was the Cherry Crostata

We got ALOT of items and every morsel was simply to die for.  Cannot wait to go back!

THANK YOU AND APPLAUSE DELFINA!
author: Maryn R.

description:
Meh. 

Everything was just meh. 

Perhaps I just had way too high expectations, since everyone raves about it?

Our spaghetti was super salty, to the point where I couldn't eat a bite without taking a sip of water. (maybe I just came on a bad night). 

The pork sugo pappardelle wasn't bad. But also wasn't mind blowingly great. 

The worst was the grilled swordfish. It was so fishy and dry, that it was really hard to swallow. 

On the bright side, they have really good service and a great dinner ambiance.
author: Cynthia L.

description: Went there last night, and called for a reservation before hand. The waitress said no reservation was required, first come first serve if we arrived around 6. When we got there at six and she said for a table we would have to wait until 9:30. Stupid, inconsiderate, and bad business motto
author: Hong Y.

description:
"I put my head on a pillow of Brentwood corn and had a sweet dream."

Delfina's seasonal, Tuscan based menu will provide you a delectable, memorable dinner appropriate to commemroate any occassion.

This weekend we celebrated our friend's marriage by bringing them from Los Angeles to San Francisco's Mission District.  

We enjoyed a Sylvaner | Kuenhof 2011 , Alto Adige (white wine) with our appetizers and a Barolo "Otin Fiorin" | Cappellano 2007 Piemonte (red wine) with our main courses.

We enjoyed heirloom tomatoes and house made mozzarella and an anchoives (such cute little anchoives bisected and laid out in allegorical crosses).  We also ordered a grilled calamari which we enjoyed also, but not as much as the other two appetizers.

For a primi I ordered the spagetti and Erin ordered the Brentwood sweet corn soup I reference in the opening quote.  For my secondi I enjoyed a special duck breast harkening back to my first meal here a decade ago.
author: Bryan W.

description:
Awesome cute restaurant with flavourful combination of food, with smiling hosts :)
Dinner started with Tartine Bread and Insalata di Campo, an amazing flavour burst of green salad. As a first time visitor and vegetarians, we were suggested spaghetti or a white truffle pasta by our host. We chose the spaghetti and it was simple yet yummy-yum-yum. This wonderful experience came to an end with a heavenly chocolate-esspresso-gelato desert.
author: Adithi A.

description:
There are few dishes that I can think of that have such a wide range in quality as spaghetti with tomato sauce. Delfina takes this staple to sublime level that I didn't think was possible, saucing perfectly cooked pasta with a robust, intense tomato sauce with a bit of a kick. There's nowhere to hide with something this simple - it's basically just the pasta and the tomatoes and amazingly good execution. The other food is great too, but we always start things off with the spaghetti as an appetizer. This past time we really enjoyed the short ribs and the profiteroles.

The restaurant is cozy but the last two times we've gone we arrived a few minutes before opening time (530pm) and got seated immediately. Sometimes the menu takes a bit of work to decode but that adds to the charm.
author: Wing Y.

description:
Received soda in a broken glass and didn't realise until after drinking through the straw what appeared to be crunchy ice , realised was glass shards. Swallowed a few pieces. No real apology, glass changed and additional bottle of soda provided. Prior to realising poured some ice into my husbands glass; after incident asked waiter to change my husbands glass which already had drink. Glass was changed but no replacement of lost drink provided.

Despite having a reservations waited 30 minutes for table during which time 4 of us were move around the busy  restaurant like we were cattle.

Food was ok, nothing special.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I'm not sure how I haven't reviewed Delfina yet.  This is the restaurant that started me on the path to California cuisine and eventually to other epicurean interests.  When I first went to Delfina in 2003, I fell in love with everything about it.  Friendly, unpretentious staff.  Simple, delicious food.  Casual dining atmosphere.  I had the roast chicken and it was cooked to perfection.  Crispy skin, tender-juicy meat.  It is probably one of the defining moments in my culinary dining history.

Fast-forward to 2011.  The menu mainstays are still there and they keep rotating the seasonal specials.  It feels a little more pretentious as the waiters now explain out all the specials.  (Thinking back it was probably not the explanation that was pretentious but the waitress' tone)  Maybe it was just that one night I went recently.  This place still feels magical to me.  Everything a neighborhood restaurant should be.  Welcoming, friendly, and absolutely delicious.
author: John H.

description:
Delfina is everything I've read about and hoped it to be. From start to finish, the food was superb and service was extremely accommadating. 

We were half an hour late for our reservation, as my parking karma seemed to have left the building. I was super apologetic to my friend (and to the hostess) as I'm probably the only Filipino I know who doesn't usually go by Filipino time. You know what? the hostess just smiled and warmly said, "that's not a problem, in fact, we are ready to serve you" (do this at A16 and they will give your table away!) 

Delfina's menu is filled with so many enticing things and everything is fresh and locally sourced.

We shared a couple of apps. Their BURRATA is amazing! Served with olive tapenade on crostinis and accompanied by a small arugula salad. The GRILLED CALAMARI with warm white bean salad is also a good choice. The smokiness of the calamari goes well with the soft creamy beans. Not a fancy dish, but even humble beans taste excellent when presented this way.

On to the Pasta. Oh THE pasta! SPQR does great pasta. Delfina does it even better. Their PORK SUGO PAPPARDELLE is made with love and isn't always on the menu. I guess I got lucky the night I came in! Wide ribbons of al dente pasta with meaty, savory braised pork, perfectly seasoned and doesn't even need additional parmiggiano or anything like that. If you love Italian food like I do, you absolutely have to sample their pasta. 

My only complaint is that the portions are not that big, so order up on the appetizers or if you look at it from my point of view, you'll have plenty of room for dessert. Bi-Rite ice cream is conveniently located across the street. Believe me when I say, on this certain night, I think I've died and gone to heaven.
author: Janice C.

description:
This is one of the best Pizza places in SF, and also has great side dishes.  
Very loud due to music and patrons, and no reservations : you need to put your name on the blackboard when you get in. You can have a glass of wine outside while waiting if its not too cold. 
We love the tuna-bean-watercress salad. All pizzas are great.  The meat balls are fantastic. 

Also great for take out food.
author: JJ B.

description: We wrote to the owner of Delfina describing about our bad experience. She apologized, sent us a gift card and made reservations for us to come back and experience the restaurant. This time around, staff was very cordial, took excellent care of us and food was really really good. Will definitely go back.
author: Lalitha V.

description:
The spaghetti was delicious! 
Risotto was loveley with fresh peas. Could have added one more ingredient to spice it up a bit for example a thick slice of bacon on the side ;) 

The bread and butter was amazing! 
Swordfish was good. 

Quail was off the charts!!! Although it was served in a bed of lettuce which inevitably was wilted. Should be served with a Napa cabbage or a baby bok Choy if they want to get the same idea.   

Great atmosphere, kind service, hipsterish. We made reservations. The connected restaurants pizza looked really good.
author: Olivia A.

description: The way they prepare things is always so much better than it seems like it would be from just the menu descriptions -- which is good.  Its fabulous!!   love it
author: Kirby A.

description:
After reading some of the reviews, I think people are too critical of the waiting time and waiters. You should be prepared to wait; you are not the only person in the world. We had a very nice server who poured the wine and asked about everything. 

There is a pizza restaurant directly next to the main one, and the pizza looks incredible. You can see it as you walk by; I'm excited to try it sometime. 

Good food is subjective. You can have the ripest, juiciest peach in the world, but there will always be someone who doesn't like peaches. Because of that, I'm not saying the food here is bad, and I'm going to make this as objective as possible. First off, let me say the brussel sprout appetizer was delicious, and we were very happy with it! I ordered a fettuccine with mushroom. The noodles were done to my liking, but there was nothing stellar about the dish overall. It was dry, and there wasn't much flavor to the sauce which was a like a butter or cream; I couldn't really tell because there was so little. There was hardly any mushroom in the dish either, so that was disappointing. My other complaint about this restaurant is the portions for the price. We sat near the kitchen and saw every dish coming out and they were so small. I understand small portions are good if the quality of the food is spectacular, but it just wasn't. It was just a small mound of noodles, and plain sauce with a little mushroom for close to or just over 20$ (I can't quite remember the exact price.) My friend felt the same about his pasta dish. 

Perhaps the owners are overwhelmed with the amount of people pouring in here and the menu constantly needing to be changed that they don't really have time to perfect the recipes for every dish.
author: Alexandres M.

description: It was a Friday night date with my wife so we wanted to try Delfina. We had a reservation and they were busy by the time we got there for our dinner.  I thought I would try the Spaghetti, since I hardly make it at home.  My wife ordered the Swordfish.  The service was very good and we got our dinner within a short time.  The presentation was wonderful. My Spaghetti was delicious, and very simple just a light sauce and the pasta, topped with a nice amount of parmesan cheese.  The Swordfish was delicious.  The portion size was perfect.  I had a very nice Italian red wine. I was slowly sipping and enjoying it since it was very good with the Spaghetti. My wife had a blood orange Bellini cocktail which she enjoyed.  Our dinner with drinks was about $85. Overall we had a very nice dining experience at Delfina.
author: Michael S.

description: We tried the grilled calamari appetizer, asparagus appetizer, the spaghetti, pork saltimbocca, skirt steak, and roast chicken.  Service was quite slow on a busy Tuesday night.  I enjoyed the asparagus but couldn't take more than a few bites of the calamari (I just don't like grilled squid because it's so chewy).  The best dish of the bunch was definitely the spaghetti.  Our group was really  underwhelmed by the protein entrees.  One person in my party called the pork saltimbocca as "pork with salt and salt sauce".  Each of us tried a couple bites of it and couldn't eat any more.  There was nothing special about the skirt steak or the fries that accompanied it.  Of the meats, the chicken was the best.  If we came back, I'd stick with pastas and not bother with meats at all.
author: Amelia S.

description:
Elbow-to-elbow with your neighbors, but it's worth it. The food is incredible. The service is fantastic. 

The pasta...oh god, the pasta. So good. Such fresh. Wow. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Julia D.

description:
Walking into the restaurant I immediately noticed how cozy it was.  I loved the blossoms that decorated the restaurant but I loved the food even more.  The spaghetti was cooked perfectly.  The smaller portion was just the right size.  The lasagna had the right amount of richness.  The panna cotta was creamy and tangy.

They often change their menu so there's always a new reason to keep coming back.
author: Rose A.

description:
I live around the corner from Delfina and have always taken guests from Europe here when in town as the staff have always been very professional and the food reliable.  We booked a table for 9,30.  When we arrived there were two free and they tried to seat us a one by the door rather than the better table further back.  Our waiter was helpful and patient.  Otherwise we fond the staff to be surely and tired.  We ordered the calamari, little gems and prosciutto.  All three were ok but nothing to write home about.  

The wine was great.

For main case I had the duck with sauerkraut and duck fat potatoes.  The potatoes were encrusted in coarse salt and so were inedible.  The duck was ok.  nothing special.

My partner ordered sea bass which they had run out of and was replaced by yellow tail tuna.  Which was nothing like described to the point of looking like salmon.

The pasta dish my friends ordered was also too salty to be edible 

The fourth party had the steak and fries which he liked but we noticed three people at the next table did not touch their fries.  Again everything was over salty

The dessert menu was boring.

All in all at $400 I felt the atmosphere was good and we were not rushed but the staff looked bored.  The food however was as bland as I have had anywhere in San Francisco and at these prices I will not be returning ever.

Why would I with places like Foreign Cinema within walking distance.

What a shame

A loss to the neighborhood as a stable place to dine.

NEVER AGAIN!!
author: Michael D.

description: The spaghetti was good but not extraordinary. However, the service was excellent. For example, I left my seat for at most 3 minutes during dinner time rush hour, and when I returned, my napkin had been nicely refolded and placed by my plate. I commend management on the training.
author: Sam W.

description: Impressive, creative cuisine but not quite worth the high price-tag. $25 for a rather small dish of pasta that was good- but almost indistinguishable  from other local Italian spots for half the price. It's also quite busy on the weekend and sort of noisy inside, not the best setting for a romantic evening. I'd say the service was probably the best aspect of this place, but doesn't justify the hefty bill. Not heading back anytime soon.
author: Brett Y.

description: This was a slightly disappointing experience. While the entrees were good and the wine we selected was a great complement to our meal, the service was awful.  Our server took no interest in making recommendations and just seemed generally annoyed with us the whole time, even though it was early and the restaurant wasn't very busy yet. Not sure I'd go back, but would try the Pizza Delfina next door.
author: Patrick F.

description: I don't understand that the fuss is over this place.  The best part was the homemade bread and butter.  The gnocchi was chewy, the pork chop juicy, but overly smoked, and the service was ok.
author: Laurae P.

description:
While Delfina has citywide fame mostly as a result of their pizzeria, it turns out they have a pretty decent non-pizza Italian side as well. 

Star 1: How was the service and atmosphere?

It's not over the top, which I like, and Delfina's service and atmosphere do the trick. Friendly and as fast as quality can allow, Delfina's would be comfortable for a large party and was more than enough for my party of two. Star Granted.

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

Make no mistake, while it's not suit and tie, Delfina's non-pizzeria is classy, so you can expect to pay classy prices. I didn't take a pic, but my Berkshire Pork Arrosto was $25. However, these prices were offset by fairly priced sides and wines. All in all: fair. Star Granted.

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

Good but not great. The pork atop my risotto was generously portioned, but it turned out a decent amount of that portion was fat, which was disappointing. From there, the risotto was soaked in butter, and the Olive Oil Mashed Potatoes were soaked in salt and olive oil. Still enjoyable yes, but I can see why the pizza at the pizzeria next door gets all the attention. Single Star Granted.

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

It's good, but not great, so I have to imagine I'd go to the pizzeria much more often than the restaurant. No Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: The only thing I liked about this place was the ambience and service.  Overpriced!!  We paid $200 for two (wine, 2 appetizers, 2 entrees).  Salty pasta.  Tasteless quail.  Such a hyped place! won't go back!
author: V V.

description:
finally made it to delfina to see how this fine restaurant establishment has been in the city for more than a decade and half.

now let's move on to the food:

appetizers:  we got the polenta and mash to share.  skip the mash and go with the polenta.  they're both mashed up veggies but polenta's cheese was just so spot on.  spread it on the comp tartine bread?  money.

pastas:  i had the spaghetti and an octopus sliced pasta.  i had trouble deciding which one to go with and they're able to make 1/2 orders!  best of both worlds.  i was able to have my mini pasta tasting and it was grand.

dessert:  holy moly panna cotta.  i am officially convinced that the panna cotta is must try at delfina.  everyone's right, it's that good.  i had a glass of cherry dessert wine to go with it and it tasted like a million bux.  

the service was fantastic.  molly(?) was extremely sweet and attentive.  we couldn't decide on which dessert wine to go with and she brought some for us to try.  LOVE.  will definitely be back!  

p.s. $25 corkage fee/bottle of wine.  i say, bring your own wine!
author: Alice C.

description: The busboy had more attitude than anywhere I've ever been,  completely rude when we asked a question. I almost got up to look for the manager right then. Unfortunately the food was mediocre. Served lukewarm and pasta was still a bit hard. Clams in the linguine  were too chewy to swallow. Our server was absolutely lovely and friendly as well as knowledgeable.
author: Elliana S.

description:
Yum! What a great meal! I came here last night with some friends for dinner and left very satisfied. They say the menu changes frequently,  but the dishes I got that night include:
insalata di campo: a refreshing, crisp salad with a lot of shaved parmesan, some walnuts and pancetta. 

chitarra nero: squid ink pasta with crab meat - i loved this dish! it had a buttery lemon sauce that complimented the crab perfectly (note: you can get half portions of the primi dishes, which allows you to try different things).

Tripe: This dish is definitely filling with a lot of tripe in a heavy tomato-flavored sauce, but really tasty (if you like tripe). I shared this with a friend and it was still a lot for both of us.

All in all, I really enjoyed everything I ordered.  It's a little pricy, but I could have probably done with a little less food.  The service is impeccable, though, and the restaurant itself is very cute.
author: Sungeeta A.

description:
Not usually one to like or try fancy schmancy restaurants, but came here to celebrate a birthday.

The first thing I have to say about this place is that I was so glad that the food portions were filling and not the size of a quarter, where you pay up the arse and leave hungry and disappointed :(

For appetizers we had the grilled calamari salad and the artichoke dish. I'm not fan of calamari but I tried some of the white beans and greens it was on and I'm regretting not taking a bite of the calamari now. The artichoke was buttery and smokey, but not soft to the point of mush.

I was a little disappointed that not all the dishes in the Yelp pictures were on the menu (I really wanted to try the short rib cappelletti!). I got the Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken(?) with mushrooms and olive mashed potatoes, and had the profiteroles w/espresso gelato for dessert. I read that the chicken was dry in a few reviews, but thankfully mine was moist and the mashed potatoes were good as well (but c'mon, where aren't mashed potatoes good?).

The profiteroles weren't my thing, but the espresso gelato was really good. I had a bite of their famous panna cotta (black pepper?) and while I wouldn't order for dessert if other options were available, I think everyone should try it because it's got this unique tangy flavor to it that I've never had anywhere else!

Service was fantastic, the servers were friendly and helpful. 

If I ever come back it'd probably be for lunch though, it was so dark I couldn't see anything and once the food coma hit it started to lull me to sleep.
author: Cassie C.

description:
All of the logistics about this dinner were perfect - made a reservation for the next night easily online, called to let them know we'd be 15 min late and was greeted with a friendly and grateful host, showed up and had a perfect table by the window ready, told our waitress we were in a time crunch (had to take one member of our party to the airport) and she got everything going and us out exactly on time!

We ordered:
- Tartine bread & bufala butter - a must get, even if you don't like paying for your bread. The bread is so fresh and soft and delicious, and the butter is unique and mild (I added salt to mine). 
- snap peas served with creme fraiche and mint - super delicious, though a tad bit oily
- prosciutto and peaches - this was good, as prosciutto is always good, but I wouldn't get this again
- chicken liver - the stand out of the whole night - the chicken liver is grilled and served on a skewer with cubed toasts and is OUTSTANDING. served with an arugula salad
- gnocchi ragu - the 2nd stand out of the evening - perfectly al dente chewy delicious gnocchi with a very tasty ragu
- chicken agnolotti - these were good, but a bit disappointing. The chicken filling was a bit grainy and certainly not as good as the gnocchi
- salmon - served in a fig leaf, perfectly softly poached, delicious green beans and potatoes and a butter sauce that was delicious to dip the potatoes in.

Highly recommend!
author: Amy Y.

description:
took the boyfriend here for his birthday, and for a farewell to our favorite kind of food for a cleanse that we were starting the next day. bread, yum. spaghetti was incredible. simple and perfect. he had steak, and still can't stop talking about it. we also had some little chicken stuffed pasta appetizer which i highly recommend. 
you're very close to other tables there and it's always busy. we knew a cardiology conference was in town and heard the guys next to us talking about it so we started conversing with them. sometime around then, one of the men had been brought an extra side of olive oil potatoes. which he asked if we wanted as soon aa they came. 
whats a girl who's about to go on a cleanse do? kindly accept the strangers side of EVOO mashed potatoes, of course. THEY WERE SO GOOD! THANK YOU STRANGER FOR LETTING ME TRY ANOTHER DELFINA DISH. LOL. but seriously. and then they brought us a free dessert for his birthday. chocolate yumminess. 

we'll be back!!! i need to check out their piZzeria, too.
author: Taylor N.

description:
How to Say Good-bye to 2012:

1)  Make a reservation at Delfina.

2)  Take in the holiday decor of green garlands, white lights, and pretty paper snowflakes in the window.

3)  Ask if the awesome bread you're eating is from Tartine.  When you find out it is, ask for more.  Think about asking for thirds so you can stuff some in your pocket.  

4)  Grab a glass of wine or refreshing limonata.  

5)  Remember reading a yelp review where she was on a date and complained about how gorgeous the Delfina servers are.  Empathize.  (And even worse, they are impossibly nice too!)
http://www.yelp.com/biz/delfina-san-francisco#hrid:3L0oBhOvIpsB7tzHESMYrg

6)  Try the Grilled Monterey Bay Calamari antipasti ($11).

Like the mix of cool, citrusy greens; olives; warm, soft white beans, and a bit too salty grilled calamari.

7)  Taste the smooth, creamy Artichoke Soup ($10).

8)  Since you are cutting down on carbs in the new year, load up on Pasta and Risotto!

The Spaghetti with tomatoes, garlic, EVOO, and peperoncini was simple, well prepared comfort food ($13).  Always say yes when offered the option of parmesan on top.  The Risotto Milanese with oxtail sugo and bone marrow was rich with good flavor but unfortunately extremely soupy ($19).

9)  Eat some veggies like the citrusy Chard with lemon and wish-there-was-more-garlic ($8).

10)  Order the Chocolate Soufflé which tastes like a warm oozy brownie ($9).

11)  Although you are stuffed, valiantly try the chocolate ganache and pomegranate pates de fruits that come with the check.

12)  Wish everyone a Happy New Year!

----------------

Update 1/2014:  Cool video!  http://vimeo.com/82970655
author: Amy C.

description:
My favorite restaurant in SF. Every time I go, the experience is amazing. The staff is extremely friendly and welcoming. They remember my name, ask how I'm doing, and occasionally bring out extra food on the house.

The menu changes daily. The portions are solid. The price is high, but reasonable. The ingredients are always seasonal, and the staff is very helpful at answering any questions regarding the menu.

Would highly recommend to anyone visiting the Mission, looking for a great meal, to try Delfina.
author: Brian H.

description: Really nice server, but I haven't spent that much money on a Safeway signature pasta and appetizers in a while. We spent 160$ incl. tip for 2 people and the only thing that made my food taste was the salt shaker from the table
author: Hendrik G.

description:
It was good, but I think it's a bit overrated. Menu constantly changes, so maybe we had an off night?

Started with a prosciutto/pastry appetizer. It was pretty tasty. Not extremely memorable, though. 

Moved on to the spaghetti (waiter recommended it as to die for). It was good. Not mind-blowing. My brother and sister-in-law ordered rabbit pappardelle, which was better than the spaghetti. But still not mind-blowing.

Finished the night on Shortribs.They were tender, juicy, and satisfying overall. But I still feel like it was missing the "WOW" factor so many people seem to be talking about on here.

Went elsewhere for dessert (the ice cream place down the street...the name escapes me right now). 

If I make it back here by invitation (I wouldn't select it again myself since there are so many other places to try in SF), I would like to order dessert.
author: Jamie M.

description:
Delfina is the place to go if you want to treat yourself and others. The staff is incredible -- knowledgeable and witty. The interior is swanky and trendy. The food is unbelievably delicious.

You definitely want to make reservations, regardless of the size of your group. And as always in San Francisco, you're going to be driving around for a while if you're looking for street parking. There is no private lot.

Portions aren't big but they are still very filling so you'll want to slow down and savor every bite. I got the Gnocchi al Ragu, and it is by far the best gnocchi I've ever had.

Save room for dessert. Delfina is known for their panna cotta, though any dessert you get will be phenomenal. My dessert came with olive oil gelato, which sounds bizarre but is incredibly refreshing.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Delfina somehow managed to live up to it's reputation, which was an absolute pleasure.

They execute seemingly simple dishes so well and masterfully!

We had:
* Heirloom Tomato Burrata salad which was transformed by the anchovies and the croutons
* Calamari in White Bean salad was lovely
* Spaghetti in tomato sauce - sounds so simple and I normally get bored with pastas that don't have different textures / flavors going on, but somehow this pasta just grew and grew on me throughout the meal.  And, I still remember it fondly whenever I think of it.

Lovely and laid back ambiance.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
2 stars for spaghetti. As other reviews say simple but all the flavors and textures just worked! So why the low review? Came here on a Monday night for my sister's birthday. We did not have a reservation but they said we would be seated next. 30 minutes later, still waiting. Since the main thing my sister wanted to try was the spaghetti, we opted to order that to go and eat at another place rather then waiting any longer. Ordering was quick and easy. However, placed my order at 7:11pm, was told my spaghetti will take 20-25min. First thought was really 20-25min for spaghetti?! man maybe reviewers were right, this is some serious spaghetti so whatever i'll wait. Waiting outside the restaurant, checked back at 7:40pm (29min later) still not ready, but they said they will call me/text me. 8pm (49min later) rolls around and we have become impatient! Checked again and it seems our order was waiting on the counter but they did not bother to check and contact me. 

Overall, spaghetti is worth the try. However, the service needs to be better. Regardless if it was my sister's birthday or not, no one should have to wait that long and be put through my experience. I'm literally waiting outside where you can see me and you fail to take care of your customers. And when you say you will contact me when my order is ready? Please do so! This restaurant seems to have a great reputation, maybe this was one mistake, who knows but hopefully the owner can address this issue.
author: Harrison C.

description:
Good service and food!
We had 4 different dishes, all good:

1. Chicken
2. Ragu Pasta
3. Salad: the one with arugula, etc, very good!!
4. Calamari

Cozy place!!
author: Carlos H.

description: Really really yummy! I wish the portions were a little bigger for the price but it's the real deal. Super authentic
author: Veronica R.

description: Good overall, but was hoping it would be great. Risotto was undercooked (still hard in the middle), and I'm pretty sure it was the source of my food poisoning later that night! :(
author: Kristen C.

description:
I wanted to give this place a pizza my heart but I'll have to save it for another place - #noodosisters on IG

I tried this place as part of the SF Sidewalk Food Tour. I love marguerite pizzas because of their simplicity and because I love basil. We had the famous marguerite pizza and I wanted to love it but it was bland. 

I have this thing about giving places a second chance because their are so many factors that plays into the star ratings. Maybe the pizza wasn't straight out of the oven? Or maybe they'll have another pizza that I'll absolutely adore.
author: Shirley Q.

description: This place never disappoints! Creative menu that changes with every visit. This is dinning in San Francisco so you will need reservations, you'r not in Kansas Dorothy.  Prices are reasonable for San Francisco if you avoid the high end wines. Seating is limited and tight.
author: Frederick M.

description:
We had a small group dinner at Delfina on a Friday night. The menu looked really appetizing. To start off with, we shared an Insalata di Campo, a Ricotta al forno, and the calamari. They were all good, but didn't really shine. We continued with a squid-ink pasta, some ravoili with walnut sauce, and a salmon. Pastas were ok, while the salmon was too rare for me. The mashed potatoes were really good.
Good, but not great.
author: Luca P.

description: This is just fantastic. Come here. Try the Spaghetti and the house bread. The wines are italian and mostly good tasting
author: Asaf L.

description:
It was tough to decide between 3 or 4 stars on this one.  The food was very good.  The calamari app missed that nice char on it that we like.  Portions were on the smaller side.  My chicken was cooked perfectly.   The other people I was with enjoyed their entrees as well. Our waiter was a sweetheart.

The part that was a disappointment was our table was in corner and I kept getting banged into throughout the night.  We were the only reservation for 4 on Valentines we were told and they normally don't seat that table.  Great- as my purse was knocked over by a waiter for the fifth time.  In addition there is a bit of arrogance.  I asked for some parmesan for my sisters lobster and pasta dish and was told we don't serve it with that dish.  Then we were told if we insist they will give it to us on the side, but the chef does not want them to put in on the dish because it is not meant to have it.  I said forget it. No salt or pepper to be seen on the table either.  Someone next to us ordered the spaghetti and they were getting the fresh parm I had asked for.  In addition they should give complimentary bread.  The prices are high.  To charge 4 bucks seems really obnoxious, even if you order your bread in from a well known bakery.
author: Merry L.

description:
What can I say about delfina that other fans have not said already?
Food is great, but pricey. Ambiance is nice but very dimly lit and loud.
author: Tsu C.

description: We loved it. 5/5 stars. Ingredients are very fresh. Our waitress was super friendly. We will be back. Ultra thin crust.
author: T M.

description: If you are looking for an excellent Italian restaurant is the Mission SF, this is the place.  The food is quality and the price is right.  Must try the calamari, spaghetti and the Quail for the entree.
author: Francis A.

description: I tried Delfina while visiting San Francisco and it did not disappoint. I highly recommend making reservation as it was packed even at 9:30pm. Make sure to try the short rib entree as well as the ravioli. I was dying to try the gnocchi but they were sold out!
author: Megan A.

description: How can salmon melt? Magic. This place is just food sorcery. And who knew fig leaves were so delicious?
author: Caroline B.

description:
This place is a "MUST VISIT" when you want authentic homemade Italian cuisine.  From the outstanding wine selection to the homemade pastas, your tastebuds won't be disappointed.  

The gnocchi is a nice appetizer for a few people to share and to get the tastebuds working.  The quail, the tuna, and the hanger steak are all excellent entrees.  If you are able, save room for one of the many tasty desserts that are made in-house.

This is a very popular restaurant, so call ahead, and don't be surprised if you have to wait a bit to be seated.
author: Ann V.

description: Hostess was extremely rude, when I inquired about a washroom she said there were none available and sent us to Delores Park.  When we returned we found out that there were indeed washrooms available.  It put a damper on what should have been a nice evening.  There were 10 in our group and we dropped a lot of money at this restaurant.
author: Anthony G.

description: Everything was amazing. Simple food, done deliciously right. I highly recommend the pasta and the brussels sprouts.
author: Kendall W.

description: Fantastic neighborhood gem. Thank god it's not as trendy anymore because now I can usually walk in and get a table without needing a reservation a week in advance! The food is just as good as always, so really it's the best of all worlds. I usually get one of the pastas, but you can try the Mary's chicken as well.
author: Mike D.

description:
Hi,

We had the Polenta at first, which was very good. For main course I had the duck, which was nice.
The deserts were excellent, both the chocolate and the Panacota.
author: Ran H.

description:
Needed a place to grab a bite before the Sunday SF Symphony.

Just happened to pass by Delfine; the name Delfina, some how resonated...hmmm
is this a fine restaurant? One look around, the food looked yummy.

No tables! blah! I asked the waiter for any seating? and sho' nuff, there was seating at the bar.  Cool '60s music pulsated thru out the area. I heard Bob Seger and Steve Miller. Kinda hippie music but okay. 

Ordered the Tuna Conserva: comes with radicchio and cannellini beans in a light olive oil. Had to try the Negromonte blend, just a glass.

Both were very good. The Tuna conserva comes with a generous helping of a bitter arugula green leafy thing that looked like clover leafs but tasted like arugula. The tuna was tastey and the radicchio added a bitter pump.

The negromonte blend was deep dark and ever so slightly spicy. Choice!

Vibe: cool.

In sum: a high quality very light lunch suitable for a light connisseur gourmet.

Parking: good luck.
author: Bert K.

description:
Bustling casual atmosphere. Decor is simple but hip. 
The waitress was friendly, and took her time recommending wines. I had a glass of Verdicchio, a dry and spicy white with a spicy undertone. Feel free to try them out before tying the knot with a wine.

We decided to say yes to their veal special of the day, which turned out to be fantastic. The veal was tender and juicy, garnished with olive oil, radishes, and sliced brussel sprout cores. The dish was delicious and very well done.

Since we weren't so hungry, we decided to split a pasta (cod  linguini). This pasta.. was mediocre at best, and especially not worth the price. Very safe in seasoning and flavors, like a night out with your parents: easy and relaxing, but with no chance of finishing with a bang.

The waitress, nice to start with, became increasingly less attentive as time went on. Though she maintained a polite demeanor throughout, it was obvious her priorities were elsewhere.

Would come back for the atmosphere, the wine, [some of] the food, and definitely the famous panna cotta next time.
author: Chia L.

description:
Great apps and pasta, but I was disappointed with the entree and dessert. The White Truffle Arancini was aromatic; the cheese nicely melts in the mouth.  The Chitarra with Anchovies and Cauliflower was tasty; the breadcrumbs added a nice crunch. The Prosciutto-Mascarpone Ravioli with Lemon Butter was refreshing, and even had somewhat a healthy feel to it...I blame the lemon zest.  I enjoyed their pastas a lot.

1 star off: We ordered the Cioppino which was quite disappointing for $24. The portion was tiny, and consisted of a few tiny and pre-pubescent mussels, clams, shrimp, and sole pieces. After a few spoonfuls, the dish was done. The only thing I liked about the dish was a nicely grilled piece of bread that came with it.

1 star off: For dessert, the Profiteroles were very hard to bite into, and thus difficult to eat with the soft espresso gelato.

I agree with the other Yelpers who say the portions are small. There are enough Italian restaurants with pasta names I cannot pronounce.
author: Ally W.

description: We waited ~30 minutes to get the food. Overall, it was pretty good - I got the small spaghetti and I was pretty grateful for the smaller portion since I wasn't too hungry. It was good texture, chewy but not too soft. The sauce was delicious. However, for the price ($11-30 a plate), this place doesn't seem worth it.
author: Connie S.

description:
3.5 stars.

We came here to meet up with a friend, and managed to sit at the "bar". It's not really a bar but a set of elevated seats in a row, so it was a bit difficult to chat when you have 3+ people.

Our friend is vegetarian, and multiple sources have told me that Delfina has good vegetarian options. Bzzt, wrong. While you might think it's easy to get vegetarian Italian dishes, we only managed to find one vegetarian pasta dish, and the rest are sides, with one or two having to specifically be made for us.

At least they were accommodating. However, I was disappointed by the limited choice.

The food was good. I particularly liked the asparagus and the carrot dishes. However, the veggies weren't enough to blow my mind -- plenty of good Italian places around with better vegetarian options. The service was really nice but the place was loud so I had to scream at my server.

Rounding up the score for now because I'm dying to try the ragu. So next time...I'll see how the meat goes.
author: Alice C.

description:
Tried this place again.
Way better.

Ahi carpaccio - not really your traditional form of carpaccio.  It is mainly 2 fennel stuffings wrapped with ahi drenched in blood orange/other citrus.  It was just too sweet for me, the blood orange really overpowered everything including the fennel and the ahi seemed only there for its texture.  Not very savory at all to me.  Maybe good if you like the sweet thing.

Quail - quite good.  Crispy skin with crispy sausage bits, which were nice.  Although I just had quail from the same farm at Boulevard the other day, and it blew my mind :p  Still preferred this to the steak from last time.

Pork - also pretty good.  Juicy and tasty, though nothing mind blowing.

Tea - legit loose leaf high quality tea (I am a tea snob).  Typically I don't like jasmine green tea all that much but I liked this.  It is pretty much the same as the default jasmine tea from Chinese places.

Service was great.

I probably still expect more for the price though...
author: Xue H.

description: How amazing it is to see a restaurant keeping up with quality ingredients and great menu choices year after year. Delfina is my special treat. Please do not pay any attention poor reviews on Yelp. Some people like to complain about just anything. If you don't want to wait, make a reservation. This place is packed all the time, and for good reasons. If you want cheap Italian, find another eatery. If you want simple Italian, they have amazing spaghetti and gnocchi. If you are adventurous, there will be something for you on the menu. And if you wish you were in Venice, they serve Spritz!
author: Frances G.

description:
The execution of the dishes here, the careful detail of the finest ingredients, the outstanding service, the decor, all warrant Delfina legend status in the San Francisco culinary world. I've eaten here for years and the consistency with which they churn out memorable dishes never fails to impress me. 

The calamari is amazing, as is the spaghetti pomodoro. Even everyday things like chicken and mashed potatoes are perfection. The difference, of course, is local and sustainable ingredients and the well cultivated cooking skills of the chefs. I would also suggest the pana cotta. One of the best I've ever had. This place is definitely not to be missed in the realm of SF dining.
author: Sam W.

description:
Tonight's meal at Defina was perfect. The food was simply delicious and everyone in my group loved the restaurant.

Before our orders arrived, we had some Tartine bread....incredible crisp crust and flavorful, springy texture inside. Yum.

For appetizers, we shared a plate of grilled calamari served over a bed of small beans and frisee. The sauce had a lovely lemony tart after taste which made it distinct. We also had the baked tripe. This was one of the best dishes. It was the most tender tripe I've had in a long time. The tomato sauce was intense and so true to the fruit.

For the main dishes, we had duck with cherry sauce (crisp skin and flavorful meat), hanger steak with fries and a rich linguine with chicken giblets; along with this we had the contorni of sauteed swiss chard. All these dishes were fine.

My favorite part of the meal, however, was dessert! We shared the plate of espresso ice cream profiteroles and also a lemon panna cotta with slices of fresh strawberries. 

I had heard so much about Delfina and it did not disappoint. Finally, having a meal here, I can say I have another favorite restaurant in the City.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Scrumptious menu through and through. Professional, happy staff.
Dynamite place for date night.
author: Christopher R.

description:
So I avoided this place for the longest time because I heard mixed reviews from my friends and the menu never seemed interesting to me maybe because I didn't understand the words they used on there.  I finally came over here 2 nights ago for a quick bite.  When I said I didn't understand the words they use on their menu I meant it.  You should have seen me asking about EVERYTHING.  I was starting to feel a little embarrassed asking so many questions but they were very informative and helpful with a smile the entire time.  Our first server was so knowledgeable! I felt like I needed her like fish needs water. 

With their help, we started off with the Grilled Monterey Bay Calamari served over a bed of white beans.  The calamari itself was such a tender surprise.  The white beans had a stronger presence of a very enjoyable savory touch that did not take away from the delicate freshness of the tender calamari.  A dash of italian parsley infused olive oil brightened up the entire dish like fireworks do the sky with a fragrant hint of herb. I really wish they gave us more calamari! Drools.

The pasta is a must over here! I asked lots of questions while I was here so yes I had to ask whether or not they made their pasta in-house.  I'm a huge sucker for in-house hands on homemade type of eats!  There's nothing better than handmade... the way it should be.  They didn't disappoint.  Note: If you read my review and want to order their house made pasta there be sure to ask which ones were made in-house because there were a couple of pastas they ordered from elsewhere.

We had the Tagliatelle with mint, Chanterelle mushrooms, and wild nettles.  Some say Marco Polo introduced the idea of noodles to Italy from China on his travels.  However much of a myth this might be, I can't deny that the Tagliatelle might be the fraternal twin of the Chinese flat egg noodle that you can normally opt for in wonton soups.  The texture of the Tagliatelle compared to the Chinese egg noodle holds a finer more gentle silky bite which we loved!  The mint, while at first thought would be too 'minty' for my tastes, was just the perfect subtlety to highlight the delightful pasta.  Wild nettles, although cannot be consumed raw due to stinging hairs, was more like spinach to go with the dish.  As for the Chanterelle mushrooms, the light earthy aroma and flavor was a wonderful contrast to the Tagliatelle brightly roused by the mint and wild nettles.  We got to experience their amazing pasta because they were able to make a half order for us!  If they didn't we'd have missed this delicious treat!

For the secondi we had the Bershire Pork Arista over a bed of iacopi butter beans, cipollini agrodolce, and jimmy nardello peppers.  The flavors came so well together that the flavor of the sauce was truly unforgettable.  The cipollini agrodolce (agrocolce is an italian sauce usually sweet and tangy) resonated quite well with the pork giving it a lovely sweet savory note.  The marinated whole cipollinis (a small onion from the bulb of grape hyacinth) itself was flirtatiously sweet which left us in total awe.  The peppers also offered a gentle sweetness to the dish although on a different note bringing a different element to the dish.  The only downside to the pork... It was not as tender as I'd thought, coming from Delfina where so far everything was near perfection to us.  Although on the pork end of things it's hard to compete with NOPA in my books, I don't know how to judge it except to compare it with the best.  Even if it was a different cut perhaps, I think maybe marinating it or brining it better would give it a better result.  I'm no iron chef but I know my personal preferences.  Overall the dish was beautiful in flavors and we love love loved the cipollini onions!

To end the night on an even sweeter note we shared the Lavender Panna Cotta with blackberries, arctic belle nectarines, and indonesian long pepper.  For a guy that doesn't usually enjoy much dessert, this is a must have!  Such refreshing flavors coming from the berries and chilled nectarine sauce to accompany the light cool silkiness of lavender panna cotta is nothing short of euphoric.  That long pepper added a very pleasant kick to the finish.  

What a night!  Considering we were only looking for a quick bite.  Had no idea we were in for such a great experience.  Service was so accommodating and friendly to go with such a delicious meal.  You can bet I did my homework on their menu afterwards.

I do wish they had a better drink menu though.  If you like bubbles grab the Peach-Raspberry Bellini... the gf enjoyed it very much.

Wanted to give 4 stars because of the pork and lack of drink options for my tastes but had to go with the 5 for a memorable first and the house made pastas!
author: Colin M.

description:
While the food was good, there was nothing about my dinner here that really blew me away. My friend and I shared the Roasted Chicken. The chicken was very tender and the accompanying garlic mashed potatoes were quite fluffy and tasty. I guess I was expecting something more though--maybe more seasoning on the chicken skin besides salt and pepper? We also had glasses of Lambrusco that were served a tad too warm and flat for my liking. 

I appreciated the open, al fresco feel of the place when we were there but despite that and the dark, cozy, candlelit lighting, it was still ridiculously loud. My friend and I were seated right next to each other by the bar and we still had trouble hearing each other. I can't imagine going here for a romantic date night.
author: Josephine L.

description: Great pasta, and the best Panna cotta I've had. Plus super friendly and helpful service.
author: Aled J.

description: Bustling atmosphere. Non pretentious but still sexy (music and lighting). The wait for the food was beyond worth it. Being that jerk that ordered the gluten free pasta option I was not ashamed. It was phenomenal. The heart of a spaghetti dish is in the sauce and this sauce was on point (the perfect amount with the perfect flavor). No one could of guessed it was good for heart and belly.. I ordered the salmon hesitantly and finished it faster than I could have imagined. Enough praise. Delfina, you're the Italian tits.
author: Anna S.

description: You need a reservation to get into this place. We had a reservation set up for 5:30, as soon as it opened and the restaurant completely filled up within 30 minutes.  I ordered the calamari with white beans as an appetizer.  It was pretty good.  The best part of the meal hands down was the spaghetti.  The sauce was perfect.  Very simple- plum tomatoes with a bit of garlic and it had a spicy kick to it.  It's probably been the closest I've had to authentic Italian spaghetti.  Definitely need to order this-you won't be disappointed! Our server brought out a small dessert on him.  He was very friendly and the service was GREAT! Loved this cute little trendy place.
author: Jenny H.

description: If I could give zero stars I would. Such pretentious and terrible service. I'm sorry, but does your stool not reek? For a highly rated place I expected better service. The server was rude and so was the hostess. Food was mediocre. I'm sure you can find a better spot that will serve top notch food and provide better service. Don't waste your time!
author: Theresa N.

description:
*disclaimer: Delfina is a restaurant that constantly changes its menu and thus any food that is posted is subject to chance, although the spaghetti will probably stay forever*

My girlfriend and I started our meal with the bleu cheese lettuce salad and the snap peas.  The snap peas were excellent.  They were the snap peas that I know and love with a nice flavorful oil coating and a splash of mint that really gave the peas a burst of flavor.  As for the bleu cheese lettuce, I was pleasantly surprised to find that I absolutely loved it.  The radishes, onions, the lettuce, and cheese was all displayed in a floral way that made the presentation of the dish itself delightfully pleasing.  As for the taste, it was just as pleasing as the presentation, the bleu cheese and the flavoring blended together in a very nice way with no one overpowering the other.

Moving onto the entrees, we got the quail and, of course, the spaghetti.  The quail was delicious, the bird was whole and cooked to perfection.  It was laid on top of what I can best describe as grits.  It was a bit pricey I do admit, but as a person who loves to eat good food and doesn't mind to spend an extra buck to do so, I do feel that the dish was worth it.  The spaghetti was, as expected, spaghetti... but it was amazing.  There was something in it that made the dish have a slight kick to it and make it ever so spicy.

For desserts, we got the sweet corn gelato, and the brown sugar panna cotta.  Surprisingly as far as desserts go, they were essentially what I expected.  They were sweet, and a nice way to end a meal.  

The total for my meal came out to be about $100, but for an anniversary and at a restaurant with $$$, it was something that I had expected to happen.

Overall, the meal was great, the atmosphere was wondering, the service was one of the better ones I've experienced, and if I weren't a student who is currently worse than broke (got loans and debt man) I would be willing to come here more often.
author: Dong S.

description:
We called ahead to ask for reservations, the hostess answered that they did not accept reservations, and had a wait list instead, but she figured it would rather be easy to fit two people.

We took an Uber from SoMa, got on the wait list which the hostess told us would be about 25 minutes. We waited on a bench outside, as there is not much else to do in the area. After 30 minutes we asked again, she said there were 2-3 couples ahead of us and then we would get in. After 45 minutes, she said there were still 2-3 couples ahead of us. We gave up and went to the pizzeria next door (which is owned by the same company). About to be seated a waitress from the Delfina came in and told us they were getting ready to seat us. 

We went back and were told to hang on. 15 minutes later, we were still waiting.

If they don't take reservations, they allow people to cut in the wait list. We went back to SoMa and were lucky to catch a restaurant just before closing.

Could not have been a worse experience.
author: Jørgen V.

description:
Delfina is a treasure and one of the many gems along the 18th street corridor.  

My first visit was years ago.  The food and service were good, a well known SF chef was sitting two tables away and I was having a fun time on my date.  However, I didn't leave with a great sense of urgency to return, although there was nothing specific about my visit to cause this.  Many years later, after walking by the restaurant many times between visits to Bi-Rite and Tartine, I had a great urge to give Delfina another try.

On a warm and sunny Saturday evening, we had reservations for an early dinner. Given the crowd of people waiting outside, I'm glad that we had a table inside.  We started with glasses of the Blood Orange Bellini.  A quick look around the room told me that I wasn't the only one that was enjoying this bubbly and refreshing cocktail.  

We decided to try two of their three antipasti specials that night, the beef cheeks (it turned out to be beef tongue) and crudo of fish (halibut?).  They  were both well seasoned, well prepared and nice, light starters to our meal.  For the main course I chose the roasted pork shoulder over farro.  I love pork and I love farro.  When it comes in a wonderful sauce to marry the two, it's a match made in heaven.  The portion size was rather healthy and there was more than enough to share, which I gladly did.  My friend ordered one of the filled pastas (agnolotti, I think) that came with the most wonderful sauce, a sauce that was begging for bread to sop up all that goodness.   Bread doesn't come automatically with the meal, but if the request for it is made, they will gladly provide it.  You'll want to ask for it.  Trust.

For dessert, we split the citrus panna cotta.  This is one of my favorite desserts, and the version served here is one of the best interpretations - light, creamy, smooth with intense citrus flavor.  It was very refreshing and a nice way to end the meal on a warm spring evening.  I started and ended my meal with wonderful citrus flavors.

Our server was helpful and friendly.  She did a great job helping us navigate the  menu. 

On this visit, the food and service were really good, the vibe was mellow and fun, and I thought it was a great experience overall.  However, on this visit, I left with a great sense of urgency to make a return visit.  So great, we made reservations that night to return the following week.
author: Melissa L.

description:
It's aite.

I'm sure the food can be good as the place was packed and lots of great reviews here, but it's not the place for me and here's a couple of reasons why.

(1) The portion was tiny. My friend and I ordered the same dish and we seriously thought they had split one order into two portions for us. But no, no, that tiny little dish is a full portion.
(2) Found all the dishes to be on the salty side.
(3) Expensive for what you get.
(4) The server got frothy with us when we didn't order any drinks and it got even worse after she heard us crack a couple of jokes about the portion size.

Like I said, it's aite.
author: Navi R.

description:
This place is great. There's always a wait so one day I got off work early, and decided to pop in to see if they had a table available. And they did! First they seated us in the kind of awkward area between the restaurant and bar, but then we moved to a table in the bar area, so it was fine. All the tables in the dinner area were already reserved.

Spaghetti ($10 or $15) -- I was skeptical when I read the description on the menu ... there's nothing in it! It's just plain spaghetti with tomato sauce. But I listened to the reviews and I was really glad I ordered it. It's delicious and everything tastes really fresh, so it doesn't need other things to supplement it.

Roasted Mary's Chicken ($24) -- This was bigger than I thought it would be (2 pieces)! I was hoping the skin would be crispy since it was roasted, but alas, it was not, and there were lots of juices poured over it. I liked the king trumpet mushrooms. But the best part was that it came with olive oil mashed potatoes!!! These were heavenly. I love mashed potatoes.

Would definitely come back!
author: Cynthia W.

description: A beautiful sunny Sunday!  A glass of Rosato from the Santa Lucia Highlands!  A refreshing chilled crab salad!  Tripe alla Fiorentina like no other!  Melt in your mouth panna cotta!  What else can you ask for?
author: Jay F.

description: Beautiful restaurant! Great place to go to on a date or with a group of friends. And this place has the BEST SPAGHETTI I have EVER had. Their spaghetti is how spaghetti is supposed to taste!
author: Chisholm T.

description:
Dined here on Friday, Dec. 12 with my wife and two friends.  The food is as good as all the reviews attest to, but the host and the table we were given was disappointing.

 We made these dinner reservations two months prior to this evening and confirmed 2 days prior to this date. We had to wait about 25 min. past our reservation time and ended up with a table next to the second entry door right behind where everyone was standing at the bar.

 When seated, my head was literally inches from some guy's ass who must have just cut an Irish Rose as the odor was repugnant.  Employees were going in and out the door which produced a cold blast of air at me and my meal every 10 min or so.  At least cleared the air from the Irish Rose.  

It would have been nice to have been given a table in the dining room given the length of time we had our reservation and the time we ended up waiting.
author: Ray C.

description:
Early birds don't always get the worm.

I have learned to always be 15 minutes prior, to the 15 minutes prior, to the 15 minutes prior for whatever, well, at least that's just what has been integrated into my cerebrum all these years (thanks for the Corps). So of course, when I make a reservation, I intend to get there abnormally early, just to knock out any kinks (looking for parking, gps rerouting over and over, etc). It just seems commonly better that way.

Delfina, on the other hand, is a fine example why my guideline is flawed. Simply put, this upscale, yet modern Italian restaurant gets crazy slammed! (and reservations are a must!). 

Grilled Fresh Calamari $11 - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?selected=pCvIPXrrQu2a7sv8rZF5yg#HyTUC4L-m3PKEx4KzL-Bzg
The calamari was grilled to a hot smokey perfection on a bed of beans and crisp green salad. The smokiness of the grill really brought out the great natural salty flavor of the perfectly seasoned calamari, along with a discrete hint of lemon yest. Restaurants serving fried calamari is an insult to this squid genius!

Pappardelle Duck Sugo $17 - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?selected=pCvIPXrrQu2a7sv8rZF5yg#Ni-DJtx8rrmMFfsfTrVNCw
I've gotta give props to the house made pasta but damn, where's the duck meat!? (see picture) The sugo, sauce similar to natural au jus, complimented the pasta quite well with much duck flavor, but seriously, where's the duck meat!?!?

Pork Arista $27 - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?selected=pCvIPXrrQu2a7sv8rZF5yg#pCvIPXrrQu2a7sv8rZF5yg
This bone-in pork-loin roast was a mouth-watering climax of epic proportions. Meat so tender, immaculately seasoned, deliciously crispy pork skin = Foodgasm. 

Chocolate Budino $9 - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?selected=pCvIPXrrQu2a7sv8rZF5yg#rgs-V2nkCWpkRVpF07x8qA
The Italian chocolate pudding was hot and creamy like butter, paired with the (real) mint leaf ice cream made for a interesting dessert duo. My girlfriend wasn't too pleased with such a powerful chocolatey Listerine flavor, but I enjoyed it. 

Service was top notch, despite having to cater to the over-capacitated patrons everywhere, and I do mean everywhere! There wasn't even any standing space at the bar while waiting for our reservation.. though a trip to Bi-Rite Creamery (which is only a block away) to kill the time (and snagging some pre-dinner dessert) didn't detour us away one bit. 

Good food, great service, lousy parking, and having Bi-Rite as a neighbor? Defina wins.
author: Albert L.

description:
Eaten here a few times and the food is always excellent!! 

The portions can sometimes be a little on the small side and it is a somewhat expensive. You also might have to wait a while to get a table, reservation or not, but the  wait is worth it. 

They have one of the best Spaghetti Pomodoro you will find and their pasta and chicken dishes always impress. They also have a phenomenal Gnocchi al Ragu which surfaces on the menu from time to time. But if you see it, get it!!

Fyi, they also have one of my favorite pizzerias next door!
author: Tony P.

description: An amazing meal with family at Delfina last night. Our servers were excellent in helping us make our menu choices from appetizers to wine to main course and dessert. We agreeably shared our individual dishes so we had a wide variety of tastes and none disappointed.  I can promise I'll be back soon for a fulll portion of ravioli!
author: Jeanette P.

description:
Delfina holds a dear, dear place in my heart - that aside, my two experiences here have been absolutely nothing less than divine.

(Bear in mind their menu changes seasonally, so this might be a bit outdated.)

My first trip here was on a Saturday night in February 2013, on a first date. I remember the menu being a bit intimidating, with few words in English, but our server was more than helpful. I remember my date joking that the only words we recognized were "Cali style." Plates are small enough to share and as I recall, we had 2 starters and an entree, plus dessert. On that night, I recall ordering a wild boar sausage, a crostini platter of sorts (crostini misti?) and some sort of main dish (can't for the life of me recall)...and then when it came time for dessert, after looking around at tables next to us, we THOUGHT we ordered one dish, but were surprised (although ended up to be pleasantly) with what we received. Again, not a ton of recognizable words on the menu, but the server was more than helpful and I doubt you'd go wrong with any dish.

My second and most recent visit was this past Valentine's Day, a Friday, at 9:30 pm. My boyfriend, having remembered that as our first date spot (awwwwww), made reservations about a month in advance and we still had somewhat of a late dinner. Reserve early people!

First, I have to give a TON of props to our server, who was dealing with an extremely intoxicated woman at the table next to us. This woman became upset when the restaurant did not offer her an iPhone charger, and even went as far as to ask the server if she could go to the sister restaurant next door to see if THEY had a spare charger. Our server, however, was nothing but tactful and respectful to the customer, which was really admirable. Also bonus points for recommending a bottle of white  that we really enjoyed.

Now, onto the most important part, THE FOOD! This time, we ordered three savory dishes to share, and then dessert. The grilled octopus we shared to start was delightful and a nice and light way to begin the night. We then moved on to the hay & straw pasta, which reminded me of a delicious carbonara, with more refined flavors, like the addition of green garlic.  We also shared a main dish, which I believe featured pork? They also had a fresh spaghetti with crab on the menu that night, but by the time we were seated, they had unfortunately run out of the fresh made noodles.

On a Saturday night at peak hours, tables are super close together, it does feel a bit busy and the servers are spread a bit thin, but all the better if you are hoping to get cozy & spend some quality time with whoever is sitting across the table.
author: Laura H.

description:
I've been to Pizzeria Delfina a few times (the one on California St) and until last night didn't realize they also had an Italian restaurant. If you're willing to shell out some money, then the food here is fabulous.

We ordered the citrus salad (citrus, avocado, fennel) and the calamari (with white bean salad) to start. Both were superb. We then shared side of leeks which was also amazing - I'd never actually just eaten leaks on their own, but oh man, yum! For my main course I ordered the winter squash tortelli - which are basically tortellini. Sweet squash pasta in brown butter with poppy seeds. So delicious! However, be aware that the pasta servings are quite small. My friend and her mom ordered a large portion of the spaghetti to share - I thought it sounded boring but I tasted a bite and it was actually quite tasty. House made pasta and house made sauce will do that I guess. 

The "parents" paid the bill and I don't even want to know how much it was :) The other downside to this place is it's a bit too popular. We had a reservation at 9:30pm for dinner (because we couldn't get one earlier) and we didn't end up getting seated until closer to 10:00. It's a pretty small space and they squeeze a lot of people in, so it's cramped and also very noisy. When the waiter was explaining the menu I couldn't hear half of what he's saying. But as long as your most important concern is the food, then Delfina is definitely worth a try.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
I get it now! I get it all!

I had kind of a mystical fantastical experience here, though. It was my birthday, we found parking DIRECTLY in front of the restaurant, we walked in and they already knew our exact reservation and were seated in less than 2 seconds.

The food is so. good. Everyone says order the spaghetti and I rejected this suggestion 15x in a row. Someone ordered the spaghetti at my table, I ate a bite and I was like woah. 

One issue: can I get a pizza in here or what? No, it's not allowed.

I want to come back! Please!
author: Carleen W.

description: Amazing pasta and service! The spaghetti is a must here. So simple but perfectly made. Plates are small but everything is made to perfection. I'll definitely be back!
author: Jason L.

description: I am writing this review because the portion of the small pasta was seriously small. A few bites at the least. Pasta was good but for the money and the mini quantity with no bread or anything as a side. Seriously waste of money.
author: David F.

description: To. Die. For. My partner, who is well-versed in all things Italian food, and I ate here around New Year's. Had an incredible meal, sharing everything. Gaya couldn't drink alcohol, but they were able to find some delicious non-alcoholic drinks for her. I on the other hand very much enjoyed the white and red wines by the glass. The pastas, meats, salads, and desserts were all delicious. Definitely coming back next time I roll through San Fran!
author: David R.

description:
Worst hostess ever!

We had some family friends visiting  and thought what better place. We stopped by and asked for a table 4 four and was told that it was no problem for a 6:30 reso. We walk around the corner to Valencia to wait and see the neighborhood. At 6:19 I missed a phone call and by 6:22 back at the restaurant we learned that our table had been given away to another group that showed up "since another table finished and someone else came" despite having made a reservation. The hostess was unapologetic and offered "bar seating" meant for single or couples, not a group wanting to sit face to face and  said that we could have a table if a 7pm group didn't show up. I wonder why she honored their time and not ours. By the time it was not settled  (and we had to start looking somewhere else) it was almost 7 so thanks for wasting an hour of my time.
author: Amy M.

description:
I am surprised that I have not been here before.  This is by far one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  Not only is the service the greatest, but the food is TO DIE FOR.  If I could give it more that five stars, I definitely would.  

I also want to say that we had one of the most attentive, sweet and incredibly knowledgeable bartenders / servers. If you do go to the restaurant portion, you should all sit at the bar and have him help you.  (it is also less crowded and noisy in that portion).  Though, I went on a Tuesday and I hear that it gets super-packed on the weekends.

Though I did not have any of the "world-renown" pizza (I guess that is a staple at their restaurant next door), what we did end up having was heavenly.

1)  The wine list.  PERFECT.  And it was paired perfectly with our meal.

2)  You cannot come here without getting the anchovies.  I know.  It's a weird thing to promote, but they were AMAZING.  So good.

3)  The bread.  Made from Tartine next door.  I probably ate four loafs to my head.  It was great.

4)  The little gem salad.  Acidy.  Perfect.

5)  The calamari.  If I had to choose, this was probably the dish that I like the least.  It was slightly overcooked and charred at one end, but it's just a preference that I don't like my squid to be burnt or bbq'd.

The only down-side to this restaurant that it is fairly expensive.  Don't come here if you want a quick and cheap meal.  Know that you are going to be spending a pretty penny and enjoy it.  

I know that I will come back.  Hopefully my bank account won't hate me too much...
author: Jenn S.

description:
I was taking some time off for medical problems so the Boyfriend organized a nice little "last supper" with some of our friends.  His original intention was for us to go to Pizzeria Delfina, but he realized he referred to the wrong place too late.

The 6 of us are incredibly indecisive so whenever we eat together, we order a whole bunch of stuff.  That night, we started with 5 appetizers.  The Crispy black eyed peas were crispy, buttery, but too small to pick up with fingers or a fork.  The Grilled Monterey calamari was not what we expected (where were the rings?).  I especially liked the contrast between the warm white beans & the crisp lemony greens  I can't comment on the olives but they were gone quick.  The Oil cured anchovies were so good & had just the right bit of "fishy."  Finally, the Fresh mozzarella.  The texture was completely different than other "fresh" mozzarella I've had; the heirloom tomatoes were soooo sweet.

For main, I had the Pappardelle which had great texture but was slightly too salty.  Also, I wish the gamey taste of the duck could have stood out more.  The Boyfriend got the roasted Mary's chicken which was moist with crispy skin.  It came with a mountain of mashed potatoes that was addicting.  The rest of our party either had the Meyer Ranch hanger steak or the Ahi tuna; both were very well received.

How could we not end with dessert?  Thy Boyfriend & I split some Profiteroles which were not as fluffy as I thought they'd be.  The bitter sweet fonduta (fancy word for chocolate sauce) was a little acidic which was great  for cutting the richness of the espresso gelato.  The gelato, oh the gelato; it was F'in good!  It was intensely coffee with a hint of bitterness; it was like someone took fresh espresso & froze it.

The food was delicious & the service was great, but I do have 1 thing that made my experience not 5-star.  We had split our bill (~$400 before tip) in the following manner: $100 cash and the remainder split evenly between 2 credit cards (so $150 each).  The waitress was super nice about it & did it just right.  But for some reason, when I checked my credit card bill a few days later, I saw that I got charge the full $300!  The matter was quickly resolved with my bank but I am quite disappointed that a mistake (I hope that's what it was) like this could happen @ an established like this one.
author: Karen S.

description:
How dumb and wonderful; all at the same time. 

How dumb of us that we've been in San Francisco these past 8 years and this was the first time we dined at restaurant versus pizzeria in Lower Pacific Heights. 

How wonderful that 'better late than never' has never been more true.

We started with warm olives and brussels sprouts and both dishes were beautiful. We especially enjoyed the brussels sprouts prepared in a tangy sauce featuring vinegar and anchovy paste.  Mmm, mm good.

We shared the spaghetti in tomato sauce as it is one of a few signature dishes for one reason: it's f(^$(&#ing bril!

And we shared a seasonal, not-frequently served spiedo comprised of sausage, pork belly and tenderloin.  Again, Mmm, mmm good.

Our dining experience was so great up to this point that we took the rare step of returning to menu to find dessert. Panna cotto and a Pot de chocolate were ordered and delighted our taste buds.

The wine list was educational and fun. The staff were seriously on top of their food and wine game and very, very pleasant human beings as well.

Kitchen and front-of-house staff in this cozy restaurant are doing some amazing things and we extend our gratitude and thanks.

And she who must be obeyed was so impressed that she immediately booked a table for our Valentine's Day celebration.

Go! Enjoy! Bravo!
author: Jay D.

description: We arrived at 930 on a Monday night. Good thing we made a reservation it was packed. Our server was extremely knowledgeable about the menu and made great suggestions. My date and I shared a few dishes. Everything was mouth watering, melt in your mouth goodness. Pretty much anything you order will be exquisite! Highly reccomend! High five to our awesome server... Daniel?
author: Lizzy O.

description:
SPAGHETTI! SPAGHETTI! SPAGHETTI!

damn. best spaghetti of my life so far.
al dente noodles
tangy, fresh, tomato sauce
minimal amount of fresh basil
clean olive oil taste.

simple.

neat.

large portion for $13 is a lot larger than it looks.

I was getting full before I was even halfway through but it was too delicious for me to box up and take home. i wanted to finish it right then and there so i did.

oh the insalata di campo is a great bitter green salad. 

but really, spaghetti.

best.
damn.
spaghetti.
ever.

anyone who says emmy's spaghetti shack is the best spaghetti in san francisco is a plebian.

make a reservation.
author: Susy C.

description:
Closest to authentic Italian cuisine I've discovered in the city!

It's certainly on the pricier side, but worth it. I had been searching for an authentic Italian restaurant since my return from Italy a few years back, and Delfina certainly does the trick to soothe my nostalgia. 

Even the simple plate of spaghetti is absolutely fantastic! All of their dishes are flavorful, I love that they use bread from Tartine, and the desserts are fabulous. Not to mention the service and ambiance of the restarunt itself is divine.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Met some foodies who highly recommended this restaurant. We made a reservation on Sunday at 5pm and still see a few tables left. So if you didn't make a reservation, try coming around that time. 

Chicken liver toast is great, very creamy and smooth. The two pasta I ordered are Shortrib Cappelletti and Rosemary Tagliatelle. The former is like little dumplings with a dark sauce which taste like soy sauce plus some lemon. It's good. The letter one is recommended by the waitress and is as good as she said. 

Other than those, I had a steak. Best steak I had in SF. They are well grilled. You can taste a bit of smoke but with a juicy and tender texture. 

The olive oil gelato and strawberry panna cotta are excellent. I love the little black olive shortcake, the figs and fig ice cream that came with the gelato and the panna cotta are so creamy and soft.
author: Mag L.

description:
Almost every pizza is good. Very rustic! 

Some of the things that you may order on the pizza like ricotta cheese or the cherry tomatoes... They WONT put it on for you but put it on the side. Only if it's take out. They say it messes up the integrity of the pizza.

If your not used to Nepoletana type of pizzas then this is not for you. It definitely has a authentic and different taste.
author: Cel Y.

description:
I was so excited to finally try this place, after falling head over heels for their pizza outpost next door and reading all the great Yelp reviews... I left sorely disappointed.

Overall, the food was lackluster and portion sizes (especially the pasta dishes) small.  I'm all for spending good money on good food - but for what it is, this place is over-priced.  Service was meh - our server was nice enough, but we had to actually ask for bread (after our apps had already arrived -- and I could have sworn the other tables all got bread).

Brussel sprouts - these were decent, but nothing to write home about

Grilled calamari salad - teeny tiny squid (I feel like our table got shafted when I saw the plump one sitting on my neighbor's plate), but nicely seasoned salad

Spaghetti - thought this was a no-brainer since everyone seemed to rave about this dish.  I honestly don't get the hype.  Yes, the pasta is al dente, but I thought the sauce was only OK.  I've definitely had better. 

Parpardelle with liberty duck ragu - I think I really would have loved this dish had it not been over-salted.  And I found the duck to be... stringy?!
