Berkshire pork arrosto - probably my favorite of the night.  Pork was tender, flavors were good, but alas, also too salty!

Hanger steak with fries - not too bad, but over-charred.  My mom had to cut away the crust. Fries were serviceable.  

Maybe I came in with impossible expectations or maybe I've been spoiled by the plethora of great Italian places in NY... but I definitely won't be coming back.  

Thanks, but no thanks, Delfina!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Nothing but goodness from this place.

The place is cozy (meaning somewhat small but warm) and the ambiance is great. Wait service was a little slow at times.

Can't go wrong with the most basic dish in italian cuisine - spagghetti - and it was extremely well done. Followed by short ribs which were sweet and sticky, perfectly textured.

No room for dessert, too full as I drank too much Chianti and ate too many appetizers (I can't even remember all the ones we ordered).
author: Julia P.

description:
Excellent food. Fresh, vibrant, fun. The spaghetti in particular is a true stand-out -- the sauce was a surprise, fresh and bright, and well-seasoned, with just a hint of heat, and the pasta was slurpably toothsome. You'd think spaghetti would be boring or played-out, but trust me, it's worth experiencing. The calamari with beans was also very good -- the white beans were sweet and creamy, and the calamari was tender and scrumptious. The wine program was complementary and not overburdened by "look at me" schlock. We had quite a few more dishes but they weren't as memorable as the two I mention.

The service was merely acceptable, with wait staff kind of clustering in corners and having a grand ol' time, laughing and playing. I am cool with that, as long as my food is hot and my wine is served in a  timely fashion (and they were not always). That was kind of a shame, because the kitchen was knocking out some great food.
author: Nathalie C.

description:
Spent the last week in San Francisco and read great reviews about this place. So I thought I would go in and give this place a taste. When I first arrived they didn't seem too busy but hostess seemed occupied and was sort of rude. She told us it would be a ten minute wait, which turned into 45 minutes. After we got our table and were seated and we waited about another 20 minutes for someone to come up to our table and take are drink orders. I ordered water and when the water was brought out it was warm so I asked for a cup of ice and the waiter rolled his eyes at me and walked away. I was dumbfounded by this because I thought having a cold beverage was a norm. So the services by this point to me was awful. I tried to stay positive because I was there for the food not the  service. 

When we finally received our food, which was very costly. The food portions were very small the steak $30 (only received about 5 thin slices), ordered $18 spaghetti (large portion was not large at all) and the $26 chicken (very little flavor). For the spaghetti though I understood there would not be much due to the noodles being hand made, yet the spaghetti still lacked flavor. 

Overall the service was horrible. The food was okay but very pricey for what you get.  Sadly, I left this place very disappointed.
author: Taryn Q.

description:
This is my favorite Italian place in San Francisco. I brought my friend from New York who has the most intensely discerning and refined tastes for food, art, you name it and he proclaimed he'd eat here every Friday night if he lived here. He's a creature of habit and frequents ciprianis (amazing food, ridiculous social who's who scene, which delfina pleasantly lacks) every week in manhattan for his Italian fix.

The menu is bit limited since they try to incorporate local, fresh ingredients in all of their dishes. I lived in Milan and Italy for a year and I will say that this isn't the most "authentic" Italian cuisine, but it's a great modern San Franciscan spin on Italian food, with great ambiance and good prices. Every dish I've tried here has not disappointed. 

I suspect it'll stay one of my favorites for a long time.
author: Kimly H.

description: I was worried after so many years of popularity our first experience would not be the same as what made it so....but was not the case! Visited with two fellow foodies and the consensus was stand out dishes, which can be hard when you're serving Italian. Hay and straw dish is a must--fresh pasta and crispy pork belly bits with a yolk that's tossed table side to coat the noodles?! Even the 8 year old next to me was gettin some of that! Bread is unreal, spaghetti truly is worth ordering even though it may seem boring. And the wine flight was definitely worth the $20, all three were fabulous and generous pours. We asked for the waiters commentary on the menu which was helpful since it was very authentic. You should feel lucky to be able to enjoy this top notch food without waiting 10 months for a res!
author: Abby H.

description:
I'm in love. 

The food is impeccable, the portions are just right, and the atmosphere is amazing. I took my Dad here and even he, the hard critic that he is, was incredibly impressed. We had their Insalata di Campo, Paccheri all'Amalfitana (Local Rock Cod), Grilled California Swordfish, and Spaghetti. All their dishes were flavorful, and the portions were spot on. We topped it all off with their delicious sorbet and lovely panna cotta. The panna cotta was sweet, light, and so well worth it. I'm big on desserts so this dish definitely won me over. 

I was worried this place would somehow be overhyped and a little frou frou for me, but Delfina wasn't that way at all. I never felt out of place and the atmosphere was really comfortable. A memorable first experience! My only tip is to make a reservation to avoid the wait. But even if you wait, it's definitely well worth it!
author: Frances L.

description:
Food was good, but the service was severely lacking. 

We made reservations and were seated immediately when we walked in. We ordered the Hanger Steak, Roasted Mary's Chicken, Spaghetti and Linguine. All were great. The steak and chicken were very tender, mashed potatoes were amazing. The spaghetti was a little spicy which was unexpected, but I still enjoyed it. The portions were large and we could not finish everything.

The reason I gave it 3 stars though was because the food just did not justify the lack of service we received. Reading the reviews, it seems the restaurant is always busy so we understand if they do not check on us every waking moment. However, the only time we saw our waiter was when they took our drink orders and then when they took our food orders. I noticed that they went to the other tables that they worked on at least 5-6 times. We saw who I think was the manager more times that we did our waiter. He came and cleared our table and check in on us. We did let him know about the situation and while we spoke with him our waiter finally came with another carafe of water (half an hour after it was empty).

I definitely think I would go back again if given the chance, but I do hope the service will get better.
author: Wayne L.

description: Visited New Year Eve, we have chosen a few from normal menu. All were good but a bit salty.
author: Yuki N.

description:
I trip-out on how this place is bestowed such amazing reviews. I find it rather hard to believe.
Well, let me premise this update by stating that I literally live around the corner from Delfina and I must pass this place at least once a day. Even so, I have not been here in approximately 8 years. And for good reason!!! Which I'll vividly explain in the next few paragraphs.

My friend Bernie wanted to go and since he scored the rezzy's, I thought...why not? It's been a while. What's there to lose? 
Like I said earlier, I had not been to Delfina in quite a while. Neither had Bernie and this dearth is due to my last couple of experiences (I have only been 3 times). 
Once I entered the front door I was reminded why I do not frequent this "reputable" establishment. 
I was led to our table (Bernie was already seated) and showed to my seat. Can I just say that the tables are very close together. So close in fact that our neighbors were pretty much dining with us at the same table. SERIOUSLY,  a mere 2-3 inches apart at most. I'm not exaggerating.
Fucking highly uncomfortable!!! 
It made me think that the owners are trying to squeeze as much as they can out of their patrons. Get a larger restaurant for Christ's sake!!! It's high time for you guys to grow up and invest in larger quarters. Or thin out the patronage. Stop over-crowding the joint! CHEAP!!!
I felt like one of those chickens you see on one of those TV magazine shows where the reporter goes under cover to expose the inhumane treatment of 20 chickens to one small cage and they've all hen-pecked each others eyes out because they hate each other due to such close quarters.
I'm assuming that one of the ladies sitting next to us was having a fantastic time because her gesticulations (which were quite chickenesque) almost took Bernie's eye out a couple of times. No joke! And just like those cramped chickens...I hated her!

But I have to say, what was even more annoying then the overly cramped quarters was the condescendingly cavalier, almost haughty attitude of our server/waitress. Really lady? Really? You work at a fucking restaurant, you are not this international dignitary with some huge responsibility to humanity. Come off of yourself! Your a waitress. Start waiting already.
By the time she finally waltzed over to our table (about 10 minutes after I was seated) to grace us with her presence, we were ready to order our apps, entrée and wine. She insisted on telling us what the specials of the night were, of which we had no interest because we were annoyed and hungry.
We ordered our meal and also ordered some bread as well. We were told it was going to be $4.00 for "The Bread Service" to which we agreed. It was explained that Delfina had recently refined their "Bread Service", which entailed hand-churned Buffalo butter and hand-wrought bread from The World Famous Tartine Bakery. Wow!!! How lucky for us!!! Can I just say that is one of the most pretentious things I've ever heard in my fucking life! 
And I've lived in SF for the past 18 years. So you'd think that I've heard some pretty God Damned pretentious shit during my stint here. 
BREAD SERVICE? REALLY? 
OK Delfina...if you say so.
When we finally received our bread, which frankly took another 7 minutes. I have to say that the bread was very good. I can honestly say that it was the best part of the entire meal.
Was it worth the wait and the price...not sure? But it did hit the spot. 

Now as for the rest of the meal, I was not as pleased. It was not horrible. It was ok. Not great. Just ok. 
I was disappointed with my salad (Green Goddess??? cant quite remember the name). There was hardly any blue cheese in the dressing. The blue cheese was the only reason why I ordered this salad in the first place and there was only a few flecks of it scattered amongst the greens. That irked me a little. Once again it seemed cheap.
I would have complained about the lack of blue cheese and ordered a side or something but our server was NEVER AROUND!!!
As for my entrée, I ordered the Rabbit and I have to say this was overly salty and I love salt!!! 
I wish I could have told the waitress about the excess of salt in the Rabbit but she was NEVER AROUND and when she finally came back to hand us the desert menus she never asked us if we needed anything or if we enjoyed our meals. She assumed that we were having the times of our lives. And why would she assume this? Because she was NEVER AROUND!!!
She just floated above and beyond us like a casually, inconsiderate fart.  
The service STINKS!!!!

I'll not be coming back anytime soon. Maybe in another 8 years. Every time I walk past this restaurant and I walk past daily. It will leave a bad taste in my mouth.

Delfina...get it together. 
Your are the predecessor of what has turned this town into the offhandedly, arrogant city it now is. You have set this standard of smugness that now permeates the dining culture that you helped spawn.
You've turned SF into a mall.
author: Gabe T.

description:
This place is pretty good for your staple Italian dishes but honestly the pizzeria is better. When my boyfriend and I were seated, we literally were sat next to a couple (looked like an awk first date) who was in the process of walking out because the girl wanted to go to the pizzeria instead.

We got some sides and 2 pasta dishes (the standard spaghetti and fettucine with nettles). The highlights were the Brussel Sprouts and for sure the spaghetti but the fettuccine was overly sauced and tasted like a fresh mouth of grass.

The spaghetti is apparently the star of the show here but as good as it was I can make it that well myself. Not worth almost $20 for a plate of spaghetti in tomato sauce. 

Nice ambiance, good service, good wine recommendations, but lacking in food caliber. If you want good Italian go to Vicoletto in North Beach.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Delfina is the Scarpetta of the Bay Area.

Phenoms bread, even better appetizers, and the best goddamn pasta in SF!

My group was very pleased with what we ordered. These dishes come highly recommended:
- Chilled Delta Asparagus: We ordered this without realizing it'd be cold. I never realized I could enjoy cold asparagus so much! It was so tender and not bitter at all. Plus it was doused in a tangy, creamy sauce.
- Vegetable Fritto Misto: Essentially vegetable tempura. No complaints here. It comes with an aioli sauce, but I ended up dipping it in the sauce that accompanied the asparagus. Way tastier.
- Spaghetti: Such a simple dish, yet most places get it wrong. Not Delfina! Who knew "plain" spaghetti could taste so good? Noodles are cooked perfectly al dente and the sauce is divine.
- Chicken Agnolotti: Rich, succulent bites of mini ravioli encrusted in some kind of crunchy deliciousness, with a lemon-chive aftertaste. I didn't even get what I was eating but it was so good.
- Rosemary Tagliatelle (aka Duck Ragu): By far our favorite!!!!!!!!!!! We ordered this upon the enthused recommendations of other Yelpers. This is something I'll probably crave from now on.

My only complaint: Why don't they serve pizza from next door here? Seems simple enough to deliver 'em, and it would offer more variety for the menu. Sadness. (TIP: I hear their new Burlingame Ave location does both.)

Oh well. We all agreed that we could come back and order completely different things and still have a fabulous time. Delfina is just that kinda restaurant.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
When I was done eating, I wished I could have the whole dinner over again. Best spaghetti of my life. 

My friend and I came here for dinner and honestly, every course was delicious. We began with rose and a prosciutto appetizer. Then the spaghetti came and the real magic happened. I don't know how they make it so good but I don't want to know because I just want to come back and eat it over and over again. Had another glass of red wine with my spaghetti-yum. Then the panna cotta for dessert and OMG-again-best panna cotta of my life. 

Overall an amazing dinner. Definitely coming back. So worth the money. Eat here.
author: Rina M.

description: Food here was AMAZING. We ordered the chicken and the risotto and both were out-of-this world delicious. Chicken was extremely moist and flavorful. The Mashed potatoes it came with were divine. Portions were huge. We loved the vibe and our waiter was great. Highly recommend.
author: Farrah L.

description:
Good God this place is good.  It is so worth all the hype.  I am already trying to think of when I can plan my next visit because it was amazing.  You have to request bread at the beginning, and it was then that I noticed that the simple details really go a long way at this establishment.  I noticed the sea salt coarsely sprinkled on the butter, and that was an amazing, savory touch.

I ordered the spaghetti, and was really pleasantly surprised.  The last time I had a pasta dish that good and of that quality was in Italy.  The pasta undoubtedly tastes fresh, and the sauce was light but incredibly flavorful.  My parents ordered the Mezzelune and the roasted chicken, and they both loved their dishes.

Definitely need to make a reservation so you are guaranteed a seat, as the restaurant isn't that big.  So, so worth it!
author: Mel G.

description:
I love the way Delphina looked from the outside. Maybe it was the Christmas lights and a cold SF night that made the place look so inviting. I liked the ambiance of the place inside too- That why its a two stars, otherwise I could make everything in that restaurant in my home and save my $75.

If your going out for a glass of wine, I'd say do it, but dinner- save your money- there are much better places in SF to dine.
author: Muneera M.

description: Simple straight forward well excuted dishes and great service, I will return to try more.
author: Chris M.

description: I'm really a big fan of restaurants and food is absolutely delicious there waitress is a very kind and professionalyou need to wait a little bit to get The food!!!that's why It's only three stars but if your hungry and you want a great food that the place !!!!
author: Aviva L.

description:
Normally I go to the pizzeria next door, but this time we decided to try the restaurant. I noticed no pizza or even cheese related items on the menu. I suppose this is to avoid redundancy but what about us craving mozzarella? 

We started with some Bloodorange Bellina bubbly and decided to go for straight forward Spaghetti and Rosemary Tagliatelle. Both were delicious and you can really tell this is some good quality pasta. We thought the Grilled Monterey Bay Calamari was overly burnt and bitter and the white bean salad couldn't make it up for it. It actually wasn't much of a salad. 

This place would have gotten 3 stars if it were not for the dessert. The crema di chocolate marsala zabaglione, espresso stracciatella gelato was simply out of this world. The texture and flavor was phenomenal.

In summary it's nothing to write home about the but experience was quite nice. I'll probably come back..to the pizzeria. 

Bonus: Also props on a pretty sweet website and interior decor and art!
author: Zahin A.

description: great place for a date.. not good for kids... lucky I don't have any.  The food was out of this world good.
author: Elenor C.

description:
Smells better than it tastes

Last weekend my bf and I were out and got hungry. I was in the mood for Italian/american food and he suggested Delfine because he had seen a few good reviews.

Reservation:
Not bad, we were able to reserve a table an hour in advance.
I called at 9pm and made a reservation for 10:30pm.

Parking:
It was Saturday, parking was a pain, took about 30 mins to find parking close enough.
Weekday goers may have better luck here.

Arriving early:
Better not arrive too early here, there isn't a place to wait, you are just in the way and uncomfortably shifting back and forth so that people can manuver past you. Or you will end up waiting outside or in your car.
We were about 15 mins early standing inside fore about 2 mins and then waited in the cold for the remainder.

Being seated:
10:30 finally rolls around we walk in at 10:31,  our table wasn't ready. 
However, I did appreciate the staff cleaning our table and seats thoroughly before seating us. It was almost 10:40 when we finally sat.

Atmosphere: 
Very clean and modern. 

I found it wierd that we had to ask for bread while we were waiting for our order to be taken. We were starved after waiting an hour and 40 mins just to try this place.

Food:
I ordered Polenta. To hold me over before my Spaghetti arrived. My bf had the Soft Shell Crab appetizer and Linguine entre'.

The polenta was ok it was plain with just cheese and butter and was the consistency of mashed potatoes.  Not the best, just ok. And I was provided with and other foods sauces or ingredients to eat it with until I requested bread.

The spaghetti was lackluster,  smelled great, but it was insult to all the great spaghetti I'd ever tasted. No sauce or tamatoe/marinara flavor. Basically a salt butter noodle dish.

The soft crab was disgusting.

The linguine tasted harshly similar to the spaghetti,  salty and buttery. I guess some people like that, but honestly the salt taste is overwhelming. 

At the end of dinner we were both dissatisfied and couldn't swallow enough chunks of salt to finish our meal. The only thing we finished was the polenta. We ended up having to eat somewhere else afterwards.
author: Demi W.

description:
I'm not much of an Italian good guy, in fact I think pasta dishes are more of a side dish to me, but we gave this place a chance and I was pleasantly surprised.

Food was excellent, we tried the calamari, ravioli, spaghetti, chicken, and much more.  It was mostly all good.  The mash was flavorless to me.

So if you're in the mood for some good Italian, try Delfina.  Bring a date, the ambiance is just right for it, but plan early.  This place does get busy and parking can be rough!
author: Hulises B.

description:
Delicious, chewy pasta. The brussels sprouts appetizer was good too.

Not the mind-blowing experience I had heard about, but definitely good food.

A little cramped and uncomfortable, unfortunately, but they're still super popular so I guess they can afford to be.

Oh, the blood orange bellinis were very tasty.
author: Mara S.

description:
I probably come here at least once every two weeks, and I get the same thing almost every time!! The restaurant is usually packed even up until they're about to close. I usually walk in, but would recommend making a reservation during peak dinner hours. If you're looking for the pizzeria, it's next door and has a separate line. 

Try their Spaghetti (simple, but unforgettably delicious). It's perfectly chewy, and has just the right amount of sauce and a hint of spiciness and basil. Pair it with the broccolini side and olive oil mashed potatoes (so creamy) to share with the table, and finish the meal with their amazing Panna Cotta. They also offer a half portion of spaghetti that can serve as an appetizer if you have your eye on another entree.
author: Rose Y.

description: This was our first time at Delfina and we had an amazing experience. We had the octopus and sautéed chard as an appetizer and unfortunately they were very salty and really nothing special about them....but the wine, bread and butter and especially the pasta dishes were unbelievable. Best pasta we ever had....we ended our dinner with panacotta which was creamy and so good!
author: Alina G.

description: I only tried their margherita pizza, which I enjoyed. The ingredients were fresh and the pizza dough was thin and crispy. They use flour that has less protein than traditional American pizzas, and more similar to Italian pizza, although not the same. Not the best I've had, but I can see  the appeal for this pizza place.
author: Farida C.

description:
I came to Delfina recently and got lucky to score a seat for two at the bar for dinner without any reservations.  I've always wanted to try Delfina, but there was always a line or really late reservations.  If you know you're coming here, try and make reservations beforehand.

Delfina is a great date spot or  a small dinner party with a great ambiance.  If you still have room leftover, you should make a stroll to Bi-Rite down the block!

Food & Imbibe: 

We started off with the: 

Bottle of Italian Red Wine (Great wine list)

Grilled Fresh Calamari warm white bean salad (definitely order as an appetizer to share)
Insalata di Campo (bitter greens, pancetta, walnuts,
Parmigiano and balsamic vinaigrette) 

Salmon baked in a banana Leaf (best entree of the night, the texture of the salmon was perfect)
Spaghetti with Ink Squid (this was a little heavy and overwhelming, but it was rich and had lots of flavor)

Will definitely be back!
author: Carli F.

description:
The food at Delfina is never disappointment.  The service is friendly and causal.  It enhanced the dinner experience.
The Yelp reservation is much better than the Urbanspoon.
author: Benu P.

description: I have to say that this was one of the best meals I had in San Fran during my visit. We got a bunch of different plates and really passed them around for us all to try! To start we had the Insalata di Campo, Little Gems, La Quercia Prosciutto Americano & Melone Pazzo, and all were seperately delicious. For our main dishes we mostly got the pasta except for one of us got the Roasted Chicken which was like butter! There were two pasta specials that we got, one had seafood, and one was mushrooms (I don't remember exactly what was in them though!) We got a small plate of the Spaghetti just to try a traditional style dish, and the Shortrib Cappelletti. All of the dished were devine and we each had our favorites. I don't think there was one dish that we all didn't like.
author: Vanessa M.

description:
Amazing food and service! We started with the warmed olives and the gnocchi fritto and proscuitto. Like perfect puffs of lightness! 

I had the pappardelle with the pork sugo and my husband had the sparerib pasta - the pappardelle was especially tasty.
We split the roast chicken which was the perfect ending to our meal. We were too stuffed for dessert!  Also -loved the raspberry peach bellini!
author: Ramsey M.

description:
I ate one of the most delicious things I've eaten in SF period! - the cauliflower sformato. It's smooth with a very nice taste of cauliflower. It was almost like a savory creme brulee but better! I could've ordered another one to eat all by myself. 

The entrees that we had was really good as well. A lasagna and the Tagliatelle and they were both rich and delicious.

The service we had that night was good, but a bit slow.
author: Terry C.

description:
OK I confess. I waited 15 minutes for Delfina to open because...I really really really had to pee. Once before they were kind enough to let me use their facilities when I had an emergency in the Mission and I vowed I'd go back for the food. And I luuuuurve Pizzeria Delfina, so this time, I did my thing and we stayed to eat, even though it was only 5PM and we had just finished brunch at 3. 

We were planning to just have dessert, but their mouthwatering sounding menu made our eyes bigger than our stomachs and it turned into a meal. The calamari (no, not the fried battered stuff, whole squid baby!), ravioli, and spaghetti were all tasty and mirrored the Pizzeria in terms of freshness. This is _real_ Italian food. The rice pudding was homey and the olive oil/fig gelato with olive shortbread was _so_ original and delicious, one of my favorite desserts so far in SF. 

The staff are wonderful, and not just because they let me use their loo. I'm looking forward to being hungry enough next time to order the 7x7 pork sugo papardelle. Thanks Delfina for offering a total package experience (and for saving my life x 2 so far).
author: Snuffles B.

description:
Items selected:

White Peach Bellini
Semolina Bread and Butter
Polenta Taragna
Papardelle with Liberty Duck Ragu
Tripe alla Fiorentina
Comped Comtesse Thibier Monbazillac
Lemon Budino - Strawberries, Olive Oil Gelato, Basil

Another day and another second dinner led myself and a friend to Delfina, a place that had somehow always fallen off of my must visit list despite numerous raves and accolades from palates I trust.  Considered by some to be the best California Italian restaurant in a city sporting the likes of Spruce, Flour + Water, SPQR, and more it came as no surprise that the bustling Mission restaurant was filled to capacity on our arrival and opting to visit the restaurant on a whim we luckily nabbed the last two seats at the bar where we were placed under the care of a young woman named Kari who offered a few suggestions, and later a complimentary glass of honey sweet Monebazillac to go with dessert.  Having both already enjoyed an earlier dinner but wanting to experience a representative sample of the menu the decision was made to order one side, one pasta, and one 'main' before dessert and with the choices left in my hand I let personal biases guide me into a rustic trio of cheesy toothsome polenta, tender pasta ribbons with gamy duck tamed by bright, balanced tomato sauce, and finally a bowl of tripe in aromatic San Marzanos, some tender and others pan fried to crisp.  Delicious but certainly not 'light,' dessert would consist of an airy sponge cake topped with light Meyer Lemon gel dubbed a budino positioned alongside typically perfect California Strawberries, creamy gelato, and a touch of basil - a delicate dessert to end a great evening and one of many reasons a return visit to Delfina for a better sampling of the menu is planned for the not so distant future.
author: Michael U.

description:
Great food with reasonable prices. This place is dimly lit and can get a bit loud, so it might be hard to keep up with a conversation at times. Make sure you make reservations, the restaurant isn't all that big, so especially on weekends, it may be hard to get a table.

Our waitress was extremely friendly and helpful in providing us with recommendations for appetizers and main dishes. Don't forget to request their bread! If you don't ask for it, they don't give it to you. 

We ordered:

Appetizers: Proscuitto w/ melon, Grilled calamari
Main Dishes: Roasted chicken w/ olive oil mashed potatoes, Oxtail risotto

All of our dishes were good, but I really enjoyed the roast chicken. It was tender and came on a bed of mushrooms and sauce.

Overall, very pleased with the food and service.
author: Angela K.

description: I like this place, the food is very delicious. Truly Italian. Will definitely go back
author: Alla E.

description:
Not the foodgasm in my mouth that I was expecting, but definitely some solid Italian food. The place was packed even on a Wednesday night. There were only a few bar seats left at 8:30pm. 

I ordered the duck ragu pasta, and I have to say that Barbacco (sister to Perbacco) in FiDi still wins. You could tell that the pasta was hand-rolled at Delfina, which was a nice touch, but I thought it was cooked a bit too al dente for my taste. The tomato ragu sauce was also good, but not great. We also ordered the white sea bass which had a olive compote on top. They didn't mention the olives in the menu, which would have been a good tip for those that aren't a big fan of olives. It was a good use of olives though, and went well with the fish. The fish was just slightly undercooked, so it still had a bit of a gooey center. 

The best part was the veggie misto appetizer, which were vegetables fried in a light batter and salted perfectly to taste. So light, crispy, and savory -- I wish this dish came with more; I could eat a whole bowl of these! 

The dessert of poached peaches was probably the biggest letdown, just because the presentation wasn't very appetizing at all. The peaches were fanned out in slices with a heavy white sauce poured all over them -- marring the beauty of the fruit itself. The poached flavor also wasn't very apparent, as the flavor wasn't very different from a normal peach. I've definitely had better poached fruit -- even the poached pear at Unicorn was better than this! If I came back, I'd definitely go with the other Yelp recommendations of panna cotta or TCHO chocolate cake. 

The restaurant was also extremely noisy and the tables were squeezed so tightly together that you could pretty much hear the conversation of the table next to you. Awkward since it seemed that there were several couples on dates. Not a good place to go if you need your privacy or want to carry out a decent conversation.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Came here from out of town for dinner with friends. We managed to get a reservation for 4 on a Monday night on short notice, and the place was pretty packed when we got there. The bread from tartine bakery next door is delicious - make sure you request some (free of charge). Unfortunately their kitchen was taking longer than expected and we waited about an hour for our food to arrive. We were getting antsy, but they won us over with their great customer service. They gave us a complimentary dish of olives while we were waiting and a plate of almond nougat bites at the end. The servers were very nice and accommodating. One of my friends barely ate her dish and they asked if she didn't like it at the end. They ended up comping her entire dish and also comped one of the sides that came late.

Overall impressions:
- great service
- spaghetti was as good as people say
- the pasta itself was cooked perfectly
- the Brussel sprouts are amazing (I need to learn how to make mine like that!)
author: Lucia C.

description:
Really loved having dinner here.
5pm on a Sunday, and it was packed. I've heard about the tables being close together, and did see a skinny guy's butt almost knock a candle off a table, but we luckily had a table at the back, so we felt comfortable.

This being our first time here, and loving their other restaurant Locanda, we didn't hold back.

Drinks: Blood Orange Bellini and for him, Prosecco

Best small bites: the truffle arancini! tons of flavor in these little guys
Sides: Polenta (must have) and the brussels sprouts (with hazelnuts, rosemary, and honey- delicious but not super exciting)

Antipasti: Crostini Misti (must eat), Lamb Sausage (good, but i've had tastier lamb sausage), Lilttle Gem salad that was delectable

Primi: Spaghetti (small, perfectly balanced in flavor), Tripe (baked, and great, but that was the one thing Bar Tartine did right, grilled), and the Pappardelle w/ pork sugo (creamy sauce and the pasta was perfectly cooked, as were all the pasta dishes)

Secondi: Grilled Hawaiian Ahi- the dish was tasty, cooked exactly as it should be, but wasn't necessary to order. The chicken dish another table had smelled and looked incredible, and probably will get that next time.

Dessert: Bf's favorite dessert- Buttermilk Panna Cotta, and we also got the Nepitella Stracciatella Semifreddo w/ sambuca anglaise. I would live off of creme anglaise and that dish was delicious, but the panna cotta stole the show.

At one point, we thought they forgot about us, but the slower pace was fine. it was just two of us eating, and so we didn't mind a small break here and there. Server was super nice.
author: Abigail W.

description: Yummy and delicious. Their Pizza Margherita is one of the best in The City. The long lines and tight seating are no fun though.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Had an amazing evening at Delfina for a birthday dinner and left with a great impression of Delfina.  The food was phenomenal (Grilled Calamari Antipasti, Pork Pappardelle, Roasted Duck) but the service was what really made the experience memorable.  We were seated immediately for our reservation (a rarity in San Francisco) and the servers were extremely helpful in providing us with wine to taste before deciding on a bottle and giving tips and recommendations when ordering.  The combination of service, food, and atmosphere was spectacular and I will 100% be returning in the future. 

Thank you Delfina for a wonderful evening!
author: Raina D.

description:
Great!

Loved this place - the spaghetti was really delicious. 

Service is good and the atmosphere is nice, classy but casual. 

They also have great salads and great wines.
author: Stephanie M.

description: We live in San Francisco and dine at high end places regularly, but Delfina's day is past...we're going to let the tourists have it. The service was slow, slow, slow and atmosphere was sort of like eating in a crowded mall. The meal was also significantly overpriced. Food is still good, but not good enough to make up for the rest.
author: Gangi I.

description:
We arrived around 8pm on a weeknight with reservations.  Strongly recommended as this is a popular restaurant and on the small side.  Street parking in front and virtually no waiting room inside.  Seating is a bit tight and cramped.  Ambiance that night was moderately loud and jovial.  We all needed to speak up a little to hear each other but at the same time I didn't feel that those near us could hear our conversation despite how closely we were seated.

Tried my first pappardelle dish with duck.  Pappardelle is a wide noodle.  It was SO tasty.  The noodles were perfectly al dente which I totally love and appreciate.  I'm not big on duck, usually tastes too gamey for me.  But love trying new dishes anyway and gave this noodle duck dish a chance.  The duck was tender and moist and not gamey.  Chicken liver antipasta dish had really small portions but was so tender and flavorful that I would still order it again.

The restaurant was packed to full capacity while we dined and our food took quite awhile to come out.  Different servers kept stopping by our table to let us know our orders were still on the way and it would just be some more minutes.  More minutes later they would repeat the same, and again.  It was a long wait for our food.  Service could have been better.  Though I appreciate their frequent updates as we grew tired, hungry, and weary it would have been better if their updates were more accurate and the overall wait was not so long for our appetizers and entrees.  We also had to ask for bread.  Those points aside, everything was so tasty and palatably satisfying that I would come back again to try their other entrees or even the same enjoyable entrees again, perhaps during a less busy hour.
author: Bertina N.

description:
The wait is always long here, so be prepared. I've been coming to Delfina regularly for the past couple of years and I always leave happy. The ambiance is great here, whether you're on a date, with a close friend, or celebrating a birthday dinner. Not once have I had bad service which is not something that you can say often about a place.

I'm vegan so I'm limited to their spaghetti. Typically at an Italian place I dread getting a basic spaghetti or marinara pasta dish because it is generally really uninspired, lacking flavor, and I feel like I could have made equivalent food at home for substantially cheaper. This is NOT the case at Delfina! Literally, I don't know what they  do but their basic spaghetti is probably one of the best pasta dishes that I've ever had. The pasta is perfectly cooked al dente and the sauce isn't overwhelming but it is incredibly flavorful.

They have a variety of side dishes that are also quite good - my favorite one is their sauteed greens.
author: Sarah S.

description: We were walking through the neighborhood and stopped at this Italian restaurant. We ordered the olives for an appetizer and the spaghetti was very light and fresh tasting. We also ordered a dessert but I don't really remember what it tasted like so it just wasn't that memorable. I think my favorite thing about the experience was sitting between the bar and the restaurant it gave us a fun dining experience.
author: Paul D.

description:
Best spaghetti and wine selection in town. Hands down. 

Incredible service. Molly was incredibly thoughtful and gracious -- loved all of her recommendations. Will definitely be bringing my parents to this spot next time they're in town.
author: Brett L.

description:
I love the food and service at Delfina, but last time we came here with a party of 3, they decided at the very last moment to split up the two small tables where they were going to seat us, and put us all around a single two-person table.

It was was extremely cramped and unpleasant, way too close to each other and to other parties. I understand that the place is popular and that they want to shorten the wait for other guests, but this was not cool. It's hard to enjoy the otherwise great food and service like this.
author: Marc L.

description: My friends and I ordered the spaghetti, gnocchi, bone marrow, scallops, and a bottle of wine. The spaghetti was great, although my friend kept comparing the sauce to Spaghetti-O's! The gnocchi was tasty and pillow-soft like cotton balls (not that I've eaten cotton balls). The bone marrow wasn't as flavorful as I would have liked, and the accompanying bread was a little too thick and crusty for the bone marrow. The scallops are a must, although pretty pricey. The wine was okay, but I could get Trader Joe's wine for a tenth of the price and enjoy it just as much (and be just as wine tipsy).
author: Jeremy S.

description:
a quickie:

no complementary bread.
prosciutto ravioli is worth ordering.
a little bummed that they removed 'parpardelle pork sugo' from the menu.
will need to try the spaghetti next time.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Scored street parking one block away after circling three times

Scored a table for two walking in around 630pm on a Friday night.

Belated Birthday Dinner -

Appetizers - I didn't realized I ordered the Grilled Calamari in 2007 and I ordered it again 2012. Still really tasty though wish the beans were a tad bigger.

Tried the summer squash, squash blossom risotto.  Not too rich or heavy.

Hubby ordered the salmon dish. 

Skipped dessert.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
The food is delicious! 
Everything is so freshly made and the flavor is amazing! I had the Mary Chicken and it was so juicy and flavorful. Their spaghetti is pretty amazing too and the large can be split amongst two as a side. 
The ambiance is very nice and staff is very friendly. We were hesitant about bringing our kids for the first time but we will definitely bring them back with us.
author: Sonya N.

description: Pretty tasty, but maybe a bit overhyped.    They kept us waiting for our reservation.
author: Michael E.

description:
Delfina was amazing. I have wanted to go here for awhile and was super excited when my friend Sherri set up the reservation. It exceeded my expectations and the flavors of each dish were incredible. 

To drink I ordered a Peach Bellini, made from fresh peach juice that was so tasty and fresh.

To start we ordered the Grilled Fresh Calamari, with warm white bean salad. This was not your average Calamari appetizer and not what we initially expected but delicious none the less.

We both had the spare rib cappalletti which was incredible. The triangle shaped pasta were filled with spare rib meat that was sweet and braised with a sauce that reminded me of Asian spare ribs.  It was a mix between Italian and Asian flavors and very unique.

For my main course, I had the Sea Bass which was grilled - slightly crunchy glazed crust on one side and perfectly cooked so that it was flakey and moist. The sea bass sat on cherry tomatoes and blanched spinach leaves.

Sherri ordered the Strawberry Mountain Ranch Hanger Steak and French Fries which was very good too. You could tell that it was marinated for awhile, because the meat had a very distinct flavor.

The Dinner was well worth the price and I can't wait to try the Delfina Pizzeria as well.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Liked it. Didn't love it. The wait staff is fabulous! Helpful and friendly. The calamari is as delicate as lobster.  The little sweet treats with the bill are so wonderful!
author: Jane P.

description:
I came here as one of my first "real" dates with my boyfriend in 2011. He had been here before and thought it was good. It's pretty nice considering it's in The Mission, my normal stop for cheap drinks and eats. However, it was really cramped. We went here on a Tuesday night to avoid the bad crowds, but it was still definitely crowded, since it's so popular. We were seated between two other couples - one guy trying so hard to woo a girl on his first date by bragging about himself the whole time; the other couple next to us was in a fight or something. This is not really held against the restaurant, but I did not like how close I was seated to these people to know everything going on between them. The ambiance wasn't really ideal.

Moving on to the food. The only thing we thought was excellent was the spaghetti and the ragu sauce on one of our dishes (not the actual dish itself). I could have eaten those all the time. The things I remember not being enthusiastic about to say the least were the appetizer and the dessert. We had some kind of shrimp dish (with the eyes and shell still on) and it was just whatever tasting. The dessert we had was the panna cotta and I wasn't a fan. I was upset too because I had heard rave things about theirs. Oh well. 

If you come here (and don't mind the crowd or the pretentious atmosphere), get the spaghetti. You won't regret it.
author: Kelly B.

description:
Nice hip decor, great service and wine selection. Good pasta, outstanding roasted chicken (better than Zuni's, IMHO).
Only negatives were that all savory dishes were very salty and that I didn't find any dessert exciting enough to fork out an extra $9. I opted for a Bi-Rite ice cream 30 yards away. So I guess it worked out nicely.
Overall, one of the best restaurants we've done all week in SF.
author: Nico D.

description: Super celiac friendly. The panna cotta alone is worth the visit. Gluten free spaghetti is amazing. Their grilled octopus and beans are delicious. Service is always always great.
author: Esther J.

description:
My favorite restaurant in town. The staples that are always on the menu -- grilled calamari, spaghetti with tomato and pepperoncino, the roasted chicken and the steak frites, the panna cotta -- are delicious and reliable. (Also the Tartine bread, which you can get by request.) But there are other specialties that come and go with the seasons and that I squeal with delight if I find on the menu when I visit: carpaccio of beef or tuna, any kind of sformatino, the rosemary or mint tagliatelle, any kind of agnolotti, the grilled quail and, once, a veal breast. I've also really enjoyed their special regional dinners and winemaker dinners. Servers make great wine suggestions, and my knowledge of Italian wine has greatly improved (from a starting point of pretty much zero). 

Yes, it's an urban restaurant: it's loud; there's no parking lot; the service is friendly but occasionally it can take a while to get someone's attention. (This last issue has gotten slightly worse since the owners opened sister restaurant Locanda.) But I don't mind. Delfina is in a class by itself.
author: Razer R.

description:
Arancini to start followed by Napoletana and Salcissia pizza. Yummy!! I haven't been to Naples but have been told by a couple of people who have that this pizza comes pretty darn close. 

They don't take reservations so come early! We arrived at 11:45 on Saturday (they open at noon) and were the first ones in line. The perfect Saturday afternoon:)
author: Shivani M.

description:
I loved Delfina so much a few weeks ago that I went back and dined there again: fresh calamari salad (so fresh and tasty!), spaghetti (yummm!), roasted pork shoulder over farro (mmmm!) and TCHO chocolate budino with mint ice cream (the budino was rich and ultra chocolate-y and the mint ice cream was refreshing, great balance to the budino).  :)

My friend and I were there for 2 hours eating, chatting, and getting to know each other, and it was so nice that we weren't rushed out the door.  A really great dining experience a they know how to treat their customers right!
author: Maile N.

description:
I've been a fan of Delfina ever since I moved to SF 9 years ago, but a recent visit has made me stop recommending it as my number one choice to friends and any guests who come visit the area. 

It's such a small thing but it really puts a damper on your meal: they charge for Butter. 

Delfina used to provide bread and butter as a free hospitality gesture to their guests. Tartine bread, no less! It was one of the draws to the restaurant. 

I noticed on my most recent visit (where I was once again bringing a friend from out of town) that they've stopped offering bread and butter for free and now charge for it as a menu item. Okay, that's fine, it's around $4. 

We enjoyed our bread but the butter ran out about halfway through. We asked for some more and a restaurant manager type person (he didn't look like a waiter) comes over and says they have to charge 2.50 for a second helping of butter. 

My friend and I exchanged incredulous looks. Something that used to be free was now $6.50? And the fact that it wasn't our waiter who conveyed the news, but rather some management type guy made it sound even more ridiculous. As if this was some piece of serious news that needed to be conveyed by upper management. We had a whole lot of bread left so we decided to BUY a second round of BUTTER for the table. 

It made everything else taste less good. I felt so bad because I had been hyping this up as my favorite restaurant to my friend for ages. And now in the middle of our pretty expensive meal, we're getting scolded by a manager about how more butter will cost more money? It killed the vibe.

When we were settling up, I overheard the next table over giving their waiter a piece of their mind over the same issue. Something along the lines of "now you're nickle and diming me over Butter??". 

We left and I kept apologizing to my friend while we walked away.
author: Minna C.

description:
Excited as we were about our experience here it was not really memorable except for small portions that kept you wanting more. Olives I love and We fell for them here along with the fried dough ravis with thin sliced salami.

Pork belly and clams with a side of embedded octopus along with an extrodinary selection of itlalian wine and kale turn ur palate on? It did it for mine and I would have never believed it rock on chef. There pasta was beyound delight and some of the best yet. Service great, attention to detail awesome and it was an excellent experience. As always I look for what G Cipriani says a rest should be an experience like a town or city!
author: Peter A.

description:
Greeting- yes
Vibe- over-crowded cocktail party
Service- very good
Parking- street
Food
Guinea hen tagliatelle was very good- $18
Cappelletti were delicious-$18
Torta Caprese was good - $9
Glass Unti Syrah $11-good
WIGB? Yes

Overall this is a very creative pasta place. Try the uncommon flavors and shapes. Delicious.
author: Hungry K.

description:
This is a small, busy, popular little place, with a hand-ful of seating/tables inside, and a handful outside.  

When you arrive, write your name on the chalkboard just inside the door, and be prepared to wait.

We went for dinner on a Saturday night (a party of four) and our name was next-to-be-seated on the chalkboard.  We waited for about 30 minutes the went inside to find out why we were still waiting...  Turns out, someone put a line across our name, and thus we were skipped.  However, about 10-15 minutes later we had a table outside and we ate the little "bread sticks" in about 30 seconds.

Our party ordered and shared the meal:  Two pizzas, some appetizers and a couple bottles of wine.

This is what we had: 
Warm Marinated Olives 
Saffron Arancini
Some sort of Fried Pepper and Onion plate
The Panna Pizza (Tomato sauce, cream, basil, shaved parmigiano)
The Broccoli Raab Pizza (Broccoli raab, caciocavallo, mozzarella, olives, hot peppers)

All in all, the food was good.  The warm olives were tasty, the saffron arancini was very tasty, the fried pepper plate was below average and not very good, the Panna pizza was very good and the broccoli raab pizza was good (but the panna was better).

Although the food was good, I wouldn't go back and wait in line.  I would, however, do what many others did and ordered at home and walked down to pick it up.  Order ahead of time and you'll be happy.

End of review.  Happy Eating.
author: Erik H.

description:
Finally able to come to Delfina and it was definitely worth it.

Great ambiance and friendly, attentive service throughout the meal. Some of the meal included:

Cauliflower with mushrooms
Grilled calamari
Pork ribs
Profiteroles

Everything made with care and attention. They have a smooth-running machine here and it was all so yummy. Can't wait to return.
author: Art O.

description:
I am so pleased with this find.  My dining companion and I happened upon this place during my trip to SF and decided to go in because it looked and smelled promising.  Though it was a Monday evening, the place was packed.  Luckily, there were two bar seats, which we grabbed quickly (the wait for a table was about 30-45 mins).  

First, the wine selection: excellent.  I had a glass of prosecco, which turned out to be head and shoulders better than average.  My companion had a glass of pinot blanc, which was absolutely delicious, especially with the food we ordered.

The food: superb.  We ordered calamari, chicory salad, rock fish pasta, and seafood stew, and all of them tasted fresh and flavorful.  The home-made pasta was so perfectly done that my companion raved about it for days. The grilled calamari was both delicate in texture and umami in flavor.  The seafood stew had such complex flavors from all the spices in the sauce, which was so beautifully balanced.  The dessert was a delightfully light and sumptuous torta, equally well-balanced and delicate in flavor.  

One caution.  The restaurant, which reminded me of many wonderful NYC restaurants, is very, very packed and the aisles are narrow. There is little space between tables, and the traffic must be negotiated carefully.  I had a few narrow-misses every time a server walked by my seat at the bar carrying a full plate or glass.  In fact, I heard two crashes (glasses breaking, etc.) behind my back while eating.  While it did not take away my appreciation of the place, it did make me wish that the aisles were a bit wider and there were a bit more space between tables.
author: hk k.

description:
Made reservations 2 weeks in advance and the only times available were 5:30 pm and 9:30 pm so we decided on the earlier time since it was a weeknight. I got here early but my friend was running late crossing the bridge. I was afraid we would lose our reservation but the waiter was really nice about it and had me seated first. He also occasionally checked in to see if I needed anything and kept my water refilled. 

The food itself was ok. I really wanted to try the pappardelle but it wasn't on the menu that night. So i ended up getting the asparagus and hay and straw. The asparagus was good but the portion was really small for the price. The hay and straw was very pretty to look at but the taste was average.  

Might come back to try the infamous pappardelle one of these days.
author: Monica W.

description: I have been wanting to write a review on this restaurant since my wife and i went there the last weekend in September. An amazing meal, perfect setting and an overall wonderful eating experience. We actually went to their pizza shop next doo the following night! Also perfect!
author: Frank L.

description:
In a nutshell: notably underwhelming food, notably high prices, friendly but flawed  service. And of course a hip scene and yuppified crowd which isn't a bad thing in it's own right, but when the other elements don't measure up, you ashamedly realize that you've just joined the hipsters in their brainless herd pursuit of cool at any price. 

The details: No axe to grind at all. Many of the elements of our experience were wonderful but the basics just don't add up. To me, the basics of a dining experience are very simple: Food, service, ambiance, price. See below. 

FOOD - 1 STAR. I ordered the lamb off the Secondi menu (one of the most expensive on the menu). In a word, it was inedible. Tough and chewy. It's embarrassing when you bite into something so chewy, you can't really swallow it so you have to put it out into your napkin hoping your date won't notice.

My girfriend ordered the rock cod dish for $27. I didn't try it but she didn't like it. She felt it was bland and bit small for the price. We also ordered the carrots but they never came out. When we notified our server, she apologized and offered to get them but it was the end of dinner so we asked to have them removed from our bill instead.

SERVICE - 2.5 STARS. Hostesses were great. Our server was friendly. The runners brought one dish to our table by accident and had to reroute it to another table. And of course our carrots never came, I guessing they suffered the same fate but whoever got them for free didn't bother to say anything.

AMBIANCE - 4 STARS. It's has a great neighborhood restaurant feel combined with the bustling vibe of San Fran. Lighting, music are all about right for a casual dinner. Crowd is hip and trendy.

PRICE FOR WHAT YOU GET - 2 STARS. This factors all our experiences as described above. Even though it's uber hip and located in an awesome part of town, it's hard to justify the price for what you get. I've dined all over the Mission and for an equally hip and well located spot, you can get much better food at much better prices than at Delfina. But for those of you from the neighborhood, you probably already know this.
author: Tom K.

description:
Reservations are a must! My boy friend and I walked in on a Friday night without a reservation and it was packed. The wait time should have been at least 45 mins if we wanted a table. But if we chose to sit at the counter located in the middle of the restaurant, we would be seated sooner, the hostess told us. It didn't matter to us. We got seated after about a 15 min wait. That's not bad on a really busy Friday night. The food was excellent - every single dish we ordered was delicious. 

Delfina is a must-try restaurant, highly recommended!
author: Chloe B.

description:
Food: 5/5 - Authentic, hand made Italian pasta and meats with a modern flair.  

Service: 4/5 - Consistently friendly and prompt service, though nothing absolutely outstanding.

Ambiance: 4/5 - Typical hip spot in the Mission, but definitely a nicer feel. Not too crowded but still cozy, and good for couples or families alike.

Value: 5/5 - With pastas below $20, and meats/mains below $30, this is some of the best food at a very reasonable price for a typical fine dining institution in SF.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Fantastic! One of my top five meals of my life!!! Molly, the waitress, was fabulous.  She guided us through and evening in heaven.  The wine, the appetizers, and the pasta were fabulous. We had 930pm reservations, with some magic we got in at 815pm.  It would have been worth the wait, but we got in quick!!! 

Good luck Molly!
author: Deepak T.

description:
Delfina.  I had been there once before several years back, and I remembered it being wonderful, but I was post-tonsillectomy and I had a killer hard time swallowing.  Major bummer.  Later, I met a guy who just so happened to be part of the waitstaff there, which made it super awkward for me to pay a return visit.  Enough time has passed now, and I decided to make this my pre-birthday dinner spot.  

8:30pm on a Monday night and the place was packed with people still waiting outside in the cold.  My reservation was for 9:00 and there was absolutely no wiggle room to get in early.  The place was noisy and dimly lit and the tables tightly packed.  I could hear the conversations from the tables on either side of us, as I'm sure they could hear ours.  I like my space as well as my privacy and I was beginning to feel a little claustrophobic.    

Then the wine came and made it all better.  I had a glass of the St. Michael-Eppan Pinot Nero which was light and smooth without much acidity--just how I like it.  

I chose the Meyer Ranch hangar steak for my meal, which was small and came sliced.  It was tender and flavorful and, along with the fries that accompanied it, was just enough to satisfy my appetite.  The fries were good, by the way, but nothing extraordinary.  

I had the panna cotta for dessert, delivered with a candle for my birthday.  It was sweet with a milky, buttery flavor surrounded by a sauce that sort of gave it a perfumy aroma on the palette (in a good way).
author: Carol Y.

description:
Great atmosphere, trendy ambiance and decor.  The dim light setting set off a great mood for a wonderful dinner that was coming along the way.  

Got seated right away upon our reservation.  Ordered a bottle of white wine, which was reasonably priced (well worth it!), grilled calamari with white beans for appetizer, and crab meat squid ink pasta and their braised short ribs for entrees to share.  Everything was excellent and their entrees were amazing!  Crab tasted fresh and wow, the short ribs were so tender and juicy.  Their menus changes every week, so you know you'll always get to eat something fresh. 

Service was great and dinner was fabulous.  The rest of the night was spent enjoying the bottle of wine and a great chat with a girlfriend.  Love this place!
author: Nancy S.

description: We must have come on an off night. The spaghetti was so salty, it felt like we were eating spoonfuls of salt with each bite. The grilled calamari starter was good. We left feeling pretty disappointed :(
author: Chauanh D.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner on a Monday night.  It was BOOKED and packed! (on a Monday night).

What I love about this place:
1) Al Fresco dining area outside (not sure if it's part of Delfina or their sister Pizzeria but it was really nice on a nice warm sunny afternoon)

2) Pasta was Al-Dente! It is so simple but so many people overcook their pasta.  Not at Delfina.

Server was friendly enough.

Here's why I knocked one star:
Portions are REALLY SMALL. Granted I do have a big appetite, my $25 or so pork belly was smaller than a credit card in size.  After like 3 bites it was GONE.

It might be a good place as an appetizer stop (you'd have their main as an appetizer lol) before moving on to another restaurant for a decent sized entree.
author: Sujan H.

description:
FINALLY got to try this place after so long and it definitely did not disappoint. Since it's a hot spot, def make sure you make reservations beforehand (even with reservations, you'll need to wait a little bit too). 

Calamari - For some reason I was expecting to get the typical fried calamari that you get at any other restaurant. This was cooked through but had really awesome flavor and the beans that came with the plate were delicious too
Spaghetti - To be honest, this was kind of a letdown. All this hype and it was just okay
Mint Tagliatelle - DELICIOUS. Such a good pasta dish
Duck - So juicy and cooked so freakin' well. Probably one of the better duck dishes I've had
Panna Cotta - One of their signature dishes but holy shit this was amazing. It's got a lemon flavor to it but damn, this was gooooooooooood. Order this for sure
author: Diana Y.

description:
Pizza in my mouth.
So yummy in my tummy,
Makes me want to dance.

(this review has been submitted by T-bone's ghost writer)
author: Josh G.

description:
My boyfriend and I were eagerly looking forward to trying this place, as it was listed as 11th most popular on Zagat!

Food was good but seemed average to my bf and I.  Meal started off great with the bread & butter. We ordered Calamari, which was sauteed - this one was interesting. I'd suggest ordering this one, totally different from the fried calamari we were expecting. We also ordered the regular Spaghetti too, since the waiter suggested it.  The sauce was super good, definitely the highlight. It was great because it had its own flavor. The flavor is hard to explain though -- tasted spicy, but wasn't spicy. We think it was the pepper they must have added. So yummy though.

Our entrees were good, but again average. He ordered short ribs, which I thought were pretty good. I'd give a 4/5 stars. Didn't have that incredible WOW factor though. I ordered a swordfish, which was average. It honestly wasn't that great. The sauce was pretty good, tasted like mayonnaise? I wouldn't order the fish.  Definitely a 3/5 stars. 

Service of the restaurant was great though! Our waiter was very personable and I felt the staff in all were very friendly.  Ambiance honestly reminded me of New York! That was a nice surprise. Parking was super tough -- plan to come early! We circled 10-14 times.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I've heard a lot of good things about this place, so I thought this place would be worthy of my fiance's birthday.  I'll just say that it definitely did not disappoint and it lived up to it's hype.  We were a little worried, as we didn't have reservations and it was a Friday night, but we arrived just before 6 and we were actually able to be seated at a table immediately, which was a pleasant surprise.

The waitstaff here was fantastic, making sure we were well attended to, taking time to explain the various dishes and answer our questions, and being friendly and cheerful without being overly obtrusive on our dinner.

We split a few dishes (bonus points for giving us separate plates even without us asking!)- the escarole salad, pappardelle with pork sugo, and the duroc pork spareribs.  The escarole was great- the greens were light and crispy with none of the other flavors (cheese, hazelnuts, pomegranates, tomatoes) being overly strong.  It was a great blend of flavors.  The pasta was cooked to perfection and the sauce from the pork was amazing.  The spareribs were fall off the bone tender with great flavor and seasoning as well.  While we were eating the ribs, my girl asked me how everything was.  I just broke into a huge smile and said, "Wonderful!"  I think that says it all.

We ordered the panna cotta for dessert and the waiter told us he'd bring it with a birthday candle.  He dropped the dessert off and my girl blew out the candle, but we realized that he actually brought us the wrong dessert (a chocolate molten cake with a scoop of vanilla gelato, I think).  When we pointed this out, he apologized and told us we could have this dessert as well.  No complaints here, as it was a great dessert.  But as good as the cake was, the panna cotta was even better.  I liked how it was a bit tangy with a citrus infusion.  The texture was perfect, not rubbery or chewy...  heaven in every bite!

Five plus stars for Delfina!  Yes, it is expensive, but you certainly get what you pay for in terms of food quality, great service, atmosphere, and overall experience!
author: Jeff C.

description:
We missed reservations at another restaurant and needed an alternate place for dinner. Delfina came to mind since I've been wanting to try them for awhile. After reservations were made off we went. 

We ordered the spaghetti with plum tomatoes, the Trippa (tripe) baked in the oven and the polenta valsugana dish. I had a glass of white wine and he stuck with ice water. Although I wished the menu was more "vegetarian friendly" food was well prepared and I immediately understood why Delfina is one if SF's favorite. 

The spaghetti dish was simple yet tasty and was cooked perfectly al-dente. The hubs enjoyed the tripe and started getting nostalgic as he reminisced about growing up eating his dad's tripe dish. 

"Yay! I'm a fan." Pretty much sums up my first time visit.
author: Esther A.

description:
There is not a thing bad to say about Delfina!  My partner and I enjoyed our last dinner of our San Francisco vacation here and would do it over and over and over.....

For drinks, my partner started with a "beer", and then we both drank Barbera d'Asti (De Forville 2011) for the remainder of the evening.

We started with the Chicken Liver Rustico Crostini, topped with marinated minced Shallot.  This was light, flavorful and really rich!  Then we had the Fresh-Cured Anchovies Nostrano with micro Arugula, olive oil and radishes; fresh and oceanic.  

For our mains we had the Mint Tagliatelle with chanterelle mushrooms, nepitella, wild nettles  and the Papperdelle with Liberty duck ragu.  Both of these were amazing, but my fave was the ragu.  The meat sauce was hearty but light, if that's possible;  the pasta was tender and tasty and the rustic bread with the devalo olive oil made the meal complete!  

For dessert we had an espresso and the Crespelle; almond cream, frutti del bosco, peach leaf gelato, which was a perfect end to a perfect meal!

The place is upscale, but casual and gets crowded!  If you aren't comfy rubbing elbows with the next table, you might want to try elsewhere - but you WILL be missing out on some Freakin' Fantastic food!

If you get to San Francisco, this place is a must try!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
We managed to walk up and get a cozy spot on a bar. Which was great since we kind of bumbled over after a day in the park. 

The food was really fantastic. If you can get over there before the menu gets changed I would highly suggest ordering the Ricotta Cavatelli. Great news as you can order half orders of the pasta!! So you can try a couple if you'd like. The Cavatelli was delicious. Probably my favorite of the night even though the Sea Bass was amazing. But pasta just always hits for me. The Sea Bass I finished so quickly my date was astonished as was I. I meant to offer him a bite but next thing I knew it was gone. Ooops. He ordered half orders of the spaghetti, cavatelli, and steak & fries. Plates were cleaned.

For dessert I got the Young Ginger Pavlova which was bonkers. If you are a fan of meringues and coconut I highly recommend it.

I'll certainly come back.
author: Angel G.

description:
Went here for the very first time to take my partner's sister out to dinner for her birthday. Service seemed pretty good, attentive staff, super friendly, smily and upbeat. 

Since they don't take reservations and the space is fairly small, understandably the wait would be a while. We ended up waiting for about a little over an hour. During our wait, we were asked if we wanted drinks, everyone received their drinks, however mine came out about 15-20 mins later...I literally ordered a coke. 

The soup I ordered came out incorrectly also my friend's pizza came out incorrectly as well.  Totally don't understand why they didn't have it together. 

Overall, food was ok good, service was off for me after the entire experience. I'll probably order take out next time or go elsewhere. Not super excited to go back or take friends here.
author: Tom T.

description:
This place rocks, period. 

Always had delicious food there, every single we've tried so far. Wine selection was good. (I usually just ordered prosecco, since I am a big sparkling wine fan) I was impressed with their Octopus dish (Antipasti), the Spaghetti and the main course of Quail and fennel sausage. They were delicately prepared and had tons of flavors, but not overly salty or overly cooked. 

I also loved their pizza place next door, but the line there is sometimes too daunting for me. :) So I resort to Delfina instead at times. 

Love the ambience, it's modern and warm. Reservation is not too hard to make (Thank god they take reservations). 

Service was always warm and attentive.

Aaron, the server is the best. He was so nice to give us extra of those free candies that they serve after you pay your bill, since I told him I love it and asked if they sell those. He just offered me a few extra more since they don't sell them. 

Wonderful gesture that makes a huge impression on foodie like me, since it tells me that people who work there care about the restaurant enough to treat customers with attention and care.
author: Kai Y.

description: I took my gf here for a Saturday date night. We are both Italian and we were extremely excited to eat at Delfina. The service was good at first but as the restaurant became busy it declined quickly. The food was good but not great. We ordered the tartine bread, white shrimp, pork saltimbocca, baked ricotta, and the spaghetti. The best item was by far the pork saltimbocca. The spaghetti was ok, the white shrimp was trying to be southern but fell short. The overall experience was 3 stars. I recommend pizza delfina it has never disappointed us.
author: GP S.

description:
Well-executed and not overly showy --- just food with simple and minimal ingredients that leave flavors unmuddled and bright.  However, pricey for what it is.  The menu also rotates, so some of the amazing-sounding options that other Yelpers have raved about may sadly not be available. 

I went with a group of 3 and had: 

- Puntarelle alla romana:  Refreshing and light start. 
- Spaghetti:  Very simple and minimal # of ingredients, and yet so savory and delicious.  Had a depth that you don't normally expect from what's essentially a 3-4 ingredient sauce. 
- Hangar steak and fries:  Medium rare that was cooked perfectly.
- Pork arrosto:  Very savory and aromatic.
- Lamb loin:  Also cooked perfectly. 

Between 3 people our bill (not including wine) came out to about $170, which is pricey all things considered.
author: Julie H.

description:
I write this review not because the food and wine were excellent (and were they ever), but because the service was simply phenomenal.  And here's why...  

A group of six of us were dining there tonight and by some oversight, the entrees came out at odd intervals.  Immediately, the manager came to the table to apologize, which was very nice and somewhat unexpected, as we hadn't said anything or complained.  Two of us had to wait a bit longer for our meals, but we were with good friends and didn't mind.  In the meantime, they comped the two of us another starter and split it between us, so we wouldn't feel left out.  Very nice touch.  Our entrees arrived shortly thereafter and when we'd all finished, rather than handing us dessert menus, they comped us the entire dessert menu, thanking us for our patience and understanding.  Wow!  That's above and beyond 'above and beyond.'

I really, really enjoyed the meal to begin with and would likely go back to Delfina, but after they handled this minor mix-up so well, I will undoubtedly go back.  What a great first impression, which could have very easily been a lousy one!
author: Gavin H.

description:
Semi-disappointment at Delfina.

Yeah, yeah, I know...a popular place in the Mission district headed up by 2008 James Beard award winner Chef Craig Stoll. You're probably thinking, why become such a debbie downer? Welp, let's just say it all started with a reservation call. Here's how the conversation goes at 3:30pm:

Me: Hi, good afternoon  I would like to make a reservation tonight.
Unknown woman (possibly host): Sure thing, what time?
Me: I would say 6:30pm if possible.
*unknown woman remains silent, checking availability*
UW: ... Sorry we don't have anything at 6:30pm. But we do have something at 8:00pm.
*At this point I'm disappointed but give in*
Me: Sure that sounds fine, you need a name or something?
UW: Oh well, let me get you down for 8PM and you can cancel anytime if you like?
Me: Alright sounds good, but do you need a name or anything.
UW: Nope just walk in around the time and there should be seating.

*fast forward after walking around the city until 8pm with my old friend whom I'm catching up with, and entering restaurant together*

Me: Hello good evening, I called in about 3:30pm for a reservation.
Host Woman: What's your name?
Me: ...Ryan
*HW Checks her list*
HW: I'm sorry but your name (or notation) of a reservation isn't in our records.
Me: I called here at 3:30pm and whoever answered said they would have it covered,
HW: Well unless you provide your name its not a reservation, you're just considered a walk in.

WELL, NO SHIT SHERLOCK. This isn't the first time attending a fine dining establishment and it isn't my last. I felt pretty insulted and frustrated at that point. But we were hungry and we waited forever until we got to eat, so I swallowed my pride and immediately sat down at the counter (no tables available, despite already seeing four of them free up within 10-15 minutes of waiting to take our orders:

Wine
-1 glass of a blend that had the number '72 (could not recall to save the life of me; picture unavailable)

Appetizers
-1 order of the Ahi Tuna Carpaccio: (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?select=xWM8nE3bqrRowXJkzx05pQ)

Second Dish
-1 order of the Pasta Fagioli: (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?select=mF8MZlHC2ZzjKHJrRMXW2g)

Main Entrees
-1 order of the Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken: w/ mash potatoes (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?select=unaAk6_nrQhK6FjgNk9ENQ)

-1 order of the Berkshire Pork Spareribs w/ mini cassoulet: (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?select=GFTNai3pZlTMuAkiM7IPXw) and (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?select=cdtIuGS2gkQmBQOl4odHNw)

Dessert
-1 order of the Buttermilk- Anise Panna Cotta: (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?select=EyCcPHBZUBUntBsJELIrCA)

Let's start with the wine. It was nice and smooth for a full bodied. It doesn't really feel heavy until you chug the last gulps. The carpaccio had a nice vinaigrette, but there was way too much fennel even for my taste. The flavor profile is complete, but the finish wasn't warm but rather "anti-climactic." The Pasta Fagioli aka The Pasta that is really a soup (term coined by my friend). It was bold flavor (it was thick and rich and had a decent kick of it with a bit more pepper than I expected). 

The pork ribs were succulent, but didn't come off the bone as well as I expected. They were a bit too salty for me. The chicken was the better choice,  balanced seasoning, crispy chicken skin and moist white meat underneath. As for the Panna Cotta, it was excellent. Jiggled like a woman's breast, sweet and creamy all around, with a bit of tang on the side. Got a bit more star anise, but Harmony our respectful waitress gave us the heads up on the "experimenting" beforehand that way we weren't in for too much of a shock. Overall, we spent about $120.00 plus tax and tip.

The chicken, panna cotta and Harmony's friendly service are this restaurant's saving grace for me. I've had better luck finding cheaper sustainable eats, compared to higher end restaurants. I hope this experience doesn't repeat at other fine dining establishments in the future (especially in SF). Otherwise, I'm in for a rude awakening. My final rating is 3.5 in actuality. Happy Holidays everyone.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Another restaurant that was too hyped up for me. :(

I wasn't too hungry when I came here with the BF to try their 7x7 duck ragu + other hit menu items as discussed by fellow Yelpers, which was good for us since their menu items are pretty pricey. Just looking at the prices aren't too bad ($16-$19 for pasta menu, appetizers $10-$15, $20+ for other entrees), but the portions are tiny! They do offer bread, which was delicious, and will fill up the void in your otherwise empty stomach.

And surprise, surprise, they weren't serving the duck ragu on the night I made the reservation. We ordered the grilled calamari and the roasted chicken.

Both were delicious, but nothing mind blowingly good I would want to come back for. Grilled calamari was tasty and different from your average fried calamari, but very small. The chicken was juicy and crispy on the outside, but then again .. it's just chicken. 

Perhaps if it wasn't so pricey. And I don't really understand why its so hard to get a reservation here when the food isn't THAT good. 

Luckily Bi-Rite is down the street, and that always satisfies. :)
author: Mina K.

description:
Local favorite known for its seasonal California-Ital specialities and local ingredients that are a picture of the seasonality.
