Try the nero, just because its a little different. They dont fry their calamari because ... most Italian's imply steam calamari when menuing ... but it was SO tender. The only reason I do four stars is because our waiter was a priss... wanted to punch him in the face :P hehehe... but good food... and he suggested a GREAT chablis so ... I half like him. lol
author: Mish L.

description:
Pretty darn good! This was dinner our first night in San Francisco on vacation, and we'll definitely keep it on the short list for our next trip here.

While I can't speak for the whole menu, the food we had was above average or better... But that's mostly because the spaghetti blew the curve out of the water. It was, honest to God, the best spaghetti we've had outside of Italy!

The risotto was just meh. It lacked the rich creaminess that comes from slowly incorporating liquid into the dish as it cooks, and the bone marrow flavor wasn't quite as rich as I had hoped for.

Service was good, not great, but the place was very crowded, so we weren't offended. I do wish our waitress had been just a touch more attentive.

Dessert was the Chocolate Marquise and it was absolutely fantastic, but to be honest we only ordered dessert because we were waiting on a to-go order of the spaghetti to eat after cocktails when the post-drink munchies kicked in. It really was that good!

If you stop by, order some bread, the spaghetti, and if you're really hungry, get some more spaghetti. :)
author: Chris S.

description:
Solid 4 stars.

Appetizer - Grilled Calamari, took no tentacled prisoners, devoured every.single.one.  

Mains:

Spaghetti - Meh, most anticipated, biggest let down.  The large portion was too small for me. Flavor-wise, this wasn't Chef Boyardi, but we weren't drooling either.  Very well executed, but basic dish

Lamb - Served on a delicate but very savory bed of polenta, NOM'd right through it like it was my job, mouthwatering 

Vino - 2009  Cascina Val del Prete, Luet, Piedmont ($32). Amazing value

Ambiance - Can of sardines

Service - Table was ready 10 minutes after reservation, no big deal.  Waitress,  she was perfect, attentive but not intrusive.
author: Steve C.

description:
Amy A., I think you are a meatball, or rather, a meathead!
The service at Delfina is supremely expeditious, and atypically friendly, and obviously would have zero problem making an inquiry to any of the chefs in this well laid out open and airy kitchen.
And there IS NOT a meatball to be found on their menu, period.
The reviews regarding the calamari are 110% true, succulent, tender, and to die for! As far as the roast chicken and pork chop go, there were also juicy and tender, the accompanying whole roasted cherry sauce for the pork was sublime and the stems were still attached.

Plus, if they offer the baked ricotta appetizer, order it immediately.

We spent 35 glorious days roaming northern Italy back in 2004, none of the food compared with Delfina's perfectly prepared menu (although the bufala caprese in Venice was remarkable!).

Thank you, Delfina, for a stunning gastronomic experience.
This Mission district enoteca is one of the top 10 "must eat" places in the city.
author: Kevin W.

description: The food, service, ambiance was incredible...but the reason I will go back is for the hot waiter with the beard, tattoos and badonkadonk....seriously, i wasnt in his section and still felt like samantha in the episode of sex and the city where she sits alllllll night in smiths section and keeps ordering things to be the last one there to take him home...sigh
author: John H.

description:
Average.  After all the hype, I am quite disappointed.  Was here the other night on a friend's recommendation.  The rabbit tasted like chicken, and the sauce was too salty.  The spaghetti was freshly made, but nothing special about the sauce, I thought it was a little too much tomato sauce.  The dessert, we had the panna cota.  I could have done without the rose water.  And the calamari was nothing special.

And automatically deduct one star for not changing my silverware.  After the calamari, the waiter took my knife from my empty plate, and put it on my table.  Yuck.
author: Linda W.

description:
The food was seriously amazing! The only downside that bothered me was the wait time. We were originally told it would only be 15 minutes which turned into a half hour almost 40 minutes wait. Then when they were able to seat us they sat us right in the middle of two walk ways. Shortly after barely ordering our drinks I noticed at least 2-3 other tables that opened up but we were stuck at the table right where everyone walks because of 'reservations.'  Would love to come again but know now to make sure and make a reservation because you'll get better seating. 

My favorite of the food was the olive oil mashed potatoes. I really liked the prosciutto and fava beans too.
author: Ashton S.

description:
In the past, we have always looked forward to eating at Delfina but our last visit a week or so ago was a disappointment. Service was poor. The server forgot one of our entrees and it ended up coming 15-20 minutes after the other entree and all of our dishes which arrived at the same time for some strange reason. 

At any other restaurant, the forgotten entree would have been comped but not here. We were just told we would get a free desert. When we finished eating the server asked about our 'free' desert which we said that we didn't want. It still showed up and we left it uneaten.

The food itself was very bland. From the number of tourists that were sitting around us, I concluded that the food has been dumbed down for out-of-towners. From other Yelp reviews, it appears that the reviews from people visiting San Francisco are far more favorable than those from the Bay Area.
author: Ken M.

description:
Pasta primo.

First and foremost get pasta.

Basic spaghetti is anything but. Rich in flavor and texture. Pappardelle meets its perfect match with a delicious duck ragu. Each five star dishes.

Just make sure you start with starters.

Brilliant zucchini topped with ricotta. Excellent grilled calamari on a warm white bean salad. Surprisingly sweet prosciutto wrapped figs. Can't go wrong with either.

Think twice about entrees.

Grilled albacore was good and complemented with great gypsy peppers. Chicken was bland and served with an unappealing mound of mashed potatoes sitting in a base of oil.

Make sure you ask for bread on the side. It's warm, soft and splendid.

No room for dessert. Fortunately nothing looked too appealing.

Space was simple and polished. Server was friendly and responsive. She was quick to replace a mistake and always stopped by right when we needed her.

Less than $50/person helped by skipping the $12 glasses of wine. Just don't get it.

Pasta and starters are prime. Rest is secondo.
author: Jason B.

description:
One word: Spaghetti.
Get it :)

Make reservations. Parking sucks, plan ahead.
author: Rosie W.

description:
Heard a lot about this place in the Mission. Decided to try it and here's what I found:

$27 for a bottle of Duchessa - Birra Del Borgo beer. 

$10 for the crispily insignificant yet tantalizing good 'insalata di campo.'

$10 for a delicious bowl of spaghetti the size of my fist. 

$25 bucks for the yummy Northern Italian inspired pork spare ribs that had a faint taste of lovely red wine. Served with some pork & beans that were not as scrumptious, sad to say. 

Add state & city sales taxes! $79.93 for one meal.

Oh, but the fresh bread was free! (You have to ask for it, though.) 

Was the food excellent? Of course, but for the prices involved I want a culinary orgasm. And, the service was painfully slow, at times. The servers are quite friendly and helpful, however. So, the slow service and insane prices prevent a 5 star review.
author: Lew A.

description:
I really think Delfina is the ideal San Francisco restaurant. The ambiance is casual but not the least bit sloppy (the service is as good as just about anywhere). The decor is understated but still intimate. And the food is simple, not overpriced, consistent, and fresh. I've never had less than a stellar meal here.

One of my best friends is moving abroad, and we went yesterday to Delfina for one last dinner out on the town. We ordered the salt cod polpette (aka fish balls), latkes, and mixed greens to start, and we had black-truffle squab agnolotti and their classic spaghetti as entrees.

I can't say enough about the spaghetti. I get it every time I come here, and it NEVER disappoints. It's a little spicy, with a robust helping of basil, yet the pasta itself is always perfectly al dente, and the sauce is fresh tomato-ey without being too watery or too pasty. Just make sure you get the large portion, which isn't even that large (but at $13 is still quite reasonable).

But the agnolotti was a revelation. Count me among those who are tired of the truffle oil fad, and when my friend ordered the agnolotti I winced inside, expecting the usual smoky mushroom flavor overwhelming everything else. Instead, it was ever-so-subtle, and the squab was tender, and the broth was the perfect complement.

Rumor has it that desserts here are great as well, but skip it and get Bi-Rite instead (egg nog with brandy until the holidays are over!).
author: Albert L.

description: Really fresh/good break. Warm olives. Ribollita. Pepper salad. Spaghetti (and my date had the hanger steak). Every dish was perfectly made. The space was crowded but comfortable. It was a memorable meal.
author: Morris R.

description:
Let me start my review with a comparison.  We had a reservation at Spork at 10pm in October.  We showed up right on time, but our table was not ready.  10 minutes past our reservation, they brought us champagne, no questions asked, with an unconditional apology.  We had to wait 20 minutes more.  When we were shown our table, they comped our appetizers, and they were incredibly attentive.  And the food was *AMAZING*, and it was an incredibly cool space.

Fast forward to Delfina in November.  Same reservation time, 10pm.  Didn't have a table for us.  30 minutes past our reservation, while we were awkwardly wedged at a corner of the bar between seated eating people, they asked if we wanted to *order* any appetizers.  We're waiting and you want us to pay for it?

50 minutes past our reservation time they sat us. 

Waitress comes over 10 minutes later, no apology for our wait.  No appetizers.  She asks us if we want anything to drink, I ask for wine recommendations, pointing to some bottles under $50.  She said she didn't know anything about the wine list, but would ask the sommelier.  Instead of the sommelier coming over to help us, she just said this $138 bottle was the best and we should order it.  I said no, I wanted one in this section (pointing to it again), and so the sommelier actually came to help us.

I ended up ordering something and after another 10 minutes of waiting they brought a bottle of wine over, but it was the wrong one -- The first time I've gotten the wrong bottle of wine in years -- years!

At this point it was around 11:20, and Delfina had done absolutely nothing to impress us.  We'd gotten no food, no free drinks, no appetizers, and they'd screwed up our only order.  All we'd done is wait for 80 minutes, WITH A RESERVATION, and we had nothing to show for it.

We left.

Best restaurants are judged by how they deal with problems -- see Spork, above.  Delfina completely failed.  It was the worst experience I've had at a restaurant in years.
author: Jon E.

description:
Loved it...loved it...loved it.  Wish I could get reservations at a more normal time than 9pm on a Monday night ... but it was still worth it.

Never have had a bad meal there...from the olives to start, the calimari is also fantastic to the great desert.  Great place.
author: Kevin D.

description:
The only thing that was decent at this place was the customer service.  If it weren't for that, I think I would have asked for my money back.  First off, everything is too close together.  You feel crammed once you're seated, and you can hear EVERYTHING people are talking about around you, but you probably won't be able to hear the person you came in with, unless you scream. The loud obnoxious music doesn't help either. 

The food wasn't all that great either.  I ordered the pesto dish that they're "famous" for; it was terribly bland.  The bread came late, which only gave me a worse impression of the dish, and when the bread did come, it was very dry. 

Finally, the prices are ridiculous.   I spent $70 on two plates that weren't even all that.   Again, if it wasn't for the waiter that was kind enough to pass by every so often, I would have asked for my money back.
author: Angel V.

description:
My fifth meal at Delfina.  Great as usual!  So happy they had the anchovy appetizer....Incredibly delicious.  All pasta dishes are made in house and are amazing!
The quail is my favorite as I'm a light eater, always totally succulent, tender and tasty.
author: Nancy A M.

description: Eh, I mean the wine wasn't bad. The decor is "romantic", but I don't see the big deal.
author: Vinson H.

description: Food partly excellent, partly mediocre. Service mixed. No excuse for repeatedly bumping into people. Bad form to leave the check before the table has finished eating.
author: Leslie M.

description:
Decided to spend Saturday afternoon wandering around the Mission. After getting my ice cream on at Humphrey Slocombe, we got it into our heads that we should walk to Bi-Rite for a head to head comparison. Unfortunately (or fortunately), we got distracted by the siren call of dinner. There was an hour long wait at 6pm, but we weren't in a hurry, so during the wait we strolled on over to Tartine to give the pastries a try.

We were seated promptly at 7 (but at the bar, which made conversation a bit difficult between the three of us). After some perusing, we settled on the spaghetti, calamari with white beans and the roasted chicken.

AMBIANCE: Super casual and... airy. I felt like the space really promoted conversation (as evidenced by the constant buzz of noise swirling around the room) with the combination of seating and lighting. If you have a choice, I would recommend sitting at a table vs the bar area, unless you are a party of two.

SERVICE: Slow. We ran out of water and it took a while to refill, but our waitress was very sweet. 

FOOD:
- Calamari w/ white beans: very fresh squid. Yum. Too bad this dish was TOO SALTY.
- Spaghetti: I really liked the acidic kick of the tomato sauce. I only sampled this dish, but I liked what I tried. I can see the flavor getting slightly monotonous/overwhelming if I had consumed the entire plate.
- Roasted chicken: OMG. I LOVED this dish. J is not a huge fan of chicken (doesn't think its special) but even he enjoyed it. The chicken is succulent, flavorful, and just... yummy. My faves were the skin and the dark meat. MMM. I'd go back just for that.

Overall, it was a very nice dinner. Total for that plus wine was ~$65 + tax&tip. If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd probably try to come at least once a month for that chicken... Make sure to make reservations if possible!
author: Susanna W.

description:
I haven't been back to Delfina in almost a year. I would say the prices keep me away but I think it's the reservation situation as I need to be a bit more spontaneous. Also there are so many choices in the Mission and the food didn't knock my socks off to the point that I was making a rezo on a random evening. I was brought there recently as a post birthday present. The servers are very knowledgeable and attentive but I'm surprised they didn't notice the birthday flyer and offer a dessert. Anyhow, I'm getting ahead of myself...

the 5 of us did it up family style starting with the Cavolo Nero-Pecorino Crostini (very fatty), Brussels Sprouts | hazelnuts, rosemary, honey (divine), Grilled Monterey Bay Calamari | warm white bean salad (delish, we were fighting over the last bits) and Insalata di Campo | field greens, pancetta, walnuts, Parmigiano, balsamic vinaigrette (very rabitty with too little parmigiano). 

For the main course we shared the $80 bistecca (SUPER fatty), Spaghetti | plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil, peperoncini (simple but a little too simple), Wild Nettle Risotto | funghi del bosco (YUM), Olive Oil Mashed Potatoes (so-so) and a squid ink infused dungeness crab pasta dish that was the HIGHLIGHT of the meal. 
We were all very excited about the bistecca since we all had been to Florence and had had one before. One came out while we were waiting for our table and it was MASSIVE and had a big hunk of filet on one side. Ours was not as big and the filet section wasn't even edible to the filet fan at the table. All in all the bistecca was a bit of a disappointment but the rest of the meal was good. 

I like Delfina but I want to like it more. I think I need to go there on a random weeknight (but special occasion) and really get a feel for the place. This big party special occasions (with high expectations) are muddying the waters for me a bit.
author: Nicole O.

description:
I came here for my bday and I must say the staff is amazing.
The food was delish...the steak is flavorful..calamari the scallops..omg!!
It' scrumpcious! 
Great cozy place will visit again!
author: Iris G.

description:
Heard rave reviews from friends and the internet so the hubby and I had to try it, we were both very dissatisfied. This place is very overrated, extremely overrated by one well known food critic that named it one of the best pizza's in the US. Now I still have not traveled to the East Coast so I don't know how this Pizza compares to those of NYC or Chicago but I've had way better pizza here in San Francisco and L.A.  

Won't be coming here again, well, only if my meal is free of course then I'll come back.
author: Roxana R.

description: I love Delfina in San Francisco and was so excited when they opened in Burlingame. A wonderful spot for lunch or dinner with the family. I love the salads, my husband loves the pizza, and my son loves the cream soda. Casual and good service, if a bit noisy.
author: Michelle P.

description: the only thing holding this place back from 5 stars is an inability to order their pizza (from next door) and get it here.  the food is excellent, the service is first rate and the prices are surprisingly reasonable for the bay area.  you can't go wrong.
author: Steve U.

description: My son recommended Delphinas. Atmosphere was great. Service outstanding. Food was delicious and lived up to the server description and recommendation. Loved it!!
author: Kim T.

description: I was extremely disappointed with Delfina. I have heard amazing things about this place and was so excited to go. I took my girlfriend and a friend that was visiting from Miami. We ordered a great wine. Although they have a great selection of wines, they are not cheap! We had 2 appetizers, one was the gnocco frito, good but very plain. And the calamari which was good. I ordered a clam linguini which was unfortunately too salty, otherwise it would have been good. And they ordered pancetta wrapped rabbit. Sounds delicious I know, but it was a undercooked and with not much flavor. Anyways, it might have been a bad experience but I believe SF has many other better italian places. Too bad Delfina...
author: Maria C.

description: Who gets spaghetti at an Italian restaurant when you can make it yourself. GET THE SPAGHETTI. It was great!  The gnocchi was really good as well. The service was exceptional. Best dining experience in quite a long time. Make sure to get a reservation in advance.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I had a wonderful experience at Delfina. I enjoyed their service as well as their food. Reservations were made at 530pm (the time the restaurant opens for business) and though we arrived 10 minutes early there was already a huge crowd outside. Despite the rush, once seated, we were quickly serviced and our waitress was very attentive- not once did we have to ask for refill on our water or bread. 

For starter: 
-Insalata di Campo: bitter greens, pancetta, walnuts, parmigiano and balsamic vinaigrette 

A small dish with great flavors and textures. A little bit of bitterness from the greens and walnuts, a little bit of salt and crunch from the pancetta and all is balanced out with the tangy and sweet balsamic vinaigrette. 

For entrees: 
-Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini 
-Saltimbocca topped with prosciutto

For dessert: 
-Strawberry panna cotta

Enjoyed every single dishes that we ordered, from the salad to the dessert, but my ultimate favorites are the Spaghetti and the Panna Cotta. I think it's so amazing that something so simple (the spaghetti dish) can taste to Divine. The ingredients are very basic but the flavors were quite complex. The texture of the pasta were truly al dente and the flavor  of the tomato sauce were just infused into the pasta. I loved it so much that I tried to do a re-make of it at home but I failed immensely.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I walked into Delfina and was immediately seated. Just myself on a work trip.  They have space at the bar and at a bar like area overlooking the main dining room. The place had a good vibe.  Then I waited ...
I had to ask for my waitress.  Once she showed up.  Very helpful.  Then I didn't see her till I was almost done.  Had to ask someone else for another drink.  So great food and friendly staff but they seem overwhelmed.
author: Pablo M.

description:
The best places give me this: a play on texture.  (water, ice, dried ice)

SPUNTINI
Warm Castelvetrano Olives - many of the characteristics I associate with green olives were not here; tang sour salty cold.  Instead found smooth, silky, meaty, nutty, warm.  
Spiced Almonds - spice that produced a heat that emanated slowly, long lasting.  similar to heat I experience with Indian cuisine (creeper spice).
Duck Liver Mousse | vin santo gelatina - flavor of a nice meat, but not in the rough form of animal meat.

CONTORNI
Tokyo Turnips and Their Greens - approximately dissolves in your mouth.
Jerusalem Artichokes | fennel, meyer lemon - ditto

ANTIPASTI
Grilled Monterey Bay Calamari | warm white bean salad - smokey, zero rubbery-ness

PRIMI
Spaghetti | plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil, peperoncini - Arnold Schwarzenneger to the eye, T1000 to the tongue
Linguine | double clam sauce - didn't try the sauce or pasta but perfectly cooked clams
Pansotti | salsa nocino - tangy shard wrapped in nice ravioli.  perhaps my least favorite dish but still nice.
author: Drew H.

description:
It's nice that a restaurant with all the hype actually lives up to it - this place was incredible.

To make for an impressive start to the evening, we were able to walk in at 6:30pm on a Friday night with no reservations and get seated immediately - really awesome!

The first course was a shared pasta dish of Chantrelle Mushrooms and Mint Tagliatelle - fresh, homemade pasta with a rich and creamy sauce; what I really liked about the dish was that the mushrooms were not overcooked and you could really taste the freshness of the pasta - the mint added a hint of a unique flavor.  I then had the Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken, which was amazing - flavorful, juicy chicken with great, buttery mashed potatoes...who knew something as simple as chicken and potatoes could be so fantastic?  We shared the Panna Cotta, which was very good - rich with a perfect texture, it also managed to be a palate cleanser.  I ordered a nice Chardonnay (Lioco, Sonoma County) that went perfectly with everything - an inexpensive white wine without the acidity I usually expect.

The service at Delfina was very attentive and friendly.  We had at least a few people helping us throughout the evening and I never felt as if I were being ignored.  

I'd recommend this place for anyone whose looking for an incredible meal with incredible service at a moderate price.
author: Ken G.

description:
For someone that's frequently underwhelmed by fancy Italian restaurants, Delfina was very impressive. This is the best pasta I've had from any restaurant. I tried the ribs and an heirloom tomato salad as well. Everything was excellent and I loved the laid-back ambiance. Unfortunately, I was too full from dinner to try dessert but I'll definitely be back soon.

A special shout-out to our server, Kelly A. She did such a great job! My wine glass was never empty but I never noticed her checking on us either. I felt right at home and never wanted for anything during the entire meal. Kelly is fantastic and I hope other diners appreciate her as much as we did.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Realistically, I thought I was walking into Pizzeria Delfina, which was next door. I realized the mistake after my date and I sat down and realized there's no pizza on the menu. Serious FAIL on our parts. BUT we decided to stay, since it was a cute place. 

Anyways, we started off with a nice thing of warm olives. I LOVE olives, and Delfina's definitely did not disappoint! I had the short ribs and my date had a pasta w/ duck. Pasta made al dente is AMAZING! The texture of it was perfect and the taste of the duck was delicious. The ribs were good as well. I really can't complain when the meat just falls off the bone!

I guess it ended up being a good end to the night even though I honestly wanted pizza!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
After having ice cream from Bi-Rite (yes, we had dessert before dinner), we saw a large crowd around Delfina and decided to check it out.  We couldn't choose between Delfina or Pizzeria Delfina, so we put our name down at both places and decided to eat at the place that called us first.  About 30 min later, we had a table at Delfina, and we ate a wonderful meal.

I had the Spaghettini in Nero with Sepia and Mendocino Uni.  It was freshly made pasta (that was cooked perfectly) with squid ink, pieces of squid, tomatoes, zucchini, and uni.  The dish really highlighted the wonderful flavor of seafood without making it taste "fishy".  I really enjoyed it!  My friends got the Grilled Local Albacore Tuna and the California King Salmon.  I got to taste a bit of both dishes and they were both good.  The tuna was served rare and the olive tapenade that came with it was excellent!  The salmon was flaky and it had a yummy corn and caper sauce.

We were too full for dessert because we had ice cream before our meal.  We were seated at a table near the bar so we had a nice view of the kitchen.  I was impressed by the cleanliness of the kitchen and the care the chefs were taking with each dish.  I'll definitely be back again, especially to try their pizza next door.
author: Melisa C.

description: Omg the food was amazing I had amazing service they really know how to take care of their customers I will defiantly will be coming back
author: Karley M.

description: Good decent food and service, nothing special...
author: Alberte K.

description:
Great place. Came here on a Wednesday around 7:30pm, and got a bar seat immediately. (There were a couple left). If you're really hungry, you can probably get away with ordering an appetizer, pasta, main entree, and dessert (will come down to approximately $100 per person w/ tip). 

After coming from Italy (both north/south), the food wasn't very reminiscent. The Prosecco wasn't as good, and at $10 / glass felt overpriced. Nonetheless, this place is worth checking out.

Bay Calamari on top of warm bean salad - 4/5. Enjoyed this a lot. Beans went really well with calamari. 

Louisiana White Shrimp - 3/5. Nothing too memorable. Portion came with 4 large shrimp. I'd skip this next time.

Linguine - 4/5. Good dish. Portion fairly small.

Mary's Roasted Chicken - 4/5. Fairly large portion, half a chicken. Comes with side of mashed potatoes which tasted pretty average. The lady next to me replaced her potatoes with grilled brussel sprouts. Will probably do this next time.

Vanilla Bean Panna Cotta - 5/5. Amazing dessert. Will come back just for this.
author: Andrey L.

description:
Great meal.  Nice ambience even though we were sitting one table from the front door and tightly nestled up against a 6-top with a baby.  Our server was helpful and friendly but the star was the wild boar sugo.  Good lord!  I don't usually eat meat but this was ridiculous.  We should have just had a giant vat of that although the avocado and grapefruit salad was delicious as was the squid appetizer.

We decided to skip dessert and our server told us that was okay as long as we weren't cheating on them with Bi-Rite.  Sorry to say we did!
author: Tempe M.

description: Exceptional food!  Great effecient and pleasant service.  Lively and fun.
author: Gail S.

description:
Third time was not a charm.

Been here twice before and had a great time with fab food. This time it was sooo noisy we had to almost scream across out table to be heard. Food good but not like prior visits. Server was very professional but had no clue about wines.

Wont be back for a fourth.
author: Bobby J.

description: Just a mindblowing meal here. I think I had the best mushroom pizza, actually the best pizza, of my life (sadly, it was a special, not a regular). The appetizers were spot-on, the other pizzas were great, but my mushroom pizza, good God. Amazing.
author: Eric S.

description:
I had no idea what a great place this was. My husband and I walked in and there was not a sole in sight. The lady told us we could have bar seating. I looked around and could not believe this place would fill up on a Tuesday night. Sure enough by dinner time the place was packed. 

  We sat down at the bar. It was first time seeing a person working hard just to put a salad together one leaf at a time.  We had ordered a hand rolled pasta dish with the most delicate Lemon sauce. It was wonderful. We had a great time and hope to go back sometime in the near future.
author: Kathryn W.

description: This is by far the worst service I have ever received at a restaurant!  We ordered two bottles of wine and they came out 10 minutes apart, food came out at vastly different times and the waitress submitted the wrong meals on the ticket so some of our dishes were wrong.  When we asked what was happening the waitress could have said sorry I put in the wrong meals, instead she lied and said that the dish just took longer to make.  I would understand that, but it took 15 minutes longer.  The waitress was more concerned with the table our friends behind us then providing good service.  The management wasn't much better in handling the situation either.
author: Brian O.

description:
My husband made a reservation for the two of us on a Tuesday night.  Service was slow and we were definitely feeling it because we were starving.

Had the 7x7 praised pappardelle with duck sugo and roasted peppers.  It was OK.  The pasta was nicely cooked and had a nice bite.  The duck wasn't that flavorful and I would have liked a bigger portion.  I was expecting a strong duck flavor in the sauce as well.

My husband had the large order of spaghetti which was more like what the small should be in my opinion.  It was delicious and again, the pasta had a nice bite.  It reminded me of a lesser Scarpetta spaghetti, which I now have the recipe for and make regularly.

We also split the olive oil mashed potatoes, which were just fine.  Tasted like something I could make at home.

I am willing to give this place another chance so I can try the other menu items.
author: Melissa W.

description:
So I made the mistake of booking the wrong day and when I showed up they did not have a table for me. oops.  Every table was totally booked on the Thursday I went so I was relegated to the bar.

It ended up being pretty cool because we could see the chefs do some cooking.  Overall the food was pretty good, a bit over priced and I will probably stick to the pizza spot next door next time, but all in all it was a good experience and the ambiance was great!

Also, I wish the wine selection was a bit better. I'd still recommend it if you haven't checked it out yet.
author: Josh D.

description: Interestingly enough the (side) dish that made the most impression on me was the brussel sprouts starter!  So delish.  Also enjoyed the dungeness crab risotto and duck which was nicely rendered.  Washed it all down with a glass of Syrah.  Quarters are a little cramped, but worth a return visit for sure.
author: Pam S.

description:
FOREVER, I've been wanting to go to Delfina. So when I found out my mom was going to be in town, I immediately went to their website and booked an 8:30 rez. When we arrived, they informed us they were running about 15 minutes behind. But to make up for it, they gave me a free glass of Prosecco. Immediately, I wasn't as bummed about the extra wait time.

I loved, loved, loved the fresh grilled calamari and white bean salad that I ordered. There was a fresh lemon taste that blended perfectly with the richness of the calamari and beans.

My mom got the Insalata di Campo, which was bitter greens, pancetta, shaved parmagiano, walnuts, and balsamic vinaigrette. Well, they forgot the walnuts, and I don't think she was super pumped about the salad in general. (For the record, I had a bite and thought it was delicious).

For entrees, I ordered a house-made rosemary fettuccine with a traditional meat ragu. It didn't look like anything special on the plate, but I was in love with this pasta. The subtle taste of the rosemary in the pasta and the traditional bolognese sauce went together perfectly.

Again, it was a tale of two dinners. My mom got the pork belly with clams, chickpeas, and chard. She didn't exactly enjoy it. She wasn't aware pork belly was so fatty and overall, I think it just wasn't what she was expecting. The waitress was SO sweet. Offered to bring her something else, but my mom totally took responsibility for ordering the wrong thing and turned them down. Still, they sent over some delicious soup to try and make ammends.

Dessert...one last shot to impress mom. And...SUCCESS! Phew! It was lime buttermilk panna cotta with huckleberries and it was seriously like heaven on a plate. My mom loved it. 

Long story short...I absolutely LOVED this place. My mom...not so much. Just goes to show everyone has different tastes. And not every highly acclaimed restaurant is for everyone. But I definitely will be back...just not with my mom.
author: Jaymee S.

description:
squid ink chitarra with dungeness crab.  this sounds so good, and i was imagining a dish like the squid ink pasta at trattoria la siciliana, but better.  

the dish i ended up getting was bland and unimpressive.  simple dishes can have great flavors, but here it really just tasted too rich while being flavorless.  it tasted the way it looked - pasta and crab with a lemon squeezed out on top.  for twenty bucks.
author: Erika C.

description: The food is really tasty and fresh. I had spaghetti with tomato sauce, the spaghetti is thicker than usual, so very chewy. Chicken here is very juicy!! Smash potato is good as well
author: Sunny J.

description: Hearty, vibrant, relaxed restaurant. Had the best calamari, spaghetti, and chicken with mashed potatoes here. There are probably more things that are worth trying, but you can never go wrong with those. Also we really loved the pana cotta! 5 stars would come again!
author: George L.

description: Food 5 stars.  Service was just ok.  Because the restaurant is in such high demand, the tall blond female waitress we had didn't seem very attentive or genuinely interested in us enjoying our dinner experience.  Go for the food though; it's very good!
author: Annie M.

description: I usually hate when people write reviews that are not based on a restaurants food so I apologize in advance.  But I want to voice how much it annoys the shit out of me the way this restaurant takes over the side walk.   And how rude the wait staff are to you when you just want to walk by with your bags full of groceries.  I'm sorry if I feel I have the right of way on a public sidewalk.   I'm happy for the success of the restaurant but can I suggest they GET A PARKLET and get rid of the useless bike rack to ease the congestion.    Be courteous to your neighbors guys.
author: Frank A.

description:
for 16 months of living in SF, I always had managed to put this place away from my list over other places.

Finally tonight, I decided to venture, and boy, am I glad I did!

their spaghetti was heavenly, I don't know what they did to it but it was simply perfect. also calamari white bean dish was excellent as well as prosciutto with chestnuts was great too. 

we tried their profiteroles as dessert, it was delightful. service was great, and i really loved their atmosphere too.
author: Sung C.

description:
Came in on a Friday night for a semi late dinner, we didn't have reservations but that was not problem for the restaurant.  We were promptly seated after a few minutes and our server was very attentive and quite informative in regards to their menu.  Plus was that there was an orange wine flight...most were quite tasty even though one of them was a favorite of mine.  

For starters we had the warm olives, little gem salad (I loved that one) and the turnips (which I found a bit too salty for my taste).  For our entrees we had the spaghetti and the tortolloni (similar to a tortellini with mushrooms inside).  Both were very tasty and we did order dessert but by that time I was too full to take more than one bite but it was obviously very good since my dining partner ate every bit of it.  We most definitely will be coming back again to try the other items on the menu!
author: Allison T.

description:
I will make this one short, based on 2 visits:

Food is good/different  but nothing outstanding.

So darn noisy no matter what time you go -- great place to get into a shouting match with your friends so as to be heard across the table. 

So darned cramped no matter what time you go.

Server had no clue about wines - steered us completely in the wrong direction with her Chardonnay choice for us, even though I made it quite clear what we were looking for.  Wonder why she is even a server.

Giving 3 stars as I think 2 for this place is a little harsh.
author: JohnJacob A.

description:
Just another vastly overrated and overpriced San Francisco restaurant. To all those people who claim this is the best " fill in the blank " they've ever had in their life, I will say: you need to get out more often. 
The food is just ok. Just Ok. nothing more nothing less. Most definitely nothing memorable and nothing I would come back to. Believe me when you have a truly superior meal you are going to know it. Those who are so easily impressed and buy into the hype, are the ones giving this grossly overrated eatery 5 stars. Get real people. This is no Brasserie Lipp.
author: Dee B.

description:
THE best panna cotta. Chocolate budino ain't too shabby either.

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description: Our waitress was obviously having a bad day or just has a bad attitude. The ambiance was nice and warm here but the service was cold and stiff. As for the food, only the brussels sprouts were memorable.  Pastas were undercooked and overly salty.
author: Hue L.

description:
Came here tonight for my friend's birthday. It was a last minute choice, but I'd been wanting to visit for a while. The bread + butter they kept bringing us was awesome! We ate so much freakin' bread. TONS. The butter is whipped and sprinkled with sea salt... AWESOME. BUTTER RULES!

I'm vegetarian, so I had the spaghetti and the Polenta Valsugana side. The spaghetti was perfectly al dente and coated with a mild sauce. Both of my dishes were relatively good, very rich, and waaaay too salty. I think the saltiness kind of ruined my enjoyment, unfortunately. On the plus side, our waitress was incredibly nice and the ambience was pleasant. I left with most of my food in to-go containers (I ate too much bread, obviously), and I'm eating some of it now... mixed together. Spaghetti with polenta is not very good, FYI. I feel sort of disgusted with myself.

Basically, I wouldn't come back to Delfina unless it was someone else's choice... and only if they paid for me.
author: Jessie A.

description:
The food at this place was amazing and the service was incredible as well.  I had never heard of this place and when I walked in i thought oh no, another hip overrated restaurant in the Mission.  I was wrong!.  The service was amazing, the waitress was very knowledgeable and professional and the food was just soooo tasty.

I can't wait to go back soon!.  I highly recommend it.
author: J A.

description: Great food, great team work, great communication, great patience. I loved this place. Thank you to Molly and everyone at Delphina!
author: Matt C.

description:
Here's the to-the-point, the skinny, or the executive, summary: food has flashes of brilliance, but there are too many waiters unconcerned about the customer experience for me to recommend this to anybody. I'm not clicking on the Like button.

First, about what I like about the place. We called at 9:30 pm on Sat June 25, and the hostess was very accommodating and polite person, giving us a table at 10 pm. In the Mission, we braved countless latino men brandishing Mexico flags celebrating the soccer victory over the US, sidewalk open-air dance parties (someone had turned their living room into a DJ studio, with throngs of people dancing on the sidewalk) at the fringes of which there were people blasting roaches, and out-of-towners searching for parking for the nearby Gay Pride parties in the castro. We skedaddled the Mini Cooper (the "PASHMNI" named after my wife and the Mini) into a tight spot, and walked over.

Back to the hostess, this could have been a different one, but she was even friendlier, assured us that we'd be seated soon, and we found our way to the bar area. That's when the bad customer experience began. I stood at the edge of a short bar, and waited patiently for about 8 minutes while a waiter busied himself behind the bar doing this and that, with nary a glance at me. Finally, I asked another waitress, and she said she couldn't serve me, but would snag the snooty waiter. To her credit, she did, and he served me a beer. Nursing my beer, I then asked the hostess (this time, a younger, somewhat inexperienced one) if we could sit at some empty chairs while waiting for our table, and she said no, it was reserved for people eating. As it happened, a couple walked in through the door, checked in, and just sat down on those chairs - lesson learned, next time I won't ask.

We ordered an appetizer, a first course, and a second course - and when the calamari appeared, I declared it "divine" because of the fantastic marinated squid (I think it was squid) that came in it. That was a great start. The Mint Tagliatelle was declared too salty by my wife, and I have to agree with her, though I downed it because I was hungry - it tasted like about 900mg of salt in a small serving - sort of like pasta soaked in chinese soy sauce, though, to be fair, it could have been a great dish without the salt. Finally, the roasted chicken with mashed potatoes - the potatoes were really great, but the chicken average. And it took so long to come to the table that we had to ask for it be to boxed up so we could get out of there and go to the great crepe place on 11th street for a butter-and-sugar-whipped-creme-crepe-to-go.

Here's my advice to the Delfina management - revamp your customer service. Our waitress, though perfectly nice and personable (she must have read the article that said a good tip comes from smiling and being friendly), didn't refill our butter, rarely came to check on how we were doing, and while we waited the interminable wait for the roasted chicken, she was nowhere to be found.

Who was attentive was a waiter whose first day it was at Delfina. We noticed how attentive he was being to a number of tables, and flagged him down to ask him to refill our butter, which he did (not saying, "I can't serve you, but I'll ask the your waiter", like the first waiter at the bar), and he even checked on our roasted chicken to tell us it was almost ready. We complimented him, and he said this was his first day so he was a bit nervous. I don't know what your name is, but we hope you remain the same person you were when you joined Delfina that day - never change! If Delfina can bottle that newness and enthusiasm, they could become a great restaurant, not just a good one.
author: Vik C.

description: This is a small and trendy restaurant.  We sat at the long bar overlooking the restaurant and had a wonderful dinner.  I got the Ricotta Cavatelli and my friend got the chicken.  Both dishes were really good.  The mashed potatoes were amazing.  This is a great date place or even a place to catch up with an old friend.
author: Payal V.

description: Fantastic evening.  Delfina has been a favorite of a number of our friends, and with our recent relocation to San Francisco, it became a must visit.  It certainly did not disappoint.   We had a great table by the window, was greeted warmly by the server, we felt right at home.  The food was excellent, from the spaghetti with tomato sauce (just the right spices), to the swordfish all was deliciously prepared, served, and totally consumed.  A definite repeat!
author: Harold B.

description:
I have lived in the Bay for all of my life and have always wanted to come to this place and dine in person. What a better day to visit for my first time than this past Sunday, one of the five days of Summer we get annually in San Francisco. 

The outdoor seating and friendly staff (especially the VERY attractive waiter that initially helped us!) at Delfina really sets the tone for a nice weekend brunch/afternoon snack/weeknight supper experience.
 
I had known the food was good before so that was never at question (I had previously gotten takeout to eat at the nearby Dolores Park on a horrible date many years prior! The pie was clearly the highlight! HAH) and this experience added to the consistency I desire from medium to higher-end eateries.

They would have earned a fifth star had they came around to check in more frequently (it took about 10-15 to get our first beverage upon being seated when people waiting in line were clearly holding a glass of wine in their hands). But the cute waiter who came by twice in between made up for it. 

My only tip is to make sure you go around 2-330p (especially so on a nice Sunny weekend afternoon) to avoid a large rush of people coming over from the park. 

We got seated within 10 mins but others had to wait much, much longer. 

Finally, this is a GREAT spot to take the edge off before a long work week at the office with your girlfriends (or boyfriends) as it might be! Tons of Eye Candy for ALL teams to partake upon! ;)
author: Michael K.

description: As a party of 4 on a Friday night, at 6:45, we were told the wait was 30 minutes. After an hour wait.. Still not seated with other parties being seated before us.. Call ins we were told.. We left.. Not good business
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Whats italien food about? good groceries and nice naturally flavors.

As a fine dining Italian restaurant its totally out of flavor and good groceries.
Everything was mediocre, except the wine.

Sorry Delfina but your not good.
author: Patrik D.

description:
If I had one restaurant to go to in all of San Francisco, it would be Delfina. 

The chicken with a nice mushroom broth and sliced steak with french fries are my stand-bys.  I recommend their bowl of spaghetti (comes in two sizes) for its simplicity and yumminess. Their pasta and fish dishes are also consistently good. 

If you need a good meal for two, I recommend you get one of the entrees above, a small bowl of spaghetti and a couple of their yummy side vegetable dishes.

And quit complaining about how hard it is to get a table. Go there at 530pm when they open and you'll either get a table or sit at the bar (any night of the week).
author: Rob K.

description: The food was fantastic, you will not be disappointed. The wine selection was fantastic as well. The waiter was very knowledgable but the service was slightly slow. I will definitely be coming back again.
author: Steven K.

description:
Food one word SALTY
Olives and Service = 4 Stars
author: A. M.

description:
Love the sleek, hip interior. Great dining experience.

My favorite dishes:

Salmon crudo
Lamb sausage
Tortelloni
TCHO chocolate budino
Lemon panna cotta

Barbera d'Alba "Donna Margherita"| Giovanni Rosso 2009, Piemonte
author: Jennifer D.

description: I love my California friends- they show me the best time whenever I'm chillin on the west coast. After a day of walking around enjoying greenery in golden gate park, followed up by beers and more greenery on the beach, followed by champagne at Vestry, I was in a state for sure. I would have eaten anything and it would have tasted great. But those fantastic friends led us to Delfina, and although I was acting a fool at the dinner table, I blame the insanely delicious spicy spaghetti, and not my decisions earlier that day. Eating off of other people's plates delicious. Harassing the waitress for the recipe delicious. Props to legendary man of mystery Joe Tan for getting our table of 5 into a packed, vibrant Delfina with no wait. Who are you Joe Tan?
author: Lauren E.

description:
I've been wanting to go to Delfina forever. And my lovely friends made it happen on my birthday last week! Anyhow, when I say forever, I mean forever...I lived around the corner for over a year and managed to go everywhere else: Tartine several times to get that oh so delicious morning bun, Bi-Rite for cheese and groceries, Bi-Rite Creamery for amazeBall ice cream...well you get the picture! But never Delfina! And because of that I didn't pay much mind to the difference between "Delfina" and "Delfina Pizzeria", silly me, I thought I could ALSO get pizza at Delfina, but for the moment that's neither here nor there.

Ok so first the bad and then the good. The bad, we arrived early, 30 minutes to be exact for an 8PM reservation. They told us we'd have to wait until 8, no probs there, but the bar space is super small and everyone in it was eating full meals, leaving not a one chair or space to stand open, so we hopped over to Farina for a cocktail while we waited. Those folks were funny, def. will go back there, but at 7:55 we closed out our bar tab and hopped back over to Delfina. We checked in at 8 and low and behold our table isn't free. Ok, still no probs, and then....an hour goes by. ONE whole hour. It was my bday, so that kinda sucked...but in Deflina's defense they really took care of us while we waited and did everything they could to get the folks taking up a table after paying and having no food left to scooch. We got lots of yummy apps on the house and they were very apologetic. So no harm no foul.

Ok now the good good good food:

Barbera d'Alba "Brichet" | C a'Viola 2009, Piemonte - Don't remember the price but nice medium bodied flavor

Warm Castelvetrano Olives $6: What is it about a warm olive smothered in olive oil? Delicious. 

Spiced Almonds $3: Could pass on this. Lots of fennel, nice if we had a beer.

Gnoccho Fritto & La Quercia Proscuitto $9: Only one in my group eats meat, so we gave her the proscuitto and w/out it the "gnocchi" more like puff pastry was very bland.

Ricotta Stuffed Squash Blossoms $13: To die for. Just the right amount of salt, cheese and lightly fried goodness. Get 2 orders if there are more then 4 people. 

Grilled Monterey Bay Calamari w/warm white bean salad $11: Very buttery and yummy. The bean salad was really tasty. 

Smothered Chard | lemon, garlic $8: Tasty and simple side dish.

Stuffed zucchini:Special, meh, could have passed on this.

Spaghetti | plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil, peperoncini $10/$15: OMG, so simple and so amazingly good. Brought me back to Rome. Get the large. 

Pansotti | walnut sauce $17: Like raviolli in a nutty cream sauce. So tasty.

Mint Tagliatelle | fresh porcini mushrooms, nepitella $18: Not my favorite but still tasty for those who like mushrooms and a little bit of cream. 

Rose-Mascarpone Crostata | Frog Hollow peaches, hazelnut croccante $9: Wow, fresh and creamy with sweetness from the peaches and crunch from the cookie. 

Straus Milk Granita | strawberries, almond cartellate, aged balsamico $9: This was like a Hawaiin shaved ice. Really fun and delicious.
author: Shira O.

description:
Overall: excellent service and antipasti; good entrees (though a bit uneven -- too salty).

The wait staff is incredibly attentive and helpful, the antipasti were excellent, and the entrees, though too salty, were prepared with skill and expertise. The photos I have posted of the beautiful entrees attest to the obvious deftness of the cooks. 

Our party of four started off with the grilled fresh calamari, the fresh-cured anchovies (impressively flavorful and balanced - the acidic lemon and wine tamed the saltiness), and the beef carpaccio (a special); all of these were excellent and served in generous proportions. 

For our main entrees, we ordered the spaghetti, leg of lamb, roasted chicken, and rosemary tagliatelle. We shared braised chard and the Romano beans stracotto. I sampled a bit of everything, but ordered the leg of lamb.

The leg of lamb was one of the most beautifully presented leg of lamb entrees I have ever seen: generous slices of perfectly pink lamb sitting on a bed of fresh beans and resting in a rich jus. The only thing detracting from its perfect texture and temperature was that it was too salty for my palette (unfortunately, this is a rather important factor). 

The other dishes were tasty and fresh, particularly the pastas, but we all agreed that the entrees were a bit too salty.

NOTE: Upon reliable advice from a friend and frequent Delfina diner, I consider last night's briny entree experience anomalous. Perhaps some of the cooking staff were a bit under the weather. Still, I was pleased to finally get a reservation here.
author: Chris T.

description:
Nettle soup, if  they have it!

I wish it weren't so pricey, but it's worth it.
author: George P.

description:
I don't know what changed. Maybe my palate changed or the direction in the kitchen changed? 

Service is lovely and the space is comfortable for conversation. The food is well done but there's nothing that knocked my socks off.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
WHAT THE HECK: I'm saddened to see Delfina associated with food poisoning as reported in the NY Times.  Reminds me of a HORRIBLE night of food poisoning my team and I got at Beretta.  

NYTimes Unreported Cases of Food Poisoning Reflect a Gap in Food Supply Safety Net
http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/06/health/nutrition/unreported-food-poisoning-at-san-francisco-restaurant-spotlights-absence-of-law.html
author: Alias A.

description: Delicious meal! The escarole and fig salad was simple, yet exquisite. The pappa al pomodoro is a nice tomato bread soup. Overall, vegetarian options are very limited for entrees.  The panna cotta is the only way to go for dessert.
author: Kruti P.

description:
Highly over-rated. Cannot believe it won a James Beard award. We had the fries that were dry and over-cooked. The broccoli rabe and pasta were way too salty, and the service was spotty. 

Hope I just hit it on an off night, but was really disappointed.
author: David K.

description:
We came here for an anniversary/graduation dinner and it was nothing short of incredible. We're still talking about how great the food was and how much we enjoyed being in the restaurant itself. 

Started out with olives, split the hard boiled egg salad, I had the fulton valley chicken, she had the tortelli. We split a bottle of Chianti and finished up with a cheese plate and some bi-rite gelato/chocolate cake madness. The food was heavenly and the price tag was more than reasonable. Our server was stellar and we had great conversation with the two tables on either side of us. 

This is my new favorite restaurant in the City. I cannot wait to come back.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Delfina was the last notch on my belt for the gourmet corridor housing Bi-Rite and Tartine.  I had been to Pizzeria Delfina before, but the Pork Sugo and Papardelle of Delfina Restaurant had always eluded me.

And.... which it continued to do on my first visit. I was greatly disappointed to find that the infamous pork sugo and papardelle dish was unavailable the Saturday night that I dined there so I was forced to make due with other dishes. 

I started off with the grilled fresh calamari and warm white bean salad.  The calamari was tender (not at all rubbery) and had an sweet smokiness that nicely contrasted with the butter-soft smoothness of the  white beans. It brought me back to a wonderful warm calamari salad I had once at A Cote. 

Next, we had the heirloom tomato salad with burrata and anchovies. The mainstay of the dish, the tomatoes, were underwhelming. What really stood out in this dish were the burrata and croutons. There aren't many more naturally perfect combinations like creamy burrata, tomatoes, olive oil, and a crunchy starch. The starch in this dish were the most perfect croutons morsels I have ever had: garlicky, infused with the olive oil dressing, but still amazingly crispy. 

I quickly got over my disappointment re: the pork sugo when I started on my main dish: spaghettini nero with uni. Most people would be revolted at the thought of black pasta, but I am obsessed with squid ink.  Though the squid ink spaghetti tasted of sea salt and was distinctly maritime, it wasn't fishy at all. The subtle spiciness of the dish was a great contrast to the briny, seafood essence of the squid ink and fresh uni. 

Overall, I enjoyed my meal at Delfina, but I'll have to return to try the elusive Pork Sugo and Papardelle. Until next time Delfina!
author: Monelle A.

description: I love this place. The gnocchi is absolutely amazingly delicious. Don't pass on this. We had the heirloom salad and these tomatoes were exploding with flavor. Our server even shared that the women that they buy the tomatoes from just delivered them 10 minutes before we sat down. That is Farm to Table! In addition, the service was second to none. Our server was well informed and checked in with us regularly. Furthermore, the wine was tasty. I recommend the chianti in a glass. Very Tasty!
author: Hoss K.

description:
This spot seems more like the place to be seen eating pizza, rather than actually eating pizza. Customer service was alright and fine, but the toppings were minimum in contrast to the entire pie. Great recipes, nonetheless, but if you're hungry and expecting to get full on some good slices like you normally do, don't go here unless you're willing to spend about $35-$40 for two people. Nice snack if you've got the money to spare, otherwise, the ingredients are readily available at any nearby grocery store, and you could fill yourself up and save about $15 bucks.
Just keeping it real.~
author: Banksy R.

description:
had a really good meal here this past weekend. my chicken dish was very good but i especially enjoyed the grilled calamari. 

wine list was a bit on the high end meaning that there were very few bottle options under $45. other than that, no complaints.
author: Jae C.

description:
I've been wanting to go here for about 8 years now and for some reason it just never lined up.  So last night I was pretty excited to finally make the trip.  

I was less excited once complete.

The two main course dishes were nothing special, way over salted imo.  Out of 3 main courses (two folks ordered same dish), one of the dishes showed up at least 5, maybe even 10 minutes before the other two.  The waitstaff was incredibly apologetic, and admitted the mistake.  But that's a pretty large mistake for a nice restaurant like this.

All of the plates were incredibly small proportions.  The calamari consisted of three pieces.  They were fairly large pieces, but only 3.  At the same time, it was probably my favorite dish.  

All the other dishes were average.  Nothing horrible, but nothing special.

Small proportions, ok food, ok service.  Disappointed overall.  I would give 2.5 stars if i could, 2 seems low, but can't seem to get myself to click on 3.
author: Joe A.

description: I came here with my dinner date without a reservation and had been told that the wait would be almost an hour, but luckily a table opened up at the 30 minute mark :) This was on a Tuesday, so reservations definitely recommended. I love the ambiance of this little restaurant, very fancy but still comfortable. We had the two classic items on the menu, the spaghetti and the chicken. Both were excellent, satisfying, and well worth the price. I would love to come here again, and it's very close to BiRite and Dolores Park for conveniently placed romantic moments afterward.
author: Ryo C.

description:
They say that the way to a man's heart is through his stomach...

If that's the truth then this was probably the best decision my boyfriend made in taking me here for my birthday.  On any given night you can expect people waiting for a table outside on the patio at 9pm with a glass of wine in hand.  Reservations can be hard to come by and the wait can be intimidating but trust me, it's worth it.  I truly can't say enough good things about the restaurant.  Skip the $26 bowl of Pasta over at Farina down the street and stick to Delfina.  You won't regret it.   

The experience began walking in to the dimly lit dining area packed with tables.  The noise level is apparent but not overbearing and you're comfortably able to speak to the other guests at your table.  The service staff is knowledgeable, friendly, and accommodating and the food...AMAZING!

Now if only I can get my boyfriend to take me to Flour + Water next...
author: Sean H.

description:
A hip, romantic place with incredible food. Reservations are a must (through their website or by phone), unless you want to risk waiting over an hour for your meal.

Two of us shared:
Warm castelvetrano olives -- Surprise! These olives were actually piping hot when they hit our table, but they were firm and delightfully lemony, great with the bread.

Grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad -- The best grilled calamari that I've ever had, and a generous portion, especially for an appetizer. Many thanks to the other Yelpers who recommended this dish.

Pappardelle with liberty duck sugo -- How did they possibly make pasta with this texture? The sauce had a wonderful flavor, with just enough bits of duck to make it interesting.

Berkshire pork arrosto with farro and cippollini onions -- An enormous portion of perfectly roasted pork with crispy edges. The farro and cippollinis were a wonderful complement to the meat.

Service was quick and friendly - you need to ask for bread if you want some, but that's alright. The only two downsides were that we had to wait more than 15 minutes to be seated, even though we arrived early and had a reservation for 10pm; also, some of the dishes were a bit on the saltier side. Think of it as an adventure - it's definitely worth the trip!
author: Erika K.

description:
My hubby and I had reservations here on a cold, rainy night.  Reservations are a must at a restaurant like this due to it's popularity and size.  

Finding parking is a task in the Mission, but apparently they have valet at their sister restaurant, Locanda, which is 3 blocks down.

The menu is slim, but the options are amazing.  It was hard to narrow it down.  We started with the spiced almonds and insalata di campo, which was perfect - a variety of bitter greens with walnuts, pancetta, parmigiano, balsamic vinaigrette. It was one of the best salads we've had.  

You do have to request bread if you desire it.  I ordered the spaghetti and it was perfect - light sauce with a little spice to it.  People do say that it compares to the real stuff you get in Italy and I have to say.....haven't ever been there.....it must be the real deal because I have NOT tasted anything like it in the U.S. 

My hubs ordered the Pappardelle with pork sugo - pork flavor was amazing and juicy and the pasta was cooked just right.

We ordered a side of olive oil mashed potatoes, which were delicious and smooth.

We were both happy campers and felt that the portions were just enough - we did not feel overly stuffed, but content.  Service was also delightful.

It was a pleasant and relaxing meal --- very cozy restaurant.  We had a wonderful dinner and will definitely plan to go back soon.
author: three's company M.

description:
Defina good to the last bite.  Make reservations or you'll be waiting outside all night and then some.    

Here's what I tried
Antipasti:
Grilled Calamari with a warm bean salad - A tasty dish with the beans being nice and creamy.  The Calamari was nicely seasoned bringing out its natural flavors without overpowering the squid.

Crostinis with chicken liver pate and pickled veggies - Pretty good dish although I thought the crostinis were a bit saturated in butter, even though this was smooth and rich, I would have preferred the crostini itself to be a little less rich to contrast the pate a bit more.

Entree:
Papardelle with pulled pork ragu - Tasty dish, but heavy on the way down.  I was a little concerned that a friend of mine who ordered the half portion looked the same as my whole portion, the only difference was the plate size.  The pasta was great.

Trippa alla Fiorentina - Tripe in a tomato based sauce with bread crumbs on top served in a single serving dish.  This was alright, although a little strange on this menu.  I enjoy tripe and this was good.

Dessert:
Lemon Buttermilk Panna Cotta - This was a good solid dessert.

Brown Butter Finanziario - This was okay, not extremely special for such a fancy name.

Decor: 4
Food:4
Service: 4 

Would I go back? You bet your pastrami I would!
author: Kelson H.

description: Love this place. Mint tagliatelle, get that immediately. Good selection of wine and great service. Highly recommended.
author: Dave M.

description: It was good but not great.  The chicken was delicious, duck good and everything else was ok.  It was a good meal overall but not great...which for SF standards it is just ok.  Would we be back, no, considering all the great restaurant in the Bay Area.
author: Tammy P.

description: Came in with BF for dinner, no reservation.  They were busy but we were able to get seated pretty quickly at the bar.  And even at the bar we had excellent service!  Food is incredible-- the quail stood out as did the duck pappardelle
author: Kevin M.

description: The food was actually fantastic but the underwhelming service made this a night to forget. Our reservation was for 8:00 -- it was 9:30 before we got bread and olives and the waiter needed to be reminded to bring those. They have an extensive Italian wine selection, but their California wine list as well as their beer selection could be improved. Overall, we had a 2 1/2 hour dinner, but with food only present for the final hour and a rather mediocre server.
author: Dr. J.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me this long to get here.  Albert was right when he said Delfina is the ideal SF restaurant.  It's just the right size, unpretentious, is very reasonably priced for what you get.

Bottles of wine vary in price but start with very reasonable selections in the $40-50 range.  Even though there's no formal sommelier, the servers actually know a lot of nuances about the wine list, so be sure to ask them.  There's warm bread available upon request, which is awesome for dipping up the last of your sauces in the end.

We started with the Louisana white shrimp in porchetta - it was one of the most plump and flavorful shrimp I've had in a long time.  They're served head on, peeled, and have such rich flavor that penetrates throughout the entire shrimp.

We then couldn't resist with the pastas - we ordered 4 of them and then ordered another of the semola baattuta.  My favorite was obviously the semola battuta, which is like a thicker, more textured ribbon pasta, topped with a very flavorful lamb ragu and shaved pecorino.  It's served super warm, so the pecorino melts as it touches the pasta.  This dish was super addictive, and I don't even like lamb. 

My next favorite pasta was the squid ink chitarra, which was squid ink throughout the spaghetti-like pasta, tossed in crab butter, slightly peppery, then topped with fresh dungeness crab and a squeeze of subtle meyer lemon to balance it out.  This was a close second to the lamb ragu.

The ravioli with a sweet kuri squash filling topped with nutmeg had a nice nutty balance with the sweet puree, but I would have preferred just the filling on its on in another dish.  The tripe was just ok for me, since I'm not a big tripe fan, but my friends LOVED IT and soaked up every last bit with the bread.

As for entrees, the pork was well flavored but not as amazing or unique as the pastas.  The shortrib was nice in that it was cooked in pieces, rather than the usual stewed fork-tender shortrib.  It was firmer, less fatty, and sat on an amazing sauce that I wish there was more of.  The accompanying polenta was a bit dry but was much better with the sauce from the shortrib.

We had to pass on desserts since we were down the street from Tartine and Bi-Rite.

I'm usually scared of having too much carbs, but I would happily eat their pasta every night.  It's definitely a place you can become a regular at without breaking the bank, and it'll be my go-to place for pasta from now on.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
I took my husband here for dinner for his birthday and we both loved it.  We were seated on time and had great service.  Loved the modern italian style of this restaurant and there were a number of things I wanted to eat on this menu.

I started with a salad which was really light and delicious and my husband had what was described to us as a minestrone soup/ bread absorbed dish.  It didn't get points for presentation but my husband loved it (which is shocking because if I had made something similar it would have been met with considerably less enthusiasm as he usually avoids vegetarian dishes).  We both had pasta dishes for our main course both fresh, well cooked and yummy.  Can't wait to return!
author: Kim U.

description:
This little gem is a great place! So satisfying when you go to a place and it exceeds your expectations. Having read some reviews on here, I expected small portions, difficult to come by reservations, and a loud ambiance; not all true. Yes the reservation was for 530, but there must have been a cancellation b/c at 330 that afternoon i was able to score it. The place filled up within 15 minutes, and only the 8 counter seats were left by 545. And yeah, it was sort of loud, but i attributed that to the high ceilings and the smashed couple sitting next to us who had two bottles of wine mostly before dinner arrived. And the food... while not hugely portioned, was delicious! They change menu often (daily?)We had:

Salt Cod croquettes: delicious! with pickled veggies
Hanger steak and fries: great stuff, good sauce, fries were good
Roast Chicken and Olive Oil Mashed Potatoes: GREAT potatoes, smooth and drizzled with olive oil, and nice chicken jus to mix it with. YUM
Coffee: very strong pressed coffee, great finisher.

Most definitely a big fan of this place. Next time i'll take BART and walk the 4 blocks instead of worrying about the parking. Now, when can I go again...?
author: Vittorio L.

description:
So much potential.  And popularity.  But our experience was much better at the pizzeria, than the restaurant.  The service was uneven - water, wine and bread arrived too slowly.  The starters were excellent.  Entrees less special.

Overall, both pizzerias are how best to experience Delfina.
author: Pierre W.

description: Best brussel sprouts ever! I licked the bowl. (Plus the staff was one of the best I have experienced to date!)
author: Preksha M.

description: This is a great place to go to if you would like to treat yourself to a nice night out.  The food is delicous.  We shared some starters and then got a plate of pasta each and everything was top drawer.  Would definitely go back.
author: Emma H.

description: great ambiance for casual dinner/ catching up with people; a little bit tight on the seating, but overall liked the ambiance. the spaghetti and their pasta were great! loved the perfect al dente. we also got the calamari salad which was great. chicken was also very tender and juicy. we also got the duck dish, which was good (but not crazy outstanding). overall, a very good experience with excellent pasta/spaghetti dishes.
author: Jenn S.

description:
I crazy love this place.  I'd give it a higher rating if it wasn't for the crowded, elbow rubbing, and the excuse-me-while-and-my-big-booty-squeeze-between-the-tables issue.  Oh, and I wish I had a translator for the menu since I don't speak Italian.  But I do think that all cuisines should have an English descriptor beneath the sexy foreign language for us foreign language deficient people. 

My favorite:  Spaghetti.  Hands and forks down the best I've ever had.  Al dente, freshly made pasta.  The sauce is tangy, fresh, with a little heat.  Awesome.

Just had the Warm Chickoree salad with egg.  Warm, amazing anchovy dressing, velvety egg brings it all together.  Yum.

Fries:  I think they are fried in rosemary infused oil with fried rosemary and sage thrown in.  Skinny, crispy, delectable fries.  A PMSers dream!  Lol.

Swordfish:  Succulent, tender, perfectly seasoned and cooked.

Desserts:  Super duper rich & velvety.  My only gripe is I wish there were more warm desserts.  San Francisco is a cold city (usually).  Warm is always good.
author: kim f.

description: I ate there last last night for the first time with a party of 5. The service was great the wines were good. The food was hit and miss. The warm olives where excellent as was the fresh tomato salad. The concept of grilled Calamari with white beans and salad was good but the beans were flavorless and mushy and I've had better calamari almost everywhere. The guinea hen ragu pasta was too salty and overpowered with rosemary. We couldn't taste the meat. All in all it was a decent dining experience I'd like to return and try the renowned spaghetti. I expected a more authentic Italian taste in the pastas.
author: Ramon C.

description:
Delfina is always a must-stop when I'm in San Francisco, and any other visit would have easily merited five stars. Unfortunately, the last time I was there something seemed off in the kitchen and front of house. 

I was worried when the table next to us ordered fresh-stretched mozzarella with tomatoes and had to send it back because there was no mozzarella on the plate! Our table had similar issues. Slow, inattentive service, bread arriving with the primi (very good spaghetti with mint) and not the antipasti (a tasty but small portion of chicken livers with arugula), underseasoned pork saltimbocca and a very dry, well-done duck. 

But to the staff's credit, they addressed all of our complaints quickly and professionally. And our wine was fantastic, which certainly helped out the evening overall!
author: Kevin D.

description: After eating here in 2007, I chose never to return. Food was good but nothing special, inventive, or vivid. I decided to try it again tonight. Nothing has changed. Food is still solidly good and high quality but not inspiring or even crave-worthy.There are so many San Francisco restaurants that make this food look bland. Plus, you can buy most of this food at a gourmet market and cook it yourself at home with no hassle. Pork from Fatted Calf popped in the oven, white anchovies by Dinon from Whole Foods popped out of the package on top of some arugula, fresh pasta from any gourmet San Francisco market popped in a pot to boil-voila you can make nearly the same meal. I prefer to be surprised.
author: Marina N.

description:
First time here. Nice servers
Long wait 1.5 hr min.
food and wine are decent, dry thin Pizza crust, with tasty American toppings. Nothing traditional.
If you can hang out and watch the crowd and stand the noise, this is the place.
BTW, electric oven here is OK for take out....no wood burning here
Ciao a tutti.
author: Bob W.

description:
My mouth waters every time we go here.

Amazing food. The spaghetti is my girlfriends favorite and we always order it! It's a must. 

The past few times we've been lucky enough to have the same great server. I can't remember his name but next time I go in I'll make a point of getting it. He is incredible! So knowledgeable and makes great recommendations.  

Last time we sat up at the bar and enjoyed a great conversation with the bartender over our amazing meal. 

We love it!
author: Harris G.

description: Excellent first visit. Our table shared the asparagus, calamari, and lamb sausage appetizers - all of which we're fantastic - especially the sausage, which my younger son said was so good, he would order it for dessert, too. Entrees ordered included the rabbit roll bathed in rabbit butter (fantastic), the quail (which was a chef's choice offering), spaghetti (with a magical basil tomato sauce), and the Berkshire pork (my dish, which was so, so, so very wonderful). EVERYTHING was extremely flavorful, and the service provided by Max was superb.
author: John T.

description:
spaghetti is really good. so fresh. 

mashed potato was a bit too salty
author: Miri Kwon R.

description:
The food was good, but I will probably not come here again. Nothing orgasmic. But I do recommend trying it once. 

Warm olive crostini with mozzarella curds - ehh it was okay. I expected the curds to be warm too.
La Quercia Acorn Edition Lonza - basically a version of acorn-fed Iberico from Iowa. 10-12 paper thin slices with some pickled capers. It was decent, but not worth $9.00.
Slow cooked Ribs - damn good. and the drippings were caught by the salad and crispy croutons beneath. Friggin' yum.
Rabbit  with pine nuts and polenta - I used to have pet rabbits, and I was not guilty eating this succulent dish. Highlight of the night.
My friend we had the Tokyo turnips, but i don't remember them at all. Strange, yet forgettable.

Servers were polite and always smiling. Smart that they put a bottle of water on the table--I drink like a fish. Also, they offered to give us more bread. Double like.
author: William H.

description: Parking is not easy around this area but we managed to find a spot on Dolores.  I had a delicious virgin Bellini with our appetizers which were prosciutto, calamari and lamb sausage. They were satisfying. I had the pork entree which was good. The chicken is soft and juicy. The pasta and ravioli was a bit overwhelming. Desserts were the highlights. The profiteroles was yummy with strawberry gelato inside n drizzled with chocolate sauce and pistachios. Our other dessert was the expresso gelato. They are kid friendly which is great but the space is not too big.
author: Jennie W.

description:
The plum tomato spaghetti at Delfina is my favorite spaghetti dish in SF! You can make a similar version at home. 

Get a flat big pan and put enough olive oil on bottom to coat.  Be liberal with olive oil.   Heat on low heat. Peel about 5 garlic cloves and put in pan.
