(You can adjust amount of garlic to taste.)  Add red chili pepper pods to pan too.  Heat the garlic and red chili pepper pods over low heat for 20 min. to 30 min to infuse oil.  Remove the garlic and chili pepper pods.
Add 2 big cans of San Marzano tomatoes.  You now simmer for at least 30 minutes but as much as 2 hours.  Mash up the tomatoes with a potato masher or fork while it stews.  You want the oil to blend with the tomatoes so that its totally combined.  The tomato sauce thickens once the tomato juice evaporates.

Boil good spaghetti in a separate pot with water salted well.  (At least one pound of pasta for 2 big cans of San Marzano tomatoes.)  When the pasta is half done (still hard and has crunch if you bite), move the pasta into the tomato sauce and finish cooking pasta in the tomato sauce.  You need to add some pasta water into the tomato sauce too because pasta sauce is too thick.  Probably 2/3 sauce to 1/3 pasta water.   You can adjust as you go.  You'll see that cooking pasta in the tomato sauce results in pasta coated with sauce.

Shave parmigiano on top.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Perhaps it was the hype or the James Beard award, or the misfortune of having called 20 minutes prior to arriving with information that there was no wait at the bar, but having to wait about 40 minutes once arrived, but I wasn't blown away as much as I wanted to.  Had I not come in with any expectations, I'd probably have rated this a wavering 4 star, but at best, it's coming in a 3.5 stars for me.

We sat down to an excitable waiter who was helpful and honest throughout the meal.  After being informed that it's best to order sides/appetizers if we're going for the pasta because "it takes a while," we went with the honey glazed brussel sprouts and olive oil mashed potatoes.  If the meal stopped right then and there, I would have loved it.  However, we waited a good 40ish minutes for our pastas to come out after destroying the amazing sides.  Note to self: try to cook these 2 dishes.

Once the pasta finally came out, with our server confessing that he was prodding the kitchen staff, it was a small, yet, delicious portion of food.  I guess my gripe was that it took so long to cook an unimpressive amount of pasta, where the taste was good, but the price point was not.  The closest thing I can compare Delfina's pasta to is Seven Hills or Barbacco, both of which impressed me more.

My girlfriend went with the Rigatoncini with wild boar ragu and I went with the Black Truffle-Squab Agnolotti in Brodo.  The rigatoncini was perfectly cooked and the wild boar ragu definitely met my high expectations.  This is savory pasta at its best in my opinion.

My agnolotti was pretty much similar to mini ravioli floating in a broth that I liken to beef consomme.  It had a watery, yet rich flavor where the broth could have been served as a delicious soup.  The pasta, unfortunately, was a tiny bit lacking, where some came out a little soggy and I didn't taste and truffle at all.  On top of that, I kind of expected a little bit more to the dish than pasta floating in soup, no matter how unique it was.  

All in all, perhaps Delfina is a place to go more for the main dishes rather than the pasta, which is possibly the point of Pizzeria Delfina and Locanda.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I've walked passed this place at least 3 dozen times in the past 5 years while scurrying to get to Dolores Park and have drinks with friends while we bask in the sun. You know, like those other hordes of hipsters. And it's hard to differentiate whether the large amount of people that seem to always be outside the door of Delfina are customers from the restaurant, their pizzeria that is directly next door or people just hanging out. But, in the last 5 years the large crowds never seem to diminish. 

Never.

I had made plans to go to A16, but when I couldn't get a reservation that worked about my school schedule, we made a joyous second plan to go to Delfina. And Urbino isn't open yet, so that wasn't even an option. Son of a bitch. Delfina and Delfina Pizzeria are the creations of maniac, 2008 James Beard Award winner Craig Stoll, who was also voted one of the best chefs of 2001 by Food & Wine. And as their menu changes frequently, perhaps everyday, and the foods are seasonal and some sustainable...I can see what the hype is all about. 

The first thing I noticed as we walked in was the entire female FOH staff. Also, most of the BOH cooks/chefs in the kitchen were women. Delicious.  The restaurant is, what the real estate market has coined the phrase, "cozy." Well, it's neither small nor large, and the tables are pretty close together. And as there is a large wooden bench that spans the entire back wall, that doubles as a seat for the tables, you're more than likely going to eventually touch the hand of the person who's sitting next to you. Not necessarily sitting with you. As I was sitting next in between an emaciated young woman and a stylish boi, I was pretty happy if either were to touch me. It's intimate, romantic, modern and every bit of what you think when you hear the term, "San Francisco fine dining." The wine list was extensive and I know nothing about wine, however, my dining partner does and I let him take the wheel. 

Oh, and the wait staff is really friendly, helpful and quite charming.

On to the damn food.

Wine - - Tiefenbrunner, LaGrien - - This is the first time I have known what a good wine tastes like. Reasonable price, a beautiful, deep garnet colour. You could smell the fruit and the wood tones, rather than just alcohol. Damn you $10 bargain wines of Food Outlets!

Antipasti - - Salt Cod Mantecato w/ walnut oil and toasted fennel seed flatbread - - This was basically nothing more than a bacalao paste in a ramekin that came with lots of crispy pieces of flatbread. Those were good.

Insalata di Campo - Bitter Greens with Pancetta, Walnuts, Parmigiano and Balsamic Vinaigrette - - The cheese was addicting.

Entrée - - Wolfe Ranch Quail w/ Anson Mills polenta, house-made fennel sausage and a Vin Santo sauce. Jesus (the Hey-sus version) almighty, I tell you...this was amazing. I now know what my instructor, Chef Brian, is talking about when he says we under season our food in class. At first, this dish was kind of a salt shock to my system. But, it made the food taste better. I really got the flavors. Tender pieces of Quail quarters on a bed of creamy polenta...ahhh. And that killer sausage, bits of it all throughout my dish. 

Mint Tagliatelle w/ Chanterelles - The mint was kneaded directly into the dough. However, my dining partner is a vegetarian, so they didn't cook this dish with their normal chicken stock which made the dish very bland. Not their fault, it's his fault for being a lame anemic non-carnivore. No wonder he's so sensitive and laid-back. EAT SOME MEAT!

Dessert - - That's right...I said. My major is Baking and any self-respecting baker is going to try out the damn desserts, right? I'm probably just making excuses for being 
fat.

Profiteroles  w/ espresso gelato, warm chocolate sauce and candied almonds.

Red Cow Parmigiano Regigiano (Emilia-Romagna cow's milk) with saba. Saba is like a grape syrup (from Trebbiano grapes) added to a high-quality balsamic vinegar. It was delicious! 

Ugh, the bill was more than I have ever spent on myself, but I didn't feel guilty during our hurtful times in the recession. We left the waitress a tip so grand that she came after us outside and thanked us, happy she didn't have to claim this tip on her taxes, I'm sure. Now, I know why the wait staff is so damn great...tippers like us. We finished our meal with a walk in the rare warm February night down Valencia, but no hand holding was involved in this cliché night out.

However, after this meal, I now understand why people like to finish it up with a cigarette, or if you're not a smoker...a night of down and dirty romping in the sack. And if you're celibate, why you settle down for a long winter's nap.
author: Illyanna M.

description: It had been quite a few years since I last ate here but as before delicious ! We were a party of 4 we started with peach bellinis , spiced almonds , heavenly tartine bread and these divine little puffy pillow things with prosciutto on top . We decided to get a bunch of things to try so we got two fava bean soups , mussels ( just 2 of them ) with a fennel mousse type thing , tripe ( didn't care for it but my fellow diners really liked it )we then had two pasta plates both tasty and some pork ribs -so tender and tasty ! For dessert we had the rice pudding that had little crunchy quinoa bits on also a chocolately square thing that was good but the panna cotta was divine ! Our waiter was great not too noisy and overall a great dining experience we were able to get a reservation within a few days so they was great also we let them know one of our party was having a birthday and they were sweet enough to bring his dessert with a candle on it ! Probably will come here again
author: lyn m.

description: Ate here last night with the family.  Everything was excellent!  We arrived without reservations, sat at the bar overlooking the restaurant, and enjoyed the view.  The servers, food, & wine were all great.  Had the calamari, ravioli, gnocchi, spaghetti, & bigoli. My only problem with this place is the wine list. They need a couple of wines by the glass UNDER $10, which also means they don't carry bottles under $40.  I can live with the food prices, but the wine is too expensive here.
author: Bob L.

description: Wonderful!  Pastas are outstanding. Appetizers fantastic, one of the best wine selections in the city.  The deserts  are to die for.  Truly one of the best restaurants in the City.
author: Dr. Octagon O.

description: I think our (lovely) server lied. I went to Delfina for the first time yesterday (although I lived on Guerrero and 18th Street 20 years ago when they opened). It did not live up to the hype that actually began back then when people from Marin were making trip to SF for this place.  It was nice ( a bit loud)  everything tasted pretty good not great. Anyway, when I asked about the pasta and the bread, our server said, "We make everything," including the bread. I knew the bread looked and tasted like Tartine. Why the lie? ALSO, I've eaten and made fresh pasta and that pasta did not taste fresh. Fresh pasta is usually delicate and melty and this was not at all. In fact it was quite al dente. How is this possible? Fresh pasta takes about 3-4 minutes at the most to cook. The duck ragout or sugo as they call it did taste good, the salad was good and the olive oil mashed potatoes good. I probably won't return to spend over $100 for this when I'm sure I can find more tasty food elsewhere in SF.
author: a. r.

description: AMAZING service and great food. seriously - there are few other places I would rather go to in the city. There is a reason it's ridiculously hard to get reservations, but when you do (or are able to snag a last minute walk in) it's worth every penny! My mouth is watering as I write this. go here...NOW.
author: Megha A.

description:
Consistently delicious.  Each time I've gone, I've had incredibly wonderful service and even more amazing food.  I love the changing menu!  And with Bi-Rite across the street (no one ever says no to two desserts in a meal), what better way to end your night?

Delfina, Bi-Rite, then a walk in Dolores Park?  *SWOON*
author: Carolyn L.

description:
Everything about Delfina is AMAZING! PERFECTION!  

There really isn't a point for me to write another review, but I wanted to share a tip.  Walking in and waiting for a table isn't bad if there are just two of you.  The right side of the restaurant has about four tables and bar seating reserved for walk ins. I've been twice, and got lucky twice-- minimal wait time.  Call ahead and see how busy it is.  However, even if you have to wait, it's well worth it.  Good luck!
author: K V.

description:
There is always a wait here, now it's my turn.

The stars were aligned with a wait of only 5 minutes.
Delicious crust, sauce, and toppings makes for a tasty pie.
Fennel sausage and peppers and another pie with pepperoni hit the spot.

Service was a tad off as I didn't get my bread sticks or my garnish to spice up my slices, but the taste compensated for this oversight.

I will be coming back here.
author: Po L.

description:
Delfina has high pedigree, but it was a so-so experience for me. The small portions left more to be desired. I'd rather stay on the Pizzeria side. 

TAKE AWAYS:
- Pork sugo here is overrated. I hate labeling anything as such, but this was probably one of the first times going to a 7x7 inspired place that I went, "aw...ok.." You know that face meme. Yeah, that was me. 
- Staff was strangely hot and cold. I got an awesome maitre'd, had a cool waitress, then was switched to ANOTHER one...the experience was odd. 
- Parking is terri-bad here. Ugh. 

Pizzeria is the better side without the slight stuffiness. Looking for pasta? Yeah, you might've heard of this place called flour+water...
author: Abel L.

description:
I started a new job so celebration was in order and Delfina provided just that.

AMBIANCE: Dim lighting and tables packed tightly together. While crowded, it wasn't overly loud so we were able to enjoy one another's company. There is definitely a fine-dining atmosphere, but that didn't deter me from feeling comfortable in my t-shirt and jeans. 

FOOD: ZOMG. Freakin' awesomeness. We shared an appetizer plate of the fried calamari. We were expected deep-fried calamari with some dip. Instead, we got an elegant dish of grilled calamari over beans (I think) and olives. The two balanced items balanced well together. I even would use the beans as a spread for my bread. You can't waste such excellent deliciousness. 

My friend had the oxtail risotto with some Parmesan cheese on top. The risotto reminded me of mac and cheese. The oxtail was soooo tender. My only gripe was that it was a bit too salty.

I had a pork dish, but my brain is fuzzy and I can't remember the name. Unfortunately, it's not on their online menu, since their daily dishes are constantly changing. The pork was thinly sliced and was pretty salty. The sauce was also very strong and sweet. However, while each item was strong on its own, there was a good balance when you had them together. 

PRICE: Expect to pay about $15-20 a dish for dinner. About the right price for this venue and its location. Portion sizes are not terrible for a fine dining restaurant.

SERVICE: Great service. Waiters would check in and make sure everything was going smoothly.

THE BOTTOM LINE: WIN. This place is fantastic. Great place for any party size. Food is wonderful and the service is great. What more could you ask for?
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Ahh yes.  The coveted 5 star review.  1st time here.  Been eatin at lots o places and this sf favorite nailed it and then some.  Casual feel, and service yet really good service. Right amount of buzz and noise.  Still talkable.

Here goes...

Apps.  Everyone a winner.  Super thin awesome Speck and fresh sliced artichokes perfectly dressed.  Mmmm. Borletta - bread soaked in a minestrone type soup.  Kind of like moist italian suffing.  Ohh baby!... Ahhhhh .  Ohhhh myyyy!  Calm down. OK.  How about some perfectly fresh lightly marinated green olives.  Yes, served warm.  Fuckin a.  Plump and so tasty.

Pastas all perfect. Had 4 of them. And the simple tomato one shows you the essence of perfect perfectness in italian pasta lore.  Made in house these noodles are. Cooked perfect they be.  Sauces to lick for I say. Little ravioli things...  Light as pillows filled with god knows what. 
( If god knew he would keep them for herself).  The god of pasta that is...

How about the duck.  Wowser.  How about the pork belly.  Melting away the taste buds did.  Yes they did.  Sauces on both of these.  
Lickin it up. Even the chicken.  Perfect all the way with a sauce worth bottling. 

Even the side dish of carrots and little umpa lumpa sized mushrooms was a unique flavor twist I have yet to encounter.  Nice.

But what is an almost perfect meal without two complaints!  Makes you slap yourself to say no ones perfect.  So even with that they still get the big "5".  And why the "f" not !  There is no such thing as perfection...but I will rag on two things.

Got a half order of little pasta sheets with shrimp.  Small portion not a problem but wheres the shrimp??  Literally 1/4 of ONE piece of shrimp. Yahoo serious!  Not cool.  Bubba gump is coming to kick your ass over this one.  Cmon cheffy, does a full order only have two morsels of shrimp.  I mean the dish still rocked because the sauce was great, but if it had say 6 small morsels of shrimp I would have been over the moon.

And now for the finest, pettiest complaint.  Bread service.  You need to ask for it and it is awesome bread.  BUT... BUT!!  ... they only slice it 80% through. It has a wonderful thick crust but this means we are talking two handed bread pull to get a piece.  Now ladies, here is the truth about guys.  At least half of em dont wash their hands after using the toilet.  So if mr. man goes first, he is grabbing and tearing "his" bread AND "your" slice.  Mmmm.   Stank from the hang low for everyone at the table.  OK, sorry about the grossout, but really, why fight with bread at the table.  Cut this stuff ALL THE WAY THROUGH!.   Does someone think this is "cute" , "rustic" , "country" style service?  It's not, Its downright fucking stupid on every level.

So there you have it.  Still 5 stars for all that they do right and from one meal with 6 folks and lots of different dishes all sampled, they do it practically all right all night!   

Hmmm... Maybe they will put a shrimp po boy on the menu with one half a shrimp on a "slit" piece of bread.  Shove the whole thing in your mouth since you cant bite it,  to capture the essence of oneness... and then curse the shrimp boaters and bread bakers who want justice. 

OK, never mind all that.  Just make this a place you go no matter if you be local or tourist.  You wont regret the lack of shrimp.

Bubba Gump the Baker- out...
author: Bruce M.

description: Our favorite restaurant in San Francisco and go to spot for special occasions.  We always order dishes that are hard to make at home and they do not disappoint.  In addition to the excellent food, the wait staff is highly professional and will listen and deliver on special requests.
author: David H.

description:
Delfina has turned into my favorite Italian (OK, Cal-Italian) restaurant to hit when visiting San Francisco. Having grown more open minded and liberal as I age (most people are the opposite), I have ventured into the Mission District, an area I describe as a transitional neighborhood and one I probably would have not visited 20 years ago when I was a good yuppie white boy living in Marin....

anyhoo, Delfina is far from pretentious and serves excellent basic Italian food. 2 things you get in SF that you do not in San Diego--good bread and good wine by the glass. You will certainly find that here at Delfina. They get some of their bread from next door at Tartine--another institution all to itself. Their salads are the BEST I have had anywhere--especially the Insalata di Campo. I love their basic spaghetti with plum tomatoes (note  the correct spelling, Quaylees) and always save room for some Scharfenberger chocolate dessert....best of all, service is always good and food is very reasonably priced....a MUST visit to the Bay Area.
author: Roy S.

description:
This certainly is a delicious place with a nice selection of wine (Italian varietals)  I had the Saltimbocca, tagliatelle with duck sugo, asparagus and the calamari. Calamari was the champion - fresh and delicious. The duck sugo did bring a tear to my eye. So tender and tasty and perfectly proportioned duck to pasta. The saltimbocca was also a tasty treat, but AlDiLa holds the reins for best Saltimbocca. If that makes any sense to you then my comparison will be clear. If that doesn't resonate with your taste memory, simply put, the pork at Delfina wasn't as tender and the batter not as tasty. 
P.S. I'm super picky about Saltimbocca. Try them both and please write to me.
author: Unkl- T.

description:
Originally our group of 4 was waiting for a table for the Pizzeria side but since we'd never had the restaurant version we asked if they had an open table and when they were able to accomodate us we decided it'd be nice to finally try it.

It's very modern and classy inside with a crazy busy kitchen that seems to move like clockwork, it's great fun to watch. The prices are definitely high and it seems like the kind of place to come for some great wine with food we were looking for great food and not necessarily wine. I think three of us went with pasta and one of us got the meat dish. Since I wasn't too hungry I decided to go basic and try the spaghetti, a great way to taste their base sauce. 

In a town where fresh pasta is not the norm, this place would be a breathe of fresh air - but it's not. I can get fresh made pasta at many places and it's not enough to just do that. The meat dish was good but I can't even remember what it was and the pastas were fresh tasting but the sauces were average, just tasted either creamy or tomato like. The pasta was good but nothing was flavorful, it was all very mellow. For these prices I expect a fresh twist on basics and I didn't find it. 

Probably won't be back as I wasn't impressed. Not bad, but not great.
author: Sam H.

description: Amazing Gnocco Fritto appetizer!! Wow like the best thing I've ever out in my mouth! So light and airy with the perfect amount of salty flavor from the prosciutto. Highly recommended!!
author: Nina H.

description:
Oh Delfina, how I love thee. If I had more time (and maybe a monetary incentive?) I would write an ode. But well, I guess you have to settle for a Yelp review.

There is just no beating a well-cooked, well-presented, local, seasonal, delicious dish - that isn't the price of a car. The fact that the restaurant boasts no real decor aside from good lighting, comfy seats and great energy from the wait staff should already be a clue as to how seriously they take their food. Also, the fact that the menu is written in English and not fancy-pants "restaurantees"  really warms the cockles. 

I actually sent one item back (the duck) because I thought it a tad underdone. Situation was handled perfectly, the duck re-fired and back on my table before we were done with the other entrees, and the waiter was apologetic but not groveling.

The servers a) know their shit and b) really seem to care about giving you a great experience. I love that they gave us a lovely extra panna cotta because I mentioned in passing that it was our anniversary. I love that the wine selection is diverse and delicious. I love that they have a pizzeria next door that is equally amazing and deserving of its own 5-star yelp review. And I love that it is across the street from Bi Rite Creamery, making that side of 18th St. a veritable vortex of unavoidable deliciousness.
author: Michi V.

description:
generally not a fan of big name places like deflina but it definitely lived up to the name

of course since they change the menu everyday, i now can't find the exact items that we had. 

what they don't advertise is that they do half and half for some of the pastas on the menu! it was a girlfriend and I and we were torn between 3 pastas and they were able to make 2 of them half and half. it was great!

and of course, the much raved about panna cotta was delicious.
author: Janet Y.

description:
I've had dinner here a couple of times, and I can honestly say I've rarely had better food. This is well overdue... and I'm sad that I can't remember what I had to eat that night -- so I'll do my best to describe what else makes the place amazing.

First off, the staff. They go about their job with a contagious sense of ease. The hosts and the servers are friendly, well-groomed, and accommodating. The noise level is probably a little high for some people, but it didn't bother me.

The next time I go, I'll update my review in detail.
author: Taylor S.

description:
My favorite part was the tartine sourdough bread. We asked for seconds. 

Everything else was just okay. I had the "amazing" chicken. Don't get me wrong. It was good chicken, but chicken is chicken. Costco chicken is pretty good as well. 

Everything was good, but I guess I was expecting heaven in my mouth given how much hype this restaurant gets. Still, I give it 3.5-4 stars because it's a solid meal, but definitely not mind blowing. I rounded up because the bread is delicious and the service is pretty good.

Other dishes:

spaghetti: pretty good but simple
lamb: tender, flavorful
calamari: unique taste with the beans
author: Lisa H.

description: my friends and i did a pizza night where several of us NY natives tried about 5 places and this def came in #1 or #2. Farina was terrible and soggy. THough I wouldn't say it's NY-style crust, it's still crispy and really good! They serve alcohol there and we were seated outside, a plus that I couldn't enjoy in NYC! only complaint is the wait is long and everyone must be there when name is called or they are kinda mean about it.
author: Emm C.

description:
My rating is based on an average of my rating of a 4 and my parents rating of 2. My dad wanted to try this place because of the reviews on yelp and from word of mouth. So we took him there to celebrate Father's Day on a Monday night. 

We started with the sardine, which was really tasty. I would definitely go back for that. My dad ordered the chicken with the mashed potatoes. He said it was pretty good. I thought the mashed potatoes were amazing. So good. My mom and sister shared the bistecca which was meh. I shall elaborate later on this... as for me, I had the salmon with the lemon caper sauce, which was absolutely yummy. 

So for my parent's review- it took too long for our food to come out. The manager (i think) came over and said that my friend who works in the kitchen said "hello" and that our steak would be a little bit; my friend was super sweet and made us a little rabe sautee. So that's when we found out that the steak takes around 40 mins. Around 45 minutes after ordering, we told our waitress that we were waiting for our food, and that she should've told us how long it would take since it wasn't stated on the menu. My parents seriously wanted to walk out. Finally, the steak came out, but it was medium rare, which was too rare for my family. Again, the waitress failed to ask how we wanted it cooked when we first ordered. So that's where my parents give the low rating.

The manager however remedied the situation, and brought the steak back to be cooked a but more. In the meantime, she gave us a free plate of the chilled asparagus, which was so great. I highly recommend it. It seemed like it was soaked in vinegar or marinated in something, which gave it a nice touch. In addition to that, the manager took of the bistecca from our bill, which was a nice gesture. 

I didn't like the steak much, but I loved the salmon, sardine, asparagus, and the potatoes. I also think the manager was very nice and took care of the situation. So 4 stars for that on my end.
author: Katrina L.

description:
One of my SF faves since 2001 because they make the best grilled calamari white bean salad and spaghetti.  When in SF, i will get take-out here typically once a week.  Bi-Rite market is 1/2 block away so it's easy to stock up on groceries too.

It's a casual dining restaurant with solid food using fresh ingredients.  The menu changes daily, except for a handful of classics that are always available (including the aforementioned grilled calamari white bean salad and spaghetti).

Note: The restaurant does not serve pizza but there is a Pizzeria Delfina next door, which people are incorrectly reviewing here.
author: B T.

description:
Visited on 3/9 and tried polenta, carrots and peas for first course, spaghetti and English pea tortelli for main course and profiteroles for dessert.

The polenta was too rich with butter and when the waiter saw that we didn't eat too much of it, he asked what was wrong and when we told him, he later took that off the bill (all we had said was it was too rich for our taste). 

The carrots and peas were fantastic - very nicely seasoned and prepared. There seemed to be a healthy serving of butter in this too, but it was very well balanced with the other ingredients.

The spaghetti was very good, though not amazing has the other reviews led us to expect. The sauce is very simple and the pasta is cooked to al dente perfection.

The tortelli was amazing though. The filling was a pea-puree blended with ricotta cheese, though flavor-wise the peas were dominant. The filling was generous and very tasty.

The profiteroles had coconut gelato filling and were topped with candied almonds and coconut strips. The gelato didn't have a strong coconut flavor and the candied almonds didn't make their presence felt. It was ok, nothing bad, nothing great. 

We were able to make reservations, got our table right away and the service was excellent.
author: Manjesh N.

description: This place is still holding it down after all these years!! Always, always good over here.  You wanna try new places but Delfina never disappoints. It seems like I do the same thing every time...get that juicy, perfectly cooked hanger steak!  And mooch pasta off my wife.  Was really loving their ribbolita too!
author: Ramon L.

description:
Yummy!  

Clam appetizer- nothing unique.  tomato broth, one piece of garlic crostini.  they gave us another one because we looked like we needed it.

Swordfish pasta- minimal small chunks of swordfish in a nicely pungent caper sauce.  Pasta had a nice bite

Mint pasta- i forget- this had some kind of creamy cheese (mascarpone) that was a little too much for me but my friend liked it! 

Yogurt pana cotta with yuzu sauce- SOOOOO good.  perfect dessert! 

blood orange bellini- light and refreshing 

(The above was enough food for 2.  we chose not to get an entree)
author: T Y.

description:
This was my third time dinning at Delfina without knowing both the quality and service have become that terrible.  It was so disappointing as my friends and I really expected better from this restaurant.  The timing between appetizer and entree was at least 30 minutes.  The server did not even bother to offer us the bread during the wait until i asked.  She should have brought us the bread from the very beginning.    Not only that, when the entrees were brought to the table, the serve did not even ask us if we needed pepper or cheese.  

These were what we ordered:
1.  Prosciutto/fava beans -- not outstanding.  (2 stars)
2.  Crostini sampler -- average (3 stars)
3.  Squid/bean salad -- average (3 stars)
4.  Pork Belly/clam -- good (3.5 stars)
5,  Risotto -- good (3.5 stars)
 
My friends and I will not go back to Delfina.
author: Preston D.

description:
Vegetarians beware!  Delfina don't a like-a you!

My boyfriend and I made reservations for our anniversary, but didn't bother to check in about vegetarian food, assuming there would be something on the menu considering that this restaurant has been touted as "SF's best".  I was appalled by what I found once we got there: there was no vegetarian entree at all.  

Much to my chagrin, the only thing they offer vegetarians is spaghetti (like  Emmy's Spaghetti Shack, only more expensive).  And they don't even offer a full plate of pasta--the waitress described it as a "smaller second plate".  I'm sorry, but if I want to eat a small plate of spaghetti I can make it at home, thanks.  Delfina, you know you can do better.  Get a specialized vegetarian chef, for crying out loud--you can afford it since you're charging everyone an arm and a leg for their tiny little meals! 

I think it was the absolute worst anniversary we've ever had.  It was so noisy and we were so packed in that we could barely hear one another above the guy at the next table who was rattling on about "Survivor".  To their credit, the waitstaff did accomodate us by moving us to a table away from the others (although it was smushed up against a wall and the waitress had to reach over us to adjust the lighting).  I mentioned this experience to a colleague and she said, "I had a bad anniversary dinner there, too!"

My advice: Don't let it happen to you!
author: Cassidy P.

description:
EXCELLENT in every way:

- Top notch service (our order took a little longer than expected so they gave us salad on the house while we were waiting)
- Softest bread (wow...like butter...moist and chewy but nice crust.. don't bother me, I'm eatin..)
- Ox Tail (wow.. melted off the bone and was SUPER juicy/tender/drool .. veggies were just as delicious~)
- Steak was uber tender (sauce was a little too heavy for me but nothing a little pat on the side of my plate couldn't fix.. )
- Lemon buttermilk PANNA COTTA (with blueberries and blueberry sauce) SERIOUSLY?!  Pinch me... texture was creamy and smooth like silk ... and the flavors were HEAVENLY.  Perfection...
- Excellent wine suggestion from our bomb ass waitress.  

The only thing I didn't enjoy really...(didn't finish) were the fries.. (I know, wtf...) .. they were WAY too salty.  I'm sure it's yummy on normal days.. someone must've accidentally knocked the salt over on my plate.  It's also on the expensive side but the quality of the food makes it so worth it.

I love birthday dinner.. Delfina was a real treat.
author: Kat C.

description:
When I need to think of a nice place to eat in San Francisco, a city renowned for its many fine eateries, I have often defaulted to Delfina in the last few years. I remember how impressed I was with the unearthly succulence of the roasted Fulton Valley chicken the first time I was there. I can tell you I just shared it with a friend this evening, and it's still the most perfectly cooked chicken in the city. We also had the equally impressive Niman Ranch steak done to an ideally tender medium rare. Both had perfect accompaniments, creamy mashed potatoes with the chicken (it has to be served on a separate plate since the portions are so large) and the just crisp enough French fries with the steak.

Now those are just two of the mouth-watering entrees. We actually began with a hearty potato and white bean pancake, peasant fare done up gourmet style, and an escarole salad with figs and hazelnuts. Both were superb starters. There was also a nice $32 bottle of a lovely cabernet-merlot wine with a nice vanilla finish..I only wished I wrote down the name of it. Our only disappointment was the somewhat overcooked green beans mixed with bacon and red peppers, which we felt looked like it belonged in one of the old aluminum trays that held Swanson's TV dinners in the sixties. Luckily, dessert got our meal back on track as we shared a lovely panna cotta with raspberries and a crispy tart with a vanilla gelato. We also had small pots of their specialty herbal teas, which made for the ideal finish to the meal. 

Even though they doubled their original space, the place still gets quite packed nightly. You will be sitting almost elbow-to-elbow with the adjacent diners. Just don't get too territorial and you'll be fine. You need to make a reservation at least a few hours in advance to get a table, and while the bar is an option, I have to admit the seats there are not all that comfortable. The wait staff is pleasant and seems knowledgeable enough about both the food and wine menus. Unless you eat early, parking can be a problem. They offer a parking lot about a block and a half away, but it costs $8. Better to monitor the streets for your lucky break. I've had the best luck parking on 18th Street beside the tennis courts in Dolores Park. Regardless of the logistical inconveniences, this is a superb dining experience worth repeating again and again.

FOOD - 4.5 stars
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars 
SERVICE - 4 stars
OVERALL - 4 stars
author: Ed U.

description: Simply the best spaghetti. I swear, you won't regret it.
author: Auburn S.

description: Got three pies and while they are good, I think I was not impressed. Maybe their specialty is their pastas? I don't know. My friend from Naples thought the dough was too hard.
author: Karina H.

description:
Hands down, the best Italian food I've had in CA. We just made the move back to CA after 6 years on the East Coast and worried that we'd miss having a wide variety of excellent Italian options (from Babbo, Bar Pitti, Dell Anima, Celeste, etc. in Manhattan). Tried a few places in the city and was thoroughly disappointed and about to give up. The severe disappointment of Bottega in Rutherford put us to the edge. Shame on me as many folks had recommended Delfina in the past...

Walking in on a Saturday night, our wait  only took 20 minutes. We started off with the gem lettuce salad along with the lardo+breadsticks. Both excellent. Then, we split the famous spaghetti with cherry tomatoes and garlic. WOW! A dish so simple yet so delicious -- that we were comparing it to the phenomenal penne pomodoro that we had in Sienna a few summers ago. Moved on to the secondi, which consisted of tagliatelle w/ wild boar and the braised rabbit. Speechless. Finished off with a marscapone gelato and bing cherry sorbet combo. 

Can not say enough about this place. SF, I stand corrected. There is hope for Italian food in CA. I will be back often!
author: Kenneth K.

description:
I ate at Delfina a few years ago, and had a wonderful time. Knowing that it is usually a scene and hard to get a seat, it was only recently that I returned for dinner with my boyfriend. On this particular occassion, we encountered astronomical hits and some disappointing misses.  

We started with the grilled fresh calamari. The squid were cooked perfectly, but  I was surprised at how small the white beans were (I assumed they were organic).  For dinner, I had the duck with homemade sourkraut.  I can honestly say that the duck was possibly one of the best I ever had- the sauce was dark and savory with pomegranate seeds. Unfortunately, my knife was dull and I had a hard time separating the meat from the bone. I'm not a big fan of kraut, though, so the side didn't do much for me. My boyfriend ordered a pasta dish with bass. He loved the noodles and sauce, but there wasn't much fish.  We weren't expecting a filet, but the fish was flaked and lightly sprinkled on the top, almost like parmesan shavings. A little more fish would have rounded out the dish. 

Dessert proved to be the summary of our dining experience that evening. We ordered two dishes- the olive oil cake and the blood orange panna cotta. The panna cotta curled our toes, and was one of the best desserts we ever tasted. The cake was nothing special.  

While we experienced some disappointing moments, the "homeruns" were a glimpse of Delfina's solid reputation as an award-winning dining establishment. Even the best restaurants have their moments, so I have to rate this night as a solid 3 stars, with the promise to return with an update of the 5 star experience they are known for.
author: Lisa R.

description:
I worked up a huge appetite after shopping on Haight and in Union Square. As a result, I forced my bestie to eat at Delfina, partly because I heard it was good and partly because Bi-Rite is across the street.

When we first got to Defina, we walked into the pizza side. Whoops! We quickly walked out and went into the restaurant side. I ordered the grilled calamari white bean salad , which was to die for. It's probably one of the best things I ate this weekend. The calamari was soft and had a really nice smokey/grilled flavor to it., the arugula gave the dish a nice peppery taste, the white bean was cooked just right, the olives added a salty element to it, and the dressing on the arugula was fab since it had a touch of lemon. YUMMMMMMMMMMMMMS. (Ok so I dissected the dish like a nerd. Whatevs...) Anyways, my bestie didn't really enjoy it since he doesn't like eating a lot of beans. SCORE!! I ordered the funghi risotto as my entree. The dish was creamy and delish but a little on the salty side. If they brought down the salt notch a little, I would have loved it. I tried the spaghetti that my bestie ordered and it was great. The sauce was light, which I like. I hate heavy sauces that drown pasta. I want to go back the next time I fly to the bay (which will probably be in 3 months. HAHAHA. Seriously, I'm obsessed with this freaken city). Their menu changes everyday, which makes going to Delfina exciting. I want to try their pizza too since I heard so many great things about it.

See you next time, Delfina.
author: Anna K.

description:
Great pizza, amazing service, and great ambience. 

Yes every time!
author: F C.

description:
Our server was awesome. She was super patient as she answered all of our little questions about the food and what kind of wine to have with our food selections.  We went with all seafood dishes and I must say everything was good. My favorite thing that we ordered was the calamari and white bean salad.  SO delicious.

Amazing little restaurant.  It has a great atmosphere... perfect place to go on a date.  And if you're seated by the windows it's great for people watching because the Delfina Pizzeria is right next door.
author: Jessica F.

description: Can't for the life of me understand why this restaurant is so highly regarded. Ambience is nil, food offerings are average at best, service is polite but far below what would be considered professional. I think Delfina diners might want to get around a little more.
author: Tom K.

description:
I went looking for an Italian restaurant on Yelp and after several unpromising leads, someone recommended I check out Delfina.  With the positive reviews here plus my friend's response of "that's one of my favourite restaurants!" I was excited to check it out.

For starters, we ordered the Insalata di Campo along with the warm olives.  Both were phenomenal and a good appetizer.  The crusty bread they brought out along with the salted butter was delicious as well.  I was worried it would ruin my appetite for the main course, but everything was very light and not quite filling enough... which made me extremely happy when my dinner came out.  Despite all the tempting options, I kept looking back at the spaghetti: quiet, unassuming, plain spaghetti with tomatoes, garlic, and peperoncini.  You would think something so simple, with so little in it... it would be boring and unappealing.  Somehow though, it wound up being perfect!  The tomatoes were juicy and flavourful, the peperoncini flavour so subtle you could barely tell they were there (oh but they were!) and the best?  I never had al dente spaghetti done just perfect.  

After waxing so poetic over the spaghetti, the rest of our meal deserves some mention: my friend ordered the Rosemary Tagliatelle al Ragu. It looked and smelled amazing, but sadly I couldn't try it (it has some sort of meat mixed in it).  He seemed to enjoy it very much though.  We also shared the Turnips and Rapini greens... why don't we ever grow up on turnips that taste like this instead of the horrible mash our mothers made??  

After so much amazing food, we didn't know if we could manage dessert but my friend was so adamant that we not ever leave Delfina without having at least *one* dessert we finally chose one to share.  We ordered the Lemon-Buttermilk Panna Cotta (with Strawberries and Thyme Caramel) and a glass of Comtess, a dessert wine with the flavour of peach nectar.  If I died right then and there, I would have died happy and in food orgasm heaven.  I have never had a dessert quite like this panna cotta, and the wine was the best I ever had.  Ever.  

Have I sold it yet?  If not, there is no hope for you.  If you love Italian food, good wine, pasta, and desserts to die for, this is the place to go.  What are you waiting for?  GO NOW.  Oh wait... call ahead and make a reservation because everyone else already knows how amazing this place is and it's not easy to get into!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
I don't normally give 5 stars to a restaurant, but Delfina definitely gets 5 stars!

My bf and I got Chicken-Mortadella Agnolotti in Brodo to start, it is very delicate and delicious. Then for the main course, I had Pancetta-Wrapped Devil's Gulch Rabbit Saddle, it is so good! My bf had Wolfe Ranch Quail with fennel sausage, vin santo and polenta Valsugana, so yummy! (sorry for my lacking of words to describe these dishes).

The main reason that Delfina gets 5-star is because of their wine list. They have most unusual wine list even for the wine-savvy city like SF. We had a bottle of 2009 Franco Noussan Torrette Supérieur from Valle d'Aosta DOC of Italy. Man, what a introduction! It was recommended by the waitress,  and it worked perfectly with both our dishes. She even gave me a sip of 10-years old Marsala Superiore Riserva from Marco De Bartoli for free, cause she thought we may like it. Oh, did I love it! I consider myself fairly wine-savvy, but never had a good Marsala before (it's nothing like the Marsala that you normally bug and cook with), all I can say is "wow"! Definitely up there with 10 years Port and Madeira for me. 

If there is one thing that I can complain, it would be the distance between tables. They are so crammed in that you cannot avoid hearing the conversation from the next table.
author: bone-dry-cappuccino L.

description:
Delfina is probably my favorite restaurant on the planet and, as a result, I am happy that it isn't in LA, but rather in SF.  If I lived within driving distance (meaning less than three hours) of Delfina, I would weigh 678 lbs. and bathe in there pasta.  I cannot recommend it enough.

Delfina is a cute little Italian restaurant with a cozy and warm atmosphere of people doing what people do... living La Vita Dolce!  Everyone is having a good time, laughing, joking, and the room is abuzz with positive energy.

If you haven't already picked up on it, the food is AMAZING!  I cannot stress this enough, everything on the menu is awesome and you will not regret trying anything. 

They also have a pizza place next door and, on my most recent visit, in a fit of gluttony, I ordered a pepperoni pizza from there and they brought it to our table--so worth it!

Enjoy and fall in love as I have!
author: Reza B.

description:
After living 4 blocks away for....more than 3 years, I finally ate here.  The place is A LOT bigger than it looks from the street.  Decor is decent.  The one skylight is nice enough to make you wish they had 2 more.  Wifey and I beat our friends by about 15 minutes, and the waitress was patient while we drank and waited for them.  I'll give Delfina props for avoiding my least favorite restaurant habit and telling us they wouldn't seat us until the others showed up.

Our friends and dinner companions were the owner of another Italianesque restaurant in the city, and his girlfriend, an entertainment industry mover and shaker.  Sometimes, I'm intimidated by my own friends.

We shared many dishes, ate, drank, and made merry for hours.  Seriously.  We made merry.  Yeah, people do that.  Just let it go, okay?  And after we paid and left, my primary lingering impression was "Yeah, that was okay.  What's the big deal?"  There was no single standout dish.  In fact now, scarcely a week later, I'm hard-pressed to remember details about ANYTHING we ate.  And I still remember the Maytag blue cheese au grautin potatoes Wifey and I shared at a restaurant in 2004.

It's not that there's anything wrong with Delfina.  They do a decent job, and the service was certainly good.  But at the $75 a head price point, I can easily think of a dozen places in the City I'd prefer.  Some within baseball-throwing distance of Delfina (I have a good arm, admittedly).

Won't rush back, but didn't leave mad.
author: Ben P.

description:
I eat out A LOT and have a pretty low bar (my reviews are pretty much all 4 or 5).  That being said, there are only a few things that really get me and one of them is too much salt.  I think I gained about 5 pounds in the night I ate here because of all the water I was retaining.  Holy moly - too much salt.  I really want to ignore this, but it's such a cardinal sin that I can't.

Warm Castelveltrano Olives - really salty (but expected)

Spiced Almonds - decent, but nothing special

Insalata di Campo - somehow they made a salad salty - and REALLY salty.  Totally burnt the back of my throught because of the saltiness

Spaghetti - the highlight of the meal.  +1 just for this dish.  Home made and al dente - very nice!

Polenta Valsugana - course polenta slathered with cheese.  They really should get some finer ground polenta and add some complexity to the dish.  Again way too much salt.

Even the butter they serve with the bread - coated with a thick layer of salt.
author: Brian K.

description:
Since I'm leaving San Francisco, we're trying to hit a few of the big restaurants our friends have been raving about for years.  Delfina was at the top of the list, so for my husband's birthday, I figured, why not?

The 2-star review isn't because the food was bad.  Everything was certainly edible and the service was great.  But the price plus the reputation made us expect something far, far better than what we got. 

Ambiance is noisy and confusing, but that's just standard for trendy SF spots.  Fine.  The menu of course is entirely in Italian.  I'm a savvy enough girl that usually I'm fine with sussing out what I'm ordering at fine eateries, but Delfina is the kinda place where you have to either know Italian or be comfortable with the waiter explaining nearly every menu item to you, which is a but embarrassing.  It makes you feel like a rube.  

These qualms would not have detracted from a 5-star rating if the food deserved it, though.  But it didn't.  We started with the "spec" which was an appetizer of a cured pork meat with raw artichokes and salad.  It was fine but not amazing.  We also had what was basically a savory flan/custard of stinging nettle and black trumpet mushrooms.  Easily the best dish we had there, just delicious.  But at a restaurant with this kind of rep and these kinds of prices, everything should be this delicious.

I ordered the Spaghettini Nero, which had squid ink and "Mendocino Uni" which was misleading.  The tiny piece of uni was the only thing with any flavor in the dish.  The rest was OK, but bland and disappointing.  My husband ordered the Hawaiian Ahi which managed to be undercooked - even for a lightly "seared" ahi - while still being dry!  And flavorless!  

We also had a side of brussels sprouts, misnamed on the menu as "brussel sprouts".  Whatever, but still kinda funny.  They were delicious, but way salty, which was weird given that everything else was undersalted.

I just don't get the hype, especially when our bill with tax and tip was $165 for two people.  Our server was helpful and recommended a great wine, but without him we would have had no idea what to order as almost all the wines are esoteric Italian wines I haven't heard of - and I'm not super ignorant when it comes to wine, either.

Maybe if I was a big fan of classic Italian food I would have loved this place, but I'm not.  But this was probably the most disappointing fine dining experience I've had in San Francisco and I kinda want to throttle the friends who recommended it to me.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Bolognese = 100 stars
Never has any place gotten this meat sauce better than Delfina each & every time; it melts on my tongue & gets my endorphins going.
I would steal the chef and lock him in my pantry if I could. Or bottle this stuff and take baths in it....

WOW

Been a frequent goer over the years. Love this place. The ambiance feels so urban and sheik.

My last visit the service was pretty lacking, which is weird because the tables are on top of each other so it's pretty obvious we were out of water for half the meal... the check never came... well then it did before the dessert.... which was also forgotten...

Even so, the ambiance & food will never fail you here.
author: AK S.

description:
The din is so loud you won't be able to hear the person sitting across from you but will be unfortunately subjected to the conversations on either side of your cramped table. 

I sampled the grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad, the insalata del campo with bitter greens, pancetta, walnuts, parmigiano and balsamic vinaigrette, the roasted Fulton Valley chicken (they were out of the salmon I had hoped to try) with Yukon gold mashed potatoes and royal trumpet mushrooms, and also had a bite of my dining companion's Niman Ranch flatiron steak and French fries. 

Delfina's been on my list of places to try forever. Countless people have told me they call it their favorite so my expectations were understandably high. While a solid meal, certainly, nothing about the food was particularly impressive or joy-inducing. I've had better roasted chicken. I've had better steak frites. Service was very efficient, no complaints there. But overall, it was a tough dining experience. Sure, I go to dinner for the food, but I also go for the company and the conversation, both of which were all but impossible to enjoy here.
author: Miriam W.

description: Everyone who comes to this restaurant needs to try their grilled Calamari.  I have tried several other dishes and none of them are as good as the Calamari.
author: Mark B.

description:
staff is incredible. Like 5 people were tending to our table, and they all knew everything about everything and were all smiley and happy and classy and sweet. Fuck every other place for being snobby and annoyed and too busy to notice. Seriously, I was b l o w n away by the service. I want to spend every moment of my life with those people. 

Food's good too.
author: Ellen W.

description:
This restaurant has become one of my favorites in SF.  Not only is the ambiance stellar but the food, service staff, and wine list are fab!

We had a great table at the window which is very romantic.  Our waiter was great and had the perfect food and wine receommendations.  The pasta with dugeness crab was so flavorful and light and the Napa Chardonnay was the perfect compliment.

Great place for a date or even just to stop in and have a glass of wine.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Typically when I am traveling for work I will only go to places that take American Express because that is how I pay for all my work expenses.  Delfina does not and I still spent 80 dollars on myself.  To eat.

Calimari. DO IT, this aint your grandma's breaded, boring and deep friend calimari.  This calimari is grilled, perfect and will slap you in the face with flavor.

Oh, how about secondi?  Well my opinion of a lot of other places pasta was wrecked when I tried Delifina's Hay and Straw pasta.  Pork Cheek & Raw Egg, and a tissue.  Yeah, I went there.

To use a simple metaphor to illustrate the awesome contained in my entree, the duck I had was a rifle toting grizzly bear sky surfing on Vin Diesel riding a shark-unicorn.

Vin Diesel has played Triple X and Riddick.  Think about it.

This place is definitely 5 star dining and has a price tag that goes with it and you shouldn't even think twice about going here.  You should have been there yesterday.

FACE!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Solid place in the Mission.  

Ambiance - low key, but packed - that's how you know that this place must be pretty good.  We didn't have reservations on a Wed night around 8, but got seated within a half hour or so.

Service - our waitress was attentive and helpful, but not overbearing

Food - the sardine appetizer was surprisingly really good. wasn't sure what to expect, but it was one medium size fish on a bed of cucumbers.  The asparagus appetizer was good too. A little small though. Just four spears!  The spaghetti was surprisingly really good! I mean, how hard it is to make spaghetti, but for some reason this was one of the best I've had.  Pasta was cooked just right and although there wasn't a ton of sauce, it was very flavorful.  We also had the chicken with mushrooms.  You never know with chicken - a lot of places are dry - but not here.  Good stuff.

Overall, four star place.  Glad I tried, not dying to come back, but would recommend to others.
author: Michelle H.

description: We went for our anniversary last night at 5:30.   Restaurant opened 10 minutes late.  We tried the half portions of all the pasta dishes and were not impressed at all.  Our waitress was truly scatter brained.  I ordered a second cocktail and it never came.  I ordered an americano coffee after dinner, and she brought me an americano cocktail.  Then she charged us full price for a half portion serving on one of the pastas.  She even said she was having a bad night and it just started.  We'll go to Flour + Water next time.  We won't be back as their pasta here doesn't compete at all with Flour + Water.
author: Sal M.

description: Solid Italian fare that overlaps many parts of Italy.  Everything made with the best ingredients and beautifully plated.  Mostly interesting wine list emphasizing all of Italy.  Recommend the calamari white bean salad and the pastas.  Ask for bread....usually from Tartine.  Busy and loud.  Still one of the City's finest.
author: John K.

description:
This review is for a dinner that we had at Delfina on January 28. As such, it's going to be shorter than usual, as the menu has changed since then and my memory stinks. :-\

I was immediately charmed upon entering Delfina; the multitude of small lighting fixtures hanging from the ceiling created an ambiance of intimacy and threw just the right amount of light. We were shown to a corner table near the kitchen, which gave a great view of the space.

Our server was friendly and down-to-earth, which combined with the casual elegance of the place further helped to make us feel instantly welcome. I remember feeling completely at ease and very happy to be there, though it was our first visit.

We each had a glass of Prosecco, which is getting close to de rigueur status as our aperitif of choice. The bread that they served was very good, as you'd expect. I imagine that we had one or two appetizers, but I don't recall what they were. For entrees, my wife had the crab risotto (which was a special that night), and I had the roasted Fulton Valley Chicken, with king trumpet mushrooms and olive oil mashed potatoes. The entire meal was very good, the chicken being wonderfully flavored and succulent.

I remember that a member of the staff (perhaps our server) graciously helped me select a wine to go with my meal. They asked if I preferred Old World or New. I said Old, and that I was leaning towards a Barbaresco. We discussed a few different options, and they brought out three samples, including a Barbaresco and a Barolo. I found the Barbaresco to be very medicinal, but the Barolo was a revelation. It's great to discover a new wine that you just love, and that Barolo fit the bill perfectly.

I believe that we skipped the desert, having had just the right amount of food, feeling sated but not stuffed. The cost that night came to about one bill, plus tip. Fairly average in this town.

We left Delfina that night having had a great experience and agreeing to come back again soon. It's a wonderful spot with great ambiance, very good food and friendly service. Truly marvy.
author: Steve R.

description:
Totally bomb. Totally long waits at both locations. Totally worth it. 

Best pizza in SF and GREAT seasonal apps. The Fillmore location plays some great music and the 18th street location is right near Bi Rite and Dolores Park.... so you can't really go wrong no matter which one you choose.

The bread they bring while you wait for your food is super good (from Tartine next door) and the wine selection is good too (price range is reasonable as well).  The mozzarella/arugala dish (don't remember what it is called) is UNREAL. And you really can't go wrong with the pizza selection... 

Go to Delfina, just do it. And yes people are always going to complain it's overrated, but they might not have tastebuds...
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
The food was creative, fresh,and delicious; the service attentive, prompt and dignified.

The comment at the bottom of the check by the owner complaining about "employer mandates" when presenting the surcharge was offensive.  Please folks, negative political energy does not promote positive digestion.  And your staff deserves more respect.
author: Rumi G.

description: Had dinner with a vendor and my boyfriend last Thursday evening. Everything that we ordered was DELISH!  We tried the grilled calamari, Mozarella with eggplant and Caviar served with Endives and they were awesome. For my entree , I ordered the the lamb with polenta and my bf ordered the hanger steak with Rosemary fries.  They were both very tender and delish!We enjoyed our 2 bottles of wine as well.  Will come back and try their pasta  but definitely will try the Delfina pizzeria next door.
author: Claudine V.

description:
We were in SF for just a few days, and had to make our dining decisions carefully. Delfina easily made all the lists when we asked chef/foodie friends. It did not disappoint.

The place is bustling, and my dining companion were seated in the bar. at first, we asked to be seated elsewhere due to the loud music, but the manager offered to turn down the music and assured us it was the quietest table in the house. 

our server was utterly charming and had vast knowledge of the food and wine offered. we started with the roasted Castelvetrano olives, that were served alongside their crusty, chewy, fabulous bread. (keep in mind, my dining companion is gluten intolerant, but broke a year-and-a-half fast and was on special meds just for this carb-loaded dinner).  we enjoyed that along with cold Prosecco.

we shared two pasta courses -- the mint tagliatelle, a mix of fresh pasta, mint leaves and ricotta; and the proscuitto/ricotta ravioli with meyer lemon sauce. the tagliatelle was delightful (though could use a bit more salt) but the ravioli were scrumptious. perhaps the perfect plate of pasta.  we also enjoyed a bowl of roasted sunchokes. 

instead of dessert, we enjoyed a few cheeses and the accoutrements. a fine ending to a fine meal.
author: Barb H.

description:
I can't believe that I haven't reviewed Delfina yet. Tonite's dinner with fellow yelper Angela W. was fabulous! We started with the salt cod mantecato with walnut oil and fennel seed flatbread. The spread was delicious but I thought the flatbread was on the salty side. We then shared the spaghetti "al dente" style. Magnifico! It was a special touch that our waitress automatically split the pasta for us. For the main entree, we shared the local petrale sole in acqua pazza with oven dried tomatoes, capers and olives. While the fish was fresh and very well prepared, I forgot that I don't really like sole all that much. I have to remind myself that I do like halibut and sea bass but not sole ;)

For dessert, we shared the warm Scharffenberger chocolate cake with creme anglaise. How can you go wrong with anything with the words Scharffenberger and chocolate? Absolutely amazing!

After settling the bill, our waitress asked if we lived in the city. We both responded with an enthusiastic "yes!" and then she told us about her boyfriend's new wine bar called Terroir in SOMA that serves natural organic wine. Thanks for the referral and we will definitely check it out. 

Delfina is fresh friendly fare. Make a reservation now...you'll need it!
author: Helen Y.

description:
I am so glad Yelp has an edit button.  Suffice it to say, I wish life had an edit button.  I am sure that some time I will return to Delfina and love my meal.  Now, however, I wish I could edit my experience, or, gasp, remove it from my past.

Eating out is about FOOD.  Ambiance, company, drinks and service are all ridiculously deprioritized in my world.  

I made late reservations to eat at Delfina on a Saturday.  Got in at 10pm.  All day I waited for the restaurant to post that night's menu on the website.  If nothing excited me, I would have canceled and gone another time.  It came: two secondis jumped off the screen.  Pork scallopini and braised duck breast.  Cannot go wrong.  I love raw meat, and spoon-tender meat comes in at a close second.

Hours later, there we are.  Waitress comes up, and I can read bad news on her face.  

"Unfortunately we are out of the pork and duck."

Double sucker punch right where it hurts.

We did our best to work around it.  Ordered some pastas, some primis, antipasti.  Nothing excited me.  The tripe was trite.  The agnolotti agonizing.

Only thing I thoroughly enjoyed was the cherry crostata.  Cherries are my favorite fruit.  I could eat of bowl of them for dessert and be happy.  So no points for the dessert.   

So if and when I come back, which I am sure I will, three great things will happen.  I will EAT, EDIT and YELP.  That is what life is all about.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Beautiful restaurant, beautiful, delicious food, perfect servers :)

We had the Broccoli Rabe (cooked the bitter down, but kept the vibrant green hue), Grilled Sardine (moist with crispy skin), Trippa alla Fiorentina (succulent, slightly spongy and delicious), Berkshire Pork Arrosto farro-nata and cippoline onions agro dolce (tender meat with melt-in-your-mouth cippolines)

Needless to say, we were more than satisfied :]
author: SF F.

description:
I went here a couple of weeks ago with my friend Butters (of "Loo Loo Loo, I've got some apples" fame). It was the Sunday of Memorial Day weekend, and the place was pretty crowded. 

While the sign for the business itself is readily visible from the street, the "formal" restaurant isn't all that distinguishable from its less-formal pizzeria cousin next door. At least not from the outside. They should put clearer signs up, lest some moron (read: ME) wander into the wrong place by mistake.

But enough about that. Let's bitch about the food.

Butters and I shared an order of the calamari. (Side note: I'm generally averse to calamari, after an incident in Thailand years ago, where my stomach got into a fight with some undercooked calamari. Long story short: the damned squid won).

Where was I? Oh, right: we ordered up a batch of Davy Jones' beard. It was actually really good. It didn't have the annoying rubbery texture that calamari usually does. It went well with the warm bean salad that came with it. And yes: the time after the meal was delightfully agony-free.

Second item: we shared a small order of the spaghetti. When they say "small", they are not kidding. If you choose to order this as your main course, you had better be either under 4 feet tall or planning to visit Burger King on your way home. But since it was just one course, it worked OK for us.

For Secondi, Butters had the Meyer Ranch steak. I had the lamb, rare, with couscous. I'm not normally a big fan of it, but this one worked for me. The Chianti I selected went quite well with it. Butters likes his steak, though he pined for a bit more of it on the plate. I guess he didn't appreciate me "safety-checking" the food. Oh well. 

Of course, had the lamb been served with fava beans by a waitress named Clarice, I could have done my best Hannibal Lecter, "fffuh fffuh fffuh fffuh" impression.

Yeah, that'd make them want me to visit again.

Overall, it was a nice meal.

Service: 4.0.

Quality: 4.0

Value: 3.7. (the spaghetti portion drags it down a bit).

Ambiance: 3.5.

Overall: 3.95. Rounds to 4.
author: Tim B.

description:
Overall, Delfina was a tasty restaurant with a trendy atmosphere.  It's not AMAZING blow your socks off good, but you will definitely leave satisfied!

APPS:
Ribollita appetizer was unique & delicious, small portion for $10!
Insalata del campo, fabulous bitter greens salad that was perfectly dressed!
Anchovy salad -  Refreshing, delicious and once again perfectly dressed salad

MAINS:
Short ribs were small portion, but luxurious and rich! Served with a creamy polenta.

Spaghetti gets a 7/10 on my spaghetti scale. They serve is a little spicy here which is nice, but I've made and had better.  That being said, it was only $13 and the pasta was fresh.

DESSERT:
Profiteroles were mediocre, if you are going for dessert I suggest the Pineapple upside down cake that is served with a pine nut brittle and sour cream gelato - much more interesting and delicious!

WINE:
I suggest you bring your own bottle, corkage fee is $18 but most good bottles hover around $50-60 here anyways!
author: Sabrina S.

description:
This place is great!  Granted it takes forever to get seated, but on the upside, once you're seated they don't rush you to turn over the table!

I didn't think that their infamous margarita pizza was anything to write home about.  However, the mushroom pizza is on my top 2 pizza's list for the city.

Lastly, I didn't try it... but their pork sugo is supposed to be amazing, and got written up, recipe and all in 7x7.  Enjoy: http://www.7x7.com/eat-drink/secret-recipe-pork-sugo-delfina
author: J P.

description: stupid bullshit! this place can hold more than 6 ppl and u can only resevere if its 6 or less bullshit ass place! 0 rating if i could
author: Linda L.

description: Holy crap.  Best spaghetti I have ever had in my entire life.  Usually I order a bit more adventurous but this was the greatest decision I have ever made.  So glad I talked my fiancee into going here because even though it was a bit expensive, it was all worth it.  Had amazing wine, desserts, and starters as well!  Also our server was the sweetest server I have ever had at a restaurant!
author: Katie B.

description:
4.4 stars
Don't order the pizza if you aren't going to delfinas pizzaria specifically. There are too many  other dishes worth having that you can't get at the pizzaria. 
The anchovies and calamari dishes are ridiculously good.  As was the octopus. 
The pork shoulder was highly recommended by our server but really wasn't very good.

They take reservations but be sure to call in advance. They are fairly booked up and don't save half the restaurant for walk ins like other new places are offering.
author: Kortni S.

description:
Amazing experience at Delfina!

My husband and I were searching for a venue to host dinner for 20 after our wedding ceremony. Delfina was recommended to us by a friend, and after doing some research we made a 'blind booking' without actually having visited the restaurant.

The process of planning and booking was amazing. We had a pretty short timeframe to plan (I think I booked 1-2 weeks before the actual date), and their event planner Heather was nothing short of amazing. She was very accommodating, pleasant to correspond with, and made sure everything was taken care of to our liking.

We had received a copy of the menu prior to the date, but other than that we really didn't know what we were in for the day of. Once we arrived and food started being brought to the table, we quickly realized that not only had we made a great decision, but that we were in for a real treat. Dinner was incredible - perhaps one of the best dinners I can remember. Everything from the first courses to dessert were so insanely good.

Throughout dinner, the staff were amazing. They were very personable, welcoming and attentive, without being pushy, hovering or overbearing. They really added to the experience.

We have received many comments since from our guests, raving about how wonderful the meal was. Everyone walked away very full, very satisfied, and wanting to go back for more.

My husband and I plan on returning for a quiet dinner with just the two of us to experience the food again. Whether you're looking at a small, intimate dinner or a small event like us, I would definitely recommend!!
author: Jen K.

description:
Since there are already 1000+ reviews for this place, I'll keep it brief:

Highlights:
Great service.
Duck conserva.
The molasses-balsamic reduction on the spare ribs.
The buttermilk-cardamom panna cotta.  Oh man.  I want this right now.  And maybe every day forever.  Che squisito!

Bummer:
Tres spendy.
author: claire l.

description:
Very knowledgeable service, nice wine list, interesting food. Overall solid effort. Went there last night, and had several items, shared between 2 people. The artichoke starter seemed to have been an artichoke heart stripped of almost all the outer layers of flesh. The inside was tender, and the exterior few layers of leaves were fried, so they turned crispy. It was served with lemon wedges, however overall, the dish was over salted (and I love my salt). 

We had the grilled asparagus, served with a bit of arugula and dressed with a grapefruit vinaigrette. The asparagus were delicate and decently charred. My companion thought the citrus (specifically grapefruit) combination took a little away from the natural flavor of the in-season asparagus. 

The chicken liver spiedini starter was deconstructed liver pate with toasts. A few knobs of liver, chicken fat, and cubes of bread were skewered and then grilled; finished with aged balsamic vinegar. Very tasty. 

We ate a fantastic homemade whole wheat pasta dish (don't remember the specific name of the pasta, but it was slightly fatter than spaghetti) with sardines, parmesan, and thin slices of fresh red chili. 

Finally, we had the braised shortribs, which were delicately wrapped inside tiny square pouches of pasta, and served with a sparse layer of incredibly flavorful  beef jus. We asked for extra bread to sop up all the leftover juices. Well done.
author: Timothy V.

description: I dine at Delfina whenever I make it to San Francisco.  I have always been glad I did.  Their food is the standard against which I measure many other restaurants: fresh ingredients, prepared very well, and with just the right level of service.  Great food without a fussy preparation and the atmosphere isn't fussy either.  No hint of bother at a table of talkative non-drinkers.  Can't wait to get back.
author: Brooks L.

description:
I've had an absolutely hellish 2 weeks. I've had to deal with moving my company,  working on very little sleep, one of my good friends has decided he's going back to the East Coast indefinitely, and the only girl that's managed to unearth my abandoned, scarred heart, subsequently broke it to pieces. It wasn't the way I wanted to start the holiday season and all I wanted to do was crawl into my bed and die. 

I have a group of friends that meet every year around the same time, to exchange gifts, have a good meal, and see each other before we all go our separate ways until the new year. I felt so crushed, I almost didn't go this year. My last ounce of will however said that I should surround myself with my friends, and not discard the tradition that we had built.

With one of my friends having had moved into the Mission recently, it was decided that we'd go to Delfina to celebrate in the neighborhood. Since I was in no shape to drive I traveled with a few friends, who are usually notoriously late. Amazingly, we somehow managed to be early, get parking right in front of the restaurant, and find that our table was set and ready to go. I don't know who's karma was in effect here but it definitely wasn't mine.

As we walked into the restaurant, we found a modern, bustling dining room, with a small bar area to the right, a counter that intersects the room, and the main dining room to the left. We were fortunate to have  a table right next to the large windows in the front. As we waited for a couple of people to show we were greeted by our waitress. She noted a few changes on the menu and items they were low on, so that they could set it aside if you were indeed interested in ordering it. So we started off with a bottle of the Dolcetto (although I wished they had a full bar - I was ready for some hard stuff) and a trio of appetizers. The rest of our group showed up and we proceeded to order the rest of our meal.

Our appetizers were as follows:

-Beef carpaccio with radicchio, parmigiano, and capers
-Salt cod mantecato with walnut oil and fennel seed flatbread
-Bitter greens, pancetta, walnuts, parmigiano and balsamic vinaigrette

The carpaccio came thinly cut, with a salty kick from the cheese and capers. I wasn't too crazy about the radicchio but others at the table really enjoyed it. The greens had a great vinaigrette with the texture and flavors from the pancetta/walnuts being a pleasant surprise. Salt cod is something I'll almost always order if I see it on the menu and this one didn't disappoint. Not too salty, good firmness, and an interesting flavor contrast with the fennel flatbread.

As my own food sidebar I aw something called Tripe Fiorentina, which was tripe in a tomato based sauce, baked with bread crumbs on top (almost an Italian Menudo). This was excellent and I think I was the only person in the restaurant that ordered it, but then I draw the line somewhere around Fear Factor so tripe doesn't really bother me.

For the entrees, there were several orders of the roasted chicken with mashed potatoes, and mushrooms;  flatiron steak and fries; and the slow roasted pork shoulder with  farro grain and cippolini onions (which the server set aside for me).  The pork shoulder was exquisitely tender, with the farro and onions in some sort of vegetable sauce which I couldn't quite discern but was very tasty. I never tried the steak but the fries were made with sage which gave them a slight complexity. The chicken was moist and also fairly flavorful with it's gravy but I wish it had a crispier skin. I also didn't try the mashed potatoes but was told by  the group that they came lukewarm but still tasty.

With the group I was with we are always bound to have dessert and tonight was going to be no exception.  Between us, we managed to sample the panna cotta, bundino (a bread-like cake), bittersweet chocolate cake and ginger/walnut gelati. I'd have to say all the desserts were fairly intriguing and tasty but nothing really blew my mind. But then I'm not much of a dessert person so I might not be the best opinion on these things.

Our waitress and other servers were all quite excellent amongst the bustling diners and we were well taken care of. There was a table of native Italians right behind us and sometimes, as I was trying to eavesdrop on their conversation, it made me feel like we were in a trattoria transported to the Mission. I'd say overall this was a 4.5 stars for the service was excellent and they make simple food wonderfully. Little drawbacks like the lukewarm potatoes are an easy fix and if this were my neighborhood, I'd definitely drop in from time to time. 

 I'm glad I didn't stay in and sulk. Delfina managed to take away the stress of my life, at least for a few hours or so. There's definitely some praise to be said for that.
author: Kim N.

description:
This place was perfect. Honestly, I was a little surprised finding this classy restaurant in the mission district since I'm so used to dive-y, mom-and-pop, hipster-like places here. Delfina was perfect for date night (although the lighting was a little tooooo dim) and the service was great. 

Grilled Calamari = 4 stars. I'm a huge fan of calamari and this was just so flavorful and cooked perfectly. The only thing was that the outside seemed a bit overgrilled and charred, giving it that bitter taste.
