Now that I think about it, it's odd to run out of a special at 7 pm. About 20 minutes later I asked if it was still available and was told yes, because only our table had been told about it. I have no idea if any of this is relevant to the fact that it arrived dry, tough, and salty. I definitely understand that salty is subjective, but not dry and tough. And it was served with half a plate of dry sauerkraut. Again, perhaps some diners like this version of sauerkraut. I will stand by the conviction that the duck was almost uneatable. The other dish that should not have left the kitchen was pork shoulder (heritage pork) slow cooked. It was also dry and tough plus had an exceptional amount of fat--which you would think would make it moist.. But it wasn't. At least the farro and mashed potatoes served with it were good and if eaten concurrent with the pork helped moisten it. My husband and I were celebrating the start of a week's vacation with our son visiting from out of town and our daughter and did not want to embarrass them by sending these dishes back, but we agreed afterwards that we were very disappointed. The Tartine bread was of course as good as bread can be.
author: Beth W.

description:
After being a loyal patron for over 5 years and having only written a fairly brief review about the magical dessert menu, the time has finally come to put joking aside and pay tribute to what I consider to be the best restaurant in San Francisco. Delfina, even after this long you are still the restaurant to which I compare all other restaurants in the City. Why? It's simple - you are the epitome of what you are trying to be.

Let me explain. You're not, nor are you trying to be a Michael Mina or the Dining Room at the Ritz - you're not serving cuisine worthy of the Bocuse d'Or and you're not about to offer up a 9 course tasting menu with a wine pairing. You're also not trying to blend in with your Mission neighbors by offering cheap, quick food for hipsters on the go. 

You are an upscale, neighborhood restaurant (that has clearly garnered much fame outside the neighborhood) that finds the essence of traditional, regional Italian preparations and uses our local, seasonal ingredients to put a modern, updated spin on those dishes. Your food and atmosphere are not arrogant or exaggerated; you're also not stuffy and quiet. You're a lively, busy, friendly fine-dining establishment run by people that love what they do and want to make great food. That's the kind of restaurant that you're trying to be, and I don't believe there is any dining establishment in SF that fulfills their role as well as you. 

While some dishes are always available, the menu changes nightly, giving you the chance to go back over and over again and try something new. I've had almost everything on the menu, and there has not been a single dish that hasn't made me say "Wow, that's delicious." My personal favorites (aside from the fresh bread from Tartine!) are the GRILLED FRESH SQUID, the BURRATA when it's on the menu, the various preparations of their rosemary TAGLIATELLE, the AGNOLOTTI (again in many different ways), and the veal SWEETBREADS. And of course as I said in my previous review, this is a place where skipping dessert should be a crime - the buttermilk PANNA COTTA is mind-blowing, as is the CHOCOLATE TORTA with olive oil gelato. Both of those dishes inspired me to try them myself,  and although I did them really well, I think Delfina would still win that throw-down.

What's really amazing is that if you read through all 700+ yelp reviews, almost every diner has had completely different meals, but each reviewer has amazing things to say about almost every item. Delfina doesn't just do 1 dish well, they do every dish well on a constantly changing menu, every time. It's fairly shocking to me that, unlike the James Beard Foundation, Michelin hasn't recognized Delfina with a star - something that will hopefully change in the next publication.

As far as the service is concerned, it's always impeccable. The servers are there when you need them, engaging, attentive, and control the pace of the meal perfectly - everything you could expect out of a well-trained, tight-knit staff. Also, unlike many successful executive chefs, the owner, Craig Stoll, is in the restaurant almost every night. I have been lucky enough to speak with him at length a few times now, and he is one of the friendliest, warmest restaurant owners I've ever come across; the depth of his culinary knowledge and experiences is fascinating, and it's just simply obvious that he loves what he does. 

Craig, and everyone else involved with this restaurant, thank you for so many wonderful experiences, and for setting the standard for what fine-dining in San Francisco should be.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Incredible. I dine here for my birthday, anniversary and anytime I want to treat myself to a special meal. The fresh ingredients and flavors are refined and delicious. From the steak or the spaghetti to the calamari and mashed potatoes every item on the menu is incredible and you will love each one. Amazing desserts. The wine list is also a plus. The service is always stellar. Best restaurant in San Francisco and its also my favorite. Indescribably delicious.
author: Alexander G.

description:
I haven't eaten here in months, but I'm going to write my killer 5-star review now just because I'm so damn mad at Farina.

Look at the Yelp distribution for Delfina... So many 5-star reviews. You walk out of this place and you feel like you've had a special night out. (Unlike Farina where you feel like you've been the victim of a financial hate crime)

Each dish is well-conceived, very tasty, and exactly what you were promised on the menu. And as you read the menu, you just want to try everything. No strange experimental food, no bizarre ingredients. Everything looks fantastic.

The servers are friendly, incredibly knowledgeable, and attentive.

The place is a bit noisy and crowded, but it has a vibrant feel and it is truly reflective of a modern San Francisco dining sensibility.  And incredibly, it hasn't suffered a bit since they've opened three other restaurants.

If you've never eaten here, you should.
author: Al M.

description:
Food here was good but not mind-blowing.  The pasta was excellent, main meat course good but would probably just get the pasta next time.  The decor is okay.  Atmosphere more casual with some tables very close the wait area or under a eat-in-bar (what's with that?  who wants to eat with other people eating right above your head?).

A good place for a nice but casual meal but definitely not a fancy restaurant for those special occasions.

Update: last time I saved Delfina's for a special occasion.  Everyone raved about what a good restaurant it was and I made reservations weeks in advance.  Needless to say, though Delfina's was good, it wasn't worth all that effort.

This time, we just dropped by during a weekday because we were too tired to cook and were given a $75 gift certificate.  It was Tuesday.  We were able to not only get seating but actual table at 7 PM with no reservation.  Food was fantastic this time.  Gravlox okay.  Spaghettini w/ squid ink (spicy!) was great.  Braised pork w/ lentils very tender and awesome.  Dessert was okay.  The waitstaff was also very friendly and efficient.  I had tried to come the preceding Monday as well but got sneered at by the hostess, when I asked about a table because they were booked up until 9:30 PM with an hour wait for the bar (on a Monday???).  

Starters are around $9.  Pastas avg $15.  Secondi (meat) course avg $20+.  For two people with a shared starter, main courses (ind), shared dessert, and two beers - bill was just under $70.  Wine is expensive with the cheapest option at $26.

I will reiterate that this is not the sort of place you should save up money or save for a special occasion.  You will be disappointed.  There is no privacy at your table and you will have to shout to be heard.  Sit next to interesting people if you can as their conversation will be more entertaining.  However, as a nice place to drop by if you live in the neighborhood, the food can't be beat.

Also Tuesday seems to have less wait and nicer staff.  I thought I read somewhere that you should avoid nice restaurants on weekend because they are so full and also full of "weekenders" (aka tourists and those that come into the city for special occasions) and instead patronize them on weekdays when the regulars do.

After this I'm going to upgrade them to 3.5 stars.  They'd get more if the food and staff weren't so hit and miss.

Bike Parking: designated bike racks on 18th St.
author: Jean K.

description:
I really want to give Delfina 5 stars but I guess I got too excited about coming here. The grilled Calamari was delicious. It literally looks like the squid was killed right before it was grilled and served to you! We tried the Malvasia to go with it and it was perfect!

I had the beef short ribs braised in balsamic. They were amazing! The meat fell off the bone! No Knife needed! My waitress suggested a very yummy cabernet but I didn't get the name. It went PERFECT! 
My Fiance had the chicken & mashed P's but it just didn't blow me away. Everything else did. Maybe he should have been more adventurous and tried something else. Chicken is easy too cook. lol. 

The service is wonderful! Every single person on the staff was all smiles and very helpful. I will definatley come back again and hope for a 5 star review. I hear their seafood is amazing and I only had a tiny taste of it!
author: Lily M.

description:
After hearing so many positive things about Delfina, I was worried it might be over-hyped. But....I was pleasantly surprised!!!!!!

The servers were incredibly helpful. They explained everything  succinctly, and were VERY nice about doing a special order.
I ordered their spaghetti pretty plain, but it was still some of the best pasta I've ever had! 
Seriously, if it can be that good with just olive oil, garlic, and a little parm...It has to be pretty amazing!
My guy loved their gnocchi too!
The halibut I had was a tad dry, but the sauce was great. Strange as it may sound, I had the best carrots of my life. (A small amount of mixed veggies came with the halibut.)
I will definitely be back!
Finally a restaurant that lives up to it's reputation!
author: Amanda G.

description:
I was in a grazing mood when I went to Delfina. The Anson Mills polenta and fontina VAL D'aOSTA  was to die for, with just the right amount of salt and a creamy texture. I also really enjoyed my Niman Ranch beef carpaccio with radicchio and salt-packed capers. The radicchio provided a bitter bite and was a nice change of pace from the more traditional red onion. The Romano beans straciotto with bacon and tomato had a wonderful flavor, but were a bit too done for my tastes. I was exceptionally happy with my wine choice, though. The Lacrima was lovely, both in terms of flavor and color.

Both the Strawberry Mountain shortribs with Anson Mills polenta and gremolata and the Strawberry Mountain Ranch hanger steak and French fries looked (and smelled) amazing. I think either would be a great option if you had an appetite.

The staff was friendly and efficient and I loved the atmosphere. I will definitely go back.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Very good service.
Good wine selection.
Food was so-so.
I had Grilled Fresh Calamari (a bit rubbery), my friend had Meyer Ranch Hanger Steak and French Fries
 (in his words it was over salted and a bit dry).
author: BO P.

description:
I ate here a few weeks ago with a friend. We showed up 15 minutes before it opened at 5. The host was awesome. he saw us peeking in the window so he came out, chatted with us and told us he'd put us on the list for first seating. We got in and were seated at a great window seat.

The food was very good. So good that I have dreams. The mashed potatoes were the most buttery, creamy orgasm ever. The host brought over something we didn't order but thought we needed. This special attention I will always remember, and appreciate. We didn't have to pay for it and he was right, we did need it. The plate consisted of crunchy slices of little bread toasted to perfection, brushed with olive oil and topped with sardine. It was delicious. 

There was no pressure to move on even though the sidewalk was overflowing with people waiting to get in. I did notice that they allowed the people on the sidewalk to drink wine while they waiting. If I were waiting I would appreciate that.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Ate here last night after many recommendations and was not impressed.  San Francisco have you become the culinary Emperor Wears No Clothes of cities?  

We did not have reservations and waited on the long side of thirty minutes outside on the sidewalk.  It was a mild November night so,  no problem there.  The hostess was passable and our server was very nice.  There were no specials and no recommendations from our server.  I had a glass of Pinot Nero, $13.50, nothing special, I should have asked to try it first.  

We went with the house salad, grilled sardines and an order  tokyo turnips and greens to start.  The salad was again passable but nothing to write home about, the turnips were tasty if not a bit overdressed in olive oil but the sardines .... blech.  As they were set on the table they had a very strong fishy smell and first bite they tasted off.  Another server stopped by and graciously removed from the table and our check.  Entrees: Mascarpone and prosciutto ravioli were ok, very small portion.  Spaghetti, ok, descent portion, nothing spectacular.  As another reviewer mentioned, I think I make it better at home.  Fulton chicken, great ultra crispy skin, delicate moist meat, mashed potatoes meh, all in all, not bad but not something that would bring me back.  

Several of the desserts sounded good, but we were leery of adding another $20 bucks to the bill for so-so.
author: stephanie B.

description:
I'm sorry Delfina.

The service was great, the wait was painful and the menu selection was really disappointing. I'm going to go back and hope that I have a better experience. Here's the dirty of it.

I'm a vegetarian and there was hardly any options. I ordered Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, basil and garlic. It was really my only option. I ordered a side of chard with it. The Chard was insanely over cooked and oily; so basically it was a mushy, oily green mash. The Spaghetti was ok but pretty boring and lacking something...I really expected more from the reviews.

The bread was amazing!! Best part of the meal...

I'll come back again hoping for a better experience on the food. Service was great.
author: Mikaela s.

description: After working with Jason rose at Rams Gate winery and thoroughly enjoying his food there. I had every interest to try Delfina because Jason rose opened this place. The service was fantastic! The food was equally amazing. The hanger steak was mouth watering. The duck breast was grilled to perfection. I will definitely be back!
author: Amanda M.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but was met with a bit of disappointment.  My friend ordered an insalata di campo which had pancetta, nuts and a light dressing.  The pancetta really added a smokey, salty component to the salad in a good way.  For entrees, I ordered a steak and frites (I've been on a steak and frites binge).  The fries were okay, not as crispy as they could have been.  The steak was cooked well, tender at medium rare, but it came with soo much sauce that the sauce completely overpowered anything else I was eating and not in a good way.  My friend ordered the pork shoulder.  That was a lot better than my steak.

Our server recommended a bottle of red wine, which actually was really good and paired well with our meaty dishes.  I got a glass of mascato d'asti for dessert and was a little disappointed in that too.  That is my favorite wine, and it just wasn't that great.

Since I am moving up north, I will give this place another go.  The pastas looked really good.
author: Pornsakdi T.

description:
I really have a love/hate relationship wit this place. I absolutely love their food but can't stand to eat inside their restaurant! Every time I eat here the place is packed and stays that way the whole night so it's always best to call ahead before you show up. 
The reason I can't absolutely love this place is because every time I eat there, I feel like I am packed into the restaurant & there isn't enough room to enjoy myself. Other than that, the food is phenomenal.
author: Penelope F.

description:
Ugh, zero stars for this craphole. 

1. It was SOOOO expensive
2. The food sucked. SUCKED. Our group of four ordered 2 appetizers and 4 entrees and NONE of them were good. 
3. Crowded, pretentious

This place is the epitome of over-hyped, trendy restaurants riding their wave of popularity with NOTHING to back it up. Proof that a long line doesn't mean a great restaurant. Save yourselves, people, save yourselves from this. 

Lipstick on a pig!!!!!!!
author: Katie M.

description:
1 word: AMAZING!
Yes, the wait is a bit of a pain, but once you dive into the food here, you'll forget all about waiting. We had the tricolore salad, the prosciutto and the panna pizza and were soaking up every last bite with additional marinara sauce.  The food is really incredible and totally reasonably priced. The staff is ultra cool and being a NYer, good pizza is hard to find. I'll definitely be back!
author: Jessie H.

description:
The blood orange "bellini" was good but I'm pretty positive they just mixed some prosecco with a san pellegrino blood orange soda.  No puree for the Delfina bellini. 

I got the spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, olive oil, and peperoncini which gave it a nice kick.  As a vegetarian I really had no other option, good thing I like pasta!
author: Athena W.

description:
Ah! I absolutely love Delfina and so look forward to spitting margarita pizza with a bottle of wine with a close friend. Such a simple and easy dinner. 

The staff is always friendly and gracious...even amidst the constant crowds that come throughout the night. Which brings up the line. Be prepared to wait 10-20 minutes every time you go- get your name on the chalkboard and just peruse the menu. 

The fresh stretched mozzarella is unreal. It is a must when you go!
author: Jennifer W.

description: Good place for a solid meal. Simple preps - our dinner for two was about $100, could have replicated it more or less for $25 at home, plus time to buy the ingredients, cook, and clean. I'll probably never go back - prefer stuff I can't/won't cook myself when I eat out - but it was a perfectly pleasant meal. Props for the turron squares that came with the check. They tasted house made, and for a moment I was back in Alacant.  Crowd was mostly middle aged folks.
author: Nick C.

description: What a great place to meet up with friends! The food and ambiance is well worth coming to the place. The food is all about healthy, tons of options for the vegetarian and a full bar to boot. They also have a great wine selection which makes all you foodies out there break a smile ... ok, I might be facetious on my review of this place, but that's the kind of excitement this place has on you. Believe me when I tell you that the food here was fantastic! The ambiance and the energy was great and the staff was very friendly and helpful. It gets busy here, so make your reservation when you can, unless you're okay with waiting. HAPPY EATING!
author: Rob B.

description:
My husband and I had a nice Valentines dinner here along with a dozen or more couples. Our waiter was attentive, the bread and salted butter was good, and the food was satisfying but not memorable.  He had some sort of whole fish and I had chicken stuffed tortellini in some kind of broth.  It could have been the pancetta in both of our dishes, but every bite was just on the edge of being too salty.  We finished our dinner by sharing Portiferoles with espresso ice cream, drizzled in dark chocolate, and sprinkled with candied almonds.  Again, it satisfied our sweet tooth, but nothing special.  

2 1/2 stars.
author: Rae L.

description: After living here for almost 8 years I finally got into Delfina.  It was probably one of the best meals I've had in a while.  I'm fat.  I eat alot and I am starting to get bored of eating the same shit.   All the food here was executed very well.  There wasn't a dish I didn't like.  The grilled calamari with white beans was awesome.  I wasn't a huge fan of the Hay and Straw but my woman loved it.  I thought the shortribs with some fancy name was good.  It was pretty much ravioli with shortribs in a short rib broth.  But they used some fancy Italian word for it.  ITS FUCKING RAVIOLI!  The roasted chicken with olive oil mash was also very good.  I ran 10 miles that day and I was freakin starving.  I am hoping this didn't mess with my fat emotions.  I would go back in a couple of years.
author: Fatty A.

description: I was really excited to eat here but it wasn't as good as I had heard.
author: Maggie U.

description:
Perfect timing, the restaurant had just opened for no more than 30mins so we were able to snag a table without reservations. We had to sit on the long table that cater more to just the individual that don't need a whole table. I didn't mind, since I've been wanting to try this place for awhile anyways.

We got the quail and the roasted chicken. Both were amazing! Great flavor and cooked to perfection!
author: Bettina L.

description:
I had dinner here last Tuesday night with my girls. I made a reservation that day for 6pm. I'm glad for the last minute spot, though it was the last one left until 9pm. I had high expectations for this place and I was ready for a great time. Delfina presents a lovely, intimate environment with low light and candles. We were the youngest diners by far in the restaurant. That always seems to happen to me. 

We wanted to get right to entrees so the bread was our appetizer. It was so fresh and delicious! The salted butter was all I needed on it. I couldn't stop eating it even when my entree came.

I got the Pancetta-Wrapped Rabbit Saddle with saba roasted farm carrots and fennel. I liked the vegetables. Even though it was a bit mushy, the flavor was still there. However, the rabbit tasted like chicken and that's not a good thing. When I order rabbit, that's what I want to taste. The sauce was a bit much as well. I gave away my last pieces of rabbit and continued to eat more bread. 

My friend's duck was nicely cooked but nothing else was special about it. Another dish was pasta ravioli and it was tiny. I'm glad I experienced Delfina but we just didn't click. We passed on dessert and went to Bi-Rite for dessert. Oh well.
author: Julia T.

description:
After all the rave I heard from my BF, I decided to take him to Delfina for his brithday because we already procrastinate on the weekends and can never get reservation here for a decent time.  I expected this place to be uber amazing, as in 5 stars.  It did not live up to my expectations. Sigh.

We got served bread from tartine (confirmed with waiter) with this smooth delicate angel like butter.  This was probably my favorite part of the meal and it was the free part. LOL

We started with the calamari and white bean salad, it was good, the white bean and sauce was probably the highlight of that dish. 

Then we decided to get two half orders of pasta so we could try more options without be stuffed.  We got the rosemary game hen tagliatelle and a longer pasta with anchovies and capers.  I mostly enjoyed the texture of the handmade pastas, the sauces were a little on the salty side.

We shared the short ribs and polenta as an appetizer.  This I thought was good, but over priced for what it was.  I didn't like that the short ribs were served on a big plate (3 pieces) and the polenta on the side in a mini dish.  I would have preferred if it was all on a big dish with a side of greens too.

Finally for dessert we got the chocolate boudini with orange gelato.  The cake was amazing and to die for.  Almost as good as the bread and butter. 

We each got two glasses of wine and the bill wasn't too ridiculous, about $140 including tax and tip.  I would come back again but probably not go full out.  Maybe focus on the bread, pasta, and dessert.
author: Skye W.

description: Our waitress while kind did not know a darn thing about the menu and thus ruined my dinner. My dining companions weren't that thrilled either but kept a stiff upper lip. The food was outrageously salty. Would not recommend except maybe after a marathon when sodium levels are low.
author: Lyn-Genet R.

description:
Good upscale SF food, never been disappointed.
Then again, one of my favorite people works here, so I am biased. 
The profiteroles here are the standard to which I judge all others.
author: Chris M.

description: The first "fancy" restaurant I went to with my fiance - over 6 years later, and it's still our favorite spot for special occasions! I always get the spaghetti - it's so simple but just so good. Every time I regret not getting a large and just making it my entree. The wines are great, service is great, always end up stuffing myself.
author: Yangchen C.

description: Nice place, good service and good wine. Good ingredients too, however, the pizza bread -- main part -- was quite disappointing, too oily and chewy, and tasteless, on both their pizza an special calzone. Way too expensive for the food you get in my opinion. I wish the pizza was good Italian-style made pizza, rather than paying $7 for a sparking water imported from Italy that doesn't taste any different than local water except for the carbon footprint.
author: Tarik A.

description:
Delfina has been on my long list of restaurants to hit up in San Francisco, and i FINALLY had a chance to go!

The Scene: 

Yellow walls, skillfully placed mirrors, squeezed-together tables and an outdoor patio add up to a warm, happy experience. The crowd is typical for the neighborhood--youngish hipsters galore--but there's always a healthy smattering of older couples and artsy folks as well. Walk-in seats are available at the counter facing the wine bar, but best to call for a reservation well in advance. 

Now the good stuff....THE FOOD: 

Insalata del campo--a salty-sharp, irrestistible combo of bitter greens, toasted walnuts, crispy pancetta bits and Parmesan shards--is a must-have, as is the grilled calamari over tiny white beans....yummy! The flatiron steak with french fries excites and comforts at the same time too. And don't think of leaving without trying the scrumptious profiteroles (stuffed with espresso ice cream and doused in shiny, dark-chocolate sauce)...sweet dessert bliss :)

Can't wait to come back!
author: Marie L.

description:
The food was excellent. Roasted chicken thrilled us all. And that's not a dish I get worked up about. Roasted Berkshire pork with faro, very good. Service good. Atmosphere nice, if a bit loud.  

The one star I'm withholding is price to serving size, excluding the chicken which was big. As one other reviewer said: "tres spendy."

I had not been to Delfina in many years. Glad to find it still serving excellent tasting food.
author: Scott R. D.

description: Disappointed. The squid salad was good; but the risotto and spaghietti with plum tomatoes were just ok, and were over-salted.
author: Chris G.

description: Ate here on March 23, party of five. Service was almost too fast but very efficient, the waiter took a lot of time explaining the dishes and their preparation. Bread from Tartine. We had pasta dishes, all were excellent, portions a bit small. Deserts were profiteroles and a very nice chocolate concoction, both excellent. Decor is not lush but very pleasant. Wine list is interesting. Would definitely recommend!!
author: Elizabeth B.

description: We were in the area and decided to stop by and grab a bite to eat. Without a reservation, we were given a rather sad looking table next to a wall. That was fine because we just wanted to sit and eat. I was feeling like a bunny so decided to share some stuff w/ the bf instead of getting my own entrée. We got the mozzarella salad and the little gem salad. Both pretty good but just salads. For the entrée we got the Whole Local Sand Dabs which was quite interesting to eat. The fish is soft and the bones are small. So the waitress suggested a technique for us to get the meat off the bone which worked out quite nicely. For dessert we got the fresh berry panna cotta which was pretty awesome. I wasn't blown away but I was impressed. The menu is small but definitely a "must try" restaurant when in San Francisco.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Delfina is a great restaurant, and word has definitely gotten out.  You'll want a reservation to eat here, but when you get in the service will be top-notch, just like the food.
author: Dan W.

description:
Dooder! 
This place is the shit! I only wish I had it in my kitchen, or in pill form.
SOYLENT GREEN IS DELFINA!!!!
Eat here now, thank me later
author: Logan R.

description: We were lucky. We parked right in front of Bi-Rite ice cream shop and walked right into Delfina and got a table for two. Their pastas are home made. I had the spaghetti with basil and it was superb. So good that since i was eating slow, my husband ate 1/5 of my plate! I wasn't super hungry so I didn't order any of the secondi, but judging by the table next to us, they were tasty and a good size.
author: Natalie S.

description: Really great spot. Awesome service, food was great. Try the tripe and spaghetti. Also the strawberry rhubarb dessert. Menu changes daily. Cant wait to go back
author: Christian A.

description:
I have been to Delfina twice and I have to admit that I wasn't that impressed the first time. My last visit was definitely more enjoyable.

I am a sardine person and I loved the grilled sardines. There is nothing fancy about this plate, but they did everything right - crispy outside, soft inside, and boneless.

Insalata di Campo was simple and fresh. However, too much balsamic vinegar was added in preparation.

Pasta with Louisiana style shrimps was plain awesome. All ingredients were fresh and tasty. Pasta had a great bouncy texture, yet not chewy. Sauce comped with the pasta nicely - not too much and not too less.

Grilled swordfish was quite impressive. It wasn't all dried up like most other grilled swordfish, and the meat wasn't all rough and tough.

Bonet Stratato was quite lovely. Cream was rich and smooth, not too sweet.

Final thought: If you don't like this place for the first time, it's okay, me too. Give it another try and you will probably grow to love it.
Buon Appetitio!
author: Edmund L.

description:
I've been to Delfina twice and both times were exceptional. 

The first was for my birthday and we splurged with a DELICIOUS 4 course meal with wine pairings. The server paired each dish remarkably well and could give us great explanations as to why...she even wrote the wines on cards for us to take with us.

The second, we decided to try our luck and walk-in at 830 on a Saturday night, and as luck would have it, we got seated at the high counter within minutes. I got the gnocchi and my date got the spaghetti - both simple, fabulous and deserving of an excellent review for the flavor and presentation.  We also ordered the Japanese turnips, which came mid-way through our meal. While we didn't mind, the kitchen apologized for the inconvenience and took it off the bill. 

This is a restaurant that appreciates the entire customer experience from beginning to end and has passion for and pride in each dish that is prepared. I have nothing but wonderful things to say and I will return again, and again, and again! Congratulations Delfina!!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
the roasted chicken ($19) was sublime - nice hearty portions and super juicy and flavorful from the skin to the meat. even the breast was tender. other restaurants should really take note. 

the spaghetti & short rib cappelletti were good, but not the standout stars i expected.

spaghetti ($13) was simple& straightforward with a nice tangy sauce and a hint of crushed chili flakes, but almost too simple.

cappelletti ($18) is a short rib stuffed pasta. these were teeny tiny and a bit overly rich for my taste. 

as for appetizers, you really can't go wrong with the grilled calamari ($11, portions for this is small for sharing) and the chicken liver crostini ($9, rich but the pickled veggies do a nice job of cutting the heaviness of the liver). 

overall - low price point and solid fare. i definitely want to come back again to try the other pasta dishes & revisit my good friend the roast chicken.
author: Lily L.

description:
LOVE Delfina. Let the wait staff help you choose, they are very knowledgeable and can help course your meal out appropriately. Creative items on the menu, excellent pastas and they have a chicken that is amazing. 

It's a little spendy, so get your frequent fix at Pizzeria Delfina, then go to this parent restaurant for those more special times. Expect a wait too.
author: jennifer c.

description: We used to LOVE Delfina's, but it's not the same anymore. Something is definitely up in their kitchen. It is simply NOT the same quality anymore. The wait staff is still attentive and wonderful (except for the hostess who asked us if we were sure we didn't want the pizza place rather than the restaurant - perhaps because we were two older women of color dressed casually!!? Very insulting!). But the food....really gone down hill...almost $200 later (with only two glasses of wine), there was not a single item that stood out. Boring, uninteresting, not worth the money are a few descriptions that come to mind. Too bad...
author: Soher Y.

description: Everything was delicious! It's a beautiful space filled with fun people and scrumptious food. I went with a group of six and it was so much fun. Go with a group so everyone can try a little of everything. The short ribs were fall of the bone goodness and they just melt in your mouth. The gnocci were so fluffy and eaten with a bite of tomato and cheese and it was a party in your mouth (and I don't even like tomatoes). The papadelle with pork sugo was what I got and I can understand why it's on the list. The papadelle just brought me back to Rome. You can taste the love that went into making it. It was delicious!
author: Eve C.

description:
Hmm Delfina.  Came on a Thursday night, called ahead for a reservation, seated right away when we got there.  Food was good.. tasty, well plated.  Service was friendly and efficient.  The server answered all our questions (had a few about the menu.. sorry I'm not fancy enough to know what all the Italian means!)

Downside for me would be the price.  Our entree was about $25 for two little slabs of pork.  It was good, don't get me wrong, but I didn't think it was $25 good.  And I believe that was one of the cheaper entrees on the menu.  Pasta plates were around $20 and also pretty small.

I'm not saying that when you spend a lot of money on food it should be a huge heaping plate.  But if it's going to be expensive and small portioned, it had better blow me away with taste.  The food was good, but not great.  I would give it 3.5 stars if I could.

That being said, I'd go there again.  Esp if someone else is paying ;)
author: Christie C.

description: This place is generally ok.  Not great, just ok.  My family (4) have eaten at Delfina on 3 ocassions.  The last experience was like the others.  Good service and decent food.  But, I don't really understand the excitement since there are better options.   I will say that Delfina Pizzeria always is great.  But, my wife's lamb was very try and may steak was just average.  My son loved his seafood linguini and the polenta.  My daughter was happy with her steak.
author: E A.

description:
Ate at Delfina this past Saturday night at a friend's suggestion and it was quite delicious. The service was exceptional and attentive. We made a reservation and were seated promptly.

We tried the cabbage involtini and a salad with pancetta. Both were fantastic...I had the pork shoulder and hubby had the spaghetti. We both oohed and ahhed throughout. No room for dessert due to the most incredible fresh and homemade bread and salted butter!

I give a half a star off since we were told that they don't serve the pizza in the restaurant side...everyone told us to try it so we were disappointed...it's always weird when diners 5 feet away are eating something you can't have...

Otherwise - yum!
author: Joyce J.

description:
Considering the number of reviews, I expected a little more. The only thing that stood out about this restaurant was how friendly our waitress was.  

For two we ordered a beef ravioli to share, swordfish, pork ribs, and a couple glasses of wine. The appetizer was delicious, but the fish was just okay. The ribs came with a side of beans which didn't really help the entree. Overall everything was good but only the appetizer stood out. Luckily we made reservations (same day at 8:30pm on a Friday) so there was no wait but I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to come back.
author: Leily P.

description:
Too.  Much.  Salt.

Seriously.

The grilled calamari, arctic char (special of the night), and famed hanger steak w/ fries were all over-seasoned.  The high NaCl content had us reaching for the frosted water carafe to refill our glasses more than I would have liked (more on this later.)  The spaghetti was nothing special - ingredients were simple and fresh, but the noodles themselves were slightly overcooked.

We passed on dessert since we had a show to catch - The Nutcracker, to be exact.  Where (due to the mass H2O intake at dinner) my bladder conveniently scheduled bathroom breaks mid-act, ruining the performance not only for me and my + 1, but the two Asian couples sitting to the left of us as well (if you're reading this, I sincerely apologize, for the umpteenth time!)

At the end of the day, I expected more from Delfina.  I'd love to chalk it up to a bad night, but given that 1) it was a Friday night so they should have had their first-string kitchen staff and 2) other Yelpers seemed to also suffer from an overdose of sodium-chloride, I don't think that was the case.

Minus points for no OpenTable reservations (come on now, we actually have to talk to a human being to make a reservation?) and not taking American Express.
author: Allen L.

description: People that work here are very nice. Food is always changing and delicious! My favorite item there has to be their margarita pizza. It is super cheesy and thin crusted. Also, the bread sticks there are extremely addicting. I eat at least a dozen before the meal comes. The people there are so lovely and always very happy.
author: Maleka M.

description:
Yes, a bit cliche to give this restaurant it's 947 review and give it 5 stars, but it deserves it.  Went last friday with the man-cub to celebrate the start of his new career path, and it was fabulous.  Great service, great food, great wine.

We, as always, ordered a variety of items to share.  We got the tomatoe salad (had to order this as the season dwindles).  It was very good.  They gave us a bonus portion of egg flower soup to try, as we had been on the fence about this one (well, I had been on the fence).  It was delicious.  We ordered the steak, which comes with a beautiful sauce and tasty fries.  It came to us a bit on the rare side, and they graciously took it back to cook some more.

I had called in my credit card number in advance to pre-pay the meal (something I rarely do...) and they were really great about making it a smooth, seamless process.

As another bonus (my boyfriend has been a patron of Delfina since they very day that it opened), they also brought a tasty ice cream surprise with a candle to help us celebrate.

All in all, a wonderful meal, surrounded by wonderful locals, and served on by amazing wait staff.  Once again, well done, Delfina.....!
author: Jane N.

description:
Great experience here!  My fiancee has been here once or twice before (we are from Washington, DC) and after a few days at Tahoe we spent some time in SF.  She said we had to go here... so like any smart man, I did what I was told, it was great!

I had the short ribs with polenta which were amazing!

She had the Paparedelle with pork sugo, managed to be light while being full of flavor and filling.

Our other three friends had the steak WITH ANCHOVY AND MARROW BUTTER (need I say more) and the wild nettle risotto (al dente, briney-cheese flavore and perfect). Then one more order of the short ribs.

Portions are what they should be, not overdoing it but not too little.

Would recommend it to anyone.
author: Niko P.

description:
Trendy and tasty, but lacking value and hearty dream-worthy dishes. For the price point, the food was not as exceptional as I have anticipated for so long - truly a disappointment. 

I greatly respect fine dining, and small/health conscious portions with exceptional taste and craft, but that is not the case here. No doubt good flavors, but I have had too many better pasta dishes in SF and other cities around the world, or even at home, to be satisfied with the price that matches the quality/quantity provided at Delfina. Skip the restaurant, and spend your money at their Pizzaeria or indulge in pasta elsewhere. Ciao!
author: Matt D.

description:
A well-time visit at lunch meant sliding into a well-lit table by the window before the place became packed wall-to-wall with diners.

Pizza were hot and fresh, the ingredients tasted local and at their peak of ripeness and flavor. Our waitress gave us honest recommendations, which we took and were pleased with the results. 

Three of us shared one pizza, as we had other places to go and eat. We had to pace ourselves. We went with one of the specials of the day, no clue how the item is even spelled. Graecia, perhaps? A pizza with prosciutto, spring onions, cracked black pepper and cream. The risotto ball special sounded good, too, but stomach real estate did not allow.

All in all, very good.

Delfinia also really passes the buck onto the diner with the Healthy SF tax.  The tax added about 25% more onto the bill. The $16 pizza is closer to $21, before a tip is added.  Much like foreign tourists are surprised when the price tag of an item they purchase is not really the price they are charged by this mysterious "sales tax," non-residents may be surprised that this value-add appears at the end of the meal.
author: Lemonjelly L.

description:
It's hard to get a five stars from me, I guess, but this comes pretty close.  It's a solid 4-star though.

My friend treated me to this place for my birthday.  I've heard a lot of good things about it and had always wanted to try it.  It didn't disappoint!

We shared the cured salmon salad.  Light and fresh!  Very appropriate for the season.  (though we wished it had more greens)  My friend ordered the spaghetti in tomato sauce and I got the sea bass pasta.  I'm most impressed with the depth of flavors in each dish.  Though they're both in tomato-based sauces, they tasted completely different yet each has such a "lip-smacking" quality to it.  The seasoning was perfect!  Right on the dot!  We then shared the swordfish secondi.  I'm also skeptical when it comes to ordering swordfish 'coz most places I've tried prepared it to such dryness that it's better to eat shoe leather.  But swordfish at Delfina is how swordfish needs to be done.  Charred just right on the outside, which juicy and soft on the inside!  Loved the grilled fennel-crusted fennel bulb that came with it.  

All in all...a wonderful eating experience.  Will definitely come back!  :-)
author: M F.

description:
Spaghetti, spaghetti, spaghetti...

This simple dish at Delfina is in the running for my last meal.  Just the right amount of spice and the noodles are perfect!
author: jane d.

description:
While Delfina may not be the latest thing, it is consistently delicious. They remain true to their seasonal and misleadingly simple menu but turn out dishes that are layered with complex and satisfying flavors. 

Recently had a late dinner for old times sake although I did not get my favorite corner table. Started with the quintessential grilled calamari w/ white bean salad, a dish that helped put them on the map. I remember reading rave reviews about this dish years ago and there is good reason that it remains a menu staple. Sustainable calamari is quickly grilled imparting a nice smokiness to the still tender but toothsome squid. Lots of EVOO, perfectly cooked beans, and a nice hit of lemony acidity round out the dish. The baked Bellweather ricotta with charry grilled zucchini and pane pomodoro was also tasty, as we layered "perfect bites" of each component. 

House-made pasta is a must at Delfina. The tagliatelle combined surprisingly refreshing mint with fresh porcini mushrooms. To add some fatty goodness to the meal, we also split the Duroc pork Valdostana. This giant bone-in chop was stuffed with fontina, proscuitto, and was perfectly cooked. 

Service was spot on as usual and I was delighted to see a full house upon our late arrival.
author: Candice L.

description:
This utopia is just that...it gives you street cred when you need it and its pathetic that I am just getting to my review. Its true my sister lived right around the corner from this place and never charged for her parking space. 

I came here to impress a potential husband. Well, still single but still the taste lingers of fine food that touched my soul. 
The waiter was a woman so, I wasn't interested and I think my date and I high fived over the table. 

This wonderous place became my quick favorite spot to go on a date if solely to watch who walked in the door but I didn't know about the back room or the reservations were so difficult. 

I liked it.. there now

Go at 5pm if you have to.
author: Patricia A.

description:
My girlfriend took me here on a week night for my birthday so parking wasnt bad at all.  The place is awesome.  its real small and intimate, the service was great, and the food was facking delicious.  I really enjoyed being there and you dont feel like youre in the mission anymore.  i guess thats the beauty of all the great bars and restaurants in the dilapidated homes of the mission because you dont feel like youre in the mission anymore.

Skip on dessert because bi rite is right down the block!

HIT IT HARD MY FRIENDS.
author: JD B.

description: I was totally Disappointed with this Over Priced place. A Big Ripoff.  They call the appetizers "Family Style". What a Joke.  I live in NYC, I don't know what kind of families they have in SF, but I can see they don't eat much.  I should have taken a pic of the dishes, at I would have had a good laugh back home I went with my wife and son and his fiancé and I really felt I was robbed.  I even shared the main course with my wife and the bill still came out to $285.00 and I left there feeling hungry.  I have spent more than that on many occasions, but I always felt I got my monies worth, this place I left feeling hungry and robbed.  I truly hope I can convince one person Not to waste their money at this place and then I would feel some satisfaction for how I felt taken advantage of.  Please avoid this, as they say, Hip Trendy, Overpriced and the So So food at best and Trust me. This is NOT A FAMILY STYLE Place.  I must say, this felt good to express my dissatisfaction on yelp. I guess this was my only recourse
author: Rich L.

description: Overrated, hyped. The pasta and appetizers are good, but certainly not exceptional. We had a weird experience with the service. The servers were pretty nice most of the time. After the meal when we asked for the check, gave our cards and then instead of the server returning the charged card by placing it on our table, he threw it onto our table. Landed with a big thud. Poor experience..
author: Anand V.

description:
This restaurant rarely disappoints. In fact, it's right nearby our house and when we try out other restaurants in the same price range, we always wonder why we bothered to leave our block. I especially like that they often have space for walk-ins in their bar area. For the anniversary of the restaurant in November (14th?) they serve roasted chestnuts to the masses. We had a lovely conversation with a chef called Jack as he served up chestnuts from a portable BBQ outside on that chilly evening. 

Their pastas are made by hand, and are excellent. Our household favors their rustic salad with bacon and pecans, Unti Syrah, and profiteroles. Even their spaghetti (plain ol' pasta in a red sauce) is incredible.
author: Heather D.

description:
I've been here, two or three dozen times and I'm never disappointed! 

I believe this restaurant has the best pasta I have ever had, and I am not easy to please when it comes to food.   Bonus points on the nights when Delfina is celebrating their anniversary (which lasts 6 nights) and they whip out the white truffles to sprinkle on select dishes.

The waitstaff is very knowledgeable and is always ready to offer great recommendations on food and wine.

This is the best of the best!
author: dianthe h.

description:
We ate here a week ago on out trip to SF.  They were prompt with our reservation and the table for $ was ready when we got there!
First off, very cozy place with nice decor and great ambiance!
To kick the night off, I got peach Bellini which was very delicious:)
The menu at the first site didn't seem all that exciting, but don't let that fool you!
****** Cheese plate was divine, it had 5 different cheeses + toasted almonds + eucalyptus honey
******Roasted chicken was excellent, very juicy and flavorful + mashed potatoes with olive oil.  The reduction that the chicken is served with is unbelievable!!!
******Steak was served with the BEST french fries EVER! Rosemary + sage french fries were mouth watering!
****** for dessert we had panna cota and chocolate souffle cake......they both were luxuriously tasty!

Service was EXCELLENT, very friendly and attentive.
We had a great time and can't wait to go back!
author: Nadia M.

description:
With so many reviews I don't know what I can say that hasn't already been said....

Grilled Calamari is a must for an appetizer!! The duck was delish and the spaghetti was perfectly al dente. The menu is seasonal, so I'm not sure which dishes stay and which go (or if it's just the sides that get swapped)??

Service was incredible friendly and not over bearing. Seating is very "close" so not a place for children or that one friend of yours that doesn't understand "6-inch voices".

What folks are saying about the bread is DEFINITELY true, you will for sure be asking for 2nds...or 5ths =oP
author: Rana A.

description:
I gotta trust my Gut more.

Delfina is a matrix of foodie buzz. My friend - in CULINARY school, no less - has raved about it for years. I live 2 blocks away and we've tried to get a table in the past but had to wait weeks and would always give up.

Yet, with all this momentum, I held off...I even partook in its lower-level offspring, Pizzeria Delfina, before venturing to the Mother Ship - and I'm not even a Pizza Person! Wherefore, then, originated this reticence?

Because as a rule, the more buzz, the more wary I become. For me, the analogy is when a startup buys schwag and gets lots of press before it has revenue. The press and the aura take on a life of their own, and the real deal is almost destined to disappoint.

Enter Delfina The Elder. My friend and I at *last* procured a reservation last week. The first sign was good: we were able to seamlessly move the 8:30pm slot to 6:30pm (or WAS this good?). The rest was, well, ok.

The best part was the appetizer: yummy brussel sprouts with bacon done up with just the right amount of seasoning and moisture. We agreed this was the zenith of the experience. While the entrees were good, they didn't blow us away: he got duck with pomegranates, I got chicken with wild mushrooms. My chicken sauce was great but they had a real issue with substituting the potatoes with chard (as in, they wouldn't, despite serving both on the side once I acquiesced to order chard as an extra which, btw, was underwhelming in its own right). His duck was good but the pomegranates were inadequately supplied, really leaving you wanting more.

A service nit: they took a bit too long to bring us our entrees, they didn't ask my friend if he wanted another half-bottle of wine (he would have had one if they'd asked), and they failed to clear off the table in between servings, leaving us to our own crumby demise.

So, good food but hardly worthy of the hype I associate with this. Shame on me for not sticking with the Ugly Stepchild, Pizzeria Delfina. Time to go back to write a fresh review of THAT!
author: Diane B.

description: My adorable, trendy bearded waiter made me laugh with witticisms while I savored beautifully cooked fare. Service, food, everything: fabulous.
author: Kate G.

description:
This place is a foodies' dream place. Never much of a wait for lunch, but be prepared for a nice long wait for dinner. Once you are in, get ready to eat from some of the most original meal combos you've ever encountered, from cubes of watermelon, drizzled with goat cheese and pepper flakes, to the tricolor salad, and mouth watering stuffed shells. Don't forget to try their special pizza, which seems to vary daily. The wood oven flavor baked in will leave an indelible impression for days and make you commit to a prompt return. 

Wait staff is always enthusiastic and on a warm day you can sit outside and people watch. Head next door for an espresso to cap off a perfect meal.
author: Frank B.

description:
Best Italian meal I have had in a long time.  We went with my Father-in-law who is Italian and he loved it so much he started comparing it to food from when he was a child.  
We started with the calamari and the warm olives.  Both were excellent. The lemon peel pieces in the calamari gave the dish such a fresh flavor.  Two  of us had the spaghetti.  Simple yet delicious.  Make sure to ask for bread so you can eat with the pasta.  I tried some of the prosciutto ravioli- I wasn't a fan.  Wine & beer list offered great choices.  I had a glass of Barbera--which any legit Italian restaurant should offer by the glass.  I wouldn't have guessed that a dessert could outshine anything but it did! The apple tarte with cinnamon gelato was exceptional. 
We ate here on a Wednesday night and it was packed, so make a reservation. The hostess was rude but you can easliy ignore her and have a great meal here.
author: Beelz D.

description:
Great place to go. I took my friend here for an early birthday celebration. 

i had the duck and it was amazing i didn't really like the pickled cabbage but the duck part was amazing. it was very tender and juicy and the skin was cooked so that it was crispy. it was really good. i also tried the risotto that was also very good. it was perfectly creamy. we didn't have have desserts because we went to the bi-rite creamery which was amazing. (see that review)

the ambiance was very loud. and i didn't like how we sat very close to the next table there was probably only a few inches between us. also the music in the restaurant was very loud. we had to talk over the music and we were only a few feet away.
author: Steven N.

description:
My friend's ex-boyfriend used to call this place (quick hide the kids) a "panty-dropper."  He said there were a few 5-star restaurants that you could take a girl to on say the second date--that girls would be so impressed by, that you (the guy) could "close the deal" early.  It was that kind of brilliant insight that made their relationship so wonderful; and why they are no longer on speaking terms.
But his Neanderthal thought pattern does have something to it.  This is definitely the kind of date restaurant that impresses women, not just because it is a little costly, but because it is really high quality. I have only been here once.  On a date of course with my last boyfriend. 
It is always busy on Fridays and Saturdays and you always have to wait for a while. I had the calamari and the gnocchi which were as good as either of those dishes can get.  With the high energy of so many daters and such great food, you really do feel filled with life after eating here.  And yes, you do feel much better about the guy who brought you here--it is very pre-frontal cortex. 
I would definitely love to come here again some time.
author: Nikki K.

description: Conveniently across the street from bi-rite stands this semi-classy pizza spot. Had the Salsiccia. Pizza was delicious but was a bit pricey. good service; very friendly and willing to help.
author: Russell I.

description:
Hadn't been to Delfina in years and found that it continues to offer well-prepared food in a warm atmosphere with really gracious service. I had the saddle of rabbit with a glass of Langhe and it was exactly what I'd hoped for.

This place deserves its crowds, and I was especially pleased to see that kids were welcomed. The service, I have to emphasize, is a model of what I hope for when I plop down $45 on a meal.
author: Denny S.

description:
Delfina, Delfina - San Francisco

 Some restaurants, modest though they seem, are just about perfect. Their humility hides their brio. In San Francisco I can think of no better example than Delfina, a lovely, sunny, airy Italianate restaurant set in the somewhat scruffy Mission District. There is little showy about the space, although it is pleasing and airy, but the plates are modestly priced show-stoppers. 

 I ordered Warm Ceringola Olives, meaty, green nuggets swimming in rustic olive oil, served with warm crusty bread (perhaps baked by the iconic Tartine Bakery next door?). Tonight San Francisco revealed its Mediterranean climate which these olives matched degree for degree.

 The olives were followed by a creamy cauliflower soup with paprika oil drizzled on top and cumin-scented croutons. The soup was redolent of flowerets, but needed the kick that the paprika and cumin provided. It was an exceptionally pretty bowl.

 Delfina's Hay and Straw Tagliarini with English Peas, Pecorino, Raw Egg Yolk, and a touch of Pancetta (or its moral equivalent) was as lush as one might imagine a spring plate could be. The green and white pasta was nettles and spinach (?). The richness of the cheese, cream, and egg played perfectly with the peas, creating a modernist carbonara. 

 They also serve a superior Blood Orange Prosecco.

 All in all, a splendid moderately priced spring meal. Bravo.
author: Gary F.

description: The service was great and very down to earth.  Their bread was delicious.  I can just come here for their bread which is from Tartine's bakery.  We ordered their steaks with fries.  The steak was good but the fries was soggy.  I didn't love their spaghetti, it was OK considering it was $15 for noodles.  We also ordered their roasted chicken with mash potatoes.  It was good, not dry.  Everything was OK to good, not great!
author: L T.

description: Consistently terrific food + service.     Never go wrong basics (almonds, salads, spaghetti), great and manageable Italian wine list, and thoughtful menu rotations.
author: jon s.

description: Best pasta I've ever had. Very friendly staff and pleasant atmosphere.
author: Joe S.

description: I don't know, honestly I thought this place was way over priced for pretty mediocre food.  We had one course that was delicious, some sort of home made mozzarella with peppers for an appetizer.  The rest was pretty forgetful, since I don't even remember what we had!  The fish course was too fishy (old) and over cooked (dry).  The pasta course was not as spicy or garlicky or fresh as I like.  The wine, desserts and cheese were all great and service was good for a busy friday night. The ambiance was very nice too.  Overall, just too pricey for the level of cooking.
author: edith g.

description:
I haven't been back to Delfina's in quite a few years, so 2 wks ago, M and I met up with my sis there for dinner while we were in town.  The service is still great, the food same as what I remembered - great.  The wine selection - pretty good.  

The bread - from Tartine and yes we ate it all.  It's almost a crime not to.
I tend to not order calamari ever unless they're grilled, and these were perfect, sitting on a bed of arugula and white bean.   
The sauteed chard - I could eat this with every meal.  But an extra squeeze of lemon would have made it just that much better.
Chicken liver crostini - my sis and I both devoured them as the pate tastes exactly like the way my mom makes it -- DELICIOUS!!  :P
M had the tagliatelle - I stole some off his plate and shared some of my short ribs.  They weren't exactly "falling off the bone" but delicious nonetheless.  My sis, not a big meat eater, opted for the tuna, which was done perfectly.  

Everything was great....except for the fact that I think I cracked a molar on an olive pit that I left on the edge of my plate and mistook (in the dim lighting and engrossed in conversation) for the garlic that was with the sauteed chard!  Completely my fault but yikes, not exactly the kind of fond memory I want of Delfina!
author: Kathy H.

description:
Had dinner here with a girlfriend of mine....this place and the pizzeria(next door) were packed on Sunday evening. 

-Grilled Fresh Calamari--highly recommend!--but there isn't actually very much calamari, more beans(which are good too)
-Squid ink pasta with Uni--my favorite dish of the night! Pasta was cooked to perfection and the uni was fresh!
-Roasted Chicken--it's chicken...but the mashed potatoes with olive oil was delightful
-Panna cotta--one of the best I've had

Make reservations, come early to get parking and leave with a happy stomach! :) 

Next time, I'll have to try the spaghetti.
author: Stef H.

description:
Pretty much some of the best pasta I have ever had, and I am PICKY about noodles. After numerous attempts to secure a reso (which was completely our fault - we always tried to get one on the day-of...not recommended!), we finally were able to try Delfina this past weekend. Considering this is Rachael Ray's "favorite" restaurant in SF, I had my doubts. However - this place is hands down, awesome. Great pasta - after two dishes, I wanted to order more if our tummies could fit it - fab roast chicken, really nice atmosphere. The only semi-dings are the parking (non-existent....seriously) and the caviar app (it was good but not great). 

You must, must, must order pasta here. You can't go wrong with any of their pasta dishes. They unfortunately did not have the pork sugo when we went, but the lamb ragu was still amazing. The spaghetti with plum tomatoes - it is absolutely delicious. I love when the simplest dishes are done so well, you can't stop smiling while chewing. Spaghetti is totally a must!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
Amazing food. Had a great time on both my visits thus far.
Only disappointment ideas been my server. Unfortunately the same one on both occasions - a dry, unhappy, I am never going to smile no matter what you say type of lady.
Also wish they would let you get a pizza from their pizzeria as an appetiser even if with a slight premium attached.
Can't wait to visit again but will ask for another server...er table.


Update 12/2012
So fixed the server issue -- had a really nice one this time that served our large table of 8 fairly well. But now the food was so so. Had the tuna for my entree and it was 4/10. Overcooked and just blah. Another friend had tuna as well and she said it was one of the most average entrees she has had. We had a couple of the pastas as appetizers/2nd courses and they were still decent but not as amazing as the last time. So I am downgrading from 4 to a 3 star......consistency is key you know....and food well food always has to be top notch to be a 4/5 star restaurant, no?
author: Neil B.

description:
Wow, perfect Cali Italian.  I'll be honest, I was skeptical going into here because of 1. all the hype about it  2. the staff looked like a hipster doofus bus dropped them off.  But I was wrong on both counts.

The food was simply terrific.  From the burrata cheese app (I give A16 the best, Berrata the next, and then here...btw, A16 is some of the most over-hyped worst/bland Italian meals I've eaten at but I'll give them credit for that 1 app), to the salmon, to the risotto. The salmon was baked, but they put this amazing sweet corn on top.  Now the risotto...i LOVE a good risotto.  This came out neon pesto green, but then I took a bite and it floored me.  Amazing, creamy, perfectly cooked...and this mushroom topping on it, what's in that sauce!  We had a side of polenta,  but it was too rich and that was the only thing we didn't finish.  Desert was a tasty citrus pana cotta.  

Total price about including a 1/2 bottle of wine was $120 w/o tip.  Perfect meal, and I'll be back for sure...finally another Italian to add to my list (Berretta, Antica Trattoria, Alpina Osteria).  Another plus: Bi-rite creamery is across the street!

Line for the pizza shop next door was insane...we'll have to try this out because I trust this place, and the pizza looked great from the ones I saw.
author: A A.

description:
Had an enjoyable dinner with attentive service. Beautiful warm country bread to start. Loved the grilled fresh calamari, so tender with a nice smoky flavor. The skewers of chicken livers were splendid. Got the hanger steak but had to turn it back because it was tough. The staff was gracious and we got the pork arrosto instead which was enjoyable. Also had the delicious roasted chicken that came with a mound of mashed potatoes on the side. For desert both the profiteroles and the panna cotta were heavenly. 
This was a meal to remember and I will be happy to come back again.
author: Bill B.

description: Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in SF. The spaghetti is da bomb; worth its salt. I'm amazed how such a seemingly simple dish can be so good. I usually order the appetizer sized portion (so I can order other dishes)  then regret not having ordered the entree sized one. The sauce for the roast chicken is also one of the best things I have tasted. This place gets crazy busy especially on weekends so best to go for extra early or late dinner. Also ask for waiter's recommendations ; I would not ordinarily have ordered the dishes they suggested based on the descriptions in the menu but they turned out great.
author: Evilyn H.

description:
One of my favorite pizza places in SF. Fantastic, reasonably-priced artisan-style thin crust pizza. I love their classic margherita as well as their panna pie, which has a superb cream-based sauce.

Tip: If you don't feel like waiting in line to sit, call ahead to order take out and bypass the invariably long line.
author: Bradley T.

description:
Came here with my wife and a friend visiting from Germany. I was able to get a reservation just a few days ahead of time, which was an unexpected treat. I wish they'd sign up for OpenTable though, instead of having to call.

We started with an order of beef carpaccio, which was lovely. It had a strong (but not too strong) vinaigrette and a cabbage salad underneath. It was the perfect appetizer with our bread. (Also love that the butter for the bread had salt on top. So yummy!)

My companions ordered the salmon in fig leaf (looked good, didn't try it) and the seared duck with figs (tasted, was very good) with a side of polenta (very good). I had the rosemary tagliatelle with guinea hen ragu (like a bolognese sauce) and it was really wonderful. The portions were adequate but not huge, which is also nice.

For dessert, my wife had the chocolate torte which was very rich and delicious with strong chocolate flavor. I had the lemon verbena buttermilk panna cota which was the total opposite of the torte -- it was light, clean, and refreshing. 

This was a great restaurant and I would gladly come here on my own or bring other out-of-town guests.
author: Kellie P.

description:
I'm surprised by some of the sub-4 star reviews, because I couldn't disagree more. My wife and I hadn't been to Delfina for a couple of years, but we recently returned from Italy and it was my 50th birthday, so we wanted to eat at modern Italian restaurant that we knew was good. Everything was triple-wow; better than we had remembered from our previous visit, and we didn't have any better meals in Italy than we had here. 

I saved the menu so we know exactly what we had. We started with the Crostini Misti - a perfect trio with squab liver rustico, cavalo nero-pecorino, and white bean-bottarga. It seemed like a small meal in itself. I followed with the heirloom tomato salad with a delicious ricotta and pane bucato. It easily beat the Caprese salads I loved to eat so much in Italy. 

For the main course I wanted to order the slow roasted pork shoulder (after seeing it brought to the next table), but since my wife ordered it, I went for the Paine farm squab served with ceci strasciacati, mustard greens, and rosemary-roasted grapes. We've eaten at many top flight restaurants like Masa's, Gary Danko, and Michael Mina, but I don't think I've ever had a better tasting bird than this one. The sauce, tender and flavorful meat, and accompaniments were all perfect. The pork shoulder was also terrific. I didn't save the desert menu, but we had some type of chocolate cake with a luscious moist center.

The bustling and lively, but still cozy ambiance was perfect. It amazed us that the place was already almost completely full at opening time (5:30PM), the only time we could get a reservation. Also the service was just right - timely and friendly. 

My only gripe is that they could add a few more lower price options to the wine list. When we return we're going to try their pastas, which sounded delicious and beyond the ordinary fare.
author: Stan B.

description:
This is one of those times when I'm glad I only have two fans on yelp (Hi Mark and other mystery follower) because otherwise not loving Delfina would get me a lot of hate mail. 

I came here with my uncle and a friend of mine a few months ago. I had actually wanted to go to Pizzeria Delfina next door, but my uncle took one look and said, "I come here from NY and you're taking me to a pizzeria?" There's no arguing with a Long Island accent, so we went to Delfina instead where, surprisingly, we were seated almost immediately with no reservations. 

The food was fine but didn't live up to the hype. I've had better Italian in SF, which is not the best city for Italian food. (Firenze by Night is far superior). We ordered an appetizer of warm olives. They were marginally better than the olives I buy in the refrigerator section at Trader Joe's. The salad was fine. And the pasta was tiny. That's all I remember. For years now, restaurants have served like 3 ravioli in a serving--but at least those are giant ravioli. It looked like my dish was plated to make it seem like there was more food than there actually was--I remember using the reverse technique when I was a kid and didn't want to finish my breakfast. Delfina was as convincing at making the claim that my entree would satisfy me as I was the time I hid my scrambled eggs on the floor (we didn't have a dog). We were all so hungry that instead of getting dessert there--we could only imagine how miniscule the portions would be--we went to another restaurant and ordered more food.
author: Susan S.

description:
Vernita called to make reservations for 6:30pm or 7pm. She was told they only have 5:30pm or 9something. We took the 5:30pm.

Oh my gosh! It was practically empty until 7:30pm. We sat in the restaurant while a few others sat at the bar. That was kinda irritating to change our plans and find they weren't busy at all.

They also open for dinner at 5:30pm and they didn't open their doors until then.. Waiting 5 minutes in the cold feels like forever.

Delfina is on the 2009 7x7's 100 things for their Pork Sugo (#11).. yet because they change their menu daily, it wasn't available. However, they do have a few staples like their chicken and steak. We were disappointed that their Pork Sugo wasn't a staple as well.

It's a lovely restaurant. Dim, festively decorated for the holidays.. They brought water to our table along with a frosted carafe of water. The server told us about the specials, brought us 2 types of bread and some butter. One of the breads was from Tartine Bakery(on the corner of the same block) and no kidding, it's fucking great bread. Fresh baked bread from Tartine is also on 7x7's 100 list (#25).

So, Vernita and I split our food. We ordered the Wild Nettle Ravioli and the Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken. The Ravioli was brought out on split plates. You can taste the freshness.. like they make their own pasta and everything... filled with ricotta and walnuts.

Our server then brought out the chicken on a hot plate with 2 plates for us to split and mashed potatoes. The mushrooms really complimented it. I didn't really care for the mashed potatoes that came with it. I just prefer more texture to my mash than the uniform creaminess. 

All and all, it's a nice sit down restaurant. We had great service. The food was great.

4 stars.
author: O M G.

description: Italian food exquisitely yet simply prepared with superb ingredients. Our server was more than happy to explain items on the menu to us without any judgement or condescension. It was casual yet classy.
author: Colleen D.

description: Pizza is amazing. Ambiance is alway hectic and loud but super fun and courteous! Would totally recommend and visit again and again
author: Romina T.

description: Oh my god. Had no idea pasta could be this amazing. Don't think I need to say much else, this place rules. Also great Italian wine selection.
author: Rad S.

description: We were walking by and happened to stumble upon this little gem! The air was filled with oven-baked goodness, so we followed our noses in. The greeter was very nice and had us seated right away during peak dinner hours (surprising for SF dining). The place is quite big but the tables are all very close to each other...At one point, I watched an older man try to scoot from the booth out between two tables and there was only about 8" of space between each table. It was a bit uncomfortable, but luckily we were seated on a nice corner table a bit less crowded. I also felt like the decor/atmosphere was a bit lacking. Nothing very unique or memorable about it. And it didn't really seem to match the type of food offerings.. Which felt mismatched. The food was really good -- we ordered their version of a spaghetti carbonara, which was rich and hearty. We also got the veal saltimbocca which was also very well prepared. However, I'm not sure that out of all the "good food" we had, anything really stood out as *exceptional* -- I definitely had a great time and enjoyed the food, but I'm not sure if anything was particularly memorable. Hence, the 4 stars instead of 5.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Great food and service but my God the prices of the wine are ridiculous.  My girlfriend and i both had the lasagna which was so rich in flavor and perfect. We also split a salad which it was nicely split in two plates by the chef, we also had the olives as starters and they are magnificent.  It was really crowded for a rainy day. Excellent just lower down the wine prices a bit heh?
author: Vanderbird V.

description:
Pasta & Sauce fail.

Their tomato sauce was so watery-- very bland.

There was no harmony between the noodles and sauce.

It was like eating fresh boiled noodles by itself with a side of watered down tomato juice....at a price that dents your wallet.
author: Cadence C.

description: a great italian/neo californian cuisine tucked in the mission district. An extensive wine list with great innovative dishes puts this place in the forefront of italian restaurants out there..The roasted lambchops and  and the spaghetti nero topped with uni pasta were cooked perfectly and the seasoning was spot on..the ambience was pretty chill but the noise level could get annoying due to the music blasting as well as the other tables are placed pretty close from each other..overall, great service and solid food prep gets this place a 4/5 judochops in my book.
author: Dustin G.

description: I went back to Delfinas last week. That place always rocks. The servers all seem to be having a great time and the service is impeccable. The food is always consistent and excellent and the interior is par.  The salads, tagliatelle, steak, brussel sprouts, deserts and pretty much everything else we have tried is so tasty and so right!
author: Annie A.

description:
We came for a lite dinner on a Wednesday night and decided to try Delfina for the first time! The place was still about 90% filled to capacity; ambiance was calming but not pretentious, the staff seemed genuinely upbeat, patient, and helpful! We didn't mind being seated along the counter; you get a panoramic view of the restaurant. 

Appetizer: Calamari Salad - this isn't your Olive Garden or other food chain wannabes. Don't be taken back by the 'rawness' appearance; it's fully cooked and Delicious!! 
Bread - Tasty, but it was served cold (probably on purpose - again, this isn't Olive Garden) and the butter was fantastic! 

Main Entrée: Spaghetti - Why just spaghetti? If an Italian place can't make descent spaghetti, then do you really want to eat here for Italian food? (Did I just answer my own question? Yikes!) The noodles could have been softer, but the sauce and overall taste was still authentic. 

Calamari, Spaghetti, efficient service and an upbeat atmosphere for $22.    Bargain.

A date that's on a diet and willing to split food portions.    Priceless.
author: D C.

description: I wouldnt go back.  My boyfriend and I were seating somewhat promptly, however, once we got to our table the experience worsened.  Our waitress was incredibly rude; she actually rolled her eyes at one point when my date was asking her questions about the menu.  She seemed annoyed that we werent ordering MORE food (as if an appetizer and two entrees wasnt enough) and grouchily attended us throughout dinner.  Did I mention it was Christmas Eve? Seems we had the grouchette waiting on us.  Good thing we could laugh about it later and continue on with our night, but the small portion of "okay" spaghetti was not sufficient enough to counteract the 'tude we encountered.
author: Katie D.

description:
I'm what some people might call a foodie. I really hate that term but I pretty much fit the mold. I Yelp, I Chowhound, I Tablehop. I'm on pretty much every email list you can imagine, from Daily Candy to Thrillist. And as a self proclaimed foodie I'm ashamed to admit that I had never been to Delfina until last night. What the hell was I waiting for?


 I had a fantastic dinner at Delfina last night with three friends. First off, the room is loud but not unbearable. One of the first things I noticed was the swarm of cute, hipster servers buzzing around the dining room. Our server was a sweet heart and totally on top of things from the get go.


 Here's a sample of what I tried:
Spaghetti, split as an appetizer - an excellent way for everyone at the table to try the pasta, since no one was going to order it as an entree. Cooked perfectly al dente, in a light, fresh tomato sauce
