The endive crab salad was crisp and heavenly with bright bold flavors that woke up our palates.  The scallops were firm and succulent, and the veal with trumpet mushrooms and jerusalem artichoke gratin unbelievably tender.

Delfina, you won me over completely.  I will stay true to you.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I read about this place in the Zagat guide and decided to give it a try. I made reservations for a Saturday night around eight. It took us about fifteen minutes to find parking. The restaurant was really busy. There were people waiting inside and outside. We had to wait about twenty five minutes for our table. The décor of the restaurant is very modern. Since this place gets really busy I would not suggest you come here for a romantic dinner date. The couple at the table next to us left before they got their food because they could not concentrate with all the noise and commotion in the restaurant. At least that is what they told the waitress. 

The food here is not the best I have ever had but is still pretty good. I really liked the sourdough bread that they serve. I ordered the Mint tagliatelle with chanterelle mushrooms and creme fraiche dinner. This dish tasted really good. The sauce had lots of flavor and was very creamy.  It was not very filling but the taste made up for the lack of portions. My friend ordered the Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini dinner. I tried it and thought it was ok. The sauce was kind of plain. It did not have the explosive taste like my meal did. 

The service here was great. Out waitress was very friendly and explained the menu to us in great detail. She made sure our drinks never got under half full. The prices are a little high for the amount of food that is served. My dish tasted really good so I was ok with the price but what my friend ordered was not really worth the money. That is the reason I gave this place a four star review instead of a five star. I think if I would not have tried my friends dinner I would have given this place a five star review but his meal really was average at best and the price was too high for the quality and quantity of the dish.
author: Craig R.

description:
Delfina will always have a place in my heart. It's where I went on my first date with my current BF :-) 

Oh - the food is FABULOUS. The pasta dishes are phenomenal - fresh, simple and delicious. I appreciate that the Chef incorporates seasonal produce to the menu.  I can easily get bored but Delfina and Quince are one of the few that can keep my interest and desire to come back. 

Wow the Italian Reds they carry really do compliment the entrees. 

I am not much of a dessert type of gal but when I am at Delfina I ALWAYS make room for it. I love the Chocolate Torta and (when in season) the Strawberry Gelato. The pastry chef is a magician when it comes to dolci -simple and pure in taste. 

The service was always good and attentive. Place can get loud on certain nights but that's part of going out in the Mission.
author: Veritas V.

description:
I give this place three stars.  But a particular dessert -- all by its lonesome -- grants it the fourth.

If you visit Delfina's website with your computer's volume on, you'll have an inkling as to the atmosphere.  It's loud and frenetic.  Service was superior, though. So as long as you don't have sweet nothings to whisper, you should do just fine.  The decor and ambiance is inviting, with low strung lights and modern touches.

The food was fine.  It wasn't bad; it just wasn't excellent.  I'm willing to reassess this on future visits but I can confidently state you can find just as good -- if not better -- food elsewhere, for cheaper.  I tried the salt cod mantecato with walnut oil and fennel seed flatbread per my server's recommendation.  It *was* tasty, it just wasn't well described. I was surprised by its presentation.  I also had the crimson grapes, gorgonzola, and almond salad.  There were 5 grapes in total.  They weren't particularly flavorful, but I was thankful for them.  The gorgonzola was all too meek and nowhere near plentiful. The salad was a resounding "meh." The brussel sprouts were well received as well as the celery root soup. 

What was mind-blowing and worth every future visit was the warm Scharffen Berger chocolate torta with olive oil gelato and Maldon sea salt.  And don't split it with anyone, either. Seriously. Things could end badly.  It's probably one of the top 5 desserts I've ever had in my life and easily ranks among the most innovative. I highly recommend you wear a blindfold and submit to chocolate & olive oil bondage.  Leave your dessert discretion at the door.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
After trying Delfina twice in the past two weeks with a large party, I think I have tasted everything on the menu. I don't know why this place is not a 5 star restaurant for more Yelpers, necessitating my review.

For starters, I enjoyed the grilled calamari with white beans, grilled sardines with fennel oil, and a baked ricotta on a fig leaf that was offered only one of the days. I feel that the primi was the best course with wonderful pastas including a 'don't miss' paccheri with sea bass, a rich tagliatelle with trumpet mushrooms and a spicy spaghetti with tomato sauce. I recommend having the primi pastas or gnocchi as available as 1/2 portions if you plan to have a meat course. I would also be happy just having a full order of pasta too. I personally really enjoyed the fowl dishes- quail with a creamy polenta and figs, and a perfectly cooked chicken with mash potatoes (simple but delicious). My only complaint is that on one evening my bass was overcooked on the edges.

For desserts, we enjoyed the lemon panacotta that jiggled like a young woman's breast and was cream heaven. I would pass on the profiterole.

For the wines, we really enjoyed the waitress suggestion of Petite Rouge Torrette and Movia Pinot Nero.





Panacotta.
author: Jeong K.

description:
Great atmosphere. Great food.

The only downside is the fact that it's in suburban area of the Mission district = no parking space around dinner time. I literally drove around for 30 mins before finding a tiny tiny spot. Should have taken BART or cab!
author: Ryo S.

description: Probably the best pasta in San Francisco...yes, including Flour & Water.  The food is excecellent...service delightful...atmosphere best described as full of energy ( yes, on the loud side, but conversation not difficult) . Whenever we're in San Francisco we always have a meal at Delfina, and fortunately we're here fairly often.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Delfina used to be one of my favorites in SF--a restaurant I could count on for good food and service.  No more.  Being the first to arrive at  7:25 for our 7:30 reservation, I squeezed up to the bar to order a drink and wait for my 2 other friends.  I finally managed to order a beer and watched the bartender open the bottle, set it down,but then completely forget about bringing it to me because he got distracted with another order.  I wished I could have gotten his attention or been able to reach way over for the beer myself.  I saw my friends arriving and signalled with my hand that I would be right over after getting my beer.  No such luck with the beer so I abandoned that effort completely, and just joined my friends near the entrance.  The 3 of us waited until 8 pm when the hostess apologized for the delay,saying everyone was taking their time with dessert, but could we please wait over by the bar and maybe have a drink.  "On the house?" my one friend suggested.  "No, I'm sorry I can't do that."  So we continue to wait another 10 minutes when a diffenent hostess meanders by and explains to us that because they were so busy "our" table had been given to another party who had been waiting longer than us.  Now we would have to wait, and so on and so on.  After about 40 minutes of this nonsense, without so much as a beverage offering on the house, the three of decided that this restaurant would have to wait its turn for good loyal patrons on a return visit --or not.
author: Paul S.

description:
I'm totally caught up in Obama fever.  Accordingly, I'm channeling the momentum from the Obama campaign into my review for Delfina:

Thank you Delfina.

Thank you to the diner to my right, my girlfriend, Kasey Fleisher.

Over one and a half hours that we enjoyed our meal, we have seen the people of Delfina proclaim that the time for good Italian food has come.  There were some people who doubted Matthew H.'s desire for good Italian food, who said that he was just hungry in general,with no thought about the quality of the Italian food he ate.  

Well, tonight, the cynics who believed that what began in the kitchen of Delfina was just an illusion were told a different story.  

When I hear that we can't get a reservation at Delfina, I think about all of the people sitting in there enjoying their food.  Don't tell me we can't have delicious Italian food.

Yes, we can.  Yes, we can get reservations.  Yes, we can.

Yes, we can sate this hunger.  Yes, we can seize a table at Delfina.  
Yes, we can seize our future. And as we leave this great restaurant with a new wind at our backs and we take this journey across this great country, a country we love, with the message we carry from the plains of the Inner Sunset to the hills of Bernal Heights, from the Oakland desert to the South San Francisco coast, the same message we had when we were up and when we were down, that out of many, we are one; that while we breathe, we will hope.

And where we are met with cynicism and doubt and fear and those who tell us that we can't, we will respond with that timeless creed that sums up the spirit of the American people in three simple words -- yes, we can.

Thank you Delfina.  I love you... and especially your buttermilk panna cotta.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I've enjoyed dinner at Delfina numerous times.  It's always excellent, food, drink, service.  Perfection.

This review however is for dessert only.  

Went here with another dessert loving fool, and had an assortment of treats.  Cheese with dates, panna cotta, chocolate crazy something, and then sweet wine and port, which were perfectly paired with each.

Can you say flavor heaven?  Yum.  I think next time I'll skip dinner altogether.  Left feeling slightly tipsy, silly, and full of happy giggles which was probably all the sugar and vino.

Delizioso!
author: James M.

description:
The pizza and the pasta at Delfina were fabulous! By far one of my favoirte mission restaurants. I live in the marina- but make the trek across town to eat at Delfina. It is on my list for good San Francisco italian. 

Also- staff is friendly and the wine list is fabulous- soooo how can you go wrong? 

Can't wait to get back here again for another fabulous dinner!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Um, hello?  Is anyone on the line?  Is there a dial tone?  HELLO?!

I have been an active yelper for three years.  I am motherhumping ELITE as far back as 2005, bitches.  AND I have NOT written a review for this restaurant.  I mean, it's the craziest shit EVA cause I have been cruising along for three and half years, yes that's right, assuming that I have ALREADY written a review for Delfina.  

I believe this is actually the FIRST nice restaurant I ate at in the City after I moved here in January of 2003.  I've eaten here countless times, including for birthdays (my own and others), random Tuesday night indulgences (that's a shout to my friend's Kritter and Jackie) and with my parents on Rental Visit Weekend.  

Well, I guess we can all surmise from the list of events and outings had at this restaurant what my position on it is.  IT Motherfucking RULES.  Yes, and when I say RULE I mean RULE people.  

This weekend I had a lovely bday dinner here, seated early on the back patio, the weather was perfect and the food even more so.  I had a Barbera by the glass that was delightful. 

We started with a pulled mozzerella plate with mini green peppers marinated in a tomato, uh, vinagrette.  Wow, PEOPLE can we sent out tails on the chefs for this place?  Just stalk them at the local FM, cause I would never figure out to buy those things and lovingly plate them with spicy tomatoes next to pulled mozz.  UGH.  It is so frustrating!!  Then again, I guess that's why I'm the lawyer and they're the chef.   I digress. 

My date had a lovely salmon entree with pureed fresh basil on a corn mixture that was to die for.  Someone had to "pardon my reach" oh, say, 7 - 10 times.  I had the fresh gnocci, which, by the way, I generally don't like but the hottie lipstick lesbian that sat us was tickling my fancy so I was like, uh, hu, whatever you say sexy lady.  AND SHE WAS RIGHT, the mini cherry tomatoes had me at hello. 

This place is an instant mouth orgasm encased in hipster coolness that doesn't even wane to the lame.   Thanks Bday Gods for delivering me to this restaurant yet again.  AAAAWWWMEN.
author: Claire C.

description:
So after over a year of passing by this place almost daily, I finally went for dinner at Delfina last Wednesday night. 

To my suprise, service was EXCELLENT- friendly hostess and very attentive waitstaff.  Our server was patient, down-to-earth, and seemed excited about our menu choices (always a good sign). The food overall was pretty good in terms of freshness and quality, and the prices seemed reasonable.  I was a bit disappointed with the choices for a main entree, I was hoping to get some lamb or fowl, and there wasn't any.

We started with Gioia Burrata- cream filled mozzarella apparently- with heirloom tomatoes and basil oil, warm Castelvetrano Olives, then Risotto with summer squash and squash blossoms. There was some kind of citrus peel in the risotto. It had a lot of complex flavors and the rice was cooked but still al dente.  Very tasty.
The spaghetti ordered by my dinner partner, though, was disappointing.  It seemed overpriced and like something I would cook when I have nothing else to eat at home.

For dessert: Warm Tcho Chocolate Torta with Olive Oil Gelato and Maldon Sea Salt. It was SALTY. And I liked it. Yum yum yum!!! I would go back just for that.

They do need to cut down on the number of tables crammed into each other, though. It was almost family-style and I had a few rear-ends wipe my wine glass. 

All in all, I went home stuffed and wanting to go back.
author: Berlin B.

description:
I declare the owners of this place... in need of some etiquette lessons!" 

Food: Good
Ambiance: Interesting-- not great, but not bad
Service: Choppy
Vegetarian Selection: Okay
Owners: Need to be aware of their surroundings

Okay... it's anniversary night and we have heard so many wonderful things about Delfina... and since Chez Spencer was closed... we figured we'd see what the fuss was all about.

We get there a few minutes after our reservation and the hostess was very nice and gracious and sat us outside.  

Then the worst possible thing in the world that could possibly happen happened.

The owners and their 3 or 4 year old daughter sat right next to us.  And with them they brought intense stress upon the waitstaff and an aura of tension and disatisfaction.

Thus began an obnoxious turn for the worst.  The daughter is very cute, but she's a kid.  A kid with a sense of entitlement. This is a restaurant that's really not kid-friendly.  You'd think that perhaps the owners might have had a clue about that.  But they didn't.  And the kid did what kids do-- made kid noises, was restless, and spilled a glass of water that splashed our direction and some water hit our shoes.  The mother said nothing, the father did ask if any got on us, but no real apology was made. 

We're pretty easy going people, so we let that slide and attempted to enjoy the rest of the evening.  The food was good.  The bread fabulous, the salad very good, the french fries very tasty.

But by the time the main courses arrived, it was hard to judge because the mother-owner kept complaining about everyone who worked there-- from the hostess to the wait-staff to the chef. From that point on everything turned sour, thus tasted sour. 

One might think we were eavesdropping, but she was not at all discreet, and our table was literally about a foot from theirs.  Plus, she had made it quite clear that they were the owners (saying it several times and telling her daughter at one point "this is what it's like to own a restaurant") so of course she's going to bring attention to her table.

After they left, the restaurant seemed to relax.  It's unfortunate that the owners of a seemingly fabulous restaurant could be so clueless as to the effect they would have on the experience of the customers they want to keep.  

A note to all business owners: when you're in your store or restaurant, try to remember what it's like to be a customer/patron.  People WANT to like you.  If you come across bossy, entitled, and not gracious, people will be turned off.
author: Tahd F.

description:
Picked up starving daughter from the airport and asked her to think of what she wanted for dinner.  And I guessed right, she wanted Delfina.  And then, by the grace of St Jean, the spirit of parking, there it was, a spot directly across the street opened up like the sea in front of the Israelites.  (It was friday night after all at 7:30).  And as we parked I said, "we will never get in".

I was wrong.  They had seats at the counter facing the main dining room.  This was probably the third of fourth time I have eaten there and each time has been solid.

Starving daughter feasted on the hangar steak.  I was knocked out by the grilled calamari with white beans and opted for a simplicity, pasta with tomato sauce.  Right on the money.

But for bi-rite we would have had dessert.  

As we left daughter looked around the busy room and said "everyone looks so normal here".  

Normal and happy.
author: Jules K.

description:
I don't think this place could disappoint.  Service was top notch.  Our waitress put up with my dirty jokes.  Blood orange bellinis hit the spot before moving on to the beef carpaccio, chilled asparagus salad and sausage served with quince.  
Then we ordered the grilled ahi, papardelle with duck sugo, and wild nettle risotto.  
Shit you not, it was all good.  Dessert was the profiteroles with coffee gelato and also the  Scharffenberger cake.
I'm getting wet (in the mouth) just reminiscing about that meal.......
author: Joyhan S.

description:
After chillaxin' at Dolores Park with a good friend, we were pretty hungry.  She suggested Delfina and I was all for it.  She's such a sweetheart to remember that I was lactose intolerant but I felt adventurous.  Surprisingly, the food didn't do anything to my tummy!  

Then again, I had the Tricolore Insalata, warm olives, and this breaded fresh mozzarella deep fried concoction that was pretty damn good.  I also tried my friend's Margherita pizza.  It was all pretty delicious.  The cute gay waiter was my favorite (he kept calling me sweet names - ahhh!).  He was way nicer than the waitress we had (God I wanted to throw my olive pits at her rude a$$).  Overall, it was a nice place but it is a bit on the pricey side for what we had (-star).  Great people watching place if you get a table outside on a sunny day.  Parking is scarce (I mean, it is the Mission/Dolores Park area) so go green and Bart it to Delfina if a visit for you is a must!
author: Dorothy S.

description: Delfina continues to be one of the best restaurants in San Francisco. Excellent wine selection, always consistent, great service, great atmosphere, and awesome food.
author: Ryan B.

description:
I've only eaten here once but it was a 5* experience.  We were sidewalk dining @ the pizza joint.  

It was without a doubt the best pizza I have ever had in California.
I suspect that it is all time top three,  but like I said it has only been enjoyed once.

I felt so on that weekend this past summer.  William H joined us for the pizza- random meeting 85 miles from home.

I personally love the Mission.
author: Robi P.

description: The pasta portion looked small, but good things came in that small package!
author: Tobi X.

description:
My fav dessert ever: Bittersweet Scharffen Berger warm chocolate cake with creme Anglaise

...life really doesn't get any better
author: Thömas F.

description:
I am so pleased to give Delfina the rare 5-star review. They have remained one of SF's best contemporary Italian restaurants since they opened almost 10 years ago. I lived down the street on 18th and Guerrero during the buzz about the fancy new restaurant opening in my then-humble hood. Probably b/c the owners entered the space like friendly neighbors, they seemed to avoid the contempt saved for other local "gentrifying" restaurants like the Slanted Door. 

And they remain a huge asset to the City's dining options to this day. When out of town friends requested Italian food this weekend--I knew right where to take them. From the prosecco through the meal (where we ordered almost everything on the menu) to the cappuccino, Delfina delivered their finest. Beth, our server, is obviously passionate about what she does--she recalled everything without writing it down (this always blows me away, I have to write myself a note to remind me to go to the store, never mind what to get there!) and even checked to make sure our guest liked his barely-touched pasta dish (we were just talking too much). Delfina won "best wait staff" award a few years ago and it is clear why. 

The menu changes daily, so trust your server's suggestions, we loved the sides the best, actually--squash with cheese, perfect chard, big green beans cooked in bacon. So yummy we kept ordering second helpings! The entrees were of course awesome as well--rabbit with pine nuts, salmon cooked rare and served with green beans, and house made pasta. And I didn't help choose the wine, but I sure helped drink it--they offer a sophisticated selection of both Italian and Californian that pare perfectly with the food.  The simple but flawless panna cotta sealed the meal with a kiss. 

Here's to another decade of Delfina making the City even better for it's existence.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
I've only eaten at Delfina a couple of times because it's so hard to get reservations here.  The place is always packed on any given night and is named after the restaurant where Chef Craig Stoll worked while in Italy.  My most recent visit happened by chance.  My friend and I were looking for a quick bite to eat and headed to Pizzeria Delfina, where we were told we would have to wait 20 minutes for a table.  We ran next door and discovered that two seats had just opened up at the counter overlooking the main dining space.  What a stroke of luck.  

Food:  5 stars.  Craig Stoll, you're my hero.  If I could come here every night, I would (darn reservations!).  For appetizers, we had the sardines (which were perfectly fileted and delicious), and the gnocchi al ragu (heavenly in its simplicity).  For entrees, my friend had the sepia in nero (spaghetti in squid ink sauce), which I thought was fantastic even though I don't even care for squid ink.  I had the tender, savory pork shoulder.  The meal was not complete until we had the buttermilk panna cotta, complemented with caramel and pomegranate seeds (the flavors melded perfectly).

Service:  5 stars.  Service is comfortably relaxed and knowledgable about the menu.  Bonus points go to Anne Stoll for being so accommodating at the host stand (i.e. getting us a table immediately as a walk-in).    

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  There's a lot of nice things to look at (and I'm not talking about the decor), especially from the vantage point of the countertop.  The restaurant definitely gets an eclectic mix of good-looking people.  The decor catches your eye from the street with its modern industrial trendiness.  I understand that the "mattresses" on the wall help to muffle the sound, but couldn't there have been a more aesthetic way of doing that?  Also, I'd hate to be the unfortunate couple sitting at the lone table between the counter and the column separating the main room from the smaller bar area.

Hits:   Pork shoulder, pastas (including the gnocchi al ragu), buttermilk panna cotta.

Misses:  Reservations are difficult.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Oliveto, Acquerello, Quince, Perbacco
author: Keith C.

description:
I'm going to put an "I Heart Delfina" bumper sticker on my car. I don't care if it kills the resale value, certainly has to be better than a John Kerry sticker at this point. 

When I first moved to the city, I explored North Beach, determined to find the one Italian restaurant that would be "The One." Amongst all the stereotypically Italian restaurants, I found one that was small, had charm, good food, interesting owner back-story and was not a crawling sess pit of tourism. It was an original. My mind was set to commit. There would be no other. I was loyal, taking family there, dates, outta towners. I was married to that little place. Then I had the affair. Strolling down 18th, innocently enough, I spotted Delfina. It all happened so fast. First a glass of wine at the bar while waiting to be seated. Then the calamari antipasta, followed by a fresh salad, and ending with the pesto pasta. I'm hooked. 

A friend lives in the area. Had to drop something off to him and was ushered up to his apartment which is on the backside of Delfina. Wonderful smells wafted up from the kitchen. I said, "That smells amazing, I'm jealous." He said, "Oh dude, don't be, we smell that all the time. (eye roll) It gets a bit much."  Clearly he has it rough (wink, wink).

4 duckets for wonderful food in the Mish. 1 ducket for luring me away from ol' reliable in North Beach... BAD KITTY, BAD!!
author: Johnny C.

description:
When I first started to appreciate food and realized it was okay to pay extra for quality meals, I had always made it a point to eat at Delfina.  How I heard about it was back in my craigslist days where I'd research about top SF restaurants for special occasions.  Thread after thread, Delfina was always suggested right next to the likes of Gary Danko and Michael Minna.  That was about 2 years ago and I finally found some folks to take with me to Delfina.  My anticipation and excitement was finally fulfilled.

It's a casual spot -- no tablecloths, stools to sit on, waitresses wore whatever was not wrinkled that day, and the menu is printed fresh from the Xerox machine that day.

The waitresses are like the girlfriends you wish you could hang out with all the time.  Not just for the hookups at Delfina, but because they were genuinely sweet and gave shy quirky smiles when they approached you.  They'd come by and say "hello, what are you up to?" in their own waitressy ways though.

Our apps consisted of the Heirloom Tomato and Stretched Mozzarella Cheese.  Lemme tell you, that ball of mozz must have been squeezed out of the udders of a heifer that morning, because that intense freshness was so rich.  And in past mozz-y experiences they were often subtle in flavor, but this one had a nice sharp tinge to it.  Amazing to say the least.  We also got the Salt Cod Spread w/ Flatbread.  Great savory flavor from the soft cod spread.  I would have liked less salt on the flatbread as the fish was well seasoned already. 

I could go on about the 4 different entrees we each ordered.  Bottomline, all were extremely enjoyable.  Exceptional dishes was the flat egg noodle and lamb pasta special.  And the Roasted Duck with creamy polenta.  Even at first bite, I knew I was going to come back for repeat visits.

There's a great atmosphere here starting from the Dolores neighborhood to the cozy dining room.  The space is clean and the crowd is your equal, where everyone is there just to eat good food.

At the end of the meal our waitress asked if we had decided on dessert and oddly one of us asked "What time does Bi-Rite Creamery close??" and w/o blinking she said "10:00pm so you have about 10 minutes left..."  Wow!  That's helpful service there.
author: Chris T.

description:
I see a trend in the negative reviews here.  Let us dissect the dimensions (we can refer to this as the Delfina matrix):
1) the food is nothing to write home about
2) the service is horrible
3) the seating resembles an internment camp
4) the price is for ambiance.....that doesn't exist

So my experience fits this to a T.  We walked in, asked for a table for two.  We got stuffed in the patio.  That was ok, because inside seemed stuffy. 
Dimension 4: check.  
Dimension 3: check.  

When the appetizer arrived we were underwhelmed by the lack of imagination in the ingredients, presentation and preparation... slicing a few asparagi (grin) at an angle is hardly innovative.  
Dimension 1: check.

Our entrees arrived an hour after we ordered them.  The table that seated themselves after we ordered had their food far before we had ours.  We did not receive any explanation or apology.  
Dimension 2: check.

When the entree arrived, we found that Delfina has a tendency to err on the side of arrhythmia-inducing levels of fat on their meats.  Fat is good, morbidly obese livestock just isn't.  
Dimension 1: double-check

Very San Francisco: much hype, little substance.....restaurant 2.0
author: H C.

description:
Horrible service. This is one of those awful experience, one would never want to encounter. It was my birthday and my boyfriend made a reservation for 6 people at 10 pm, which was the only opening. When we called to add just one more person, they refused and cancelled the reservation. We were shocked, and appealed asking for some type of compromise -- e.g., seat us apart, squeeze us all in one table and we won't mind, but they said they could not accomodate us at all. Sorry, it's not our policy to have more that 6 people. Without any remorse she hung up.

Needless to say, we got reservations at Limon and had a wonderful meal. Great service, delicious food, and a very happy birthday.
author: crimson p.

description: My first experience with Delfina was a very pleasant one! I thoroughly enjoyed the menu and ambiance of the restaurant. I know that it's common in big cities to have little restaurants with limited seating but it was SO cold down there and it would have been nice to have more inside waiting room while we waited for a table. Other than that, the service was incredible and food was delish!
author: Leigh C.

description:
As a server, it can be a very oppressive and difficult thing when someone says to me, before I even get them water, "we have to be out of here by -fill in specific time constraint-".  It just makes for a tense time, though of course I like to hear it BEFORE the meal gets under way rather than during... anyway, I found myself on the giving end of that sentence a couple of fridays ago at Delfina, with tickets for the theater after dinner.  My server didn't even blink an eye, and as soon as she came back with water we had our order ready to go.  

3 courses in 1 hour and twenty minutes?  No problem.

Our server not only made the evening flawless, she coursed out EVERYTHING we ate, much to my surprise (just because it takes quite a bit of finesse from the server and the kitchen)... So we started with their Insalata di Campo - a collection of bitter greens with a pancetta vinaigrette and walnuts.  Our second course were grilled Monteray Bay Sardines... I believe with fennel?... Third were absolutely DELICIOUS prosciutto and rmarscarpone raviolis with a lemon butter sauce and parsley... Delicate (the best I've ever had) Halibut with melted leeks and fingerling potatoes followed... and finally the Hangar Steak, which was cooked to perfection.  

The wine list was amazing.  Mom had prosecco; I had Coenobium (a Trebbiano blend from Lazio) and then I believe a glass of Lagrein... a couple of espressos later and we were out the door.   

The service staff (from host to backwaiter) were all professional and friendly, and our own server was kind, knowledgeable, and knew her kitchen well.  The food was a revelation... I can't believe I live in the neighborhood and don't eat here weekly!  All I can say is that I look forward to many more dinners at Delfina!
author: Emily H.

description:
I have eaten at Delfina a couple of times, most recently this past Saturday night, and have always been happily satiated.  My date and I walked in around 8pm and were seated at the counter within a few minutes.  

We started with the chilled delta asparagus, which tasted fresh and delicious.  It came with a healthy dollop of prosecco zabaglione, which was the perfect creamy complement to the crispness of the asparagus.  I particularly enjoyed the subtle citrus notes in the dish. 

For our entrees, I ordered the butternut squash ravioli and my date got the spaghetti.  My ravioli was a treat to look at and quite sweet to the taste.  Our server grated what I'm pretty sure was a graham cracker cookie over my dish, which provided a nice bit of textural contrast.  The sauce was a very light and simple olive oil- I'm not sure what else was in it.  The spaghetti was wonderfully hearty, yet delicate and understated.  The fresh pasta was served perfectly al dente and the plum tomato and garlic sauce was very toothsome.

For dessert, we had a trine of tropical gelato - passionfruit, coconut, and one other type of sorbet which escapes me at the moment.  It was a light and heavenly end to the meal.

Delfina is great for consistent, Italian family-style cuisine with a gourmet flair.  I will definitely be back for more.
author: Shana F.

description: Great atmosphere and terrific wine list.  Food is incredible.  Had the lamb sausage, risotto, and duck.  Amazing quality.  Busy place, so be patient with the service.
author: Lil Y.

description:
I'm tempted to give Delfina 1 star, just to negate all the high ratings people have been giving it.

Are you f-ing kidding me?  In no universe imaginable is this restaurant 4 stars.  Impossible parking and young (read: inexperienced) wait staff aside, the food barely rates 2 stars, if that.  3 out of the 4 entrees were overly salty, each having the same salty rub over everything.  The duck was inedible, grossly overcooked and when we brought it to our waiters attention (as constructive feedback, not trying to get a freebie or anything) he said "The chef cooks it that way on purpose."  Really?  On what planet should duck be cooked to a dark grey, and be hard to cut?  The panna cotta that everyone raves about is nothing to rave about at all.  The flavor was overwhelmingly sour creamy or yogurty.  

Any Yelper who rated this 4 or 5 stars should automatically be discounted and all their reviews suspect.  For shame.  Never going back, and never recommending this to anyone.  Everyone's last comment in our party was "Why the F is this place always so packed?"
author: Junglist S.

description:
Delfina's been on my "list" of places to go for ages now, and I finally got there for some good birthday eatin'.  And I wasn't disappointed.  We managed to try a soup, two pastas, and a main course (all between two people--yeah, I was stuffed by the end).  

The soup was great--a light minestra with plenty of veggies and beans, and not too filling.  A good way to start off.  Then we had the guinea hen ragu and a special pasta that wasn't on the menu, ravioli stuffed with...a mix of greens I think.  I know dandelion was one of them.  Anyway I'm a huge sucker for ragu (just see my review for NOPA) and this one was awesome and so flavorful.  And the ravioli was amazing too, and so different from the ragu, since it was so nice and vegetable-y.  I actually liked the main course the least out of everything, which was spareribs over panzanella with ramps.  It was good, but the glaze over everything was a little too balsamicy for me.  Anyway, I would have loved to try dessert but at this point there was no way.

Another little touch I liked--even if you're getting wine by the glass, they bring the bottle out to your table and pour a taste before you decide.  Something you don't see very often!  And yes, they're packed all the time.  We couldn't get in until 9:30 on a Wednesday, so make a reservation early.
author: Leslie R.

description:
We arrived late, post Symphony, with no reservation, expectations were low.  But we needn't have worried.  Out trotted a pretty-nosed Prosecco very light and lively, then came a long-legged Valpolicello vivacious and salacious.  There were fishes and maybe rabbits and other creatures presented with skill and aplomb, but what I remember most is a slinky papardelle that danced on my tongue like an Orion slave girl. I think it ended with a full-bodied Port but I had been so ravished by all that came before, I can't be sure.

All I can be sure is that -- I will return.
author: Tom Y.

description:
It is really good, especially the pasta dishes... it is expensive but I think it is worth the price and there are two reasons for not giving them the 5 star treatments.  Yes, Parking!!! It was a pain.  Especially since their reservation is at 5:30pm or 8pm, otherwise, I would be able to park across the street which is available after 6pm.  Then it is the meat entrée, which I think it was just avg.  Here is what we have

Grilled Fresh Calamari with warm white bean salad - a good match with tender flavorful calamari.  The only other grilled calamari that I liked was from Crustacean in which their sauce is a tad over powering as compared to Delifna. 

Veal Sweetbreads with white wine, sage and prosciutto - if you have read my review, you know I am a big fan of sweetbreads, so there =)  Succulent sweetbread with the salty bite from the prosciutto and crispy sage. Heaven!!

Lasagne Vincisgrassi - thanks to the server's recommendation, I decided to try this dish and it was out of this world.  It now has replaced Pasta Carbonara as my new favorite pasta.

I have a bite of my friends' Fregnacce with Louisiana white shrimp and Spaghettini In Nero with sepia, uni and English peas. Both are good, I guess you can't go wrong with freshly made pasta.

However, where they lost me was the Hanger Steak and French Fries. I won't say it is bad, just didn't win me over.

Dessert, it is a tough choice since Delfina is right next to Bi-Rite Creamery, so we decided to venture out for ice cream instead.  Otherwise, would definitely try the panna cotta or the Meyer Lemon Semifreddo - which I don't see being offered in a lot of restaurant.

Will definitely go back and guess I will follow others' footstep and keep checking and drooling over the menu in the mean time!
author: Prascilla L.

description:
I was there only once and I'll never go back.


There was a cockroach crawling on my table and when my dad caught it and showed it to the server, she said, "Ahh, you have a little friend!" in an excited voice.

My mom said, "That is a cockroach" and all they did was comp our drinks.  

Pathetic.
author: Tori F.

description:
I first came here five years ago and I had forgotten in the interim how AMAZINGLY good it is here.  Just two gripes -- which are not major for me, considering I would come back in about a second:
1.  people, you canNOT serve prosecco in a regular wine glass!  the point of the champagne flute is not pretentiousness -- it just keeps the bubbly BUBBLY!  (This did not stop me from having a big glass of it at the bar and then sharing a bottle over dinner.)
2.  I, the queen of salt, found the sauce accompanying my fish to be too salty.  (The chicken, flatiron steak, and mashed potatoes, were, however, sex on a plate.  Or plates.  Because they came on separate ones.)

it better not be five years before I get to come back!  MMMmmmm.
author: Nat K.

description:
This place really is THAT good. It's totally worth it.  We could only get reservations for 9:30, and now I know why.

It has an upscale atmosphere without the pretension or stuffiness of many 'fine dining' establishments, which  is refreshing and soooo San Francisco.  I felt completely comfortable.  The food is also all spectacular.  Truly phenomenal. 

We had an exquisite experience from the food to the service to the wine to everything. 

My friend and I split a bunch of little starters, salads, soups and side plates.  
~Warm Olives
~Cauliflower Soup
~Asparagus and Parmesan
~Salmon with a small, crunchy salad
~Wild nettle tagliatelle with nettle puree and pinenuts
~Olive oil Mashed potatoes

each dish was delicious, divine and unique.  

Our server was also fabulous. She helped us pick out a 1/2 bottle of wine, she returned to recommend another wine by the glass, she coursed out our meal perfectly, and she even had the kitchen split most of our food onto two plates.  We never spent any part of the evening lacking drink or food... it was perfect.  Halfway through our meal we told our server we loved her, she smiled and said we made her night.. i think the feelings were mutual ;)

Anyways, I feel like everything I have to say has probably already been said. But I think I have found a new love.  

I will give this place a smiley face AND a "check plus" and several gold stars all around. 
awesome!

Update: 
Have been back again and again it was great.  I will certainly return for more.  I LOVE this place.
author: Shayna N.

description:
VEGETARIANS:  AVOID
BIRTHDAYS:  AVOID

Went there for my wife's 40th birthday -- mistake.  In spite of checking their menu the week before (looked promising), when we went there was all of one -- ONE -- meatless meal.  Even the salads were off-limits.  HELLO?? People, you're in SAN FRANCISCO where not everyone wants A STEAK IN THEIR SALAD.  

On a better note, the one vegetarian dish (tagliatelle with porcini mushroom) was quite good. 

And don't bother telling them it's your birthday.  They'll give you two micro-bite-sized croutons -- I mean, biscotti -- so small they can't even fit the single birthday candle on them.

Won't bother with them again.
author: TradeMark G.

description:
After 10 years in SF, I finally made my way to Delfina.  While my date and I had a very good, solid meal, it didn't live up to the legendary status it has attained.  

The calamari was the standout dish - not the fried squid you're expecting, but a wonderful and subtle sauteed thing with white beans and, well, it was awesome.

We both had the steak frites and it was good but not amazing.  It was what you would expect from a $26 hangar steak with some fried potatoes.  The brussel sprout side was pretty awesome, though.  We finished off with profiteroles and again - solid but not inspiring.
author: Matt S.

description:
a fantastic, rustic style eatery that has a very lively atmosphere...

the apps...
 
Pozzi Farm veal sweetbreads saltimbocca ...  
..this was my first experience with sweatbreads and it will not be my last. 

Crostini misti: fava bean-pecorino, chicken liver rustico and white bean-sardine ...
..wow!!! what a great combo.. im not a huge liver fan, but it was very smooth... sardines are my weak spot and the reason i ordered this dish...

the primi...

Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini...
.."why would you order a spaghetti plate? its such a waste of money!!! i can make this at home!!!"   thats what i was saying the whole time while my friend was ordering this dish... the noodles are to die for!!! so perfect with the texture!!! the sauce was amazing, but i didnt like the strong after taste of the tomatoes they used mainly because it reminded me of times when i had to much to drink (if ya know what i mean)...the acidity... thats all im going to say... worth trying though...

Pappardelle with pork sugo and piquillo peppers...
..this was simply amazing... i almost would prefer it over the spaghetti... a must try!!!

secondi...

Strawberry Mountain shortribs with Anson Mills polenta and gremolata...
.. falling off the bone, tender, juicy, and to die for... enough said...

Strawberry Mountain Ranch hanger steak and French fries...
.. the steak was beautifully cooked, but my short ribs dominated the block!!!...if you can order both, i suggest you do!!!

overall, i put delfina on my favs list... im in love with rustic at the moment and they accomplish this style very well... the servers are very friendly and informative as well... 

delfina is a must!!!
author: Nic M.

description:
BREAD
Really good sourdough here!

RIBOLLITA "da Delfina" 
Homey. Takes a little getting used to.  Is some kind O soup that is soaked in bread overnight then cooked like a pancake.

CHICKEN
Good sauce, well cooked chicken, nice gentle crisp to the skin.  Just wasn't that exciting.  Comes with a very smooth, yet boring, mash.

RAVIOLI
Ricotta and Pine nuts.  Very tasty!  I'd eat this by the bucket.

ATMO
Hip yet not overly done.  Sound proof blankets up along the ceiling are a nice touch.  It's almost too noisy in there and the blankets keep it manageable.  

STAFF
The ladies are really nice.  The guys are rude, yet trying to act like they are not... maybe it's a high pressure enviro for them.  But they are all on the ball and that's what matters.  Anyone will hook you up at any time, doesn't have to be your server.

PARKING
HA HA!!! Good luck!  In the alleys, they have the rounded corners curbs with no handicap ramp.  SF cops have told me it's okay to park around those curbs (best bet when all else is taken over here).

SEATING
Get a reservation, or show up when they open to get a bar or counter spot.

PRICE
About right.  Wasn't a fan of automatically charging an extra 1.25pp for what I don't even recall when the price was already up there.

OVERALL
Seems best for the seafood and pasta.  Tasty SF Italian food!
author: Dan M.

description: This pizza is so awesome. I haven't had anything better in the city yet. I can't give a higher rating though because the service is so slow and don't check up on the table often enough (which is weird because the place is so small)). Be ready to wait, but it will be worth it!
author: Brandon R.

description:
Really wonderful food, and a bit of a wait on weekend nights but well worth it. I would suggest getting there earlier than you plan on eating to put your name down and enjoy talking together or going for a brief walk. 
The pizza is great and has a unique touch that my family and I very much enjoy. 
I highly recommend Delfina.
author: Joyce S.

description:
After a year of trying to get a reservation, i have to say i am underwhelmed by Delfina.  The food was good, but not great.  It was expensive, and honestly a little odd.

I mean, I am an adventurous eater, but fennel encrusted fennel is a little off.  And it was one of the best things we had.

It will probably be at least a year until i return.
author: Steve S.

description:
I'm debating if I should review this. 

I have yet to eat at the restaurant, but I went to Craig Stoll's free cooking demonstration, where we were served two restaurant-sized dishes that people would be served at Delfina, so I think that counts.

The panna cotta was a little disappointing, but then again, it had been premade for the demonstration, and I'm not a huge panna cotta fan in general.

However, the mozzarella appetizer Craig made was amazing, which is further magnified by the fact that it was also premade yet had so much flavor to it.

I get the feeling that when I actually go to Delfina to eat, it will indeed by the best Italian food I've had outside of Italy (as well as better than some of the food I had in Italy).
author: Mark A.

description:
Delfina's pretty great.  The food is delicious and the service is spot-on, but I can't give it five stars simply because I'm beginning to get bored by the same type of approach in so many different Italian trattorias.  Sure, there are tweaks here and there, but really, if you're at flour & water, or delfina, or picco, or A16 or pizzaiolo in Oakland, you're really having a very similar experience with just a few tweaks on the concept.  It feels like there's a bubble forming in that market and I could see it getting tough for places that can't set themselves apart.

All that aside, delfina knows how to do Italian.  Simple but powerful flavors, top-notch ingredients and excellent preparation.
author: Freccia S.

description: Really solid Italian. I've eaten here several times and been pleased on each occasion. The spaghetti is prepared perfectly al dente and the meats, salads, etc are all good too. Very reasonable wine list.
author: Kevin F.

description:
I had high hopes for this place, but alas, they were not to be met!

My friend and I ventured into this place late at night (a bonus that they're open until 11 during the weekends).  My $20 pork shoulder was about at the level of maybe $10, and my friend's pasta was just OK.  Props to the restaurant for offering unique dishes, but it just wasn't up to par with what I was hoping for.

The other strange thing is that though the restaurant was presenting itself as a classy establishment (via ambiance, prices, etc), the wait staff wasn't really dressed appropriately (a grey t-shirt with a faded NIKE printed on it).  Service was also mediocre, as our waitress made herself difficult to track down.

The dessert did help to rescue the evening somewhat, but not enough for me to want to return any time soon...especially considering all the other offerings of the Mission.
author: Corey C.

description:
I love Delfina. It's reliably tasty, down-to-earth, and enjoyable. The mostly hip-chick servers are always friendly, and although the dining room is always full, it's never too loud, just bustling. I dig the subtly lit, mellow vibe. A diverse clientele comes here, including everyone from Mom and Dad to queer couples to girly-girls out on the town.

My favorites: Grilled calamari with white beans, spaghetti with tomato sauce (and almost any other pasta), chicken with mashed potatoes. I don't know much about wine, but Delfina's by-the-glass list works for me. And the warm chocolate cake, ohhh.

Good luck finding a parking spot near this uber-fancified block of 18th Street!
author: Tara M.

description:
I went there with my boyfriend at the time. We lucked out since we did not have reservations and we were able to sit at the bar. I had the hanger steak and it was incredible. Hanger steak's typically not the tenderist cut but they were able to cook it so that you didn't even need a knife to cut into it. I kept repeating to myself, "This can't be hanger steak?" Execution was flawless. I still remember this meal to this day. 

I definitely owe it to Delfina for turning me on to fine dining. It was a defining pivotal moment, I finally understood the meaning of good food. Delfina has set the bar for dining experiences to come. Thank you Delfina!
author: Christine D.

description:
its aight.. i guess.. hella overpriced IMO. did not like the "grilled" calamari which obviously cuz of my quotation marks means it wasn't really grilled, at least not how i was expecting.. clearly. eh.. meh.

the third star is for great service.
author: M S.

description:
Located in the funky Mission District, this place draws the perfect 'locals' crowd - fun, happy, exotic and hip.

I've gone here about 20 times and [I swear] they have been consistent all those times.

My favorite is their salmon seasoned simply with melted leeks and Meyer lemon-caper butter - it is absolutely high pleasing!  The chef has some awesome salad and pasta creations - they're colorful like the interior of this restaurant.  

Visit this San Francisco landmark - the wait is soooooo worth it!

PS. Their wine list is as good as their espresso bar.
author: Reese M.

description:
Even though I've giving this place 5 stars, I think maybe only 4 stars...

The food was excellent, I ordered the roasted chicken with olive oil mashed potates and the bf ordered the Albacore Tuna. Both were excellently prepared, and they even let you decide on how well done you want the tuna (i.e more sashimi style or more well done). Foodwise, definitely 5 stars.

Service was rather mild, nothing to rave about, we didn't hear any wine suggestions or offering of wine tasting like the table next to us did. On the other hand, the hostess was very nice and made it possible for us to have table seating instead of counter seating even though we didn't have reservations on a Sunday evening. 

All in all, the food is AMAZING, but I feel like the whole experiance wasn't as good as the reviews hyped.
author: Annie C.

description:
Yes, it's really good, and as the 223 reviews preceding mine (and that horrendous wait) will indicate, not exactly overlooked. So, rather than my spot for a saturday night sit-down dinner (who the hell can plan three weeks in advance for dinner unless mom and dad are coming to town???), Delfina has become my spot for:

 A) A weeknight dessert treat. Head in some time north of 9, sit at the bar, order chocolate cake and ENJOY.

 B) A late pasta dinner on week nights. God, their pasta is good, it's cheap, and you can do a solo dinner or a twosome at the bar, as long as, again, it's on the later side. 

The upshot is that my Delfina bills are always south of $25, and I get to enjoy their food without fighting the crowds.

As an aside, can I just say that if you are doing the sit-down dinner thing with entrees, their steak and fries is AWESOME. Esp. the fries. And since Delfina is generally about pretty standard fare cooked really well, you don't have to feel guilty about not going the adventurous route when you order it.
author: David K.

description: I came here for an early dinner with a relative, who is a cook.  She said this was one of the few places in the area that consistently executes - boy was she right! Even the sides were right on point.  The mashed potatoes and the brussel sprouts were the best I've ever had.  I got the tripe, which had wonderful texture and flavor.  Although we started dinner at 5:30 with reservations, the whole venue was bustling within half an hour.  I certainly hope to visit this place again next time I'm out here!
author: Mark M.

description:
BOLD PRINT:
Salt cod mantecato with walnut oil and fennel seed flatbread

E X C L A M A T I O N    P O I N T S ,  P R E F E R A B L Y   T H R I C E   T I M E S.

UNDERLINE:
Never had anything like it. Don;t think I ever will. You crunch off a piece of the flatbread and smear on the soft cod in toasted top ramekin. So delicious.

ITALICS:
Service was quick and unobtrusive. Decor was quite refreshing. Glass and whites. Try the grilled calamari for the warm beans underneath. Skip the spaghetti. Dig into the juicy chicken. They LOVE the LEMONS here... be aware. Lemon shavings on salads.
author: Annie P.

description:
Delfina is so amazing in so many ways....  if I could make it my lover, I would have gotten it a ring, proposed, and been happy for the rest of my culinary life... MARRY ME DELFINA!

Food is simply delicious and consistently so.  The sophisticated and under-stated hip factor is probably what gets me the most excited about going to Delfina.  It doesn't try to impress you..it just does.  The carpaccio is yummy and the calamaris were just right.  The neiman's steak and fries are perfect together.  The ambiance of the place just makes you want to come back over and over again and makes the wait list/reservation system worth it.  YES, I will take a 9:30 reservation if I need to.  AND I will say it once again, THIS BITCH DON'T WAIT!  It's that good.

The wine list was more than adequate.  Good times every single time.
author: Myko L.

description:
I have been waiting forever to try going here. The weekend reservations is close to impossible to get unless you book 3 weeks in a advance. This place is tiny and its bursting with people. Now I get why. It was simply delicious!!
The bf and I were able to get the coviteted 7pm Friday night resevation (3 weeks in advance might i add.)
Here's our low down
-Started wtih the fresh calamari with white bean. Amazing! The calamari was fresh, slightly grilled and on a bed of tender white bean. There was a slight zest lemony taste. YUM.
-Then we shared the Pasta with the atlantic cod (primi course- so the serving was small). They split the dish for us (nice touch). The fish was perfect and the pasta must have been freshly made that morning. Chewy goodness.
-Chicken entree: Bf declared it was the best chicken he's ever tasted. So tender he thought he was eating fish. The skin was crispy and the meat was moist. It also came with potato that was equally yummy and mushroom (myfave)

Other nice touches:
-They clean your table after each course
-They refill your bread bowl and water frequently. (They slice the bread in the corner of the room)
-I want to come back again and again! (if it weren't for the notorious hard to get reservations)
author: T H.

description:
So having a reputation for being highly regarded and always busy, my wife made reservations for when they opened at 5:30pm.  The person suggested 6pm instead, which my wife accepted.  Whatever.

We get to Delfina a little before their 5:30pm opening so we can browse Bi-Rite before dinner, but noticed a huge line already.  So we decide to get in line.  We were seated without problem, but I did notice that they filled ALL of the tables by 5:45pm.  I'm pretty sure there were others with reservations at 6pm onward, so that led me to think that if we got there at 6pm, we would have had to wait until 7pm at least before we were seated.

Anyways, we were seated around the same time as 4 other tables, served by the same waitress (Kari).  Water was brought to all of the tables except for ours.  Nothing.  For 20 minutes.  Whatever, maybe slight overlook.  By this time, we were ready to order.  So when Kari came by, I inquired about the specials.   I get a response of 'like I had mentioned, we have the ___' (can't remember the crap of the day). Um, excuse me?  You haven't even greeted us, and you give us attitude like we're doing YOU a favor of dining there?

Whatever.  I asked if Delfina was like a traditional Italian restaurant, where we need to order a Primi and Secondi to be filled.  She said that since we're ordering our own appetizers, a Primi would be fine.  

We get our appetizers after about 10 minutes (a long wait, but not too bad).  Chicken Terrine was excellent, and crudo Sea Scallops was very fresh, not fishy, and very flavorful.  Ok, so maybe the service sucked, but at least the food is good!

But here's where the wheels begin falling off, and the dining experience changes from a PG rating to a NC-17 'f-bomb' movie.  For the next 40 minutes, not a single fart from Kari comes our way.  Now, the entitled older d-bag couples from Sausalito, with the old man with an oh-so-cool wannabe hipster ponytail and his over the hill cougar wife, the ones that asked Kari if the scallops were fishy, and demanded that their food be brought out in a specific order, they got all the love and attention.  These tools didn't have to wait long for their food.  When the yapping cougar told Kari, 'if the chard isn't out here in 2 minutes, I don't want it', the manager came back in 2 minutes to appease her.  All the while I sit there twiddling my thumbs, looking at everyone else eating their main dishes, and wondering why no one came to fill up our water, or give us more bread.

After seeing everyone, including the busboys and the bum outside, finish their main courses, our food finally arrives.  By this time, I'm pissed off and the lack of attention and the impending $2.50 SF surcharge for health insurance diners are forced to pay.  I'm sure the main courses were good, but all I tasted was bitterness, hatred, and anger at an establishment that does not treat their non yuppie customers the same way.  If you want me to cause an uproar to get some service, I will do so.  I just thought that I'd break the stereotype of uppity San Franciscans being such smug snobs.  

And, no, I was not filled after the small portions.  So Kari, you SHOULD have recommended that we ordered a secondi.  But I didn't know if I could wait until closing to eat that dish, (which would be when you would have brought it) so it's probably a good thing you wrongly suggested that we didn't order a secondi.

So this was my birthday dinner, which was acknowledged by Kari as I asked her for the check.  But I didn't get a birthday dessert like another couple that she served.  

One regret I had was that my wife tipped them.  This was the second time in my life that I seriously considered running out on the bill.  And I probably would have succeeded, because Kari wouldn't have come around to our table for another 30 minutes.

Did the sit/lie law pass? Because I'm ready to squat on Delfina's doorstep and leave them a present.
author: Pick S.

description:
When I treat myself to a meal at Delfina, I always end up parked at a table for about 3 hours, chewing each magnificent bite with my eyes closed for about 5 minutes, like somebody eating their first home-cooked meal after serving a few decades in prison.

Last time around I got a glass of wine, didn't much like it, and before I even said anything, the waitress's spidey-sense began to tingle.  She knew my wine was not ideal and asked if I'd like something else, free of charge, and hooked me up with a glass much more to my liking.  They're in my head, man!
author: Paul B.

description:
Probably the best Tuscan-style Italian food in the Bay Area! Although Northern Italian style food is not my favorite of all the flavors Italy has to offer, there's next to nothing at Delfina that I can find fault in. The food is always exquisitely prepared; although I am an accomplished chef, especially with Italian food, there's very rarely I dish here that I feel could be better than it already is! Those who have compared this to Farina astound me; I tried them a few months ago and was disappointed. The fresh pastas at Farina lacked the flavor and perfect consistency of Delfina, the portions were the same or smaller for the same price point, and the service was poor.

Notable highlights at Delfina include the mashed potatoes (so good!), the calamari and bean appetizer, the homemade nettle pastas (wonderful, delicate, gamey flavor!), the hanger steak (among the best preparations of steak I've ever had) and the handmade pasta with white sauce (I forget the name). Several of my friends have also given the fries major kudos.

The wine selection is small, but one can find some interesting and reasonably priced wines that are hard to find elsewhere.

This is a place for someone with a sophisticated, urbane palate; this is NOT a family-style Italian-American resturant. The portions are small and best suited to those who can appreciate the taste and delicacy of the more subtle, refined Tuscan flavors. 

The dining room itself is well-decorated, noisy, crowded and populated with the wealthy and beautiful people of San Francisco. This probably is not a good place to have a romantic dinner or to bring children. Reservations are difficult to get, but one can usually stop by and be put on the list and be seated within an hour.

The service is superb; solicitous without being pushy or annoying. Water is refilled promptly and free bread is served before the meal with butter or a high-quality olive oil if requested.

My only warning is to not order the desserts, with the exception of the Panna Cotta, because it is their weakest effort-- you're much better off going to the bakery a couple doors down from them or Bi-rite creamery near the park, if either shop is open during the hours you dine at Delfina.
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
Delfina just reminded me what a foodie-tool I am.  I had eaten here a while back and didn't remember being all that impressed, but Farina down the street had an hour wait as did the Pizzeria Delfina, so I figured what the hell, I'm here, they've got a table (when Farina and Pizzeria didn't, go figure), I'll give it another chance.  Well, I go into Delfina thinking, it's a little pricey, I'm not that hungry, I need to save calories and money so I'll just get a salad.  Cut to me walking out 2 hours later having finished a four course meal.  It's a trap people.  I think I'm smarter than these places but they sucker me every time.  More than that, I just don't have will power.  What can I say I'm a yelper, I have to try it ALL.

Here is a short(end) list of why I couldn't say no:

Service: Amazingly knowledgeable about the menu and wine - every time I asked a question the answer made me want to order it... and so I did.  Like all SF restaurants it wasn't the most attentive, my glass stayed empty a little too often, but the waitress made up for it in the end.

Food:  Damn good.  Simple salads with lots of flavor, superbly cooked meats (perhaps the moistest chicken I've ever had - it was like it hadn't even been cooked... but in a good way), perfect pasta tossed in hearty ragu.   

Decor:  It's fun, I'm fun, I wanna stay so I keep it going.  The whole restaurant is boisterous and lively, moreover we were seated near the kitchen where there is even more action.  With a view of the chefs and more importantly every plate that comes out, my mouth could not say no.

Free Pana Cotta:  Yea that's right.  Read it and weep.  Our entrees took a little too long to come out, which we weren't really bothered by, but the waitress took it upon herself to see that we enjoyed the house's panna cotta on the house.  Like whoa.  First off, that's exceptional that she noticed our wait in such a busy restaurant, and moreover that she made up for it without us having to say anything.  (Somebody got a big tip).  Secondly, panna cotta is one of those things that I never order because it's not something I'm accustomed to eating.  I'm typically distracted by something with chocolate and or a crust.  But I cannot express how glad I am that she ordered it for me.  She knew what she was doing.  It was amazing.  Orgasmic finish.
author: Dubs W.

description:
Hard to say what went wrong with this place tonight, but not that hard: it was the waiter. He evidently thought that everyone wanted to hear him talk, which apparently everyone did, since he never once shut up. I couldn't hear my date talking 9" away from me across our small table, but I could hear our waiter yakking it up all over the place. I now know all kinds of personal details about his life, thank you. 

Deflina is known for its friendly and good-looking staff. This waiter was both, but he was his chatter was LOUD and CONSTANT. He spent way more time standing around talking than checking on his tables. 

The chicken we ordered was fantastic, but the fish was bone dry. Had our waiter visited our table (instead of yakking it up at all the neighboring tables) we would have told him this sooner and probably sent it back. Instead we ate the veggies and poked at the fish, leaving it 2/3 uneaten. When he finally made it back over to us, we told him it was dry.

What should he have done at this point?
a. Removed it from the bill ($27)
b. Comped us dessert
c. Comped us a glass of wine
d. Said, "Oh, I'm sorry"
e. Comp dessert to the table next to us (nothing dry at their table, no complaints)

Correct answer? d, followed swiftly by a, b, or c.
What did he do? d, followed by e.

Nice.
author: Mary J.

description:
The best part about Defina was the food.  Very yummy not-too-fancy reasonably priced Italian food.  The roast chicken was juicy and flavorful and came with a side of creamy mashed potatoes.  My dining partner and I shared a half bottle of Italian white wine that came in a very cute bottle and complimented the meal perfectly.  If you are a chocoholic, you will enjoy the Scharffen Berger chocolate cake.  I did.  

The dining room atmosphere is very hip and lively, although maybe a tad too cramped.  Service was fine.  Wait staff had cool clothes, not uniforms.  I will definitely return.
author: youssarian w.

description:
I'm sorry if this review comes off sounding like a five year old wrote it, im basically legally braindead from my current work/school schedule . I had a dinner at Delfina last night that was whatever adjective could mean more than amazing if there is such a thing. I started off with a blood orange bellini, i mean YAY right! then came a salmon salad that was the freshest little salmon you ever did eat-so tasty. followed that up with the most scrumptious hangar steak consumed by man. tender, tender,tender wine saucey goodness. I died. I DIED

the staff was so attentive. i love this place its worth the money
author: Lauren V.

description: We had a nice anniversary dinner here. Anti pasta calmer and artichoke were good and pasta was delicious. We also liked the rabbit...
author: Ali E.

description:
My boyfriend and I are from Boston, and had some SF friends recommend Delfina for our romantic night out while we were in town.

This was the perfect dining experience from start to finish.

First off we were greeted by the friendliest hostess, who informed us that our table was not quite ready but that we could enjoy a drink at the bar while we waited. 

The bartender was incredibly upbeat and knowledgeable on everything she was serving, beer to my boyfriend and wine for me. I don't think I have ever had a complete crash course on grapes even before the wine was finished being poured. She also let us taste different options before we ordered a full glass. Top Notch. 

At our table I was able to admire the swanky yet cozy atmosphere of Delfina; the metallic tables, glass windows and mirrors balanced with the candle lit tables, warm overhead lighting and local? artwork on the walls. It was prefect for the date I was on, and larger groups seemed to be comfortable as well. 

The service was impeccable. The entire staff seems to be so happy to be there, and very excited that you are about to partake in their food. I also liked that they seem to work as a team, one person brings you your wine / water, another brings (delicious) bread, another introduces specials and then you have your main server who handles the entrees, and throughout the evening there is always someone around to check on you - everyone worked flawlessly together and we didn't feel harassed or ignored. 

The food was incredible. I feel like we tried everything on the menu, and our server, Jessica, paired different wines with the food perfectly. A new glass for every course, it was great. 

All around one of the best dining experiences I have had. Can't wait to go back.
author: Danielle M.

description:
Salt does not equal flavor. Don't get the specials, order off the menu 

Pros: 
Had the rabbit saddle & spaghetti, they were good size, cooked well and were nice spins of classic Italian dishes. 

Cons 
My girlfriend ordered the special for the evening (Mussels on fettuccine). The pasta arrived under cooked (al dente is good, raw is not) and the sauce was pure SALT. We asked the server about the pasta and he said that it was a brine sauce and so should be salty. 

There is a difference between salty and drinking the Pacific Ocean. 

He replaced it with the Mint Tagliatelle which for $18 is rather expensive as there is no protein and the chanterelle mushrooms were few and far between.
author: Alex L.

description:
Best Italian food I've ever had in San Francisco.
Plus, great service, comfortable laid-back atmosphere.  Five big-fat stars baby!

So why did it take me a YEAR to finally try this place?  Probably because it's like impossible to get a reservation day-of and I'm not really the plan-ahead kind.

But here's the secret: they won't take reservations for the main bar or the small bar that looks over the main dining room.  So if you show up as a party-of-two there's a good change you'll get seated within 15 minutes or so, even on a weekend night.  And the people watching view can be very entertaining :)
author: Tessa M.

description:
Delfina is great food in a great neighborhood.  The only problem is driving around hunting for parking and getting late night reservations because all the good time slots are booked.  The food is filled with different influences from French to Italian to Californian style cooking.  Ingredients are made up of only the best that can be found in SF (organic, sustainable, grass fed, etc.).  Really attentive service that won't leave you asking for water when you need it the most.  Being at Delfina, you get the cool SF Mission vibe and the feeling of  "This restaurant just gets it!"  Not too stuffy, not too ghetto, it just is.

I know the menu can change slightly from time to time, but here's a few tips.
*Salads are pretty small, so try not to share
*French Fries fried with basil and thyme are a must with any meal!
*Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini  - large or small its all good!
*Can't go wrong with any of their Secondi dishes.  If they have the seafood stew special that night you go--get it!  
*Desserts are good and they have Ritual Roasters Coffee to help speed up your metabolism!
author: Jason A.

description: Not your typical pizza place. Very average and very pricey. Wont be back again.
author: Aussfchi R.

description:
Really good Italian food. 

The salt cod mantecato with flatbread is really, really good. The mantecato mixture isn't too salty, with potatoes and a crispy top. The flatbread is both crispy and sometimes chewy in thicker patches. Portion is huge and can be a lot for two, unless you're like us and can eat for days. 

The spaghetti is perfect. The noodles are cooked perfectly, the sauce is full of plum tomatoes, garlic and olive oil -- peperoncini make it slightly spicy and leaves you wanting more. Order the small portion and you'll still have room for an entree. The large is big enough to share between two, if you're having another dish. 

Pappardelle and duck sugo is delightful. Savory and tender pork folded with perfect, flat noodles. 

Roasted chicken is done to perfection. Half chicken is really juicy and tender, even the breast meat -- it's topped with a light mushroom sauce. Mashed potatoes served on a small plate on the side. 

Steak and fries are yummy. French fries are skinny and crispy. 

Buttermilk panna cotta is the best panna cotta you will ever eat. Simple, and perfect. Perfect texture, perfect flavor. Try it with the Moscato d'Asti. Yum. 

I love Delfina.
author: kristen b.

description:
There's a reason some items never leave the menu...my recipe for a perfect dinner at Delfina.

1)  Start with the Prosecco special.  They'll usually have a Bellini of some sort and depending on the season the fruit can be peach, or pomegranate or something else delicious.

2)  For starters, get the little gem salad.

3)  Eat lots of bread.  They serve two types, but you can request only Tartine bread.  It's amazing.

3.5)  Order a simple red wine.

4)  Eat their spaghetti.  I know, "Spaghetti??"  For this dish alone I would come to this restaurant time and again.

5)  Have the chicken or steak.  What they do to the chicken is what I had hoped the chicken would be like at Zuni (but seemed to fall short)...something memorable and delicious.  The steak comes with little fatty morsels and incredible fries.

6)  Get the panna cotta.

Tips:
***Delfina is notoriously hard to get a reseravation for.  If you show up early...and by early I mean RIGHT when they open...you can usually get a table or certainly a bar seat.  It's also worth dropping by when the weather is bad...I've had great luck at otherwise busy dinner seating times during bad weather.
***Tartine bread is not available on Mondays or ??Tuesdays
author: Pink ..

description:
Delfina has been on my list of restaurants to try for quite a while.  Finally got to experience it last night.  The servers were friendly and knowledgeable (helped us pick out a great bottle of wine).  The chicken was really tender and absorbed the sauce really well, and the portions were extremely hearty.

We ordered the most random dessert on the menu (both of us combined knowing four words).  Turned out to be a chocolate mousse thing with almond shavings, which was a great end to a fabulous meal.

I walked out full, and with a temporary delfina tattoo on my arm.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Normally I wouldn't waste my time writing a restaurant review unless I had just eaten at the French Laundry and saw a famous person choke to death on their food.  However, I'm making an exception for Delfina because I have a story to relate.  It begins...

My father becomes OBSESSED with restaurants.  Apparently it's  a recessive trait because I didn't inherit this particular gene and beyond that, I find it a little excessive.  Whatever the case, he recently became fixated on eating at Delfina and so we took him there for his 60th birthday dinner.  Our reservations were for nine o'clock and we all had two very strong drinks before arriving.  We were feeling good.  Until the salads came.  That's when my  dad bit into a piece of rolled up gauze.  That's right,  a rolled up piece of nasty ass cloth.  I watched it as he pulled it out of his mouth in horror.  I laughed.  But it wasn't funny Delfina!   The worst part is that my Dad was so grossed out he canceled his rabbit and on top of that they didn't even comp the meal!!!  

Two days after the Delfina Debacle the owner called my sister to beg forgiveness which was nice.  Then she talked to my Dad, poor lady, and my Dad expressed his concern about HIV infection (geeeez dad) and other outlandish possibilities.  The owner lady said the gauze can look pretty nasty because they use it to wipe of the edges off plates and they reuse it till they have to throw it away.

As for the food, I had some very unremarkable swordfish with sodium laden lentils but the vino flowed freely and that's all I really cared about.  

Oh Delfina, you would cringe at  the shit-talking festival that took place during the cab ride home.  But you started it.
author: Danielle G.

description:
What a disappointment. We went here expecting alot from its reputation. Our grilled asparagus was good, not spectacular but good. My BF ordered the sole and I ordered the skate. Both under seasoned, tasteless, and underwhelming. For dessert, the panna cotta was average nothing exciting.

I've been waiting to go to this restaurant for years. But I think its hay day is on the DEcline.
author: Cat B.

description: Yes, this restaurant lives up to its hype.  Very excellent food, and nice wine list.  Their spaghetti rivals the spaghetti pomodoro at Lupa NYC.
author: Anna K.

description:
AWESOME!!!!

Food is great, service is fantastic and the ambiance is comfortable.

We shared salad, calamari, salt cod with flat bread, prosciutto, hangar steak, halibut, gnocchi, ribs, chocolate cake of some sort, berry tart and some coffee too (did I mention I like to pig out?).  All that for about $60 per person with tip (excluding wine of course), so I feel like I got my monies worth.

The worst part of the experience was looking out the window and watching the folks enjoy that pizza from next door, damn that pie looked good.
author: Will C.

description:
There was a cockroach on our table.  We stopped it with an empty glass and showed our server who laughed and said "looks like you've got a friend!" NASTY.  For an expensive restaurant like Delfina, I REALLY don't want to see large bugs crawling across the table.  The only time they come around is when there is food to eat...in other words, DIRTY!!!
I have been to Delfina many times and the food is great - but the cockroach incident, and then all the denial around it just turned me off.
author: john s.
