description: Great good, good service, good atmosphere. Getting a reservation is a bit of a pain, and I'm not sure whether this place is worth waiting 2-3 weeks for, but overall its a solid bet. Delicious appetizers, especially the brussel sprouts and asparagus.
author: Julia S.

description:
Ok I'm feeling generous today, so I am going to increase my star rating.  Not as if Delfina needs another review, but I did want to share some recent dining suggestions.  Ordinarily I may have to dock an entire star for the noise rating, but people don't seem to mind because although this restaurant has been around for years, it is consistently crowded.  Delfina has managed to become an SF institution, which is quite a feat considering the volume of restaurants in the city.  I would say this is because the food is consistently good.  If you don't mind sitting very close to the table next to you, and eavesdropping on their conversation, come here.

Here are some tidbits from neighboring tables.  Left side.  A bday party.  A man walks in with a large present in a giant box. Naturally, I assumed my date had arranged this and that I was about to open a Vivienne Westwood jacket, or perhaps a Playstation.  Nicht.  Right side, a party of two on what appeared to be a first date.  I was amused because the man was photographing the food.  While I, like many Asians, enjoy photographing food, even I am not gutsy enough to do this on a first date.

Yesterday I had a delightful grilled calamari dish, which was garnished with fava beans that were melt in your mouth smooth.  Not enough restaurants do grilled calamari, and I don't like the fried variety, so it was refreshing to taste it here.  I also had the escarole and grape salad, which was light but flavorful.  The ahi was a bit dry, but the duck was flavorful.  Duck came with polenta which tasted a bit like grits.  I also enjoyed a pinot that was light, but full bodied.  This pinot complemented the majority of the dishes we had, so I have to find out the name.

The dessert wine selection is also fairly extensive.  The sparkling dessert wine was dry and crisp, a great compliment to your dessert.  A chocolate torte dessert was immemorable for me, and I want to try the panna cotta next time.
author: apple r.

description:
Wow, we got a reservation for dinner two weeks from now, on a Tuesday, at 5:30pm!  Good job guys!  Such is the situation at the now ridiculously popular Delfina.  While the food is highly lauded even in tourism books, the excellent service and ambiance are what set it apart.

We started with octopus, mussels and chickpeas in a broth and a mozzarella with fried zucchini.  The octopus was superb as was the rest of the dish.  The mozzarella tasted like any of the high quality variety you can get at the grocery store.  It didn't even compare to the homemade version at A16 which I still crave.  Next, we had lamb with fava beans, sole with dried tomatoes and olives, and sea bass pasta.  The lamb was moist but it was not the best I've had here.  I think the preparation was perfect but the meat wasn't top quality.  The sole was unusually flavorful and flaky.  The sea bass pasta was only sprinkled with pea-sized sea bass but apparently the flavor marinated the pasta so that it was quite tasty.

They have a good selection of wine.  We tried the wines from the winery featured that day which ages their wine in stainless steel.  Good way to kill some good grape juice!  We missed the barrel and we got some with our next bottle of the cheapest Chianti.

We finished with dessert and rowdiness.  We ordered what looked like a boringish molten chocolate cake in creme anglaise (I could see a couple vanilla seeds).  It didn't have any embellishment and I wasn't even tempted to try it.  I had cream puffs filled with pastry creme, strawberry jam, and covered with granulated sugar.  A nice original idea but the strawberry jam tasted to sweet and syrupy.  I like the texture of the sugar-covered cream puff, however.  My other friend had a sweet cheese tart with apricots, really good.

Our server was attentive, always there when we needed her with great explanations.  Other servers were always around and ready to deal with our loud table.  

Diners were actually dressed up in this beautiful, dark-wood, blue-walled little space!  I really loved the setup, enough room between tables so we could hear ourselves.  Good fun.
author: Elena S.

description:
My husband and I were in San Francisco this past weekend and decided to try the restaurant side of Delfina. We had been to the Pizza side and loved it! 

We started off with Rosemary tagliatelle with guinea hen ragu and vin santo which was delicious! The pasta was hand rolled and the seasoning was perfect! We also got the Grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad which was amazing. For an entree I got the Meyer Ranch flatiron steak and French fries which were pretty tasty. The steak was cooked just as I had asked, "medium". The fries were pretty good, fried to a perfect crisp. My husband ordered the Roasted Sonoma leg of lamb with fresh cannellini beans and charred Nardello peppers. I usually don't like lamb but thought his was pretty good. It didn't taste gamey at all. I would have given Delfina 4 stars but the service was mediocre. Our waitress didn't check up to see how we were doing and it took a while for someone to come take our order. I'd definitely give it another shot because the food was quite good.
author: Szu L.

description:
Oh my delectable Delfina!

The wait for a table was definitely worth it because my meal was oh so wonderful! 

We had the little gem lettuce with gorgonzola, radishes, sieved egg and lemon-dijon vinaigrette and the Fresh-stretched mozzarella with padrn peppers, zucchini alla Napoletana and cherry tomatoes (probably one of the best appetizer's I've ever had). 

For an entree we had the whole-roasted local petrole sole and the salmon. The sole had such good natural flavor and the salmon was good, but too dressed up. 

We had a bottle of Verdicchio wine (can't remember specifics on the name b/c I was pretty drunk by the end of the bottle), but it was really good. Had an aroma that (I know sounds weird) smelled like ocean. It really made you want to eat seafood. And the wine finished dry so you could go on eating w/o mixing too many flavors. The Barista was extremely knowledgeable about the wine and very helpful in finding something that matched both our tastes.
author: Laura G.

description:
D - Difficult to get in without a reservation
E - Extraordinarily knowledgeable and friendly servers
L - Lovely candelight atmosphere in the trendy Mission
F - Fresh pasta that is made there...perfectly al dente!
I - Incredibly delicious beef carpaccio
N - Nice bathrooms with cool sinks
A - Affordable for the quality you get!

I'm going to the Pizzeria next!
author: Annie C.

description:
Pros
- Tasty food
- Good service
- Nice ambiance

Cons
- Very small portions
- Coffee not on part with the quality of food and desserts

Verdict
- I'll come back for a special occasion. I may eat first and skip the coffee
author: Roger R.

description: I had dinner here with my girlfriend last night after having a friend recommend it. We both had the Syrah, I ordered the flank steak and she opted for the special that day, ravioli with prosciutto and maybe a lemon sauce. The flank steak came out perfect, but my girlfriend was given the wrong dish. The staff was quick to fix the problem, and although my steak got slightly cold while waiting they offered some free salmon crisp appetizers and even gave us a delicious dessert for free to make up for it.  In the end, both entrees were outstanding and I'd come here again if I happen to be in San Francisco.
author: Kyle S.

description:
My favorite place in the City to dine.  Lively atmosphere and surpassingly good food; a superb meal every time.

Their pork loin is a guaranteed best bet and cannellini beans always make me smile.

Strong wine list but when I do bring my own bottle, the attentive staff graciously opens and decants it.
author: Adam W.

description:
Being new to town, I had heard both sides of the coin in regards to Delfina. There is the camp that loves it and the camp that doesn't understand the fuss. It's kind of like a movie that gets hyped too much. I had a reservation here one night (an anniversary dinner in fact) and looked at the menu online before deciding to cancel - it just wasn't doing anything for me. 

Well, on a whim we stopped in there one night a couple of weeks ago and they actually could seat us right away, so we stayed. And were very happy we did. The food is really wonderful... even from a menu that still didn't really speak to me... everything - the food, wine, service and ambiance, is perfect. 

Update 06/08: We've been lucky enough to go back a few times now and can say for certain this place is a keeper. Particularly fond of the grilled calamari, a dish we try anytime we see it on a menu. And their Northern halibut with melted leeks, fingerling potatoes and prosecco-caper butter is one of my favorite fish dishes in the city. I dream about it. You cannot go wrong with a night at Delfina.
author: margot b.

description: The food was great, the vibe made the food taste even better.  I will return!
author: Diem O.

description:
We went out for a very large, very long work-related dinner at Delfina.  This is certainly NOT a space for a big, formal, stuffy business dinner, but as we were dining with a young, engaged couple, it was a more casual type of work dinner.  

First off, the space is small, crowded, dimly-lit, bustling, and lovely.  It's exactly what I look for when I am going for a dark, cozy, intimate dinner with a significant other or to catch up with some close friends.  For business?  Less appropriate but not uncomfortably so.

The dining room was packed all night, but the bar was basically empty.  This seems to be more a place where people dine rather than a bar-destination.

The wine list is small but concise, with some great Chianti options.

We sampled nearly the entire menu:

Grilled Fresh Calamari with warm white bean salad - a favorite, as it was warm and light, yet a substantial first course.  A great value for the price, I'd recommend ordering this.

Insalata di Campo with bitter greens, pancetta, walnuts, Parmigiano and balsamic vinaigrette - This was a bit unremarkable as far as salads go, but had a nice salty tang to it that would set it apart from a house salad.  I'd recommend this only to fill/round out the menu, but don't make this your only app.

Beef Carpaccio with radicchio, salt-packed capers and Parmigiano - at $15, this is one of the pricier appetizers, yet one of the most delicious.  If you're feeling indulgent, go for a little splurge here.

My date ordered some sort of steak frites, which were very very mediocre.  However, to the restaurant's credit, I think getting steak frites at a tiny, polished Italian restaurant is a mis-order.  The fault, i think, can be shared by my date for ordering this, and by the restaurant for even making this an option.  You know it's only there to appease the "safe orderer"...perhaps offer a boring pasta or pizza option instead and leave the steak frites to the French bistros?  I don't know.  I would just caution you against this, as it's the same dish as you would have elsewhere.

We ended up with some pasta of the day specials, which are now not listed on the website's menu but were all solid offerings.  We didn't go wrong with any of them, so take the plunge and go for the special!

The waitstaff was very helpful and friendly, but the service was extremely slow.  While a quick-diner on a schedule would perhaps wish for more servers, I had a perfectly leisurely meal and did not feel rushed in the least - adding to the appeal of this place despite the long wait for a table.

Would I return?  Perhaps.  It was very pretty and really cozy, so I may take a date on my next trip to SF, though in a city filled with great restaurants, repeats are rare.
author: Heather G.

description:
Always heard great things about Delfina.

"A rockin' good time!" said one SF socialite.
"Authentic Italian food." reported by my best friend (who's chinese and not the greatest authority on authentic Italian).
"It's sooooo good..." squealed a thirty-something drunk woman on the MUNI.

Well after this impressive critical acclaim, I had to drop everything to see what all the commotion was about.

Delfina's in an eclectic location which is primarily residential.  They're surprisingly tough to book and the average wait for reservations is about 1 month.

The food is very good, and has a homestyle/rustic vibe.  Fresh ingredients, reasonable prices, and an attentive waitstaff.

I'm a little conflicted about Delfina though.  It's a great neighborhood restaurant, but I'm not sure I'd want to wait another month to go back.  Parking is almost non-existent in the neighborhood, so either valet or take MUNI.

Perhaps I'll add to their accolade the next time on on the N-Judah.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
It took me a while to get here (ie, a year after I moved to the city) - and once I did, was like, why the f**k did I wait so damn long?

Maybe because I'd tried to make a reservation and it was a nightmare.  I'm not really good with the 2-3 weeks in advance planning.  But then I learned of the very nice bar available for walk-ins.  And then I learned that two can easily get a prime table at a prime hour on a night like Sunday.  Last night I even got to be picky and reject two tables before committing.  I love when I can be successfully high-maintenance.

This is just really good, rustic, simple food.  No fancy sauces or gimmicky anything.  Like when you've been sick and crave comforting stuff that tastes like what it is.   Super-seasonal and fresh salads are made with really good lettuce (yes, it makes a difference!).  Housemade mozzarella is worlds apart from the that week-old watery crap sold at the market.  Even the salt cod brandade (which, by the sound of it, could have been dangerously fishy) was clean-tasting and well-complemented by fennel flatbread.   

Pastas are solid, period.  I wasn't the biggest fan of the gnocci bolognese, but that's just because gnocci to me is mooshy baby food.  But the sauce was delish.  I should have asked for a bowl of that, plain.

The sweet spot on the menu is the 4th entree.  This is for the always-changing, always-interesting special dish.  One night it was perfect roast lamb with eggplant and tomato and white beans.  Another night it was equally perfect slow-roasted Berkshire pork shoulder with farro and roasted peppers.  Both hearty and full-flavored but not heavy at all.  

And the goodness keeps coming with dessert.  Order it.

In a nutshell: great food, eclectic crowd, flattering lighting, casual and good-looking space.   What's not to love?
author: Melissa B.

description: Solid food for San Francisco, albeit a bit overpriced and overhyped. The wait time was a little long (1 hour), and although the food was certainly not bad it didn't blow me away by any stretch of the imagination. A better choice if you are in the Mission district is Range.
author: Peter S.

description:
I'd give it 5 stars just for service alone. Our waitress rocked and was extremely attentive and genuinely nice.  I absolutely loved the grilled asparagus. I could have ate nothing but that, but the spaghetti was delicious too.

I'd recommend making reservations and going on a week night if possilble. Parking is tough, so arrive early.
author: Darby L.

description:
When your mom is in town, or your friend's mom is in town, or your mom's friend is in town... let's go out to dinner is spelled D-e-l-f-i-n-a. I don't trust myself to go when my own wallet will take the hit because I want to order everything and it's torture to see all the delectable things on the menu and not be able to order, and order, and order...

I have to admit that I've only been once, but seriously, oh how that joy has carried me. I went in February and loved the seasonal use of blood oranges. I had a blood orange bellini. A blood orange fennel salad. And panna cotta with blood orange sauce. I grew up with a blood orange tree in my back yard and, in true adolescent fashion, felt like a freak of nature that my family's orange tree wasn't like the other orange trees in the neighborhood. Thank you Delfina, for allowing me to make amends with the blood orange. 

What's more, the aforementioned, fennel and blood orange salad also broke my years-long loathing of fennel. 

Delfina is food magic. But in a down-to-earth, food magic for the masses sort of way. Especially when the masses' moms are in town.
author: reb f.

description:
So, there is this great new restaurant that nobody* has heard of called Delfina. Wait? What? This is the 254th review for Delfina? Ok, scratch that. 254 reviews?! My review is the literary equivalent of adding a sentence to the Iliad.

Regardless, I have to weigh in with my opinion of the place.  I had an epiphany last night while laying in bed clutching my stomach -- Delfina is the Babel of the SF restaurant scene.  

No one in his/her right mind thinks Babel is an incredible movie, yet when it came Oscar time Babel was nominated for Best Picture.  Why?  It looked the part from the cinematography to the acting -- it had that Oscar caliber sheen. The only problem was that the story was quite simply a turd rotating down a toilet bowl into oblivion told from 3 different locales.

Delfina is very similar.  It looks the part of a great restaurant.  There are crowds outside, the inner ambiance is hip with great mood lighting and giant mirrors, the staff is extremely helpful, the wine list is big without being intimidating, and the menu has a wide range of dishes to pick from.  Then, when everything arrives, so does the cognitive dissonance.  The food is average.  Wait, all this buildup for average food?  It's not bad like Babel is bad, but something doesn't click.

*Of note, Tim Gunn was there last night sitting at a window table trying to come up with a catch phrase for next season's Project Runway.  I can't wait to see his yelp review of the place!
author: Tim G.

description:
apologies to tone loc... 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zligio51yP4
and it goes a little something like this....

I went out with this girl... and she said, Hi my name is Xena
I thought she'd be good to go to a spot they call Delfina

She said, I'd like a drink, I said, tell the waitress to go fetch it.
So we ordered up some pinot grigio and let it hit the palate.

The mozzarella salad with the tomatoes was our beginner.
But the other couple said the cod mantecato was the winner.

Some small talk and some laughs got us to the meal
I was eyein' the salmon, but that spaghetti is a steal!

Dinner was good, but would I remember to yelp review???
Fucking 3 days later I still got on their disposable tattoo.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/YqvoyaNvtoC8N5dA8pD2JA?select=jKwgWH-LUR1wXhvg_4cs2A
author: Kevin F.

description: Delfina is a winner, each and every time. This restaurant is like a well-oiled machine. Service is always excellent, dishes come out at a good pace, food is consistently superb.
author: Mona B.

description:
I really dislike this restaurant-way over-rated. They cram people in like sardines.

We were seated at a table that was right under people eating at a counter, facing us. Those people could and did cough right into our faces and food-gross!

The wait staff were quite abrupt and not that friendly.

The food was okay, no complaints there but I'm in no hurry to go back to this restaurant.
author: John D.

description:
My pasta was so good!  I am a huge pasta fan, but try to stay away because of an ingrained fear of carbs.  That being said, I do enjoy it every once in a while and I especially enjoyed the dish with spicy cauliflower (I don't see it on the menu right now).  They also have a great wine list.

One thing - My dining companion ordered the Prosciutto and mascarpone ravioli with lemon-herb butter, which wasn't as good (even though the waiter recommended it).  

I also love the decor and the waitstaff was really friendly and easy going - we were seated right away with no reservation.
author: Sarah S.

description:
5 stars for the orgasmic Castelvetrano olives served warm and in orange infused olive oil.  I still fantasize about those.  Unfortunately, the rest of the meal failed to live up to that one extremely high note.  

We split the salad, and I ordered a cioppino-like seafood stew and tried some of my friend's steak.  It was good, but not anything spectacular or particularly memorable.  Perhaps we just ordered the wrong things and should've gone with pasta instead.  But the fish seemed overcooked and the flavor of the stew was not very interesting.  Steak and salad were good, but very standard.

Service was exceptional.  They were extremely accommodating when our party exceeded our reservation by 2 people and did their best to seat us nearby.  At times, the service felt even a bit excessive (do we really need 3 different people to help us pick a wine?)  But they were very friendly and did pick some great wines.

I just wish I could rave about the entrees as well.  I'd be willing to give them another try, if only getting a table without reservations wasn't near impossible.
author: Leslie L.

description: Wow. The food is extraordinary, but the service is to be experienced. The staff work as this incredible team that make your dining experience so memorable you will want to come back and bring friends. We asked our waiter, Aaron, to please let us relax and enjoy a leisurely dinner and that is exactly what we had. Come and experience this wonderful restaurant for yourself but do call ahead for a reservation because the word is out how good it is. Thanks Delfina
author: Alan G.

description:
I went to Delfina during Hanukkah so I had the privilege of trying their Latkes! So yum, especially the apple sauce. For my main course I had Gnocci Ragu, it truly melted in my mouth. For dessert my boyfriend and I shared Profiteroles they were pretty good, but next time I'll try a cheese plate.  All of this plus another large plate was only about $60! Yes! 5 Stars!

I have one minor complaint and that is the way the tables are set in the back of the restaurant. They're a little crammed, I could use some more room for privacy, more room to breath and eat/indulge!

5 Stars!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Janice K.

description: This was my first stop after arriving in SF, I was starving and this place didn't disappoint. I ordered the hanger steak and it was delicious. I ordered it medium rare and it had so much more flavor than a typical filet. For dessert we ordered the profiteroles which were delicious, the chocolate was rich and dark and they were filled with espresso gelato. The service was excellent, they were very friendly and efficient.
author: Alex W.

description:
We recently had the pleasure of dining at Delfina and we had an amazing meal.  We were a party of five so we had the opportunity to try several of the dishes.  I have to say that my favorites were the Squash Blossom Risotto and the Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken - others in our group loved the Meyer Ranch Hanger Steak and the Grilled Monterey Bay Sardine.  But the real highlight of the meal was the incredible desserts by pastry chef Abby Olitsky.  Being a chocolate freak, my favorites were the Profiteroles - amazing! - and the Warm Teho Chocolate Torta.  The Lemon Verbena Semifreddo also got rave reviews.  Can't wait to go back there next time we're in San Francisco!

Debra W.
author: Debra W.

description:
I have to agree with other reviewers.  I had huge expectations given how difficult it is to get a reservation.  The atmosphere was fun & chic.  The bread was great and I do like having a pitcher of water on the table.  

We ordered the following:

Fresh ricotta wrapped in fig leaf w/pardon peppers & tomato soaked bread - it was good, not fantastic.  The cheese is bland, the peppers were good and the tomato soaked bread was good but clearly not enough sauce.  You needed more sauce for the bland ricotta.

Tried the romano (flat green beans) sauteed in tomatoes & garlic - again, just okay.

Spaghetti - good - not memorable
Risotta w/squash and squash blossoms.  The risotto had orange zest in it so all you tasted was orange flavors.

This was not a memorable meal and with all of the hype and other good restaurants in SF - I wouldn't return.  

They were quite pricey for the small portions as well.  Happy to spend a fortune if the meal is memorable.

Wait staff were friendly.  

The best part about the meal was to sneak across the street at bi-rite ice cream and get some organic ice cream - that was worth the trip
author: Michelle S.

description:
I haven't been back to Delfina in ages, but wanted to take pookie there. We showed up on a Friday night at 9:30m and the place was hopping. We were able to get a seat at the bar right away though. 

The waitress at the bar was friendly but a little busy, but we were patient. The patience paid off. The food was even more delicious than I remembered. Everything is perfectly prepared and so different and delicious. We had a homemade ravioli that were filled with short ribs and finished with a great meaty flavorful beef reduction with orange zest. The pasta was perfectly al dente and the filling and sauce were amazing.

Everything was delicious, but homemade pasta is always my favorite at a nice Italian joint. I can't wait to come back again soon.
author: Karen C.

description:
You know how sometimes a restaurant gets all this hype, and then when you get there, you're disappointed? Well, that's not the case here. Delfina is one of my absolute favorites! Their pasta dishes are particularly good; I never knew gnocchi could melt like butter. (I take that back - it's not butter, but BUTTAh! ) And the setting is perfect. Great for a date or for a group of friends. 

If you could only see me writing this review... I'm practically rolling on the ground just thinking of how fabulous it is. That's not a pretty sight, but I can't help myself. Divine!

3/31 UPDATE: I've lost count of how many times I've dined at Delfina, and since I consider myself to be a foodie who loves to try new places, that says a lot. I have a hard time getting past two trips to most restaurants - even with the ones I like!

Last night was wonderful, as always. This may have been one of the best nights yet. We ordered:
-Grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad
-Insalata del campo (Bitter greens, pancetta, walnuts, parmigiano and balsamic vinaigrette)
-Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini 
-Fazzoletti all rag
-Niman Ranch flatiron steak and French fries
-Cauliflower "bagna cauda"
-Buttermilk panna cotta with candied kumquats
-Bittersweet Scharffen Berger chocolate cake with crme Anglaise

If I were to go by myself, I would definitely get the spaghetti, with the insalata del campo to start... and I might try to throw in the grilled calamari (and promise myself I'd go for a long run the next day). If I had to choose my least favorite from the list above, I would choose the steak - but that doesn't mean I didn't enjoy it! It's like asking a mother to choose which child she loves the least. I'm just trying to maximize the dining experience of anyone who is reading this and planning to visit.

DELFINA, I LOVE YOU! If you would let me set up a bed and live within your walls, I would do it. I realize a live-in crazy stalker might not be good for business, so I won't ask. But you won't be getting rid of me anytime soon. Please don't file a restraining order.
author: jenn h.

description:
Ooooh, what a date that was! 
Prosciutto (or was it pancetta) and marscapone stuffed raviolis in a butter sauce worthy of an award. I was nearly crying in ecstacy. My date ordered the flank steak that was killer. I believe we ordered an app too, but I really don't remember what we got!!!! The entrees rocked my world enough to lead to temporary amnesia.
Seriously good date restaurant!
author: Jessa B.

description:
This place is always good.  Went last night and had the petrale sole, which was amazing...cooked so perfectly, so moist, so yummy. My friend had the tuna which i passed on because of the olive tapenade.  I know, they go hand in hand for most people. I am not a fan. Keep your olives away from my tuna.  It's like mayo sauces in a sushi roll. Overpowering.

Anyway, we both enjoyed our food, the bottle of sauvignon blanc was outstanding, and the service was nop notch.  The only downside is that we had to wait 10 minutes with a reservation, and there were no seats at the bar. The bar area is pretty tiny, so you're kind of trapped. 

tip: get a drink at the bar and sneak out the front.  there's a bench outside to cozy up with while you wait.
author: k. w.

description:
I went here a while back, but I still remember the night (at least my half of it).

I had the spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini and mashed potatoes. I can't remember what my friend ordered, but I do remember that when I placed my order my waitress said something along the lines of, "Someone's not on a carb diet," which kind of put me off. Like, oh, should I be on one? What can I say? I love my carbohydrates.

The food was good. The atmosphere was buzzing. The people eating there were very diverse. You can definitely listen in on people's interesting conversations as the tables were very close to each other (looks like they changed the layout of where I sat).

Most interesting thing of the the night though was that this is the night I had a close encounter with a celebrity.

There was one table open by the window. While we were waiting in line we wondered why no one was being seated there. They said it was for a special guest.

The special guest was Owen Wilson plus one.
author: Zi C.

description:
When they pull attitude as you try to make a reservation a month in advance (10 mins. on hold on a Sunday night - "Oh, who are you again?"), you expect that there must be some reason that they can treat you like this - and you think, "Oh boy this place better ROCK!"

It's a beautiful room, very well lighted, and I felt somewhat smug as those waiting for a table gaped as the hostess led my friend and I right past them.  Yeah, that's right baby - I have a SOLID reservation!  But that was about as much satisfaction as I could get out of it, as the hostess seemed stressed, in a hurry, and didn't make much of an attempt to make us feel welcome.

We had a corner table, which was very nice, very romantic, and our server was an absolutely charming woman.  There were some minor missteps in service (not having the right utensils, bread arriving way way late), but the celery root soup was heavenly and the insalata del campo had the right balance of bitter and tangy.

Entrees were less exciting, but still very good, especially the Caifornia sea bass.  

I can imagine that Delfina is extremely consistent, so I'm likely to want to return, but I'm having a hard time seeing what all the hype is.  Is it that hard to get consistently good food in SF?  I say no.
author: Evan G.

description:
Another place with no need for my comment - 

but I love it  - fresh, simple, seasonal - what I think of when I think of San Francisco food.

The buttermilk panna cotta was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOO yum perfect!
author: Robyn C.

description: The best in the city. always take my parents (from belgium) there and they are real foodies on Italian cuisine, they always love that place. Simple but good, no fuss, the way good food should be !
author: Jef C.

description:
I used to work at Bistro Aix way back in the day...and the owner of that restaurant is buddy buddy with one of the owners of Delfina. My co-worker friend at Aix got hooked up by the big boss man and was offered to go take a gander at Delfina. So, lucky me I got to go.

Now, at this point in my life I was definitely not a "foodie" like my friend so I really didn't comprehend her mouth watering drama at the prospect of dining here. And, of course because our rez was called in by our boss, we got VIP treatment. This was a while back and really all I could remember was there was a weiner on the menu...as a special. I thought this was the funniest thing I had ever seen, and you know we had to order it. I don't recall how it tasted or the presentation of that weiner on the plate...but I remember the laugh we had. Fun times.

My friend had a food orgasm since we got to taste basically everything on the menu (it's nice to be a VIP). I also remember the server being really awesome..but again, we had special treatment. I think it would have been a whole different ball game otherwise. 

It was a great night and knowing what I know now...I feel lucky I got to experience this restaurant the way that I did. I wouldn't say that it blew my mind in any way shape or form, but the special treatment was....special.

P.S.  Bisto Aix is the bomb!
author: Jocelyn J.

description:
Still awesome. (I'll probably go into mourning the day it's not.)

Normally, I'm not a big fan of gnocchi. I'd rather have mashed potatoes or pasta, not some weird hybrid of the two. My friend ordered it here the other day and I stole a bite. Delicious.

I have been noticing something strange though...Every time I come, I get the grilled calamari. Sometimes the plate comes with two squid and sometimes it comes with three. And it's not like the two squid have been bigger while the three squid have been smaller. I really need to ask about that the next time I'm there...
author: D E.

description: Ahh, Delfina, let me count the ways...I have been here too many times to actually admit considering all of the wonderful restaurants that exist in SF.  Everything that comes out of that kitchen is pure gold (edible of course).  Why are you still reading these reviews, GO...GO ASAP!
author: a c.

description: This review is a bit overdue...but Delfina was hands down one of the best meals in San Francisco that I have had!  Everything was perfect, from the Bellinis we had as an aperitif to the last ounce of panna cotta for dessert.  Absolutely divine! I wish I could remember every dish we had, though I do remember choosing most of our dishes based on the waitress' recommendations - we were not at all disappointed!
author: Laura C.

description:
Best asparagus I've ever had (wrapped in Prosciutto and sauteed in butter = to die for). Prices were very reasonable for the quality. Arrived on a Thu night, 9 PM with no reservations and ended up being one of the last tables seated about 90 minutes later. 

The staff was very knowledgable and down to earth, providing us great attention considering how busy they were. Holding back the 5th star until I try something more than just pasta (even then -- amazing sauce, but I can't give 5 stars without trying the meat).
author: David M.

description: Great food.  Very nice service.  The only reasons I give it 3 stars is because the tiny tables are really packed in so it feels overly crowded, and the noise level is phenomenal.  The acoustics must not be very good because it was really difficult to have a decent conversation.  It's a shame because the food is worth the trip.  Might try the pizzeria next door if I ever feel like waiting in line forever....
author: Linda P.

description:
I don't have anything to add that hasn't already been said.

Ridiculous food (especially for the price).
Perfect service.
Amazing wine.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I am not a foodie.

I have never been one...and I never will be. HOWEVER.

My friend from NYC was visiting, and she is allergic to soy. In case people don't know, that basically limits her to eating lettuce. Its sickeningly hard to find places to eat out at that have anything that won't kill her. Shes also (surprise surprise) really abrasive and hard to please. Yankee and all.

My friend Alicia has been singing the praises of this place to my bored ears forever, and she convinced me to go with her and take my visiting friend along, saying it would cater to her needs and be the best food she has ever eaten.

Oh my word, was she right. Not only were the staff competant, cute, sweet, and ever so poised, the FOOD was -amazing-. I had clam linguine in natural salt water brine...some sort of decadent cheese risotto thing...a cocktail with blood orange juice in it (oh so sexy)...and the centerpiece - some sort of sweet cheese dessert thing with caramel sauce.

The dessert was nearest to orgasmic that food has ever brought me.

My friend ate everything, loved it like life itself, and still talks about it even after she left to go home.

Go here. Love it. Tell your friends. Take your family...and tell the cute dessert chef I said hello ;)
author: Rylan S.

description:
I ate at Delfina last Thursday (admittedly, a less-than-ideal 9:30pm ressie) and I can't stop thinking about my meal there.

Yes, it's tiny.  
Yes, it can be loud and you will probably hear more of your neighbors' conversation than you'd prefer to (see below).  
Yes, the size will probably mean that you or your guest will have to make the "ass or crotch" decision articulated so well by Brad Pitt in Fight Club (for what it's worth, I went with ass).  
But these truths are applicable to many SF restaurants and yet very few have left me as smitten as Delfina.  I'd also like to point out that Delfina's website plays "noise" in the background.  If that's not full disclosure, I don't know what is.

My "no red meat" dining partner and I shared the gem lettuce salad and the grilled calimari.  
Yeah, I know what you're thinking: salad, schmalad.  But oh MY GOD, you'd be wrong.  I was one glass of wine away from asking for a straw to slurp up the remaining drabs of dressing.  I'm not even sure what all was involved in the making of this little bit of nectar of the gods but it's not to be missed.
The grilled calimari was tender and delicious.  Both dishes were perfect complements to the entrees.
My friend did the salmon and I had the special: spaghettini with cuttlefish and cuttlefish ink (e.g., black spaghetti).  The flavors in this dish were incredibly complex: spicy (in a Thai-like way despite the Italian preparation), salty, sweet...and just incredibly fresh tasting.  
I remember loving my friend's salmon but that love has given way to a singular and unwavering focus on my cuttlefish pasta.

Our experience was, it must be said, augmented by the attentive and, at times, hilarious service of an adorable, curly-haired waiter named Oliver.  Sigh.

Finally, and I realize this is in no way a reflection on the food/service at Delfina, our evening ended on a high note when we overheard this conversation between the couple next to us: a normal looking dude who appeared to have requested an escort dressed in Ice Capades thematic garb.
Him: Let's order dessert?
Her: Okay...oooh, fromage--what's that?
Him: That's French for cheese.
Her: Oh yum.  And profiteroles...what are those?
Him: Um, these cream-stuffed tube-shaped dough thingies.
Her: Oh wow...it all sounds so good.   Panna cotta...hmm--what's that?
Him: A flan-like, er, custard.  It's custard.

You can't make this shit up.
Five stars to Delfina for broadening the culinary horizons of one lucky whore in San Francisco.
author: Auburn D.

description: I visit San Francisco about 4 times a year.  After having a wonderful meal at Delfina's I might increase it to 5 times a year.  Great food, Great service.  I can not wait to go back.
author: Pamm S.

description: Appetizers were great - a light  fritto misto (not overly deep fried) and a riboletta (a vegetable and bread soup reboiled to the point where it is eaten with knife and fork) were exceptional.  My entree was less exceptional: a small slab of pork belly cooked with cockles and chick peas. The cockles and pork married well in the broth but the dish lacked substance.  Perhaps some rice or polenta to soak up the broth?  A fine meal, but one that fell a little short of its potential. Sophisticated service and ambiance.
author: art f.

description:
I've lived around the corner from this restaurant for years, and I remember walking by it when it first opened, thinking "this place looks good, I'll have to try it some time."  Well, being on a budget, I kept putting it off and putting it off, so I didn't actually wind up going for the first time until about 2 years ago.  

Overall I found the experience mixed.  I would say that you pay more for ambience here than you do for the actual quality of the cuisine.  The food is certainly good, but it was not so good that I walked away feeling that I had experienced anything special.  The service was competent and professional, yet we were rushed to finish our courses so that they could reclaim our table and we were cramped in so tight that the woman at the table next to me kept bumping me with her elbow.  Delfina is certainly nice if you can afford to go to a place like this often, but if you're like me and can only do so every now and then, you're much better off giving your business to someplace like Bizou where the quality of the meal is a notch higher, and the waitstaff is so sensitive to the pacing of the meal that they seem to read your mind.

In sum, Delfina is good, but the hype about it is unfounded.  There are many far better places in the same price range to choose from in the city.
author: Matthew M.

description:
So, finally, I went to eat at Delfina....
Honestly, not that impressed.  It was....alright.  I can think of 10 gajillion more impressive restaurants in the city.  
Food was good, but not outstanding.  Server was nice, but service was a little sloppy.  
All in all, not a bad experience, but not awesoooommmeee as everyone else's reviews would have you to believe.  Not worth the moula, or the hype, or the reservation wait, for that matter.
author: Mary S.

description:
Does it need another rave review? 
No. 
(But I just wanted to throw my five-stars in.)
author: Val U.

description:
I went here last night with my friend for his birthday and I had an excellent experience. The placed was packed with people waiting outside (on a cold january sf monday evening) so it was good that I had made 8:30 reservations. 

From the moment I walked in the hostess greeted us with a friendly smile and made us feel very welcome. The lighting was perfect, the other diners were upbeat without being too loud and our server. What an angel. She took us through the whole menu and choose a wine for us to taste (Franciacorta - Contadi Castaldi, delicious throuought the entire meal).  

We ended up having the calamari and white bean salad to start. I had eaten this dish here before and it was just as good in round #2. Our dinner took a long time to prepare and the waitress was such a doll and kept informing us of its ETA and even comped our wine. It was worth the wait,  I had the Spaghettini "in nero" with sepia and uni which was an incredible dish. It looks and tastes like a regular tomato basil spaghetti combination but the squid ink provides an exciting and beautiful flavor at the end. My friend had a gnochi bolognese that wasn' t on the menu and was equally delicious. 

Delfina was great the second time and I give it five stars for food, five for service, and five for atmosphere.
author: Tom V.

description: I usually don't think twice about the complimentary bread they serve at the start of your meal. But the bread at Delfina was simple and delicious. It was fluffy, moist, and warm. I couldn't get enough. Highly recommend the grilled fresh calamari as an appetizer. I ordered the roasted Fulton Valley chicken. The chicken was juicy and tender, and the mushrooms (though few) complemented the dish very well. My friend ordered the gnocchi, and he seemed to enjoy it, but I was more satisfied with what I had ordered. We ordered the vanilla-roasted strawberry crespelle (apparently Delfina's made-up word for crepe) for dessert. Nothing spectacular. My friend really seemed to like the home-made mascarpone that topped the crepes though.
author: Sophia B.

description:
A friend was just raving about how great this restaurant is and how it's hard to get a reservation. Needless to say, this set a certain expectation for me. So, when I got there I was disappointed... it wasn't as great as she was raving. 
Mostly I was disappointed by the set up and the ambiance of the restaurant. The tables were set up way too close to other tables, such that I could easily put my hand on the other table. But to be fair, the food was good and I really liked the pairings. We had the grilled sardines with white beans and a salad to share. We also shared a fava bean ravioli, which tasted bland. However, the muscles and spicy garbanzo soup, that I ordered was very good. My friend ordered her favorite dessert with coffee. I was too full to order dessert. And that's okay, because the best dessert can be had at Cafe Esin near my house.
author: Susan M.

description:
Not nearly as pricey as I thought it would be!  And it was lovely--there were quite a few things that interested me on the menu.

We opted for an appetizer we'd never heard of before: Ribollita "da Delfina."  It was explained as taking minestrone soup, and adding enough bread to soak up the broth, then pan frying it.  Really interesting flavor--we liked it!

I had the salmon, which was just delicious.  The best salmon I had had in a long time.

I guess I could go on and on about the menu items, but that would just be disappointing, now wouldn't it?  I just peeked at the menu online, and it already has changed....wouldn't want to build up something you couldn't get.

The takeaway then might be that there were 4 of us, and we all enjoyed our dishes, which were very well-prepared.  It's likely safe to assume that the food is solid and thoughtful.  Ambiance was good, as was the service.  We'll be back!
author: Lori G.

description:
I LOVE This place. It is consistent, and the staff is very friendly! You definitely want to make a reservation though. I went on a random Wed night, and was lucky to get a seat!! at first I was a little unsure if I wanted to sit at the bar area, but it turned out to be wonderful; only because the server was amazing. He was attentive, had great recommendations, and even asked us if we wanted to wait before our entrees came out since we were still eating the cheese. He was on point! 
The food was amazing too. I had the roasted chicken, which was soooo flavorful. It came in two pieces, so by the time I had my wine, cheese, and mash potatoes, I couldn't finish the whole thing!! 
Will definitely go back!!!
author: jennifer h.

description:
Delfina (the restaurant) is my least favorite of the Delfina Group restaurant. We had dinner reservations tonight and were seated promptly. Sevice was friendly and attentive throughout dinner, but the food is kind of "eh". During our visit, we had the squash custard as an appetizer. This dish was good (not great). I had the duck paparadelle, which I was really looking forward to, but it was disappointingly salty and boring. Bf had the short ribs and he also thought his dish was salty and boring. For dessert, I had the lemon meringue which I liked, but it was nothing special. Dinner above and a couple of fizzy drinks was $84 w/o tip. 

Overall, I'm glad I came here to try the food and so I'm not curious anymore.  But, if I was feeling like Italian for dinner again, I would go to  one of their other restaurants instead.
author: Trinh N.

description:
The holidays are days when I like being a local.  The restaurants are far less crowded than usual and it takes me all but TWO MINUTES to find a parking spot ... in the Mission!  

The food is great here but seriously, this place is overrated.  I was expecting phenomenal but, comparing this to my recent dining experience at Trattoria La Siciliana, I was about a quarter shy of that.  The atmosphere is very chic, very Pottery Born or maybe Z Gallerie, if they were in Italy.  The service was timely and accommodating.  They seated us even when our entire party hadn't showed up yet.  The food and the waitress arrived when we wanted it too.

Their grilled calamari is tasty, though I wouldn't recommend sharing this "made for 2" dish among 5.  Their sea bass pasta special was a winner.   Their risotto wasn't half bad either.  The chicken was juicy but as all non-sauce-y chickens go, was on the bland side.  I really liked their panettone.  Their chocolate torte was an interesting mix of sweet and salty.  Overall a very pleasant dining experience though nothing truly exceptional.  I would say 3.5 stars, with a half star extra for being a great place to enjoy good company.
author: Jean A.

description:
Very nice Italian place that has a seasonal menu.  I got their "scallops on a bed of leeks" recipe from Gourmet's website and made it at home.  Simply blissful.

It's always crowded, so make a reservation.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Yum!  

Before last night I'd been to Delfina once with some work colleagues a couple of years ago.  Due to copious amounts of wine and squabbling over changes in staff, I didn't remember much about the food but know I thoroughly enjoyed it.  

Anyhow, on to the present.  Or more recent past. 

Mister B was able to secure a reservation for three a couple of nights ago, which was somewhat surprising but whatever, I was happy.  We walked in and were seated immediately.  I hate to sound like a betch but we did wait for a few minutes to be greeted and offered water.  And I'm a patient person.  Anyhow, the conversation and people-watching made it easier to suffer through it ;)  Delfina is lively but not so much that you can't carry a conversation.  

Our server was candid and awesome.  He had some great wine recommendations based on what we were looking for ("a white, not smelly-feet-esque, not too crisp"  HAHA!  seriously, Mister B said this)

The food was fan-effing-tastic.  We started with the Salt Cod Mantecato which was delicate, but the accompanying fennel seed flatbread was the real star.  The insalata di campo offered a different and vibrant flavour in each bite---uber salty pancetta, tangy vinaigrette, parm shavings, my mouth is watering just thinking about it.  

I wasn't terribly hungry so opted for a primi, the rosemary tagliatelle with guinea hen ragu and chestnuts.  The homemade pasta was delicious, and ragu was a happy medium between brick-in-my-stomach and I'm-still-hungry-let's-order-a-pizza.  I regret not getting a side of the broccoli rabe or greens as I think they would have gone well with it.

Mister B had the king salmon, which was absolutely beautiful.  It came on a bed of asparagus and carrots, topped with this meyer lemon sauce and capers.  The salmon was silky in texture and had a more delicate essence of oily goodness so often associated with the fish.

Mister E had the mixed grill which consisted of rabbit (he said it was ok), chicken liver (didn't seem to impress him much but he's not a big liver fan), and lamb sausage.  I usually find sausage to be too fatty and don't like it, but this stuff was unforgettable.  Darn, my mouth is watering again!

Good wine selection, I think it was split between Italian and American.

Another really cool thing about Delfina is that they have open bar seating, some in a little room facing the actual bar, and another in the main room overlooking all of the other diners.  Great idea!

We didn't have room for dessert, but since this place is only a five-minute walk away, I will be back.  I kinda want to go back right now.
author: Aimee B.

description: Loved Delfina! It's a nice little Italian restaurant. While waiting to be seated, me and 2 friends ordered drinks (I went with the bellini), which I enjoyed. Service was great there. We ordered the spaghettini (I wasn't too impressed with that), chicken, and beef. We all shared those and unanimously liked the beef the best. It came with olive oil mashed potatoes and some kind of corn meal side dish. Delicious bread as well. I'd definitely recommend stopping in for dinner!
author: Allison R.

description: I've walked by Delfina countless times and have never seen the place less than brimming with people. After eating here I can see why. Though the menu is brief, the food does not disappoint. We ordered the mint tagliatelle with chanterelle mushrooms and creme fraiche. It was pretty solid, but lacked salt. The chard was great, as was the fig salad. All in all, a great dining experience!
author: Kelly N.

description:
I'm really not sure why I haven't reviewed Delfina yet, being that its one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  This place is awesome and I always have a great meal here.

Our last meal was the day after Valentine's Day.  We've gone to Delfina to celebrate Valentine's Day on either the 13th or the 15th for the past few years (since Molly usually works on Valentine's Day) and its great because you don't have to deal with the crowds.

We had a 9pm reservation and showed up on-time and were immediately seated.  Even though you could practically reach over and try your neighbor's food, we settled into our cozy table and blocked out everyone else.  We brought a bottle of Bandol rosé that we opened and ate with our appetizer courses.

We ended up having 5 courses, but each had just one dish that we shared.  For us, this is the perfect way to dine.  We started with the Ahi Carpaccio ($16), a paper thin piece of pounded ahi on a bed of shredded fennel topped with blood orange segments and chervil.  A delicious, light and clean dish.  Next we got the Calamari with White Beans ($9.25), a Delfina classic and a dish I can't imagine getting tired of.  The calamari is tender and served on a bed of warm white beans with a delicious vinaigrette that has enough citrus and richness to feel hearty and light at the same time.  I get this dish every time I'm here.  Next we shared a half order of the Crab Spaghetti ($11.50), a simple and delicious dish with succulent pieces of dungeness crab and aldente pasta.

For our entree we had the Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken ($18), a hearty bone in chicken dish served with king trumpet mushrooms and olive oil mashed potatoes.  Definitely a portion fit for sharing, this was the perfect dish for a cold night.  With this dish we shared a glass of barbera ($9.50), a great compliment.  

We didn't order a dessert, but our waitress could tell we hesitated and brought us one on the house.  I always love their panna cotta and lucky for me, that's just what she brought us.  The Buttermilk Panna Cotta ($9) with blood orange and vanilla caramel sauce was absolutely delicious and hard to stop eating.

Our waitress (I think her name was Allison) was great and made our dining experience that much better.  She was knowledgeable about the food and wines and had a relaxed way about her that made us feel at ease.  

Once again, another perfect night at Delfina.
author: Ariel D.

description:
Whenever we have extra money, something to celebrate or someone in town who wants to take us to dinner, we try Delfina.
We don't always get to eat there because we usually don't have time to make reservations but lately we've been able to sit at the bar to eat (having only two and trying a weeknight really help).
We love most of the salads we've had and they change so we try whatever sounds yummy and it usually is.  It's the pasta, wine and dessert that keep us coming back.

Pasta Highlights
- fresh artichoke pasta with baby artichokes - amazing! We could taste the artichoke in the pasta - which, was a little bit of heaven.
Our server/the bartender told us about how they don't usually have artichokes in February but there was a warm snap and there were some very tasty but ugly chokes in their veggie delivery. So, they made pasta so we could taste the wonderfulness but not get turned off by the looks of them. 
I love a place that tells you stories about the food you're eating.
- short rib ravioli - holyness in my mouth. The sauce was like barbeque but not standard. It was a thin glaze that added just enough flavor. Amazing.
- nettle tagliatelle (I'm pretty sure it was tagliatelle) with a nettle sauce - I was skeptical but the waitress assured us it was wonderful and it really was. I wanted greens that night and I got them in such a delicious way.

Wine highlights
- We found a most wonderful wine there - Lacrima di morro d'alba - it tasted just like blueberries (without being sweet and cloying) and our bartender/server told us all about it.
- They always have really tasty and seasonal bellinis - the blood orange one was out of this world.

Dessert highlights
- Buttermilk pannacotta - always amazing. I loved it when they served it with ruby grapefruit but my man didn't care for the dramatic contrast in flavor and texture. The next time it came with blood orange and we both loved it.
- Chocolate torte with olive oil gelato and sea salt - WOW. I love olive oil and I love chocolate and I had to try this. It sounded interesting and like something I couldn't imagine. The olive oil gelato really tasted like a very flavorful olive oil - not olives. The salt was the perfect touch and the chocolate was rich and thick - tho, a touch dry, but that's torte for you!

I highly recommend 
- anything pasta, it's always outstanding
- ask for a wine pairing or suggestion rather than heading out on your own (unless you are a super wine connoisseur and know regions/flavors etc) 
- save room for dessert.
author: Adriene C.

description:
I hate to review the restaurant thats all hype but MMM-MMM-MMM!  So small and crowded but great dark sexy lighting and the food is to die for.  Spaghetti is just spaghetti until you come here. Its the best i've ever tasted.  Small portions so 2 people can order an appetizer, a pasta and a main dish and maybe have room for dessert if you come hungry (which you should).  I suggest sharing, dont limit yourself to one dish.  Save it for a special occasion (unless someone else is picking up the tab!)  and dont forget to make a reservation.

I want to come back...so badly...
author: Cathleya G.

description:
I waited almost 2 years to eat here, until just the right time, when I could find someone to pay for me, haha. Anyhow, ate here with family one warm summer evening (like we've ever had one of those in the city). This may have the best atmosphere of any restaurant in SF. It's full of energy, everyone festive, fantastic friendly service. And Delfina lives on on of the coolest blocks around, right next to Tartine, Bi-Rite, Delores Park, and the rest of the Mission flyness. 

What I can recommend: the beef shortrib pasta, if they're serving it. It's handmade pyramid raviolis filled with the hearty stuff. fantastic. Not a big entree, but worth it nonetheless. the nettle pasta is fantastic, a similar to pesto. The menu changes frequently so you never know what they might be serving that night. 

And while the food's creative and pricey, this place has none of the trappings of hushed, fancy restaurants. It's loud, hoppin' and overally a social experience. As any great restaurant should be. 

Now I must get back to writing my semi-autobiographical rap album about a porpoise and a man with a purpose. Good night.
author: Andrew K.

description:
MMMM.... I've been the Pizzeria in Pac Heights, but I've been wanting to go to the restaurant for a long time, because I've heard so much about it from my friends who live in the Mission.  I finally took my girlfriend there for her birthday, and we were not disappointed!

We couldn't get a reservation but when we walked in at around 6:30 on a Friday, we were able to get seated immediately at the counter.  Maybe not the most romantic seating arrangement, but we were hungry and just happy to be getting some food!  

We like to try a lot of things, so we ordered two apps and two "main" dishes.  We had the grilled calamari with white beans, the corn & basil soup, the papardelle with duck sugo, and the risotto with squash and squash blossoms.

The calamari was really good, but I really loved the white beans!  I used all my bread to scoop up all the beans until the plate was clean.  The soup was really light and creamy, and had a very nice flavor.  I didn't think that corn and basil went together, but it was a great combination.  

I thought that the Risotto was good, but I've had better Risotto elsewhere.  The papardelle was the star of the meal.  The pasta was cooked perfectly and the the duck sugo was so tasty that I again used my bread to get the last of the sauce -- it was the theme of the night, I guess.  If it wasn't my girlfriend's birthday, I may have actually licked the plate clean.  

We were too full for dessert, but the ones we saw looked really good, especially the profiteroles.  

Our service was very good and everyone we encountered was very nice.  We look forward to going again, and I'll definitely be having the papardelle again!
author: Pilan C.

description: The food is decent, but to me, this place was just okay~  nothing special with a very long wait.
author: Elena L.

description:
There's three things I love about Delfina - food, food, and more food. It's amazingly good.

Oh yeah, the people working there were super nice and informative and the ambiance was also great.

Highly recommend this place.
author: barry s.

description:
This place is definitely reviewed like crazy and everyone is a fan. This was my first time to Delfina, my husband and I were given a gift certificate as a wedding gift, but because I have to call for a reservation I have always put off using it(ie 3 years have passed!) What I loved most is that nothing on the menu screams WOW. Then, the dish comes, and you are amazed that "grilled calamari" actually is one of the most delicious things you have tasted. 

So, that being said, we started with the grilled calamari over a white bean salad(LOVED THIS!). Great great flavor. We also had a gem lettuce salad that was also great. My husband had the quail and I had the ragu. There is nothing better than fresh pasta, and the quail dish was fantastic! 

We ended with a chocolate torta, basic, but good. I wouldn't say this dessert is the reason I would go back. 

Loved the space, had a great server. I would definitely go back.
author: Jaime C.

description:
Grilled calamari with white bean salad, drizzled in EVOO and served with endless baskets of delicious, warm bread was a great way to start off.  

Our waiter recommended a great bottle of California white to accompany the meal. I had the hanger steak with olive oil mashed potatoes...the steak was tender and succulent but I must admit it was a bit salty (hence the 3 stars). Mashed potatoes were flavorful and creamy! 

My bf had the short ribs with a bean pudding....as picky as he is, he seemed to enjoy it. Had a late reservation but the ambiance was lovely and the hostess and waiters/waitresses were very polite and helpful. 

Can't wait to try the Pizzeria!
author: Ijay J.

description:
Outstanding meal. I hadn't been back here in a couple of years and it was just as good if not better than what I remember. Friendly efficient service, excellent meal and such a reasonable price for the quality you get. 

Had two appetizers, an heirloom tomato bread salad and house cured anchovies. wow wow so yummy. Entree Special of the night was beef shortribs, so tender, so flavorful with a side lil ramekin of polenta. Outstanding.As for desert...omg the profiteroles stuffed with mocha gelato. to die for. 

We walked in at 5.30 and left close to 9 bellies full and so happy. Can't wait to get back here.
author: Lulu S.

description: Still one of the best Italian places in the city.  Pasta is out of this world, looks like the place has gone under a bit of a face lift since I was last there.  Grilled Calamari starter was amazing!  Duck pate was OK... We stuck with the pasta, had 4 total they brought them out 2 at a time as separate courses.  Great friendly service, good people.  Delfina is a can't miss!!
author: Tom W.

description:
An absolutely brilliant meal. I came here with three good friends / project mates to celebrate the end of our project. 

The menu offered selections of up to a 5 course meal, and we all ordered 2-3 selections plus desert.

The wine list was appreciably sorted by region and offered a nice cross section of Italian wines at a good range of prices. We were exceptionally happy with our 38$ bottle of red (min prices around 35).

My salad was substantial, complex, and meticulously balanced. My entree was flavored and cooked very well. It is always nice to be able to experience an array of flavors that don't overwhelm the palette. 

The best part may have been dessert though. We ordered four desserts and split them all and it was like heaven. They have excellent espresso and Ritual coffee as well. 

Every meal should be like this. I will be back.
author: Aaron V.

description:
A very fine restaurant. For my first course, I ordered a very simple salad with avocado and hazelnuts, and I remember thinking, "they must really know what they're doing if they can make something this simple taste this wonderful."

I can't recall what else we ordered (it's been a while), but I do remember oohing and aaahing for the duration of our meal. The service was beautiful - friendly, knowledgeable, and extremely attentive.

It's always wonderful when a restaurant lives up to all the hype.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description:
Good pizza on the west coast is very hard to find unless it's 2am and you've lost your judgement--but that doesn't count. Delfina can probably be categorized as yuppie pizza, but I'm not complaining. Simple, good quality ingredients on top of thin crust. We always go for the Hens Nest: 2 eggs, sunny side up on top of our pie. Broccoli Raab, beet salad, insalata tricolore and the sardines are also on frequent rotation.

Uhhh...

Last weekend, we had someone projectile vomit his dinner in our bathroom after a crazy night of drinking.
Upon exiting our facilities, one friend inquired:
"What was that? Thai Food?"
"No, it was Delfina!" I replied.
"Awesome!"
author: Angela C.

description:
Whoa, hold the salt.  
Grilled Calamari and the Salad with Parmigiano were dealt a heavy salt hand.  Even the butter for the bread had coarse salt crystals on top.  

In spite of NaCl overload, the meal was so delicious.  Peach Bellinis on a balmy Indian Summer night.  Acme bread that you would recognize anywhere.  The quail over polenta and ROAST fig (genius!!).  

Didn't stop there, no boy.  The Scharffenberger cake with creme anglaise was rich without being cloying.  The buttermilk panna cotta with the visual and palate zinging pomengrante seeds was like eating the best creamy thing ever interspersed with a little jolt.

And the service?  The best.  My water glass never went below half empty.  (and I was downing that per the salt content, supra)  The beautiful bohemian waitresses in their crisp long white aprons flowing through the airy space.  Even as walk-ins with a table in the bar area, it was a treat to watch and be served.

It was just a great meal.  (next time, I'll go superhydrated before hand)
author: K W.

description:
I love Delfina, but I know it's not everyone's cup of tea.  I agree that the pasta portions are stingy, and sometimes the dishes don't quite work.  I remember having squash blossoms with PEI mussels and being extremely disappointed with my meal (not to mention that the squash blossoms had a lot of sandy grit in them -gross).

However, there are a several dishes that no other restaurant can top:

- grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad
- insalata di campo (totally worth the $9 price)
- tagliatelle (or pappardelle?) with lemon, mint, and ricotta
- gnocci with nettles 
- gnocci with fava beans
- buttermilk panna cotta

I'm still not hot on the $1.25 per person charge.  It's tough when your  neighborhood restaurant gets more expensive every year, and the additional $1.25 is just another grievance (albeit a good one I suppose).  I'll have to just make due with dining here once a year .  I'll stop whining now.
author: ML P.

description:
Came here on a whim late Friday evening after meaning to try Delfina for quite some time.  I would sum up the experience as unique, and I guess therefore memorable.  The food was thought provoking (if there is such a phenomenon), with unexpected combinations of tastes and aftertastes.  I appreciated the new flavors, but I wouldn't say that the food was spectacular.  My reactions were more of "hmm...how interesting" as opposed to "wow...that's amazing."  

Service was friendly and I wouldn't say that the prices are unreasonable.  I'm glad we finally gave Delfina a visit and would probably return to try out the rest of the menu.
author: Wendy L.

description: Must try if you're in the area! One of my new favorites in San Francisco. The octopus, tomato salad, short rib pasta dish and mint tagliatelle all very delicious. I don't think there is anything on the menu that isn't delicious.. Especially the mint tagliatelle, the perfect juxtaposition of unexpected flavors make a great combination. It's nice to try something different every once in a while! Dessert was profiteroles and pomegranate sorbet. Te profiteroles again, were the perfect combination of sweet and salty. I'm not big on dessert but I'd gladly go back again just for that. Waitstaff was very educated on the food and drinks and prompt and friendly.. My only gripe is how close you can be seated to the next table, unfortunately that is the way in the city.
author: Danielle M.

description:
So, I have an aunt who would always make me "try everything" on my plate.  "How can we take you to Europe if you don't try ____", she would say as I sneered at the funny looking things my grandmother made for dinner.  Her words echoed through my head while making my dinner selection last night. Delfina is one of those restaurants where you need to be a little adventurous.  Of course you don't eat duck giblets on a daily basis - but when it's mixed with homemade pasta and provides a rich earthy flavor to the sauce - it's decadent!  The actual giblets I passed to my date to enjoy.  I did try one - Aunt Carla would be proud!     

So go to Delfina with an adventurous spirit and a willingness to try something new - you won't be disappointed.  If you go, you must try the calamari - it's a delicious treat.
author: Rebecca Z.

description:
I finally was able to try Delfina last week and the food is as fabulous as everyone describes!!  My only gripe is there was a mishap with our service in that they either forgot to put our dinner order in or someone else took our dinner entrees because we had to wait over 45 minutes between appetizers and our dinner to arrive.  They gave us a complimentry ricotta appetizer which I don't really recommend...I wish they would have comp'd us on our dessert that we ordered, oh well.

Otherwise I would give this 5 stars other then the blip in the service.  All the pasta dishes were excellent...I'm definitely going back.
author: Marcie L.

description:
The search for the best Italian restaurant in San Francisco can finally end.  Finally after all this time living in San Francisco, I got to see what Delfina is all about.  One word can sum up our experience:  Stellar.  

It was another outing with abl and yet another multi-course event.   Our server Derek, who was very gracious, really cool and very warm, was really easy about our 5 course escapades.  He quickly brought over the pink bubbles that we had ordered to start our evening right.   

We started with the Salt Cod Mantecato (a brandade) with fennel seed flat bread and the Wild Boar Sausage skewers with a cherry tomato compote and baby arugula.  What I liked the best about everything was that you can tell that its all about the ingredients.  Too much technique could kill a potentially great dish.   Needless to say, our first course was stunning, simply prepared and delicious.

We then had the Spaghetti pasta with plum tomatoes, EVO, garlic,  peperoncini and a hefty amount of grated Parmesan.  It was excellent with the bottle of Chianti Classico Riserva that I had brought in, and the extra EVO I drizzled all over the dish.  Flawless second course.  Again, I was super happy to see little technique and more focus on the ingredients.

Next we had our main course.  I had the Pork Spare Ribs with Cannellini beans and tomatoes.  Abl had the Local Sand Dabs with Frisee, Capers, Potatoes and Lemon.  We loved everything, but we were quickly feeling the effects of ordering a bit too much food.  However, I did leave only 1 rib behind, and it allowed abl and I to  chat it up and take our time with our food.  

To clean our palates, we ordered the Insalata del Campo.  A wonderful blend of radicchio, arugula and endive (amongst other  greens) with pancetta, walnuts tossed with a balsamic vinaigrette. It was a perfect way to get us ready for dessert. 

The one thing I was very keen on noticing too was the fact that Derek, our server, had paced our courses seamlessly.  We weren't overwhelmed with course after course at all.  It was timed perfectly.  Also, this place thrives on the whole team playing.  Everyone was helping each other out.  It's no wonder that Delfina is regarded as one of the best restaurants in the city.

For dessert we had the Profiteroles with Espresso gelato and chocolate ganache, and the best damned Panna Cotta I've ever had in my life.  I think abl would agree with me on that one.  I was saddened by two things:  1.  That dessert had to end (I could have eaten 4 of those Panna Cotta's) and 2.  Delfina doesn't serve Grappa (possibly because they don't have a liquor license).  However, Derek suggested we try the Vernaccia di Oristano and the Malvasia della Lipari.  We loved both of them so much, but I think the Malvasia was the winner of the two.  Such a lovely display that not all dessert wines have to be sweet.  And to top it all off, the dessert wines were on the house and our corkage was waived, which sealed the talks I had heard that Delfina is a generous house.  

Overall, Delfina lived up to and surpassed all the hype I had heard about it.  I cant wait to return and play around some more with the fabulous menu!
author: Maz N.

description:
Overpriced and underwhelming. This is yet another oh-so-trendy restaurant that puts everything into plate presentation. The food is completely unremarkable in every way. The few times I've eaten there I can barely recall what it was I ate. The service is somewhat less than mediocre. You know you're in trouble when you walk out of the restaurant thinking, "let's go get something to eat". 
On the other hand, if you want to impress someone who is easily impressed by a restaurant with a yuppie buzz, you can't go wrong here.  
It would have been one star but the pannacotta scores them an extra star.
author: Joe H.

description:
How stupid am I?  It has been waaaaay too long since I have been to Delfina, and it is simply just one of the very best restaurants in the City.

Five stars, even though the evening started with a bottle of prosecco that exploded over two people in our party.  

The food is without exception excellent.  We had the signature calamari dish and the tomato with mozzarella for starters and they were both amazing.

Two in our parties had salads, one was with little gem lettuce and egg, the other had pancetta and arugula - both salads were excellent.  

For the main course we had the pork ribs, pasta with duck sugo and the hangar steak, and all three were full of flavor, perfectly cooked and were seasoned perfectly - strong yet balanced yet contrasting flavors.

Our desserts were equally enjoyable - fresh intense blackberry flavor in the blackberry sorbetto, intense coffee and chocolate flavor in the espresso profiteroles and last-of-the-season peach crisp with a yummy amaretto cookie.  

The staff were fun, relaxed, professional and, despite a few bobbles in who ordered what, incredibly competent.

The room is filled with rich old white people with really expensive glasses frames, but, the evening is still incredibly fun and satisfying.

We have to go again very very soon!
author: Jim K.

description:
After months of wanting to try this place but never got around to making a reservation and didn't want to try waitingin line, I finally got to go to Delfina last weekend and enjoy the great food that everyone's been Raving about.

We didn't have a reservation and decided to take our chances walking in. To our surprise, they had a table for 2 as long as we were out of there by 8 (and it was 6:15) No problem! We started with the grilled calamari appetizer and lemon asparagus. The calamari was absolutely tasty and served on a white bean salad that was super delicious!! The asparagus was ridiculously great too, not too much lemon but just right. 

For the entrees, the BF had the steak with french fries and I had the squared pasta with pesto sauce (I forget their name for it but in English they told me it meant "handkerchiefs" because of the thinly sliced squares). The steak was soo juicy with an amazing thick sauce. My pasta   was delicious as well--the pesto sauce covered the pasta and had a sprinkle of pine nuts in it that added a little crunch to my pasta. Both dishes were served piping hot and I'm glad that it was right out of the stovetop and not sitting under a heating lamp or anything. 

The service was absolutely excellent. Everyone from the hostess, bussers and server were simply amazing. Since the BF and I didn't know what the names of the dishes were and what they meant, our server happily read through the entire menu to explain what each dish was. 

Will totally come back here and try the rest of their yummy food and this time, save some room for their dessert!
author: Joy A.

description:
My husband and I went here after rave reviews from his sister.  We were not disappointed.  The service was great.  The food was amazing.  The only complaint I have is that the seating is rather tight and they have to pull the table out for you to squeeze into the booth.  What can you expect for a Mission gem though?

Our server, Oliver, was amazing.  He was calm, collected, charming, funny and had a great knowledge of the food and wine menu.  We had the Puntarella alla Romana salad and the Jerusalem artichoke soup with black trumpet mushrooms for a starter.  Bother were amazing, but the soup was, by far, my favorite.  For dinner we ordered the halibut and the duck.  Being red meat fans, we both assumed that the duck would win us over, but --while both were amazing -- this was the best halibut I have had in my entire life.  The sauce is to die for!

We had a great time and will go back, but I think next time we will sit at the counter that overlooks the restaurant.  :)
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Fantastic food with fresh new tastes. Love sitting at the bar or counter, where we can usually get in at the last minute and people watch, but more importantly, look at all the other food.  Staff has always been friendly and knowledgeable.  Very helpful in recommending dishes and wines, can get some dishes in a half portion if you want to try several.  The place is always hopping with diverse crowd makes for a fun experience.
