Love the calamari antipasti.  Lightly charred little calamari on a flavorful bed of frisee floating on a warm white bean salad.  Refreshing alternative to the fried ones seen everywhere else.  For dessert give the chocolate torta with olio nuovo gelato a try!
author: Andre D.

description:
Delfina is San Francisco's Bungalow 8. Average people just can't get in! You can call months in advance and they only have the 5:30 or 10:30 reservations open and everyone knows those are reject times. The only time worth going to a restaurant is around 8, especially on a Friday or Saturday. At least that is what the cool kids told me. 

Imagine my surprise when I was invited to dine at Delfina at 8:30 on a Saturday night. (I can only imagine this but) I felt like I was picked to go into Studio 54 in the 70s. Acceptance, finally! I must say it does really feel good to glide by all the jealous, hungry hordes to a cozy table. 

So, I wouldn't call Delfina classic "Italian" food. It is definitely food of the 42nd parallel made in San Francisco. Or what San Franciscans believe that bougie Italians eat. 

I really did enjoy my calamari and anchovies. They were both nice and salty. I didn't love my guinea hen ragu. The hunks of hen were tough and lack appropriate gamey flavor. 

This is redeemed by the buttermilk panna cotta. I LOVE panna cotta and theirs is excellent. I could eat this everyday and be happy. 

Our server was a gorgeous, stylish, enthusiastic gay man. He was adorable and recommended a tasty rose to go with our seafood and game selections. 

In conclusion, I can now tell people that I have been to the promised land, Delfina at 8:30 on a Saturday night.
author: Monica L.

description:
I hate being in a hurry. But, time being what it is, I found myself dashing into Delfina under the assumption that it was Pizzeria Delfina. After clarification by the hostess we took a high top in the bar. We told our server that we were in a hurry and he had no problem what so ever. There was a nice selection of wine by the glass. It came immediately after ordering. We ordered lamb sausage with lentils and grilled squid with warm white bean salad. I thought both were delicious. There was poached lemon zest in the warm bean salad that my girlfriend didn't care for. 

We got two kinds of bread on the table. One from Acme and one from Tartin. The bread from Tartin was fantastic and very fresh. Unfortunately, next to the Tartin bread the Acme bread tasted stale and flat, which it wasn't. 

I'm allergic to fish, not shell fish. This is always hard to explain in a restaurant. Especially at an Italian or Asian restaurant. But, our server took it all in stride and found out exactly what was in the shrimp dish I ordered for my Secondi. Turns out there was fish stock so I ordered the Flat Iron steak with fries. That was fine because it was the first thing that I smelled when I got into the restaurant.   I ordered it MR and it was cooked perfectly.  The fries were a little soggy.

My girlfriend ordered the ravioli stuffed with prosciutto and mascarpone. It was really tasty. The pasta was a little softer than I'd like. Her mother ordered the cauliflower soup which was excellent. 

The service staff did an amazing job of keeping our small table bussed and our wine glasses full. I'm sorry that we couldn't have stayed for dessert and coffee. Normally that amount of food would've taken us about an hour and a half to eat. They got us out of there in under 40 minutes. I'd give the service staff an easy 5 stars. I LOVE GREAT SERVICE.
author: Aaron B.

description:
I heard a lotta hype about Delfina. I've read reviews in magazines, here on yelp, and heard great things from my friends about this place... but I must say I was not at all impressed.

My brother, his gf and I put our names on the waiting list and the host tells me the wait is 45 minutes to an hour. We go get a drink down the street then come back 35 minutes later and whoops! he's given away our table and there's no hope for us to get a seat. So finally, we are starving and can't take the wait anymore so we are squished into sitting side-by-side at the random bar stools in the middle of the restaurant. 

Food was okay, but took a long time. I honestly felt that the best part of the meal was the little gem salad. My pasta was so-so, but I felt a little guilty for having my brother pay for a dinner that didn't taste any better than a simple pasta I could've made at home. To make up for the wait, the waiter gave us a bowl of raw chard. Yes that's the vegetable chard, not chardonnay, which I thought was a little odd. At least they kept the rounds of bread baskets coming freely!

It was a disappointing dinner. I think Delfina is a blah restaurant don't think this place is worth trying
author: Kelly R.

description:
I get the feeling everyone who works there is walking on eggshells. Maybe because of the strange regulations that are imposed, like words that can't be used ie. "enjoy" or "right this way". I got that info from friends.  I have heard from insiders that training there is like entering another dimension. 
The food of course is amazing, the space is perfect, but with the number of adds on craigslist that are always posted someone should ease the anxiety levels among employees since it is so apparent no one working is comfortable. This is possibly due to the delicate balance between causal and fine dinning the venue is known for.
author: allen s.

description: Excellent home made pasta here, cooked perfectly with tasty sauces. If the line for pizza is too long next door, go for pasta!
author: Derrick V.

description:
I came here for a New Year's Eve dinner and quite frankly, I expected a lot more based on all of the positive reviews for this place. I thought that the food was average, but the service was very good. 

First of all, don't come here for a romantic meal. The lighting and decor is very nice, but the tables are so close together that it's almost a communal dining experience. You can't have anything close to a private conversation here because you will be overheard because you're either too clost to another table or you have to yell over other people's conversations. 

My date and I ordered the Insalata di Campo and a side of Chard (as recommended by our server) to start with. I am a vegetarian and didn't realize that there was pancetta in the salad, but spoke to our server about it and he was very nice and brought me a pancetta free serving very promptly. Both of these dishes were very good and the best we would have all night. 

The main entrees we ordered were the Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil, and peperoncini and the Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken with olive oil mashed potatoes and chanterelle mushrooms. I didn't personally try the chicken as I am a vegetarian, but my date said that it was average at best. I did try the mashed potatoes and thought they were good, but really nothing special.  While the sauce was good on my pasta, the pasta itself was much too al dente for my taste. I appreciate firmness in my pasta, but this seemed to be simply undercooked. I was also extremely surprised at how small the "large" serving was.  

While I appreciate the good service at this restaurant and the couple of good dishes that we did experience, my overall experience at this place was simply average and not worth the money spent. I don't think I'll be coming back to Delfina anytime soon.
author: Jonathan A.

description: The staff is really friendly and the food can be quite good, depending on what you order.  (I really like the Spaghetti!).  But it gets so cramped in there that it is kind of hard to enjoy the meal (though you can overhear some interesting conversations).  We like Locanda better.  More spacious and comfortable and lots of tasty dishes.
author: Chris B.

description:
Sooooo ... the service at Delfina was pretty good.  There's something to be said for chicly attired waitstaff sans uniform that all seem to have the same sense of impeccable taste.  Taste.  Hmm.  So the calamari/white bean salad appetizer that I shared with my friend was pretty tasty, but otherwise, the rest of the meal was just okay, somewhat bland, and not at all the spectacular build up that weeks and months of awaiting a reservation slot had us anticipating.  The food wasn't BAD ... it just wasn't as good as, say, a hole-in-the-wall Mexican place can be the morning after a bender.  And that's what a five-star restaurant should be as far as I'm concerned.  *sigh*

And I wanted to like you!
author: Homey G.

description:
I've had some incredible meals in San Francisco but the one I had at Delfina recently was one of the best.  The tagliatelle with mint and chanterelles was outstandingly tasty and the pork shoulder with figs and white beans had a succulent porky quality that few pork dishes I've tasted have achieved.  And the white beans were unbelievably rich and creamy; how I wish I could replicate them in my own kitchen!  For dessert, I had the molten chocolate cake, a menu item that has become something of a cliche at upscale restaurants nowadays; this one, however, was as close to perfect as any chocolate dessert I've ever had.  It just tasted like a molten chocolate cake should, which is probably the highest praise I can give it.  Also, our server was courteous and professional and gave us expert wine recommendations.

The only reason I give Delfina four stars instead of five is that the tables on the back patio where we were sitting were about three inches too tall for the chairs.  I felt like a little kid sitting at a big person's dinner table.  But that was a minor inconvenience that I just about stopped noticing after I started eating the restaurant's delicious food.
author: Dan L.

description:
Burr, I arrived on a windy and cold evening.  I clutched my scarf over my nose and ran across 18th toward the warm glow of Delfina's front door.  I open and I'm embraced at once with the restaurant's quaint interior, diners buzzing and soft smile of the approaching hostess.  Deep inhale and my eyes dilate from the mixture of flaming brick oven and fresh baked bread. Welcome.

Delfina is the epitome of casual elegance. 

The staff is right on mark.  Our party started with a glass of wine while waiting for our table.  The knowledgeable young lady behind the bar gave us a couple tasters before we decided on one - fabulous.  

While sipping (me gulping) on our wine selection, I glanced into the kitchen where I witnessed the gorgeous choreographed chaos happening.  The kitchen was alive with talented men and women working shoulder to shoulder creating what is just wonderful food.

Although the service is friendly, organized and helpful, it is the food that I have fallen for.  Each dish prepared with thought and skill almost overwhelmed my senses.  Calamari, the best I have ever had.  Salt cod, you have my heart. Brussel Sprouts, no one does them better.  Braised Short ribs, finger licking good. Linguine with sole, delicate and delicious.

Wine list is fabulous, you can spend from thirty to a hundy and won't regret a second of it.  Our party of four left happy and I fell asleep last night with visions of my next visit.

Delfina, I can't wait to have back in my arms.
author: Foodie J.

description:
My friend took me to Delfina a few nights ago which was a real treat since I'm usually (but not always)an impoverished Zen student.  Damn it was good!

the anchovies were shiny sliver and slick, served in several "X" shaped pairs with lemon and olive oil and a mound of cucumber and radish salad.  They were so delicious--smooth, bright and rich tasting and then the crunchy cucumber for contrast.

The salad was dandelion greens with thick pieces of sauteed porcini and ribbons of shaved Parmesan.  The porcini were just how I like them--crisp and golden on the outside but moist and meaty.  And they had a great wild flavor too.

The pasta was perfectly cooked, almost chewy, with a thick sauce made by stewing fava beans in pancetta (or maybe it was the stuff made with jowls?)  and it was so very good that we stopped talking for a while.

My entree was sand dabs (my first time!) and I ate them all up but the next day I realized it was more about the soaked-in-buttermilk-and-drenched-in-semolina crust than the actual fish.  I did have a lot of fun with the deboning part.  For some reason, pulling out the spiky spine made me feel like I was in a cartoon.  My friend had the CA sea bass which was delicious but I don't remember exactly why.

The buttermilk panna cotta was the best ever because the texture was perfect (smooth and lush without being too jell-o.)  But even better was the contrast of tart buttermilk with bitter caramel and citrus kumquat.  

Our waitress was also perfect.  She gets five stars for being well informed and genuine and quietly attentive but Delfina only gets four because the tables are too close and it's far too noisy.  I could smell my neighbor chocolate cake (admittedly not a bad thing) and my neighbor on the right had this frequent (and aggressive) way of swirling his glass of red wine that was a little scary.  I kept expecting it to fly into my lap which was just a few inches away from his.

The next morning I got up and had formal breakfast in the Zen Center meditation hall which begins with the chant  "we reflect on the efforts that brought us this food and consider how it comes to us."   Sometimes, having so many opinions seems a little cheap and easy and I feel like I'm squirming under that heavy boot of privilege and entitlement.  I mean, what are they yelping about in Iraq?  Africa? Am I being too virtuous here?  Maybe  I'm just new to this Yelp business
author: Dana V.

description:
Just got back from a light dinner.  Crazy good.  Started with the calamari and white bean salad.  Perfectly dressed and the seafood was tender and flavorful. Moved onto the salt cod (which I eat whenever I go there)- really, I could have ordered another one, it was that good!  My friend commented that the cracker bread that came with it was amazing.  Had a little well seasoned chard as well.  How do they make something so simple taste so good? Top that off with the perfect, not so sweet chocolate budino and a few glasses of wine that the server let us taste before committing made the 4 stars a no brainer.  The 5th star goes to the service; from the friendly host,  the
accommodating server  and the detailed food runner- they're all over it!
author: Dina R.

description:
My uncle gave me a very generous Delfina gift card for Christmas so I ordered almost everything on the menu. Here are a few things that stuck out. The calamari was not great but the beans that were on the plate were the best Ive ever had. The seabass was also very good For dessert we ordered a chocolate cake that rocked and a really gross buttermilk panna cotta. Our waitress was very helpful and kept the plates from crowding the table. My only warning is make sure you have lots of time....our dinner took almost 3 hours but well worth the wait.


Overall I walked away a happy customer.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Some of the patrons can be stuffy and detract from the dining experience but you can't take anything away from the chefs who provide quality innovative dishes at very reasonable prices.
author: Earl G.

description: We still love the tripe and the spaghetti.  Our new favorite is their lemon-infused chard - vitamins never tasted SO good!  We also have discovered their seasonal pastas are always worth trying (one word: ragu).
author: Alice C.

description:
I've never had a hostess bring me a glass of wine while I waited on a table in a packed restaurant. Then, after waiting only about 10 minutes for my reservation to clear, she apologized for the "inconvenience" by presenting me with rosemary french fries, a gratis. This is the kind of royal treatment you get at Delfina. 

The wine list is fit for a queen. It's extensive but the server (who amazingly seemed to know every last one of them) was super patient and helpful. You can tell everyone who works there loves what they do. One server even ate dinner at the bar as soon as her shift was up. Gotta love that.

As for vegetarian offerings, they have great sides and appetizers you can make a meal out of and the spaghetti is simple and simply yummy. I also recommend getting coffee afterward. Maybe it was the cute little French presses that made it taste so good, but it's up there with Philz.
author: Regina S.

description:
I've been here a few times and the food has been extremely good.   This place is quickly becoming one of my faves and I'm sad that it took me so long to actually try it...
Last Friday I had the Alaskan halibut with artichokes and potatoes sott'olio and black olive tapenade and it was delicious!  Simply prepared and a great combination or flavors.  I truly enjoyed it!

I would never say no to an invitation to Delfina.  
Bravo!
author: Rose C R.

description: As good as it gets. I went to try the pizza but they don't serve it in the restaurant side. But I am glad because I had a fantastic meal.
author: Scott M.

description:
My friends have been telling me to check this place out for 
ages! Finally go there and was very impressed. The cafe style dining room reminded me of a cafe I visited in Rome, I loved it. Very cozy and no attitude. 
The service was also excellent, very informative and clear.  
The food was excellent, I ordered the steak and it was tender and cooked just right. Excellent and worth the trip, I will be back!
author: Mark S.

description:
Thought it quite good, although somewhat expensive.  They really do cram you in.  I would not rush back, surprisingly I prefer their more casual pizzeria next door, which is worth waiting in line for.

The highlight was a special beef carpaccio appetizer, which also included greens, black pepper and cheese in the dish.

The gnocchi with rabbit was just ok, not worth noting.  

Wine list had some nice selections from both California & Italy at reasonable prices.  Overall, a good meal, not a great one, and nothing to justify all the oohs and ahs.
author: Aaron T.

description:
" really, really, wanted to love this place"  
Really!
So I went with my wife and my brother and sister in law:
The grub was overall good.
Fresh ingredients.
But not very creative.  
For the value I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.  

Well, maybe if someone else paid.

$50 per person, including 1 bottle of wine.
author: John L.

description: This is one of my very favorite restaurants in SF and I always bring out of town guests here. Love, love, love the food, the staff, and the atmosphere.
author: Heather Y.

description:
I wish I could love Bar Tartine as much as Delfina!

Best dish: beef carpaccio. It melts in your mouth, simply divine.

The menu changes often, and waitresses know it inside out. 
The wine list is unique, and great recommendations from the waitresses.

5 Star food
5 Star service
5 Star restaurant

Oh the Chef won the 2008 James Beard Best Chef: Pacific!
author: Yuchi C.

description: Great crust!  Surprisingly the thin crust on the margarita we ordered remained crispy 5 mins after we got it.  The bubbling mozzarella cheese and the tangy tomato sauce never leaked through.  Awesome pizza, discouraging line.
author: MTBer I.

description:
Delfina started off in an unassuming way, opening up shop in late November 1998 in a pretty out-of-the-way location in the Mission.  No Bi-Rite Creamery next door, no Tartine Bakery around the corner.  Instead the Dovre Club was down the street and not much else.

I happened to stroll in that first week they were open and had a meal which included their now famous spaghetti.  Annie Stoll -- the co-owner and wife of chef Craig Stoll -- was in the front of the house making everyone feel welcome and wonderful.   Was an amazing dinner.

And we all know the story from there.  The restaurant changed the Mission.  And the place has just kept getting better.

Went back for the first time in years and was met at the front by a lovely hostess who found us a seat, sans reservations, in the bar area with a great view of the kitchen.  The waitress knew her stuff, telling us all about the great glass of Montepulciano we shared and recommending that we enjoy the acquacotta -- a simple soup with kale, garlicky crouton, and a poached egg.  They offer bread from both Acme and Tartine.  And on the menu this night: a fabulous grassy olive oil which was delivered tableside in a small tin dispenser.

My main course was a beautifully booked piece of Hawaiian tuna with perfectly pillowy butter beans.  We lingered over some espresso mousse and left very, very happy.

Meal for two with two glasses of wine was under $100.  And in a marvelous place that has only gotten better since that autumn day in 1998.  No resting on one's laurels at Defina.

If you haven't been in awhile, it's time to go back.
author: Rob R.

description:
Bleck!  This place is VASTLY overrated and way to pricey for what you get.  I got the sole that advertised artichokes and potatoes and just sounded scrumptious.  What did I get?  A crappy piece of fish with 1 lousy artichokes and 1 small potato both cut in half.  The artichokes were not fresh and had been drenched in marinade out of a jar.  Bleck!

For a place that gets great reviews for being local and creative you can keep it.  The best part of the night was the Lost Coast Great White.
author: Wes B.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite restaurants here in San Francisco and they are consistently good (just like their salt cod mantecato...).

I've eaten here about five-six times in the past twelve months and have not once walked away disappointed. If you call same day for a reservation be ready to go for a 9pm or later table.

4/2/06 Update: Went here again. It was great. So there.
author: Rich S.

description:
Wow! This place is one of the best I've been to in a long time. They have an outdoor patio in the back which is sheltered and oh-so nice. The tables back there are fitted tightly together so it's a bit difficult to get in and out of your seat. Reservations at least a few weeks in advance are definitely required here!

Wonderful fresh bread is delivered before the meal, which they make in-house I believe. I had Insalata del campo to start off and an unusual type of pasta (can't remember the name). Brian at Sea Bass, which -- of course-- I sampled. His was by far the most outstanding item of our evening (perhaps I ordered the wrong dish?).

So worth it!
author: Greg G.

description:
Call me a foodie. 

The owner of Delfina (Craig) whom I met by mere coincidence somewhere outside of the restaurant even called me a food connoisseur. The food is exceptional in quality, flavor, and experience.  This place serves up Italian with a casual ambiance and local flavor. t's a great place for a special evening and phenomenal food.
author: Jessica D.

description:
I am completely baffled as to all the fuss about Delfina. My husband and I ate here last night for my birthday. 

Service: Very good

Atmostphere: Hustle bustle. We were there for first seating on a Sunday at 5 p.m. and there was a line out the door waiting to get in. The place was full by 5:30 p.m.

The music selection was very strange for an Italian restaurant though. When we got there, there was hip hop/club-type music, then it switched to something pop-like...it was just odd. It kind of disrupted the mood of the place for us.

Food: Just good, but nothing spectacular, memorable or original. I have had much better Italian in the city at several different places. 

We started with the insalata salad with bitter greens, walnuts, parmesan and balsamic vinaigrette. That was very good -- well-blended flavors and beautifully presented. I then moved on to the gnocchi al ragu. It was well cooked and the flavors were "good," but again nothing special. I've had much better. My husband got the fregnacce with shrimp. It smelled REALLY low-tide and fishy, which both of us were really surprised about. Good, FRESH seafood should not smell that fishy!! Again, the flavors in that dish were just so-so. My husband was very underwhelmed.

The best thing was actually the bread they serve, which they brought in fresh from a bakery called Tartine a couple doors over. That bread was so fantastic I've actually been thinking about it all day today and may have to go back to that bakery to get some more!

Seating: Very uncomfortable! Tiny chairs, wooden benches, no padding, tables very close together.

Parking: Apparently it is very challenging in this area, but we got lucky and found a place a couple blocks away on the street without any problems.

With so many fabulous Italian restaurants in the city, we have no plans to go back here. The place is friendly and the food is decent. But I think this place is highly overrated overall.
author: Christine P.

description: Their food was excellent but their service was not. Boyfriend surprised me with this one and I was very hesitant but I knew he wouldn't take me anywhere bad. It was the night before Valentine's so it was super packed and we sat in a table smooshed between two other tables so close where I felt like we were all in the same party. The people next to us sat down after us, ordered after us, yet got all of their things faster than us. The waitress was super understanding of my dietary restrictions and me trying to change the menu. She helped us pick things i could eat and made sure other things were changed. She was super sweet but very awkward in a way. The bread was great and the food we had was delicious. Boyfriend and I shared a squid appetizer, a tomato sauce pasta special dish that had shrimp, and swordfish. They were all delicious, I couldn't even pick my favorite. All of the seafood was super high in quality and you could even tell that the pasta was handmade in house. I was very impressed with the food, the only reason I gave 4 stars was because the service was not very good. While our waitress was nice, she was not very attentive- I felt like my very tiny water glass was always empty, and again, the couple next to us, even though they ordered after us, was always getting their food before us. Definitely somewhere I would go again and hope the service is better!
author: Michelle S.

description:
We've been experience bizarre wait service lately. Went into Delfina for an early reservation. Our waitress was fabulous! Soft-spoken, helpful and a gentle sense of humor. The ideal expert. As usual, the food was fabulous. Heirloom tomatoes, chicken and a fish dish. We gobbled up 3 helpings of bread, too. 

We discussed over dinner that we should get our waitress' name so we could yelp her great service. Turns out we didn't have to ask. She brought us the bill and typed near the bottom was her name... Harmony. How fitting. Thanks for a wonderful night!
author: Megan D.

description: Went on my birthday, July 12.  Interesting flavor combinations, especially the olive crusted white bass on artichoke.  5/6 dishes we had (2 apps and 4 entrees) were heavy on the olive oil.  Seemed like they added olive oil onto the plates at the end "just because."  It added unnecessary richness and took away flavor from the other ingredients/sauces.  Portions were small for the prices (c'mon ONE sardine! ) , but I guess this is to be expected at a longtime trendy restaurant.  I think we paid for LOTS of people to work at the restaurant to provide mediocre service.
author: Lee U.

description: Came here last night with my bf and ordered the prosciutto pizza and a butter bean pancetta soup and lamb sausage. The pizza just wasnt impressive when you compare it to the hype ppl give this place. The prosciutto was ok. My bf loved his lamb sausage and I thought the soup was ok. I feel like we didnt try the right pizza because ive heard the tomato sauce is good. The wait tho was around 50 min. And to me wasnt worth it. Id try it again some day but when the wait isnt so long.
author: Tamara T.

description:
This was a disapointment!  I waited 7 weeks for a decent time reservation and was treated to so-so service and a steak that came seared when I ordered it medium.    Molton Choclate Cake is good and the location is great - especially if you get a window seat. 

Thumbs UP:  Nice wine menu 
Thumbs DOWN: Poor quality food and aloof staff.
author: Jeff C.

description:
I should probably try to make it back here one more time before writing a review, but with other better, more authentically Italian places around, coming back to Delfina isn't a high priority for me. 

The food is, of course, fresh and passionately prepared, but the flavors weren't powerful or memorable enough to warrant repeat visits. The most notable thing I tried here was a nettle pasta in a nettle sauce: green papardelle made with nettle and a green nettle sauce to match. It was a bit like basil pesto, but not quite as flavorful. I enjoyed this, but it didn't blow my mind. A dish involving salmon and potatoes failed to truly impress despite its freshness and artful presentation. Anything else that was ordered just wasn't very memorable. Overall, it was a bit too "California-comfort" for my tastes. If you want authentic Tuscan cuisine, you're not likely to find it here. 

Somewhat irksome was how at 7:30 they were already out of the lobster for a special they were touting that night, yet 20 minutes after placing our order, a couple seated next to us who knew the waitress by name, ordered that very same dish sans problem! Maybe they made a mid-evening lobster run right after I ordered, but regardless, that was still slightly annoying. 

The place is crowded, lively, noisy, etc., so take that for what it's worth. Also, the awkward and callow conversations overheard from the tense Marina types you're likely to be seated next to makes for no end of unintended giggles. Delfina seems to remain a very trendy place, so reservations are a must. I came to Delfina expecting exquisitely prepared Italian-ish food, but went away feeling that other places, like Dopo, Antica, and Olivetto offered more flavorful and much more consistently authentic Italian dishes. In short, Delfina is worth a try, but I don't quite see what all the fuss is about.
author: Giofreddo W.

description:
Okay okay okay...so I'm in the minority but I'm PISSED!  In fact it's taken me the better part of a week to get over it.

So we're not hipsters with $400 jeans from Bloomingdale's wearing $300 sunglasses...but we like to eat and we know a good thing when we see it.

So here's my dilemma...I literally walked into Delfina on a Saturday night in June with man and friend in tow and lo and behold scored a table without a reservation.  The hostess was charming, the server engaging, and the food superb.

So why the 2 stars?????  Flash forward to last Sunday evening.  Friends in town from Seattle, a whole day of doing touristy things, and of course lots of walking.  Around 8 ish we become peckish and I suggest Delfina (based of course on the superlative previous experience).  Rather than take a chance, I call to inquire about accommodating our party of 5 (no pun intended).

Dial...ring ring ring...
Hostess:  Delfina
Me:  Good evening
Hostess:  SILENCE
Me:  I was wondering if you would be able to accommodate a party of 5 this evening...anytime would be fine.
Hostess:  No
CLICK

CLICK...WTF is with that?  CLICK...I don't think so.  So I now I'm pissed and I go O...F...F... in front of my company.  I want to go down there and rip the bitch's throat out.  Now keep in mind, I wasn't expecting necessarily to be accommodated, I was simply asking about the likelihood.

So in the end we go to Panchita's #3...where were are graciously accommodated and feast like princes.

But something didn't sit right...am I obsessive compulsive, why can't I get this bad behaviour out of my mind.  So in the end I elect to YELP...maybe that will help.

2 stars for Delfina but I'm such a pussy I'll try it again...
author: Grant C.

description:
underwhelmed. best thing we had was the rigatoni with some type of ragu style sauce. 

the other pasta that we had, papperdelle something, was ok. i had a similar dish at Drago Centro in LA and this version did not stand a chance. 

i liked the squid.

asparagus with some type of mayo sauce was disgusting. 

we got a salad but I forget which kind. 

Totally forgettable and pretty much a big letdown.
author: J A.

description:
The homemade pasta was delicious! I only gave this place three stars because it seemed that the portions were ity bity for the type of food it was. I think I prefer to eat at Pizzeria Delfina. Maybe I just wasn't mentally prepared enough to go out for a fancy meal so my expectations were off. I'd give it another chance.

I should say that they didn't seem to have our reservation but were very gracious in sitting us. I really did appreciate that!
author: Monica D.

description:
We had wanted to go to Delfina for a couple of years and chose my husband's birthday celebration as the time to go. 

Everything was perfect; the atmosphere, the food, the wine and the wait staff.
We really appreciated our waiter, Aaron. He and his fellow waiters made sure we had everything we needed. Aaron answered many questions about the dishes and delighted us with an outstanding choice for our second bottle of wine.

We would recommend ordering some dishes to split so that everyone in your party gets to sample this wonderful food.  It was all delicious but a couple of dishes were outstanding; the wild nettle risotto, the pappardelle with pork sugo, and the duroc pork spareribs!
author: Kathleen T.

description:
I've been dying to come here for at least five years.  For a belated bday present, my three lovely friends took me to dinner here last night.  beautiful space, very warm and cozy. 

to start, we shared a salad and four antipasti: 

first, calamari w/white beans and frisee - the best dish of the night - the calamari was tender and SMOKEY - sooo good.  lots of good olive oil;  only thing was, it was a rather small serving.  i'd want my own.

salt cod mantecato w/fennel seed flatbread - reeeally good, creamy, not as salty as some I've had -  the fennel flatbread was really light, flavorful and crispy; 

whole silvery sardines with some kind of relish - I think eggplant and then something slightly sweet, and a piece of reddened toasted bread soaked in tomato juices and garlic.  when you ate a bit of just the sardine it was a tad fishy, but if you had a bite of everything together it was the perfect combo - crunchy from the bread, salty, sweet, fish-bite, garlicky. 

chicken liver spiedini - liver on a stick! - interspersed with grilled bread.  good but a little too bloody for some.  served with little blocks of seared fat - SEARED FAT, WHAT'S BETTER THAN THAT?

and for the salad - heirloom tomatoes with mozzarella and basil oil - 2nd best item of the night.  such a simple dish, but prepared so well - the tomatoes were PERFECTLY ripe and juicy and PERFECTLY SEASONED with just sea salt and pepper.  great oil. 

on to the primi:

agnolotti - a Piemontese type of filled pasta, know as a "priest's hat", filled with chicken and mortadella in a light butter and lemon sauce - really good, light, silky.

gnocchi with cherry tomatoes in some sauce - ehhh.  I always find gnocchi boring; sorry to say this one was no exception.

tripa alla Fiorentina - i'd been dying to try this, as i'd had a fantastic version of it in Florence -  where it was silky and rich, not menudo-like at all.  Delfina's tasted tripey, very offal-y, and the texure was a bit rubbery.  yes, i know it's tripe, but again, i've had it prepared sublimely before.  one of my friends grew up eating tripe and never liked it and wanted to be wowed into liking it.  this didn't do it for her.  ALTHOUGH, i have to say . . . i ate quite a bit of it.  something kept drawing me back to it.

We were too full from all that to have an entre (secondi), so we had the cheese plate - which was not great - Italians just don't make a lot of great cheese - i lived in Italy for 5 months and only loved a handful of cheeses.  the pork chop with figs sounded great, and the halibut looked fantastic.  but we'd eaten slowly, with good wine, and so just couldn't squeeze in an entree, even to share.

of course, my friends all LOVE dessert so we DID have room for two of those - a molten chocolate cake, prepared to order, and profiteroles with homemade espresso gelato, with a chocolate sauce and candied almonds.  these were pretty damned good, i must say - non-dessert-person that i am.

All in all, I'm a bit disappointed that I wasn't totally wowed by this place - I think I built it up for myself too much.  it was GOOD, but I don't need to go back right away - it's always that thing - too many other places to try first before I do a go-back.  but I DO still want to try their pizzeria next door, because you can get their highly touted pizza and most of the antipasti, which were the best things.  The service was excellent - our cute little hippy-dippy server was friendly, attentive, and totally knowledgeable about all the food and wines.

Oh and they brought me a couple of cute little amaretti-type cookie-batons, with a candle, for my bday.  shh - don't tell them it was actually in August!
author: maria a.

description:
Delfina is one of my fave restaurants in the city. It is consistently delicious, as long as you are into Italian-style food. And when I say Italian-style, I mean more like real Italian food (maybe some bitter greens, stuff made out of beans, slightly less mainstream types of meat), and less like Olive Garden (pasta slathered in cream sauce). 

The menu changes seasonally, although they usually have some stand-by dishes like the roast chicken with olive oil mashed potatoes. I love this dish. It is really simple and yet really good. If you share this with someone, you may end of fighting over who gets the last bites. Just a warning. 

About a year ago, I ordered one of the specials, and I still dream about it to this day. It was saffron risotto with oxtail ragu, and it captured my heart. I'm not going to try and describe it with all kinds of foodie vocabulary. I'll just say that this dish is proof that Delfina occasionally knocks it out of the park (in addition to their already solid menu). 

The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is because occasionally I order something that just isn't that great. Don't get me wrong, nothing is ever bad there, but some dishes just don't live up to the rest. 

The other reason to knock off a star is the long wait. If you don't make reservations way in advance, you will likely have to wait 1-2 hours during prime dinner time. I understand this is not their fault, supply and demand, yadda yadda, but sometimes I get a hankering and want some instant gratification.
author: Julie J.

description:
Meh. 2.5 stars.

The place is really, really cramped in the greedy, money-making style. Removing one or two of the deuces that overcrowd the passages would make the place much more comfortable for patrons, and Delfina would still make tons of profit, seeing how overrun and overpriced they are.

The service is casual but good, the decor is uber-hip, but very satisfying if you're in a "wanting to be tres chic"-mood.

The food. The food is good. Lovely bread and cute butter dishes (and SOFT butter, hard butter is a pet peeve of mine, so yeah!). The dishes are the right combination of unpretentious and yummy, yet still with a slightly creative twist. The execution however is a bit lacking. Granted, I was there on a Friday night, which is a bad night to judge food on, but everything was on the verge of being overdone/having sat way too long under heat lamps. Nothing had really gone over the edge, but also nothing seemed perfect. And my pork chop was definitely on the wrong side of medium and a tad dry. Also, the WOW-factor was missing, good is not equal to great.

The prices. Now here's the reason for the 2.5 stars. The prices are way out of line for what you're getting. I don't mind paying for my dinner, but I do want to get my money's worth, and you definitely don't get that at Delfina. Were the cost about 25% lower, this would be a great spot for a casual dinner in the neighborhood on a Tuesday evening. But the place is definitely not worth 100 bucks/head for appetizer/entree and a little bit of wine.

To sum it up:
Delfina - not enough bang for your buck.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
A friend and I stopped in here on a Tuesday evening and was able to get two seats at the thin bar with high chairs. The place was packed and we didnt have to wait more than 20 minutes, granted it was a Tuesday and the seats were very uncomfortable. 

After hearing rave reviews I was expecting something impressive, or at least memorable. The server was attentive and answered our numerous questions about the menu and wine pairings. We ordered a glas to share , I believe it was a Barbera- my friend is the wine expert. The glass was corked- unpleasant and had probably been sitting for a few days.  After this we decided an unopened bottle would be safer and had a chianti that should have paired well with the calamari, chicken and pasta we ordered. 

The calamari were tender and not the typical over fried rings
that are all too familiar on appetizer lists around the country. The chicken was cooked well and the pasta was nice. That is the best I can say, "nice" none of the food was particularly impressive, very run of the mill and while fresh, not providing much interesting flavor.  Essentially while the service was fast, the menu interesting there was nothing about Delfina that stood out to me, or that warrants the lines and buzz that surrounds this place. While it may be somewhat elegant or upscale for the mission- for such a great city for food, im surprised this is a hot spot.
author: Alanna M.

description:
I have lived in the Mission for many years, and have eaten at Delfina a handful of times over the past 10 years.  I have always thought that the food was very good.

My husband and I decided to celebrate our anniversary at a local restaurant instead of going out of town as we usually do.  We had an 8:30PM reservation at Delfina on a Monday night, and we were seated within 10 min of arrival.  We received our glasses of wine within 10 minutes of being seated, our bread within 40 min, our chicken liver crostini appetizer within 45 minutes, and our main pasta courses within an hour.  The kitchen seemed to be very backed up.  There were 3 two-person tables packed into a corner that would comfortably accommodate one table for 4, and we were forced to participate in the conversation of the other 2 tables.  It was truly community dining.  The noise level was very high, but my husband was still mostly intelligible. Spaghetti was simple and delicious, and the pear torta for dessert was also very good.  The waitress was obviously beleaguered by the chaos in the restaurant, but she was impeccably courteous at all times.

Delfina has very good Italian food in a casual, boisterous setting.  I would not recommend it for special occasions.  It is a noisy, chaotic scene, and you will need to air out your clothing when you get home due to the proximity of the tables to the kitchen.
author: Bathsheba M.

description:
We had dinner here on Friday night and it was "ok", i remember this place being much better a few years back.  We had the baked cheese appetizer which was very very good, then again, it was baked cheese so.... of course it was good. We also had a salad which was fine, the spaghetti which was awesome, this was our favorite dish by far. For entrees we had the chicken and the steak which were both good but not nearly up to our expectations for this place. The mashed potatoes came out cold but they fixed it immediately.  Neither entree was especially flavorful which was disappointing.

For my dining dollar I will head to Range which has awesome food and it a little less expensive.
author: Ashley T.

description: The Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken was everything it was cracked up to be. And they do the little things well -- brussel sprouts and chard sides were excellent. Overall just a nice vibe and good menu, throw in high quality ingredients and you got yourself a winner. And not to mention that the best ice cream in San Francisco is right across the street at Bi-Rite.
author: Brian B.

description:
Let me preface this by saying that my impression of Delfina was probably influenced by the fact that I went there with a friend after we finally completed our long and arduous apartment search, so ... consider that my cathartic ratings-creep warning.

That said, my friend's brussels sprouts and duck were AMAZING.  My ravioli was some of the best I've had, and the atmosphere was great.  It was very comfortable, I thought.

The sauteed greens, however, were overly salted.

But wow, that duck was amazing.  AMAZING.  Plus, the service was very friendly, attentive, and overall enhanced the experience.
author: Tim B.

description:
"It must have been an off night" is what I told myself as we left Delfina.

Got a gift certificate to Delfina as a wedding present.  We decided to make a weekend out of it and got a room at the St. Francis.  

Everyone told us how great the food was and how busy the place was.  We called 2.5 weeks out and could only get a reservation for 6 pm.  I haven't had dinner that early since I was 8.

When we got there the place was packed.  It felt like Ikea on a holiday weekend.  The staff was constantly hustling by.

Service was friendly.  And the food was just okay.  Just okay and $150 for two???  Not really what I was hoping for.

We started with crostini with olive tapenade and  pulled fresh mozzarella.  I think the dish would have been much better if the tapenade was not already on the crostini.  Since fresh mozzarella is so subtle, all I could taste was the tapenade.

I had the bitter greens with pancetta (okay) and the ribs(totally tough and over cooked) with the canelli beans(boring).  My wife had a green garlic soup that she thought salt may have spilled in and the duck which was the highlight of the meal.

I am sorry, but at these prices you only get once to impress and that just did not happen.
author: Erik L.

description:
i'd been wanting to eat here for awhile.  not sure what that has to do with review, but i thought i'd tell you that.  i could also tell you that the topic at the dinner table was revenge...sweet, sweet revenge.  but again, that is not germane to this review.  i wrote all of that so i could use the word "germane" in a sentence.

the mashed potatoes were freaking good.  i don't know who invented mashed potatoes, but they were really good.  i guess what i'm asking is if that is an actual Italian dish.  bet you never thought of that, didja?  the answer is it originated in the Americas....well, that's what it said on one website...too lazy to try to verify that.  point is, they are good here, m'kay?

the spaghetti was excellent.  pasta cooked perfectly.  i had the "hay and straw"...two types of angel hair pasta with peas, and an egg yolk over it.  i like egg yolks.  i really like egg yolks.  

the bread they give you at the start is phenomenal.  is that Bakery Tartine bread?

ummm, so they don't serve the pizzas over in the restaurant.  go figure.  

the service was good.  the atmosphere was fine.  it's not really the type of place where you might enjoy a leisurely 2+ hr dinner, especially if you have a conscience and are concerned for the people waiting to get seated.  not a complaint, just something you should know.  

the profiteroles were good.  the almond cake was even gooder.

prices are not horrible, but the price-to-quantity ratio isn't excellent, but i am concerned about gaining too much weight, so the quantity was fine for me.  it's no Olive Garden or anything though.  yes, i TOTALLY went there...so suck it.
author: Miss P.

description:
Delfina never fails me. The calamari appetizer is divine. The pasta's are always amazing. Love the Panna Cotta. Scoring a table and sitting outside without a reservation was one of the most magical nights of dining in San Francisco. 

The wines have a broad price range, so you can go spendy or not so spendy. 

Love the wait staff too - funky, knowledgeable, friendly and lets face it, foxy.
author: Paige B.

description: Greeted nicely by a very friendly hostess. While standing the manager came by and offered us a drink, he was very helpful with wine and offered a little tasting and educated us on them. Great service and amazing fresh food.
author: Nicole P.

description: Great selection of very tasty thin crust pizza. The restaurant is a bit small but if you're lucky you can get a seat outside on the small terrace on the street (heated). Very relaxed ambiance.
author: Simon C.

description:
When I get the chance to have a delicious dinner out with friends, one thing I really appreciate is the ambiance. The staff are all very helpful, gracious, and non-pretentious. Bread is always sliced fresh and butter is sprinkled with sea salt for an extra dab of baked love.

Since my friend was running half an hour late, the waitress asked if I wanted to wait with something to drink, and suggested the moscato d'artsi ($9.75/glass) after asking me what kind of wine I liked. It was AMAZING. What I also love is that she didn't try to sell me the most expensive wine on the list, but rather suggested something that suited my tastes instead-- it's rare to see a restaurant not take advantage of your wine-innocence and stick you with an expensive glass of something you don't really like- so +stars for that. The muscato was so good that I had two! 

+ the Rosemary Tagliatelle with wild boar ragu was absolutely delicious, and worth the $18 tiny portion. It was creamy, thick, piping hot, fresh, and just great
+ the calamari appetizer ($9.25) was also really good. I'd expected it to come out sliced and fried, but instead it came out whole. One of the tentacles was extremely salty though, but still yummy. Since I'd ordered it since I was starving waiting for my friend to arrive, the waitress came over to apologize because she said the chef had been holding the calamari back because he'd been watching my table to see when my friend would arrive, but that they were re-making a new plate to send over right away.
+ Casual atmosphere. Makes for fancy dining without the faux-faux.

-- Cramped!! Small dining area. There was a makeshift tarp jutting into the sidewalk that I suppose served to cover the sidewalk patrons, but you're literally on the sidewalk.

I would come back here again for a casual meal, but wouldn't jump at having my birthday or anniversary dinner here (but I'm a snob for pretty venues.)
author: Cheryl F.

description:
I will rate this place purely on the food and service and NOT the loud and annoying tool seated at the next table.  

I had a wonderful meal.  Husband and I shared the insalata di campo, gnocchi, and halibut.  The salad had just the right touch of vinegar and saltiness tossed in the fresh greens.  Their gnocchi is perfectly light and melty (is that a word?) with a savory sauce.  Our halibut made my mouth water and had a hint of coconut in the buttery sauce.  So good!  For dessert, we had the profiteroles made with espresso gelato, chocolate sauce, and candied almonds.  That just sounded like good with good and some more good.  Mmm...

The servers were attentive and helpful.  The chefs actually split everything for us without us asking and the portions were pretty satisfying.  The space is cozy and always bustling but has such a fun vibe.
author: Nina L.

description:
My neighborhood favorite! Delfina consistently hits the mark with excellent food and service. Their revolving menu is inventive, but not too outlandish. The focus is on great quality food and friendly (but not fussy) service. 

You never know who you are going to see there! Perhaps it is the laid-back urban elegance that attracts the wide range of visitors. I've seen Parker Posey dining there and I heard that Kate Hudson and Owen Wilson were canoodling there recently. 

I love the stretched mozzarella. Each time I eat there I learn about some type of food I'd never even heard of.
author: lisa l.

description:
Deceptively simple food. The sort of food that makes unsophisticated diners say, "overpriced."

As a former chef, let me tell you... the more simple the food is the harder it is to hide your technique or ingredient failures.

Delfina is, for me, my "back home" restaurant. When I've been traveling away from SF - this is where I go to welcome myself back.

As a tip - there are a couple of dishes on the menu that (while actually quite good) are placed there for the folks who are afraid of their food. The chicken (for example) is something I'd probably skip. Just take the risk and order things that are out of your comfort zone. It's worth it.
author: Malachi S.

description:
the food was delicious all around, and the shortrib cappelliti melted in my mouth.  the spaghettini nero my friends ordered was very tasty and didn't try to whack you with the squid ink flavor like some other places do.

I had the chocolate budino for dessert and while it was good on its own, it wasn't spectacular... unless you made sure to perfect the dessert bite: a bit of budino, and bit of ice cream from the accompanying quenelle.  delicious.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Delfina is kind of like the movie "Juno."  Maybe if everyone hadn't made such a big effing deal about how great it was, you could've just enjoyed it as the standard experience it was, instead of thinking about how it failed to meet expectations.

Similarly, Delfina didn't posess any fatal flaws, but it's not worth making reservations weeks in advance, either.  Also, the "Italian" classification is straight-up wrong at this point; it's new American.

And c'mon, a little explanation on the menu wouldn't hurt.  I mean, I do speak fluent Italian and all (*snort*), but a few English adjectives wouldn't break the daily printing budget.
author: Alissa K.

description:
When I walked into Delfina for dinner recently with four friends I was thinking to myself, "I really, really hope this place is not overrated."  I immediately took to the gorgeous low lighting and the small tables situated closely to one another.  I'm kind of an Italian food snob and hardly ever eat at Italian restaurants because they can be so disappointing.  I'd much rather buy fresh pasta from Falletti's and cook it perfectly al dente myself.

We sat down and started with an excellent local Syrah and some delicious appys - calamari on a bed of warm white beans (YUM!), beet salad, broccoli raab (loaded with garlic and olive oil, perfect) and perfectly grilled fennel-encrusted fennel. Fennel in any form besides sliced on a salad with citrus is a big plus in my book. 

Next, the pastas.  Holy mother of god - absolute fucking perfection.  I ordered the wild nettle risotto with mushrooms.  I knew Delfina could win me over if the risotto was top notch, and it really was. I'm pretty sure there was a stick of butter swimming in my dish, which may have helped.   The spaghetti was stunningly simple and delicious, and reminded me very much of the pasta found in casual trattorias in Florence or Rome where people swarm in for lunch, eat a bowl of perfectly cooked pasta standing up at the bar with a cup of red wine.  This is one of the few restaurants I have been to in the United States where the pasta ACTUALLY tastes like pasta you find in Italy. YUMMM!!!!  The ahi with warm lentil salad and anchovy aioli was perfection as well. 

I already feel like a blubbering idiot about this place, but I do have to mention one more thing - dessert.   The espresso profiteroles were alright but not really my thing (I'm not a big chocolate person).  The blood orange panna cotta, however, almost knocked me out of my chair.  I took the first bite and my eyes grew wide as I silently savored the insanely heavenly deliciousness on my tongue and waited for someone else to try it and join me in my dessert-gasm. WOW.

As you can see, I don't have many (any) complaints about this place.  I do have to say, though, the wine list was very limited in terms of affordable selections.  I think there were only 3 or 4 reds under $40.  I mean, as much as I wanted to I couldn't just breezily order the fantastic but pricey 2001 Brunello for $110.  Maybe this is how they keep out the riff raff - by making it prohibitively expensive for you to get drunk.  And hey, it worked.  After dinner my friends and I hit up the 500 Club and the Lex for $3 drinks at both.  Sweet.
author: Leona K.

description:
An intended quick cheap pizza eat-outside night flip-flopped into a pricier, wine, appetizer, shared entree, desert, eat at the bar night.  It was a good swap though, except for the budgeting attempt which is not working so well.  We drank tons of wine and the bartender was great at choosing fun new kinds for us to pair with our appetizer, turned entree, turned cheese dish, turned desert.  Plus, by the bar there was a door open to the outside, so it was almost like eating outside, but warmer and just as lively.  I liked eating at the bar better than sitting at a table (although i never ate at a table here so really i wouldn't know), it was freer and more fun.  I liked the busy rushing environment around us as we drank wine after wine.  We shared all the dishes and managed to stay right at $100, which we thought we were well over and happily were not, so that wasn't soooooooooooo bad.  

If you are still hungry after trying not to spend too much and drinking your budget accidentally instead of eating it, there are some cheap markets around open late that you can grab a chocolate bar and mexican candy treat, both for a buck even.  It would be fun to get to go broke pretending you're rich until you were totally poor and had to change your lifestyle (if you could then start over).  There should be a reality show on that i think.  Not sure where that came from but i guess that's how i felt when i left and went to the Mexican market with my candy.
author: Today Y.

description: Came here after happy hours on a Friday evening and was seated on the counter within five minutes.  Though I was still reeling the effects of the massive amts of vodka consumed during happy hour, the hangar steak was very good.  I also had a tasting of their sea bass and it had very good flavor as well.  Wish I didn't drink so much that evening I had some close calls slipping off the stools at the counter. . . parking can be a bit of an issue but if you're willing to walk. . .there's parking on the other side of Dolores Park.
author: Max L.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Good ambiance, good service, and I love their crab risotto. After dinner friends would always drop by the ice cream shop a few blocks down the street to get the desert. Would absolutely come back again.
author: Linda S.

description:
A recent visit to Delfina topped the last one documented below. Loved our server who made a great wine recommendation and let us taste it before we committed to it...

Had the delicious Ligurian fish stew - cacciucco - lots of great seafood and a wonderful smoky broth. A side of the brussels sprouts with pancetta was so good I would order it as a meal!

Desserts were to die for - their new pastry chef is a rock star! Butternut squash crostata with sage gelato was the perfect balance of savory and sweet and so creative. The buttermilk panna cotta with blood oranges was the perfect consistency and so tasty.


Had another excellent meal here last week. While waiting for our pulled mozzarella and chicken liver crostini to arrive, ordered a bottle of Pra Soave Classico (I know the winemaker) and enjoyed a toast to summer on the patio.  I'm never very wowed by the Secondi on the menu, but of course could not resist the Pappardelle with Pork Ragu - divine! Washed that down with a bottle of Barolo from A.Fantino (from Monforte d'Alba) 1997 - incredible! Profiteroles for dessert were delicious!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
I love this place.  A girlfriend and I went here in August and had a fantstic meal.  We had a few plates to share.  That is really the best way to go if you ask me.  Get one salad, one app., one pasta and a meat dish.  Just share it all.

They have great wine at the wine bar also.  Our waitress offered us a taste of a few wines before we got a bottle. (We picked the priceiest one, I guess we have good taste?)

The food is filling in a healthful way, you leave satisfied, not in a food coma.


...

On a side note, the date was going well, she came home with me.  We sat on the couch and made small talk, then she threw up all night and slept on my bathroom floor.  I don't blame the food, I blame those terrible Campari sodas that she was having at the lone palm after dinner.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Perhaps the menu is just not my taste but I just can't get excited to go here.  

That said, I'm always willing to give it another try because I can't shake the feeling I'm missing something and I haven't had a particularly bad experience to date.

With Farina opening to significant disappointment down the street, adding a star to Delfina for making our neighborhood so much more pleasant.
author: Jenny S.

description: When your friend says mean things to you , your boss just doesn't understand you or you are having just a plain old bad day , come to Delfina to forget all your troubles. Everything was cooked to perfection.The waitress was super attentive and the table by the window was perfect for people watching. Try the Panna cotta you swear your problems just melt away
author: Sophia C.

description: The spaghetti is delicious here and reasonably priced for such a popular place. The insalata di campo salad was really good too. I was most impressed though with the service. The staff was super attentive and always offering you more bread or water.
author: Jackson G.

description: Meh, it was only okay.  WAY better places here in the city and definitely not worth the cab ride across town since parking is almost non existent.
author: S W.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco and I have been coming since 2000 when they first opened and were only half the size. You can count on a delicious meal here. Great ingredients, flawless execution and great wine list. I always like the service here but it is definitely a hipster place! All the servers know their stuff, though. All time favorite items are the insalata del campo, spaghetti with tomatoes, the grilled calamari and their fish or their steak. I am usually always here for my birthday and anniversary.
author: Vanessa B.

description: The food is terrific, but I guess the Delfina chain is prone to the more-than-occasional  service f-ups. The waitress failed to submit one of our dishes to the kitchen, leading us to eat our meal out of order. First course, third course, second course. (A similar thing occurred at their pizzeria recently.) Received a verbal apology, but that really wasn't enough. The restaurant wasted my time and marred my experience. I'll be back, but I'll be wary.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
Looking for some good tongue? I know, who wouldn't.  As for the beef tongue at Delfina, I was hesistant to try it for the first time (even with my Chinese chicken feet eating heritage) but I figured it had to be good since it was Delfina.  It was delicious, you would never know it's beef tongue.  Hard to describe...thinly sliced like carpaccio, but cooked, tender beef, served with pine nuts and small currant berries.  

I don't remember what I had last time (too much wine?) but only had good memories.  Despite the hype and popularity, Delfina still has fab food.  In fact, everything was excellent, the ambiance, the food quality, the wait staff.  Parking might be the only (slight) issue, but you can hope for good parking karma.  Or do the $8 parking lot a block away at 18th and Valencia.

This time, the lamb sugo pasta (great wide noodle pasta!) and quail and polenta entree were fabulous.  The panna cotta with raspberries came out looking like flan but tasted like perfect, creamy not too heavy not too light panna cotta.  

No reservations? Walk in and sit at the bar/counter.  The wait is not too bad even on a wkend night (e.g. 20-30 min).  Service was excellent and the staff at the bar was fun.
author: Chris P.

description:
I've eaten at this establishment twice now.

Both times I have been completely statisfied.  

The food is fantastic, the wine list is as well.  The menu changes daily so unfortunately I can not recommend anything.  

The tables are indeed a bit too close for comfort and both times I was here, it was completely packed.  I recommend calling ahead of time and making a reservation.
author: Inga B.

description: Wonderful starter of grilled calamari over white beans and carne cruda. The rest of the meal included a couple of pastas, chard, italian green beans with tomatoes, french fries and panna cotta. Bread from Tartine was a plus. Loved everything except the pastas and french fries. Pasta was good, but nothing special and the fries were basic.
author: Nicci R.

description:
any pasta with any ragu - you can't go wrong.  Though know that the portion is tiny.  an app + a pasta + desssert probably won't be enough food.

I learned this first hand 2 years ago, when we first moved into the neighborhood.  Literally moved in that day and walked down to Delfina, having heard wondrous things about it.  About 9pm, we got two seats at the high bar adjacent to the dining room.

Two apps, two pastas, and a half bottle of wine.

Brandade was okay but the pastas were fantastic - one was a simple spaghatti and mine was a sheet pasta with duck ragu.  

Problem is, I took four bites and my pasta plate was DONE.  I had an inkling that the portions may be structured that way since the menu does subdivide into antipasti, primi, and secondi.  I talked to the waiter, who did not warn me that the pasta is portioned to accompany a secondi plate.  He brought the manager over who was gracious to the tee.  She asked me whether she can bring more food (I say yes - same pasta, just a double portion).  5 minutes later, the pasta got to our table.  She came by with two glasses of wine on the house.  And then sent us a panna cotta.

By this time, I was completely satiated - by the food, by the wine (our half bottle was so good that I asked to keep the empty bottle), and by the extraordinary response.

The bill came and it was like $150.  First thought was that - damn it, they charged us for everything!  Looking at the details, I saw that our half bottle of wine was like $90.  I went and grabbed a menu and realized that my wife had picked out a half bottle ($25) but pointed to the $90 bottle when she ordered.

I was wondering why they decanted our $25 half-bottle wine, why she apologized that she couldn't pour us the same wine (on the two freebies)  and why this little bottle was so darn good.  Well, now I knew why.

But in the end, it was a fantastic meal that could have easily, easily turned out disastrous if the restaurant did not take care of us as they did.  I start to think about whether the treatment was correlated with us ordering one of the most expensive bottle of wine on the list (and we were NOT dressed to impressed, having just spent the day moving).  It must have.

Regardless, I love telling this story and I love recommending Delfina to people who ask me about my favorite restaurants in San francisco, despite the impossibility of getting a table there.

It could have easily landed on my avoid at all cost list.  

Good wishes to Kristy at Delfina who made our first visit there a memorable one.
author: Hanson L.

description:
Yum Yum Yum. Their short ribs just fall off the bone.
Absolutely heaven.
author: umeboshi l.

description:
wow, perfect dinner and an awesome restaurant. I was in SF visiting from Seattle and wanted something local and good. And I must say that Delfina did not dissapoint. Sat at the bar and had awesome food and great service. 

I had the calamari, little gem lettuce, ravioli and profiteroles. (ok, i was really hungry). Every dish tasted amazing. Perfectly seasoned, not too filling and full of taste. 

Definitely plan to come back here next time I visit the city. Exactly what I needed.
author: Francois A.

description:
This place comes really close to 4 stars but for the price and the time you have to wait, I kind of expected better.

There's no real waiting area and even the bar is tiny (5 seats?) so when it is crowded it is not the most comfortable waiting environment. I managed to snag a seat solo at the bar and some guy (I think the manager) made sure to get me a glass of wine and didn't even worry about ringing it up or starting my tab.

Even though my dinner companion had not yet joined me, he seated me as soon as a table opened up and that was really nice.

The server, a young guy also running the bar seats, seemed overwhelmed with everything. I would have liked a better job of him making suggestions, making sure we were taken care of, etc. for the price but maybe he had more tables than he was supposed to.

The gnocchi was quite good and I forget what kind of cheese thing we had with bread, but it was really tasty.

I think it's great that the menu changes and they have really unique dishes which I am sure keep people coming back, but if the dishes are going to be unique and difficult to pronounce, it would be helpful if each of them included a description as to what they were, what kind of sauce they come with. We don't all speak Italian...maybe we should in order to eat there?

I couldn't fit room for a main course (non-pastas) nor a dessert so I'll give it a try, but you're on notice Delfina!
author: Mike T.

description:
To start we had the warm olives, anchovies, and calamari and white bean salad.  I love any salad involving white beans.

For pasta, we had the gnocchi with bolognese sauce, papardelle with pork sugo, and wild nettle pasta (I forget if it was spaghetti? I always wait too long to write reviews and forget these important details.)  All the pastas were 5 stars.

We also tried the tripe, which I was pleasantly surprised to discover I liked.  The seasoning and sauce gave it a delicious flavor.  I think this is a great place for those of us who are queasy about tripe to start giving it a shot.  

For meats we had the roast chicken, the pork, and the rabbit.  Everything was good, but nothing blew me away.  However, others in my party were more excited about the pork and the rabbit than I was, so maybe I just didn't give them enough of a chance. We all agreed that the roast chicken was yummy.

In the end, I just wasn't feeling the five stars for this particular night, but I'll definitely be back in order to re-assess!
author: L C.

description:
I have been here a number of times over the years and it's always been consistently excellent. 

the desserts are all good but the chocolate cake is special. i am a fan of chocolate cake and this has spoiled most other recipes for me. the creme anglaise sauce is the perfect addition to the warm and soft little treasure of a cake.
author: ari s.

description:
It's been almost 6 months since my last visit to Delfina, and it wasn't for lack of desire, but rather there are tons of restaurants in the city. We returned last Friday, and WOW! It was better than I remembered. Service was outstanding...she was on top of everything. And like many SF restaurants, food is ingredient driven, rustic with simple appearance, but by no means lacks on flavor. This place should set the standard for casual Italian cuisine! 
What we ordered:
Roero Arneis "Sanche in Vezza d'Alba"- Brovia 2005 Piemonte 
(great wine list with nice price range)

Crostini misti
Salt cod montecato 
Gnocchi 
Bucatini
Pork Belly

I went with the cheese tasting for dessert. This was certainly one of the best cheese plates in the city!  My bf (who has a huge sweet tooth) went for the Profiteroles with espresso gelato,warm chocolate sauce and candied almonds. Yup...he ate them all!

Can't wait to go back!
author: Allison H.

description:
I heard Jake Gyllenhaal ate there last week, so it must be good.

I loved this place - it was my birthday dinner and everything was so good.

The desserts were awesome - the best I've had in a long time - freshly made and amazing. The profiteroles were light and crunchy, and the warm chocolate cake with creme anglaise was great. 

The rest of the food was excellent - pork cutlets with morel mushrooms and polenta, and the spaghetti. Yum!

We ate late so no wait - we also had reservations and they seated us right away.
author: Nicki H.

description: Delfina is my vote for best Italian food in San Francisco- I realize that's a tall order, and I'm sure some will argue- but it's damn good. Not cheap, but entirely worth it. Best quality ingredients, prepared exquisitely- really nice tasteful décor too, great staff- I went there for my 50th birthday, and it was suitably "special". I remember, among other things, a pasta with morels, which was mind-blowingly, roll-your-eyes-back-in-your-head good. One of the most memorable meals I've had. Delfina is IT!
author: JOHN S.

description: I was going for dinner with my boyfriend and his dad. We didn't have a reservation but were there before anyone had come for a dinner seating - the place was empty. The hostess was totally rude to us and said was not going seat us for some time, if at all. She didn't even apologize when we walked out the door.
author: Iguana G.

description: The food is definitely really good, but it kind of ruins it for me that the portions are so small.  Hence the 3-star rating.  After a meal of 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, and 2 plates of bread, my friend and I went across the street and shared a steak and shrimp burrito for dessert.  That being said, we're kind of beasts, so maybe the average human would have been satisfied.
author: Gloria L.

description: I remember coming here years ago and really loving the place, but over the past few years I think I have raised the bar for great restaurants. The food is still very high on the quality, but nothing that innovative or new. Atmosphere is great, service is top notch and the food is fresh, but for the price, I feel I can get better values elsewhere. I think Delfina either needs to step it up one level or adjust pricing.
author: Joseph C.

description:
I had a very expensive but very lovely pizza here. I heartily recommend the fresh mozzarella to start with and have that with a broccoli rabe pizza. All the flavours were like little bombs that went off in the mouth leaving you feeling thoroughly spoiled.


 The service was excellent and this is amongst one of the best restaurants in SF. Sod orth Beach, here is a great place for good Italian and Pizza.
author: cleoisaleng

description: Food was ok but nothing great. Paid $200 for an experience that left alot to be desired. Usually when I pay that much for an experience I leave full and happy. Not in this case. We left still hungry and the wine selection was poor and extremely overpriced. Will not come here again
author: Fan S.

description: We really enjoyed the focus on organic and local ingredients here, and the waitstaff was professional and well-trained.  We sat at the bar before meeting a friend nearby for an art show. Some of the dishes seemed a bit pretentious, but everything we tried was prepared well and tasted good. It's been a couple of months since our visit, but as we remember the Meyer Ranch hangar steak was particularly tasty.  There was a nice selection of dessert wines, and the desserts sounded amazing. That will be on the list for a future visit. The decor is fun and the crowd is young and typical for the neighborhood.
author: Tamara M.

description:
Fabulous service and really one of the best meals I have had in years! Never felt rushed even on a busy Friday night.
I have tried to get reservations at Delfina's for a few years and all I can say is it was worth the wait! Big Thumbs Up!!
author: Claude S.

description: Handcrafted food. Soulful. I feel like I'm in Italy when I enjoy some of their pasta or their marvelous chicken dishes. Creative, fun, and festive.
author: Victor Z.

description: Maybe I didn't get the right dishes? I have heard from friends this was a great place to get good italian food. I had Little Gem salad which is nice, I wish there was more egg but the dressing was good and it had a nice tang to it. I ordered the small spaghetti and when they say small they mean small. However, I was surprised that though it was simple, it had alot of flavor. I wish they had the Pappardelle with pork sugo, because I wanted to try that from reviews I've heard. I wish we didnt order the chard because it lacked any flavor or garlic or lemon. Call ahead to get a reservation cause you don't want to end up sitting at the bar/walkway. Also its cramped, so be prepared to strike up a conversation with your neighborhood.
author: Vanessa C.

description: Look outside North Beach for an authentic Italian restaurant where spaghetti is cooked al dente with a simple, hearty tomato sauce.  It's a happening place for hip mixed drinks while you wait.  End with profiteroles to sweeten the palate.
author: Jenny L.

description: I've been here twice in the last few years and I'm about ready to go back. Yes, they're always very busy. What do you expect? It's a great restaurant.
author: Andrew L.

description:
gave delfina 3 stars but it's probably more like 3 1/2.

my friend and i split the ricotta cheese and tomato/cucumber appetizer. this was very good. the nice mild ricotta went perfectly with the bold sauted /tomato/cucumber. it was served with a nice crostini.

for dinner we both had the duck which looked great on paper but lacked in actuality. the flavor was good but the meat itself was tough and rubbery. both of ours were the same texture and a bit dissapointing.

for dessert, i had the pear tart with vanilla ice cream. this was good but unfortunately for delfina, i had just been hit over the head the night before with the best tart i have ever tasted...(the plum tart at chez panisse), so altough good, the pear tart wasnt quite a standout as it might've been if not.
author: Mark Y.

description: Steak source was great and fried potato was good too. I also ordered duck pasta and feta cheese appetizer. Everything taste amazing! Buy one thing... Wine by the glass was little pricy :(
author: Natsu Y.

description:
After a full decade i decided to go back to Delfina to see how it's doing and what's new. OMFG it became ridiculous i look at the menu and the dishes sounds very yummy so we ordered few plates. appetizers were bigger than the entree no kidding!! The entree was a simple sole in linguine pasta and it's $15-17 with practically no sole..hello am i at fleur de lys or something i know at the grand cafe they have bigger portions and it's more expensive so i'm wondering how would be the quail  dish for $25 ? 1 leg and 3 potatoes around ;-)
On the other hand the service was pleasant and the staff seems to help each other on the floor  a lot but food wise it's a freakin joke people, this place is designed for people who don't know how to cook or/and lazy to cook so they stop by for a " bite "
author: A D.

description:
My first time at Delfina and it was great.  Staff was super nice.  (e.g. we had a reservation for 6 and only 2 of us showed up!
