We confessed our situation (before they figured it out) and they said "no problem" - moved us to a table for 4 and converted our table for 6 into 2 smaller tables - win win.)  

As for $$$ rating - not sure about that.  We had one glass white wine, chicken liver crostini appetizer, blue cheese salad appetizer, 2 pork pappardelle, and Jerusalem artichoke soup.  With tax and tip - $51 - so quite affordable given the quality and diversity of cuisine!)

The soup was particularly "killer".  The crostini was superb too - Fava bean spread with lemon zest I believe - was amazing - even more tasty than the chicken liver crostini...  The pappardelle was a bit peppery/salty for my taste,but the pasta was homemade and tasted as such.

The bread - Acme and Tartine - I particularly liked the Tartine bread.  And the butter with what I believe was fleur de sel - was excellent.

All around a good time.
author: Bill T.

description:
My first visit wasn't so successful, although the menu seemed ambitious. I remember ordering a spaghetti that was good, but not great and the goat, which was marbled in fat and tendons, had a hairy exterior, and mostly inedible. It didn't help that we couldn't see what we were eating and out service was brusque and rushed.

Our second time was much more successful and although we sat at the bar, it was some of the best service I've ever received [though I'd have to admit that being cute has its perks].

Little gem lettuce with mountain gorgonzola, seived egg, radishes and lemon vinaigrette 8.25
My salads have been stellar lately, with Delfina being no exception--fresh, crisp, and with the depth of gorgonzola to boot.

We then shared two mains, a pasta and a fish:
Bucatini with fresh fava beans and guanciale 13.00
Local petrale sole in acqua pazza --- white wine, capers, oven-dried tomatoes and olives 24.00
The smooth chewiness of the bucatini (a hollow spaghetti) acted as a good compliment to the grainy starch of our fava bean puree. The flavor, however, wouldn't be able to holds its own as a standalone entree. I've had the petrale sole prepared with branzino at both Kokkari and LuLu's, where the fish was much more moist. When I ordered, I knew I was getting a carbon copy of something I had already had many times before, but the special ran out half an hour after they announced it.

We ended with a Bittersweet Scharffen Berger chocolate cake with crme Anglaise, which was the same dessert I had had previously at Delfina--and with good reason. The creme Anglaise reminded me of a pool of condensed milk floating at the bottom of our moist cake. I chose the Linden Tea because of its "buttery...natural sweetness," which I thought would go well with the cake. However, tea service at Delfina is a little troublesome, due to the one-cup pots and erratic espresso machine that only releases water in little spurts.
author: Monica T.

description:
Super delic. Rob, take the lady here...

Appending more to my post. Just went here for Halloween and decided this may just be my absolutely most favorite restaurant. Well, OK fine, ONE of my  absolutely most favorites!

Make reservations well well in advanced. You will not be disappointed.
author: Ali K.

description:
You must go to Delfina if you're in the Mission and you must get the Roasted Chicken.  GREAT food, love this restaurant.  

They should work on having a full bar (unless they do now because it has been super long since I've been).
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Despite all the reviews...I thought I would toss in my two cents.  

The food here was fantastic.  I can't remember the name of what entree I ordered, but it was a special that night, so you probably wouldn't be able to get it anyway.  To start however, I had an amazing calamari salad which was super fantastic.

The wine list is extensive and varied which is not all that surprising in SF.  I hear lots of whining about waiting, but we were able to get seated in the backyard patio immediately (and no, it wasn't 5PM).

Remember...if you can, try to get seated in the patio.  It's really neat out there.  I give 4/5 stars only due to the high prices and smallish portions.
author: Michael C.

description:
Delfina was a good dining experience.  The staff was very friendly and attentive.  The food was good as well.  

Was a little crampy though.
author: Delilah B.

description: I chose Delfina to treat my dear friend on his 30th birthday. I had never been there, and was happy to try it on this special day. I called the restaurant to make a reservation -- which I was able to get for the same evening --  and to leave word about the special occasion and that I wanted a discreet but meaningful birthday treat. Everyone, from the office person I spoke with who offered excellent service and professionalism, to the hostess who received us having been properly informed of our names and special occasion, to our servers, plus the gorgeous corner table under a wonderful bouquet of flowers they gave us, and the fantastic food, was FIVE STAR. The Delfina team truly made the evening a memorable one. THANK YOU!
author: Lucy K.

description: Delfina has been our "go-to" place forever. When we lived in the Midwest and visited SF, it was always on our must eat list. Since moving to the Bay Area three years ago, we have been happy to drive the 50+ miles each way just to eat dinner there. While the pasta remains stellar,  last night's main courses (duck for 2 diners) was inedible. Tough, tasteless.  So disappointing.  And I see today that other yelp reviewers said the same thing.  They didn't bring or offer bread, although all of the other tables received it. We ordered a bottle of wine, and brought a special 1997 Italian bottle with us. We gave a glass to the server.  In the past, they've waived the corkage under those circumstances. Not last night.  No restaurant, however fabulous, can afford to rest on their reputation.
author: Paula S.

description:
Fantastically wonderful Italian food, and the portions are sized such that you actually can eat a 'real' Italian meal - appetizer, pasta course, and second course. Don't expect just one to be enough, unless you've a very small stomach. Also, the patio out back is much better than the restaurant - often somewhat quieter and more relaxed and intimate, unless there happens to be a huge party there. Great fresh seasonal ingredients.
Read my full review at: http://sibilous.blogspot.com/2005/05/delfina.html
author: Don H.

description:
Followed Toro E's advice and got the plum tomato pasta (yummy, juicy, spicy, simple, memorable!) and the roasted chicken (perfectly done, even the breast meat was moist and juicy). So, so good. Love the cozy atmosphere, sat at the counter space; super cute! Romantic, I can definitely see this as a great date place.
To complement the savory, we had the peach bellini, and olive oil ice cream and chocolate torte dessert; bellini was good, as expected. Um, the dessert was... interesting. There was something about the sauce didn't quite click with me. Still, very interesting.
Altogether about $35 including tax, tip, and the SF tax thingy.
author: Jessica L.

description: Delicious food and knowledgeable, friendly wait staff.  4 instead of 5 stars because it is crowded, that is a lot of tables in a fairly small space.  But still, a nice dining experience.
author: John S.

description:
I go to Delfina to celebrate birthdays and more. Delfina is a great Italian restaurant!!! I love their fish dishes. The red wine was so smooth and with a silky taste. 

Great food and atmosphere.
author: Fabiola A.

description:
Not a whole lot for vegetarians butthe decor is lovely.
The staff is spry and the table is regularly bussed.
Wine list is great and the place has a terrific minimalist style.
Despite the lack of veggie fare and the long wait to get in and the oh whose elbow is that in my back, o hello next table scrunchy feel, I remember it fondly.  Perfect escape from the Castro to a good restaurant stop.
author: Sean S.

description:
Delfina is great.  My friends think it is okay or over rated.  i don't think Delfina is over rated.  It is one of SF best restaurants.  My meals are so well prepared.  something i look forward to and can't wait to go back.  My most memorable dish was the steelhead salmon-- amazing-- and i am not a big salmon fan.  everything is thought and delicious here.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Crowded, but when you taste the food, you will understand why.  When this place opened there was such a buzz about it that trying to get reservations was virtually impossible.  So, my cousin and I chose the "walk-in" option and dined at the bar.  Reservations are always accepted and are the way to go for parties greater than two.

The food is modern Italian.  What I can recommend off of the current menu:

- Prosciutto San Daniele with warm, marinated Italian chestnuts
-Insalata del Campo
- Roasted Fulton valley chicken with Yukon gold mashed potatoes and royal trumpet mushrooms

The restaurant is always bustling and the noise level can be a bit out of control on a busy night.  Parking is generally easy to find in this area of the Mission.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
They were super busy and packed out for a Monday night!!!
The food was delicious and fresh but everything tasted rather salty...
My friend and I ate:

-- House-cured salmon salad (while you'd expect cured salmon to be salty...this one was especially salty!). The crunchy salad part was good tho I wish there were more of it to offset the salty fish.

--Grilled fennel-crusted fennel was delicious but a bit too salty!

--Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil. Surprisingly really good flavor despite the bland sounding description....Just about the yummiest tomato sauce I've tasted on spaghetti! (We were bummed when they said they could not/would not add meat to the dish even though we were willing to pay for meat.)

--Prosciutto-mascarpone ravioli with lemon-herb butter. This was probably my favorite thing of all the dishes we tried. It was delicious!!

Not sure I would come back here again though...or perhaps I'd have to say I'm on a low-sodium diet to get them to cut back on the salt.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Finally had a reason to go to Delfina.  Parents were in town (and the girlfriend has been wanting to try it as well).  Not to mention I've lived all of 3 blocks away from it for the last 2+ years so I guess it's time.

So what, precisely, is the source of all the hub-bub about this place?  The decor is what I can best describe as 'hectically bland'.  The service, while friendly, was pretty sloppy.  The quality of the food (i.e., the ingredients) is tops but the presentation is pretty uninspiring and all the dishes we had in our party just didn't seem to be anything special.  My girlfriend even commented "don't these mashed potatoes taste like they're out of a box?".  

Yes, they did.  Given what we paid for 4 people I expected a lot more 'oohhhh' and a lot less 'meh' from this place.
author: Ross A.

description:
So I really like to give Delfina 3.5 stars.  I guess if you round up it should be 4.  But I really didn't think it was a 4.  So there...I gave Delfina 3 stars.

With that said....
I tried the insalata del campo.  I wasn't overly impressed.  The dressing from the salad was actually really good with the bread .  I had the pork shoulder as my main course.  I liked it but wasn't wowed by it.  My friend had the spaghetti.  The pasta was not cooked.  I know I know, pasta should be al dente but really, it was under-cooked.  So we had to send it back.  We also shared the brussel sprouts.  That was really good.  

The food overall was pretty good.  Here are the reasons why I didn't give it four stars:

1.  A restaurant with Delfina's reputation shouldn't serve pasta that's undercooked.
2.  Although the brussel sprouts were amazing, it shouldn't be the highlight of my meal.  

I really want to like this restaurant because everyone raves about it.  Maybe I'll have to re-evaluate after my next visit.
author: jenn c.

description:
This was a fabulous restaurant!  We had never heard of this restaurant, until we got a gift certificate.  The food was fantastic, the wine was perfect and the dessert was delectable.  The staff was friendly and very attentive.  I highly recommend:  

-  appetizer:  piatto di pesach
-  entre:  roasted Fulton Valley chicken (very succulent)  and Strawberry Mountain Ranch steak
-  side:  broccoli raab with garlic and peperoncini
-  wine:  Barolo "Ravera" (Novello) - Elvio Cogno 2003 Piemonte and Moscato d'Asti-Sori del Re ...
-  dessert:  Profiteroles with espresso gelato (covered in chocolate, YUM) and Meyer lemon semifreddo  (great texture and not too sweet)

Street parking is not great, but there's a lot with an attendant a block away for $10.  It was empty when we arrived, but it was full by 8:30pm when we were done with dinner.  I also recommend making reservations.  I called about three weeks in advance for a Saturday night dinner, and the only opening was at 6pm.  It worked out well, but the restaurant filled up quickly.
author: San D.

description:
Everything that needs to be said about this restaurant has mostly been said. Exceptional menu, exceptionally executed. So let me point out something that hasn't been mentioned before: The music. 
Whoever creates the mixes for Delfina has impeccable taste. There are artfully selected tunes from Brubeck, the Pixies, Coltrane, Wilco, Lester Young and I think I heard William Bell. A perfectly curated soundtrack to a perfectly prepared meal. 
Delfina truly rocks.
author: Jamie D.

description: Every time I walk around mission there is one place that is always buzzing with foodies ... Delfina. Excellent pizza. Casual atmosphere with great hosts and friendly servers. Simple, cozy , casual and tasty food. Great place 1
author: Chetan K.

description:
this place is a hidden treasure, amazing pizza, and i like how they give you those italian bread sticks just as a small appetizer.

SERVICE: excellent, i've been here twice and both times it was well above average. 

i accidentally ordered a pizza with no cheese on it, and even that tasted pretty good. they have very unique style pizzas also, if you're into adventure.
author: san francisco k.

description:
Incredibly fresh salad, very nice pastas but my main entree, the lamb legs, were really just average.

Restaurant is located on a charming corner of Dolores Park area of town.  Great casual vibe and friendly locals.  The spaghetti is prepared perfectly.  Service is somewhat slow and needs to be more attentive.

Really a 3.5 star restaurant.
author: Laurence H.

description:
By far, my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  There are lots of wonderful things to say about Delfina's, but this entire review will center around two items on the menu that I find myself craving at 2am...often......

Spaghetti & Panna Cotta

The spaghetti served at Delfina's is swoon worthy.  It will redefine what you thought a soup bowl of pasta could be, especially with just a plain, red marinara.  After much research, the magic ingredient seems to be pepericinos (sp?) but despite the best efforts, can not be reproduced in my kitchen.  They use wonderful (and expensive) pasta from Bi-Rite according to good sources.  By all means, if you are going to Delfina's, do yourself a favor and get the spaghetti!

The Panna Cotta is another can't live without it item on their menu.  While lots of other panna cottas tend to be super sweet and more reminicient of creme brule, theirs is perfect.  I think they put a little sour cream in it or buttermilk or something, but I couldn't be sure.  The sauce that it is in changes seasonally, but it is always absolutely amazing.  

By all means, if you haven't been here, go.  Even when we couldn't get reservations, we were able to walk in and get a table within 20 minutes.  And, if you get there earlier and are bored waiting, you can go and wander the aisles of the Bi-Rite market just a few doors down.
author: Julie H.

description:
I still have a lot to learn about fine dinning.

I wasn't blown away byt the menu, but the food was exquisite. You know when you look at a menu and nothing really jumps out at you?  That's sort of what I felt about last nights meal.

Salt cod mantecato with walnut oil and fennel seed flatbread. Meh not great but interesting texture.
Heirloom tomatoes and fresh-stretched mozzarella with basil. I thought they were great but my mom said she's had meatier Heirlooms before. Got my vote.
Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini.  Good choice. Served el dente. 
Summer minestra with ditalini and pesto. meh Decent.

I think my problem was that I forgot to check yelp for food suggestions  and thus was lost when it was time to order.

The service was amazing. The dark bread is awesome. The red wine was ok. Not sure which one I ordered but they have a great wine selection.
author: Adam L.

description:
I had dinner here last night.  I was not impressed.  I ordered the chicken and my friend ordered the steelhead.....neither of us were wowed. My chicken was just plain old chicken, not much flavors going on with it.  It came with trumpet mushrooms and mashed potatoes....both of which were just mediocre.  The chicken was tender...I'll give them that, but the flavor was lacking.   I didn't try the steelhead, but my friend said it wasn't that great either.  Prices there are not cheap either...like $20 to high $20s per dish (unless you order pastas which is around $15)  For that price, I don't think the food quality is outstanding.  One of my favorite restaurants is Range (also in Mission) and they had similar prices and the food there is outstanding!!  I mean they do have 1 Michelin star...hehe :)

For dessert, I ordered a chocolate-cake type thing.  It was good....it melted in my mouth and quenched my urge for something sweet, however it wasn't something I would crave to have again....just average.

I doubt I will eat here again.....if I do, however, I would order the pasta.
author: Neety P.

description:
-1 star = pricey
+2stars = good service
+3 stars = amazing food
+1 star = great ambiance and location

I wish I had written this review a few months ago so I could give you better details. 

called day of to get reservations = check
went w/ 4 of my very picky eater friends from Texas = check and nervous
food wine and dessert = heaven

I remember, quite vividly, my gnochi (sp?) with cooked veggies and rabbit.... oh my goodness. the gnochi would just melt in my mouth it was so fresh and light, the veggies were the perfect hints of sweetness, and the rabbit now that was truly amazingly tender. My super picky friends tried it and loved it (even the one that only eats chicken and hates veggies).

i do vaguely remember decent service (this is after several cocktails at Orbit Room and two bottles of wine at Delfina).

and I definitely remember being a little sad that I didn't make more money when we split the check.

On a separate occasion I shared some french pressed coffee and a chocolate dessert with a friend (walked in no reservations). And that was definitely amazing as well.

Do at least go here once, as far as excellent cuisine goes in the city this is pretty good bang for your buck
author: Acid B.

description: We came here to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday.  The waitstaff was great and the food was even better.  We will be back to try other items.
author: priscilla p.

description:
After hearing about this place on "Check Please Bay Area" (PBS) with favorable reviews, my friend and I decided to give it a try. I usually like to go to a restaurant a couple of times before I pass judgment, but we probably won't return to Delfina. This is not because of the food or service, but because of the 45 mile drive we have to make to get there. It's good- but not good enough for a long drive for a special dinner. First , the bad. No full bar- beer and wine only. Now I'm certainly no alcoholic, but a pre dinner Jack and Soda is my drink preference. Why I didn't catch this on their web site, or remembering hearing about it, I don't know. Maybe I just didn't do my research well. I really needed that drink, because parking is non-existent anywhere within two blocks of this place. The web says street parking, but with all the residential housing on the street- well good luck. They have valet parking at their sister restaurant Locanda on Valenicia, two and a half blocks away. Get ready to pay $12 for the valet- up front. 
Let's talk atmosphere. There is none. Go here for the food. My companion and I both wore business casual and seemed out of place. She was surprised that it didn't look muck like the photos on their site, all blamed on great photography- kudos to their ad agency. You could come here in sweats or cargo shorts and sandals and fit right in, even though it bills itself as "trendy". The atmosphere is, well, kind of reminded me of Chipotle. Hard metal table- hard chairs- really casual. Casual is ok with me, but don't bill yourself as "trendy". 
On to the food- the best part. We started with the Gnocchi Fritto and speck and warm olives. They were both prepared quite well, the olives warmed and bathed in garlic, hot peppers and olive oil. The speck on the Gnocchi Fritto looked a little dried out, but was a top quality brand. Next up the house salad. Excellent balsamic dressing and a generous thinly sliced shaving of Parmigiano-Reggiano atop, with a clean, well seasoned taste. We then split an order of Parpadella with a wild boar ragu. Best pasta dish I've had in a while. Perfectly balanced with the ragu sauce, the pasta was fresh and perfectly cooked. I have a feeling the pastas is the highlight here. Go for a full order. My friends entrée was the Roasted Mary chicken. Moist and flavorful, it had a rich natural sauce surrounding it. Her olive oil mashed potato side was a perfect consistency. I decided on the Berkshire Pork Arista. Perfectly cooked and seasoned, but about 15% lost due to fat and toughness. It was a shoulder cut, and they should change this to chop cut. I would have paid a couple bucks more for a chop cut. They have a great wine list by the way, and our Barolo fit the food well.  Last, the Panne Cotta desert. Perfect. Best I've had.
Anyway, go for the food as they have some great dishes. For a special dinner though there are better places in SF.
author: Nick D.

description: We needed to pick up 20 pizzas for an office event on Friday morning.  Amongst all the places we called the day before, only Delfina's was willing to have the pizza's ready for pickup by 11:45am.  When we arrived to pick up the pizza, all the workers were very pleasant and friendly.  They worked really fast and sent us on our way in a matter of just a few minutes.  We ordered a variety of pizzas.  The prosciutto and sausage pizza were the favorites!  I've tasted better margarita pizzas, but theirs was okay.  Delfina's is definitely on the top of my list next time I'm in the mood for pizza.  Great job guys!
author: Marie I.

description:
Oh, so disappointed. After so much hype, Delfina was a let down. 

First, good things: 
Pastas. Spaghetti was great. Ragu was yummy, but pretty small considering the price. 
Free bread from Tartine. 

Pretty decent things: 
Grilled Calamari App
The sauce served with the halibut entree (particularly good when eaten with the bread)

Most disappointing: 
Overcooked halibut (which was advertised as Medium to Medium Rare, it as neither) 
Pork Cutlet, too salty for my taste. 
$18 corkage seems a little steep. 

All in all, nothing amazing.
author: H g.

description: Small place ,upscale, n  food is yummy. Will come back definetely but make sure to be open with small portion serving.
author: cecille p.

description:
As a long time regular resident eater in San Francisco, only a hand full of restaurants have remained at the top of my rotation. Delfina is definitely one of those places. Uncompromisingly good, Delfina's standard roster of usual plates including the steak (request a mash for fries substitute), the mind-blowing chicken in a mushroom/wine reduction, the homemade spaghetti, gnocchi, and fish are always lovingly prepared, served simple, and always with fresh ingredients, and pair perfectly with any number of their varied wines. During the warmer months, I highly recommend booking the back patio for early dining (you must be out by 9:00 AM) for a relaxed, outdoor Mission Dolores feel.

The ambiance inside is perfectly bustling with excited faces of people who made reservations weeks in advance, and those of the lucky few who waited outside at 5:30 PM for the doors to open and snag a walk in table. I love going just a few minutes early, checking in, and then ordering and taking a glass of wine out in front of the restaurant. There are a few nice benches on the sidewalk near potted trees, and you can sip outdoors while you wait for the table to be cleared. Plan for a Friday meal at one of their 10:00 PM reservations... in the summer when it's dark at just 9:00 or 9:30 PM, that's a perfect way to start the weekend!
author: Ankarino L.

description:
The boyfriend took me here for a little "fancy dinner" and I totally enjoyed it. He said that it was his favorite restaurant to go to, and I totally now have a new "restaurant that is tasty" on my list! 

First, the best place to sit is at the little bar area they have in the restaurant. Not at the actual bar that serves drinks. Just a little bar along a wall that gives you full view of the restaurant and all that is happening. It's the best.

The food. AMAZING! The salmon was so delicious! And this is coming from someone that hates fish too! And the leg of lamb was totally tasty. Fairly reasonable price for the excellent food AND the excellent service. The host and the waitress were so nice and friendly. 

Seriously, check it out when you want to do something a little special.
author: Nicolas H.

description:
My first five star rating!  Finally made it here after hearing all the hype and wasn't disappointed.  I had three friends in tow, which always bodes well for getting a good sampling of the menu.  

Atmosphere:  seated us out on the back patio.  a nice quiet, setting for  a good meal w/out having to deal w/restaurant noise.

Service:  top notch, prompt, polite, and always helpful w/the menu.

Food and Wine:  We were all on board w/going family style and had one appetizer (sausage stuffed mushrooms), one salad (greens w/pancetta and walnuts), two pastas (a ravioli in some type of lemon creme sauce and a simple pasta pomodoro), and two entrees (grilled salmon, and grilled skirt steak and pomme frites).  My favorite was the simplest dish:  the pasta pomodoro.  My friend chose a Slovenian wine that I've never heard of but went great w/the meal.  Unfortunately, even between the four of us, we didn't have room for dessert although the Bittersweet Scharffen Berger chocolate cake looked awfully good.  I won't make the same mistake next time I'm there.
author: Simon N.

description:
Yum.  Nice wine list.  Great ambiance for a date or chatting with friends.  

Call WAAY ahead for a rsvp.
author: janice l.

description:
We were the first people seated on a lovely Sunday evening. We had a couple of drinks, browsed the menu and did some great people watching. 

We had two great pasta dishes, the gnocchi and spaghetti. fantastic, we want to return just for that.

The main course wasn't as good, the roast pork dish I got was OK, but  not exciting. The cracklin's that came with it where so thick and dense that it actually hurt to bite and chew it. The GF's fish was slightly dry, but had good sauce and veggies with it. 

The dessert, dark chocolate cake,  didn't do it for me. Not that it was bad, I just think it's not my thing.  

The service was very good, friendly and efficient. Surprisingly so considering how fast the place filled up. By the time we left, every table was full and the place was quite bustling and noisy. 

All in all a nice meal, and a place we want to return to, maybe at Passover when they sometimes serve matzo ball soup!
author: Chuck K.

description:
Honestly, I thought it was a bit over hyped. The food was good but not great. 
Positives: Desert was definitely delicious, got the chocolate molten cake and so where the fries and olive oil mashed potatoes. 

Negatives: All the pasta entries and apps we got tasted like butter and olive oil. We went for a small birthday party at 7:30 on a Tuesday and it felt as if the servers were trying to rush us through the ordering process. (Now I realize I am used to a New Orleans pace). But really coming back every five minutes to ask if we were ready. (At least ask if we have any questions.) Is inexcusable. (So yes I am picky about service at nice restaurants...but hey I worked as a server in New Orleans I know what it means to be gracious). In addition to the good (but not great food) the wine list did not wow me. (And we tried several glasses of different red varieties before settling on two bottles). 

So all in all not as great as expected. However I might go back and sit at the bar area with a friend.
author: Courtney R.

description:
I don't think I have ever had an even average meal here. 
The wine list is great and the food is fantastic. It gets crowded fast, but since I eat early, I haven't had much of a problem getting in.

Like Tony The Tiger says...."THEY'RE GREAT!"
author: JR H.

description:
It goes without saying that Delfina cooks up very fresh and delicious fare. The reasons for my fantastic meal there last night however, are because of restaurant's impeccable service and exciting ambiance. If you want to know about the food, read the other reviews; this is an ode to Delfina's excellent staff.

First, I do not believe that one need have intimate experience with the restaurant industry to appreciate fine dining. Yet, since I have been a hostess, server and bartender, I am overjoyed at great food coupled with great service. And I can tell you that the latter is also much harder to come by.

This popular restaurant was a buzz last night, of course being a Saturday. My partner and I live very nearby and stop by ever so often just to try to slip in. Last night, we got lucky and got a seat at the counter within minutes. This is the best view of the restaurant, in my opinion, because you get to watch the seamless operation of Delfina without feeling imposing. I am awe-struck by the genuine niceness of their large staff. It was hard to tell if anything went wrong, so gentle and smooth the employees move and talk with diners and coworkers alike. 

Every single person, hostess to food runner, made us feel like we were valued guests. Even servers and chefs who didn't directly serve us threw a smile our way as we stared, bemused at the calm and graceful dance before us. They clearly pay attention to detail from the cleanliness to food, from music (not louder than conversation-level) to kind and professional service.

Watching this packed restaurant pump effortlessly like a runner's heart makes me want to work for them. But, I think I'll just go back and watch from my glass of torre di re.
author: G Z.

description:
I finally got to try Delfina!  From its reputation and how much I enjoyed Pizza Delfina, I had pretty high expectations.  I did my homework by reading all 5000 reviews on yelp (or almost) and contemplated very carefully over their menu posted online to see what I should be eating. 

We had a group of 4.  Even though only 2 of us showed up on time for the reservation at 6 (by the way, hard to make so call early!), they gladly seated us.  So happy to see restaurants without the "unless everyone is here, you need to be shoved into the bar area" attitude.  

In fact, we waited for our 4th person to arrive for quite a while and didn't order anything in the mean time.  The waitress came a couple of times to check on us, but never pressured us or made us feel bad. 

Food is very good, but what's with the salt?  The bread was chewy and delicious until I tasted a huge chunk of salt in there.  Then I had my grilled calamari.  Wow, what a great combo of flavors.  The white beans and salad was so tasty and the calamari was tender.  But then again, there are parts of the calamari that is covered with salt.  Way too salty for my taste. 

I also had the Mint Tagliatelle with creme fraiche.  I love creme fraiche.  There is a huge difference between your standard creamy alfredo sauce and something creamy but light like creme fraiche.  I can barely taste the mint, but it's probably better not to overpower the dish with it.  

One friend had the dungeness crab with pasta special.  It was so flavorful and the crab tasted so fresh!  We all had a bite and loved it.  The other two friends had the steak, which they liked a lot.  One friend substituted french fries with mashed potato.  It was good. 

A cauliflower soup was also ordered.  I had a spoonful.  it was really good and I would have never guessed it was cauliflower, but it also tasted different from any creamy soup I have had.  

For dessert we shared the profiteroles.  They were good with strong espresso flavors, but way too sweet for our taste. 

We had a very fun and pleasant dinner.  Service was friendly and efficient.  The bill was reasonable: $170 after tips and taxes for four of us, and that included some beverages, appetizers and dessert (although some are shared.)

I would love to go back to try more dishes.  And hopefully next time the chef can go easy on the salt.
author: Candice B.

description:
Came here the other night for a friend's bday dinner.  I had been wanting to eat here for several years now, as it is very much an established SF foodie restaurant, so my bar was set kinda high.  But boy, did this place live up to the reputation.  Execution was spot on, and I liked their subtle, but unique translations on classic Italian dishes.

Started with a Jerusalem artichoke soup with black trumpet mushrooms.  Delicious!  Their warm chicory salad was nicely dressed with a red wine vinaigrette-spiffed up Caesar dressing.  My entree was a pork rib chop with fennel seed crust which was so slowly roasted that is was amazing!  As for the desserts, I'm a total sucker for anything panna cotta, and their buttermilk panna cotta with red grapefruit wedges was so simple but so beautiful - I nearly cried.

Very impressed with this place, even given my high expectations.  It certainly lived up to the hype for me.  Simple and innovative Italian, minus any pretense.
author: Adrian L.

description:
I just adore this place!!

Salt cod mantecato (aka salt cod brandade)- good
In love with the fresh-stretched mozzarella

Roasted Fulton Valley chicken with Yukon gold mashed potatoes and royal trumpet mushrooms
Spaghetti with plum tomatoes
California Swordfish with escarole and blood orange-pinenut conserva

All seasoned to PERFECTION

perfect mood lighting
great wine list
author: Heidi L.

description:
I love this place!  Their staff is friendly, food is awesome, the atmosphere and decor is fun and hip~ what else can you ask for? 

They have a heirloom tomato and mozzarella salad that just melts in your mouth (this is seasonal) and their pastas are all good.  Linguine with clams, spaghetti... and their fish dish is good too.  They have a little pizzeria next door that is separate, but still a part of Delfina.... I haven't tried it, but it's always crowded whenever I walk by it. 

You just can't go wrong with Delfina.  Next time you are in town, you should definitely try it, but a reservation ahead of time is a must!
author: Catherine H.

description:
This was just yummy!  My 2 friends and I came here and the food was great!  Delicious and delicately made.  From the fish to the lamb it was full of flavor and the ingredients just spoke for itself.  I just wished they had more vegetables with their meat - because the veggies were magnificent!  Great ingredients = great food.

I would come back again - and its worth booking in advance
author: Bess N.

description:
To be honest I'm really not sure this is worth all the hype.  Service was cold and rushed/ inattentive.  Food was good, but not great...and totally not worth the price.  Restaurant is REALLY loud, this is not a place to take your parents when they're visiting.

I feel like we need to try it again b/c it's always talked up so highly, but maybe if someone else is paying the bill?
author: Kimberly G.

description:
I just had to be the 544th reviewer. This place has awesome, fresh, seasonal, tasty food. All of it was perfectly cooked and seasoned. Yes, it's not cheap, but you get what you pay for, and it's ALL good. For those who compain about portion sizes, please stop, these are perfectly sized dishes, not an all you can eat buffet. Very friendly, laidback service. Nice, but not snobby, didn't rush us.

I had grilled calamari (the best appetizer), the pasta known as "little hats" filled with shortrib. mmmm, like meat flavored butter.  And the side of turnips was just perfect. It's rare when you go out to eat and all 6 of your dining companions all equally LOVE their food.

My only disappointment was that I haven't come here sooner.
author: Nima K.

description:
I took my wife here for our wedding anniversary since it was voted the best Italian restaurant of the  year (Bay Guardian 2008). Reservation went fine, street parking was very challenging.

The restaurant was already packed by 5PM. Hostesses were courteous and greeted us promptly. We didn't have a baby sitter so we had to bring our 9-month old, but the staff accommodated us with a high chair upon request.

Expect decibel noise to be very loud during the busy hours. Also, despite the wide floors positioning of adjacent tables and chairs is very close. My wife and I were almost rubbing elbows with the couple next to us.

A clean, contemporary look with lots of hanging lamps and other tidbits sets the tone for an upbeat dinner atmosphere. Wait staff can be seen walking hurriedly back and forth. Outdoor seating on the sidewalk is a less desirable option but still is available.

The menu was filled with great items, including the ribs that I ordered. My wife had the filet mignon with mashed potatoes. Our appetizer was the calamari, which had a delicious, smoky flavor and went surprisingly well with the beans. The ribs were succulent, tender and tasty. I highly recommend them! Unfortunately the mashed potatoes and my polenta was unforgivably salty, a disappointment for a business that was recommended so highly.

Additionally, for the prices that Delfina charges, their service that evening was horrible. On my wedding anniversary we had to pull teeth to get any of the staff's attention, including to take our order, to get a refill on the water and drinks, or to give comments on our salty meals. We watched as other people who were seated after us were served first. You may have to order from other customer's waiters/waitresses as you struggle to track down your own.

One positive note is that my wife received a free dessert for our wedding anniversary, and the waitress took a photo for us. But by then our mood was already soured by the quality of service and the quality of the food.

The bill was just short of $100. I do not mind spending good money on a quality experience, but Delfina failed to impress. I was bitterly reminded that the views of a local newspaper aren't necessarily accurate. Perhaps it was just an "off" night for the restaurant. Even so, a couple with a wedding anniversary dinner reservation should not have to endure such inconsistencies.
author: Danny H.

description: This is the best spot regardless of the genre. Ryan and Chris are always adding something fresh to the menu. The people are friendly and passionate which is very comforting to a foodie in the industry.
author: Reid O.

description: I always spend way too much money here, and yet I keep coming back. The hanger steak is amazing, the wines pair nicely, and the desserts are incredible. This is a great place to splurge.
author: Martin E.

description: Amazing! My favorite Italian Hands down, please open one closer to my home!!!! Cant wait for the truffled pasta in Fall!
author: Megumi B.

description: I LOVE their pizza. Most of their pizzas are very unique and delicious. I love eating in the restaurant as well as picking up a pizza next door at the pizzeria. The atmosphere is fun and romantic. I crave their pizza MmmmMmm
author: Jenna Q.

description: Had an amazing meal for our group. Started with Little Gem, Asparagus, and Artichoke. Great flavors. Hanger Steak tender and great flavor. Ahi was perfect, seared and pink on the inside. Three different Gelato/Sorbetto had great flavors. Presentation and service top notch throughout the evening.
author: Andy M.

description:
in simple terms, one of the best restaurants i have ever been to.
everything was right, the menu, the taste, the presentation, the service, even the iced tea was really really good.
if i had to complain about something, i could do without the wait, but with a place this good it's inevitable

everyone should try their spaghetti at least once in their life
author: Ja A.

description: Lukewarm food, too little too late service. No longer the Delfina it used to be.
author: Beatriz M.

description:
Visited Delfina Thursday night and it was a real treat!
We called for reservations 2 days earlier and asked if we could make a 7:30 show if we were seated when they first opened. They assured us that they would have us to our show on time and even inquired when we arrived whether we still need expedited service to make our show! That gets extra points in my book! The service was excellent all through dinner.
We began with the crudo (I think the citrus was grapefruit) and it was very good. A bit heavy on the salt but still very tasty. I would order it again.
Next we had the carpaccio served over radicchio. The amount of radicchio was a bit much and since it is naturally very bitter I had to balance my lettuce/beef ratio carefully. It was otherwise well prepared.
I ordered the duck served with a rich pomegranate reduction. The sauce was so good I wanted to drink the left overs from the mini pitcher in which it is served. The duck portion was a bit small leaving me desperate to do something with all that incredible sauce. The waitress brought out extra bread to solve my problem. 
We ended with a pana cotta with blood oranges which was also very nice!
I can't wait to go there again.
author: Rob C.

description: Well worth the wait fo 2 months to get a reso.  I've eaten here over the years and Delfina continues to serve up AMAZING food, service and the warm, local neighborhood feel keeps the vibe alive.  Our waitress was a gem and made our evening with the commentary, friendliness and knowledge of the food.
author: C S.

description: This is quite simply an excellent Italian restaurant in the Mission (I'm Italian but I'm not related to the owners). We had the home-made spaghetti with their tomato sauce and peperoncino flakes (which is the most basic dish in Italian cuisine and yet it's the main test to tell a good place from a bad one): it was spectacular, both the pasta and the sauce. Then we also had tagliatelle with chanterelle and nettles: it was just as perfect. If you haven't tried it yet, do yourself a favor and go!
author: Marco Z.

description:
I know  many people who will swear that this is the best Italian restaurant in San Francisco. I can understand why they say that but they are wrong.
Delfina is definitely a good restaurant. All dishes are quite good, but in the end, no dish leaves you with a the feel of "I got to come back here".

So from where delfina gets its name?
From its overly sophisticated dishes that you won't see anywhere else. From special and unique sauces to deserts of chocolate and salt together, the small menu is very unlike anything you saw before.
But again, although unique and special, in the end the results are good but nothing more.

Prices are slightly expensive and you will probably go out with about $90 for a main course, desert and wine for two.
author: Shahar N.

description:
I was expecting something completely different. I had a vision of an old dark large circular booths primarily candel lit. Don't ask me where I got this from...? It was hardly that, but not in a bad way. Very Retro I believe the word would be.  Pretty tight quarters and a lot of hussle, but nothing took away from the holiday dinner with friends. 

The service was excellent! Glasses of wine the minute we walked in the door, they were on top of our every need. On that note they were able to recomend very good and reasonable choices. I was not as impressed with the food as I think I should have been, but I would certainly go back to try more. I got a decent taste of multiple dishes. I LOVED the calamari over white bean salad app. Also my steak was very good. The ravioli that my friends had was by far the best thing ordered! A couple others had the ahi and it was a little dry, I was glad that I opted out of that. 

Overall I had a good experience and would definetly go back. Would not recomend it as my favorite in the city, but it was perfect for our girls night out!
author: Lisa K.

description:
The food is still wonderful, but on the night I was there, there was no love in the dishes.  When the chef really cares, you can tell, be it from the graceful drizzle of bechamel in a puckish design on the plate, or an artfully careless sprinkle of garnish, or that deft touch of truffle oil on the finish.  The carpaccio, crab salad, and pasta dishes were honestly quite wonderful, but the lack of love was evident, and while they pleased, they didn't delight.  

The Fulton Chicken, a tried and true warhorse of this menu, just wasn't up to snuff on the night I visited.  The stock/jus below tasted ersatz and ruined what was an otherwise perfectly cooked chicken.

If you've never been to delfina, you'll love the food.  If you've been before and haven't been back in a long time, you may be disappointed.  It's a matter of perspective: for some, Venice is perfectly satisfying as it is, for some, it's the rotted husk of a once-was empire quietly sliding into a swamp.  Same thing with Delfina now, I feel--it's a matter of perspective.
author: Kosuke I.

description:
Okay, so I know this place is hailed as being one of the best in the city but frankly I wasn't impressed.  Not only was it difficult to get a reservation but the place was packed to the gills on a Tuesday night and it was difficult to enjoy the company of the people I was eating with.  The food was tasty enough but it was very rich and fairly greasy and was a long way from blowing my mind. If I want a meal that relies so heavily on the fat content for its flavor, I'll order cheap Chinese takeout for half the price. If I pay 25 dollars for a plate of food I expect something more.  No offence to my boyfriend's mom who treated us to dinner, but I don't think I'll be going back. 

On a more positive note, I have heard really good things about the Delfina pizza place right next door.  Perhaps that will live up to my expectations.
author: Katie V.

description:
We hit it on a Saturday, sans reservations.  It took some waiting, but we got in.  The service was a little slow, but is was BUSY, so all is forgiven.
Our meal was delightful.  If you are smart, get a reservation.  

Without a reservation, Prepare to wait . . . discuss Kafka, or some other such esoteric literature, you'll probably come to a consensus before you are seated.  Hope you like talking to your wife, SO or date :)
Well worth the wait!!!
author: C M.

description:
My number one pick as the most over hyped place to eat in SF! Hands down!

You ask, "How could this be?"

I have herd from quit a few people that we had to go there. There was a two week wait for reservations. We finally got in...

This was my experience.

The first thing that struck me was the menu was boring and straight forward. Fish, Chicken, Rabbit or Skirt Steak. I had the calamari which was nice, bitter green salad was good but nothing special, and the Rabbit was decent but nothing worth talking about. The waitress had was nice. The 60.00 bottle of wine  which was recommended should have cost 35.00.
We were sat outside in the back under a heat lamp that felt like a blast furnace! The chairs were very uncomfortable, the table felt awkward and wobbly. I don't recommend sitting outside!

So yes, it wasn't bad, it overall was a nice dinner. But after waiting 2 weeks to eat there and having to call to verify our reservation which was very annoying, It wasn't even close to the hype! I was expecting to be blown away, not even close.

We had a much better time there about two months ago when we walked in with no reservation and sat at the bar. We had apps and wine. The bartender was really sweet.

I know that you can't judge a place by a single experience and I'll try again but I think Dalphina probably use to be amazing and now is just a shadow of it's former self. In Delphina's defense, it's almost impossible to be as good as the hype.
author: Jeff C.

description:
For what seemed like forever I kept hearing about how great Delfina is, you've got to go there, but high expectations can often be a major let down..

Nonetheless, I definitely had to try this place. So, I tried and tried to get a reservation a decent time, and finally I randomly got  a reservation for Wednesday at 8:30.

We walked in right on time and were seated immediately. Love it. Then, they sat us in the far right corner table, only the best table in the restaurant. I know this was purely coincidental, but it was still awesome.

Service is warm and friendly, the bread they give you is from Tartine, and is soft, bready and delicious (especially with the room-temperature butter they give you). 

Our server gladly reccomended a wine in our price range that was delicious. But even better was when the server delievering our bread accidentally knocked over my glass! It wasn't that big of a deal, but the staff was so accommodating it was completely refreshing. They cleaned up our table right quick, and had another glass of wine on the way for me.

Then the food came. My BFF ordered the  Mint tagliatelle with artichokes and mascarpone ( in addition to a superior pre-pasta salad). I ordered the gnocchi with rabbit. Both dishes were absolutley fantastic. Not overly heavy, just heavenly. 

We witnessed the table next to us order the profiteroles, so we couldn't escape them, despite being somehwat-full from dinner. So glad we didn't leave without trying them. Crispy on the outside, cool and yummy on the inside, with  bittersweet chocolate sauce and almonds to boot.

It definitely is pricey, but you get what you pay for. The ambience is fantastic, as is the food and service. I can't wait to go back. It's easy to see why this place is easily in the top ten restaurants in SF.
author: Amanda D.

description:
With a group of 5 friends, I finally managed a trip to the famed delfina establishment on a busy Tuesday evening.  They squeezed us in almost immediately with no room to spare, and I walked in carrying two backpacks and two shopping bags, which the manager gracefully swept into the office for us.

Decent wine list, with moderately priced tasty bottles.  A Brunello di Montalcino for $105 in San Francisco?  A bargain!  We ended up with a Campagnole, and a Nebbiolo, both priced below $50.

We split pretty much all of the starters on the menu.  Must-haves:  The squid ink risotto, calamari, and Mozzarella and Heirloom tomato salad.  

We didn't make it to the mains, because we had such a large number of appies....  Until next time, delfina!  I'll be back for sure.
author: Dave F.

description: Absolutely delicious dinner.  We started with Speck (prosciutto) and artichoke, followed by a rocket salad.  The Uni (sea urchin) spaghetti was salty and flavorful but not overwhelming.  Waitress also recommended a great Barbera.  Not the cheapest meal, fantastic meal.
author: Aki N.

description: We loved it.  We came here as a family of 4 for my husbands birthday.  We were able to get a 5:30 reservation, 2 days out.  We arrived at 5:00 and waited on the benches outside and people watched and visited.  We were the first to be seated and the restaurant filled up quickly.   We happened to have a bottle of wine that was given to my husband earlier in the day, so that worked out great. Corkage is $18. The atmosphere was just what I was looking for a special occasion and I love the music they play, at a perfect volume.  I had the roast chicken with mushrooms and mashed potatoes - very delish! My husband and daughter thought likewise of the brisket. My youngest daughter enjoyed the pasta with wild boar ragu.  We also shared, the best brussel sprouts we'd ever had. I guess the secret ingredient was pork fat..no wonder they were so good.  The only thing I wasn't impressed by was the spaghetti, but my daughter liked it and ate it all.  I thought it was nothing special, but many people rave about it here.  We had the grilled calamari with warm bean salad, also good.  For dessert, oh my, we had the panna cotta and the warm, filled, donuts, I don't remember what they were called, but were a wonderful way to finish a memorable meal. Service was perfect.  Friendly, but professional. Not a hint of snobbery (pet peeve of mine).   Yes, it was pricey, but it was a special occasion for us, and we felt it was worth it.
author: Annie D.

description: Definitively my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Great food and service. Don't miss it.
author: Xiutico ..

description: The first time that I tried this restaurant was with my parents for dinner.  We did not have reservations but arrived early (before they opened) and were greeted by a line up of naturally beautiful servers who each individually had their own unique style and funky jewelry.  The best part of the experience was the very knowledgable waitress who knew everything on the menu, wines, etc.  The rabbit pasta dish melted in my mouth, bread was very fresh, and the artichoke soup was to die for.  Parking is a major pain, so early arrival is best.
author: Desirée S.

description: Everything is done really well. From the more detailed dishes to the pizzas. Take time to make a reservation or you will be waiting for a long time. Every dish I have had (about 20 of them---during the course of 6 months) have been excellent.
author: Alex A.

description: I don't mean to be a spoil sport but I just don't understand what all the fuss is about regarding Delfina. After moving to within walking distance I was excited to try it and was frustrated for a long time about how difficult it was to get a reservation. When I finally had dinner there I found the food mediocre. I gave it another try and had the same experience. For that price, I'll give it a miss next time.
author: Denise G.

description:
Delfina.  We have waited so patiently to dine with you.  Finally, you do not disappoint.  

The service here is great!  EVERYONE was so nice and very genuine. The food was amazing.   Me and my man decided to split one item from every course so we could get maximum variety and indulgence.  Delfina was so nice and served everything already split up for us... How many restaurants would do that if you told them you're splitting 6 plates?

Food is delectable, rich and worth the money.  It's a place you go to to treat yourself and feel well treated.  Decor is beautiful and sleek.  We are excited to go next door to their pizzeria.
author: Lorissa A.

description: NO restroom, cramped quarters, and long wait to get seated during peak times. There's a restaurant next door that's almost as good and has outdoor seating. Kind of too loud to be romantic, but it is and the service is on point.
author: Drew T.

description: We have been wanting to try Delfina for a long time, but never seems to be able to remember to make reservation in advance. Finally we did last Friday for a 9:30 dinner with our friends. I like the space and atmosphere a lot, it's a cozy space. The hostess and the waitress were very sweet and make you feel welcome immediately. I am giving a 4 star base primarily on the homemade pasta. The texture is just so good, it is more than just the Al Dente texture, it was just right, chewy but breaks easily with every bite. It was just right, and the unique texture only handmade noodle has. I had the wild boar ragu, the ragu sauce is good, but just like any good ragu, the noodle was the key. My date had the ravioli filled with prosciutto and mascarpone, again, the noodle skin was perfect, but the filling was a bit on the salty end. Of course, it's because of the prosciutto, but it could have been balanced with more of the mascapone. Another note is on the serving size, in US, we are not accustomed to order from appetizer all the way to dessert. But this might be a place where you have to, because the main dishes are in the size of an appetizer.
author: Fung S. O.

description:
An old standard that has still maintained it's quality in food. I have been going to Delfina for years since it opened to be exact and there classics are still the best in town.
Sadly though as all restaurants expand into a mini industry it has lost it's neighborhood charm. 

Grilled Calamari: Tender and perfectly grilled and seasoned with delicious white bean frisee salad.

Crab Polpette: Delicately fried crab balls unfussy and lets the crab flavor shine through partnered with a frito misto of citrus and fennel. Just beautiful with an ideal amount of seasoning.

Campo Salad: This has been my favorite salad over the years. Simple mixed greens with panchetta, walnuts and parm. Nothing is over saturated allowing the ingredients to speak for them selves.

Mint Tagliatelle: Chanterelle mushrooms with béchamel. 

Gnocchi Ragu: I love there ragus absolutely the best no matter what they make there ragus out of it is great just like their sugo.
author: Gee C.

description: The pizza is legit. Definitely reminiscent of a quality Italian thin crust with a touch of California. It's my go to for a simple margherita. The baby oregano is a nice add on.
author: n. k.

description:
So, when we go out to eat my husband goes only for the food.  If he loves the food, he loves the restaurant.  I, however, feel that once a cuisine that I was born into (Italian) begins commanding $27 dollars a plate, the overall experience better be pretty darn amazing.  

$100 per person (with wine) with ice princess service (why should we be pressured to order within 5 minutes of sitting down?) dirty plates crowding the table, food spilling down the sides of plates, two or three dishes out of 10 being stellar, the rest being something we could, and have, made at home...why would we return?  

When a restaurant starts buying its own press and thinking it's too good to be true, it usually is. SF is loaded with amazing restaurants serving amazing food for half the price (try VEGA on Cortland) with servers that actually appreciate you being there instead of treating you like an afterthought.   I suggest trying one of them before you waste your time on  Delfina.
author: andy d.

description:
I love Delfina.  Every time.  Every damned time, it reminds me of why I should have never left Rome.

The calamari is simply brilliant.  The food is flawless, service seamless and the ambience is exactly what we find in a roman trattoria.

By far one of my top restuarants in the city, if not in the US.
author: Aaron G.

description:
8/26:  fabulous again.  Can't go wrong with any of the pasta dishes.  Looking forward to my next meal here!!!
_______________________________________

9/27:  i have to downgrade this from a 4-star to a 3-star b/c the last few times i went, the dishes have been too salty.

__________________________________
another restaurant that is consistently serving great food.  the wait staff is also very friendly.  be sure to make reservations as it's always crowded.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
After wanting to try Delfina for years now, I finally got to go last night as a spontaneous hanger-oner.  I was meeting with a professor beforehand and she was meeting two friends for dinner and somehow I got lucky and got to go.  Not that that would normally matter, but they have much more SF eating experience than me and knew how to order.  

We decided to get a bunch of stuff and then all split it.  Our cuisine for the night was:

a really good salad
roasted turnips
lamb sausage

short-ribs with polenta
swordfish with escarole and beans
nettle-pasta
and hald chicken with mashed potatoes and mushrooms

All of it was really good.  I was a little dazed the whole time because of a slight cold and the fact that I had actually made it to Delfina (with really cool people to boot) when I had planned on having a night in and microwaving something from Trader Joe's.

The chicken I ordered was far and away the best chicken I have ever had.  The other stuff was good too,  but nothing could compare to this chicken.  

I thought all the appitizers were delicious too, and my advice to future eaters at Delfina is to get a bunch of them when you go.  If I had not gone with SF experienced eaters I would have not done this (being a cheap-skate grad student) and it's very worth doing.  I especially liked the turnips.
author: Biggie M.

description:
I rarely order chicken out, but I dream about the chicken at Delfina.  The spaghetti with tomatoes and chiles is fantastic...as are most pastas.

They lost a star b/c it's annoying making a reservation and I feel like a hipster eating there.
author: Scott W.

description:
Oh man. 

You know how some place have really simple ingredients and the food is still fucked up? Yeah, that is so not the case here. Everything here is about really great, simple, fresh flavors to make really elegant dishes. 

I had the chicken-mortadella, a really simple small pasta dish. The sauce was a fresh and summery lemon-chive butter sauce that didn't overwhelm the pasta and provided the perfect amount of flavors. It was a harmonious dish and it made me go all Tom Colicchio with the descriptives. 

The service was prompt and friendly and the food just looked so good, I wanted to steal bites off of the plates of the tables next to us! Clearly another trip is needed.
author: Jackie I.

description:
What more can one say for the 491st review of Delfina?

After being daunted for years by the inability to get a reservation and the crowds waiting outside, last night we took the plunge and within 15 minutes were seated at one of the two bars.  

Delfina has the *nicest* staff I think I've ever seen in any restaurant.  Sweet without being cloying.  They actually seem to be enjoying themselves there and share the joy with patrons.  

Really enjoyed my food:  green garlic soup tasted like spring; house-cured anchovies were bright and sparkling.  My wild nettle ravioli with ricotta was light, buttery, cheesy, lemony, and chewy all at the same time. 

Delfina reminded me lots of my favorite LA restaurant -- Angeli Caffe on Melrose.
author: John C.

description:
If you don't have the foresight to make reservations a month in advance, then you'll probably be shit outta luck. 

I was in no rush, so I went there really late one night with a girlfriend, put our name down, went down the street to grab a drink at a nearby bar, came back 50 minutes later and was seated at the small communal bar.

But I would go back in a heartbeat... for one reason and one reason only: their Salt Cod Mantecota (with walnut oil and fennel flatbread). I'm drooling just thinking about it. It's so good, and I'm not even a fan of fennel.
author: lily l.

description:
A San Francisco gem, this place really is as good as it gets. The food is simple and glorious, the drinks are great and the servers are the best in the city. I've been coming here for years for birthdays, celebrations and it's the perfect place to take out of town guests, who are always impressed. 

The menu changes but they have a few staples that I adore. I love the simple perfection of their spaghetti with tomato sauce and chili flakes. My all time fave is the grilled calamari over white beans. The charred calamari is still tender and the white beans are flavorful and incredible. 

I recently celebrated my two year wedding anniversary here and was delighted to receive complimentary drinks and the best service of all time! I love that the servers look all hip and cool and artsy but really know their food and wine and are extremely attentive without being overbearing. 

There is room for improvement only when it comes to the sparse dessert list. I always order the coffee ice cream profiteroles but feel that the dessert doesn't match the high quality of the rest of the menu.
author: Shira G.

description:
Can't believe I've never written a review for Delfina - I love it here! I've eaten here so many times and I've never had a bad meal. 
I absolutely adore there spaghetti. Not normally something I might order (especially because I love meatballs, and their spaghetti is classic sans meatballs) but this is really worth the carbs! So great! 
If they have steak on the menu, I almost always opt for that as it never disapoints. Cantucci (sp?) dessert is usually great - my favorite is the peanut, but they switch up the flavors a lot. If you've never tried Delfina definitely go for it!
author: r e.

description: damn you Delfina.  I want you.  I visit you at least once a week and crave your pasta daily.  last night was so joyous.  the rice pudding with pistachios were delightful and those raviolis are to die for.  happy dinner, jubilant severs ( Nick is a doll and Andrew is too accommodating) made for an almost perfect dinner.  tables are a little close-don't stare *!* please.  consistently delicious food is why this place is divine.
author: Noel J.

description: I was blown away with this place. Delfina serves spaghetti with only tomatoes as a compliment in its own sauce. I never knew how good spaghetti was, and yet it's so simple! I left wanting more! I also tried the gnocci and "Hay and Straw" dishes. Definitely try "Hay and Straw" because it's such a unique taste. The server will mix a raw egg with the noodles at your table. But I must say it was a tad too rich with all the cheese. Must go back!
author: Wendy L.

description: It would be extraordinary if the service was as good as the food.  Unfortunately our slumpy waitress was so blasé that she forgot to put in our main course order. After waiting a long time after our appetizers were cleared someone finally came over to offer up an excuse that blamed us for the mishap. Sheesh. We were offered desserts. The food arrived shortly after served by every other server but ours. The food was delicious but not a peep from our waitress on the looong wait we had to endure. We were given desserts without given a choice and while they were tasty they were not the desserts we would have chosen. If you're looking for a hip, casual, somewhat expensive trendy Italian restaurant with delicious food, this is the place but don't go for the service. Even the manager did not bother to extend her apologies after we paid the bill. Good help IS hard to find.
author: Di A.

description:
I really loved Delfina. Not just for the food, but for the atmosphere as well. I love how you can get top notch pizza and pasta in such a casual, laid back atmosphere! I went to Delfina on gay pride weekend and this was especially fun. There was just so much celebration going on outside that made the experience so much more enjoyable (especially while we were waiting for our table!) When we did get seated, we really loved the comfortable atmosphere of the place. Most places of this caliber are stuffy and not a lot of fun, but still really good (ie, Drago in LA) but this place was the opposite. We really loved our waiter, and I can't remember his name, but he was really nice and friendly. 
Now to the food: it was superb. I had the Gnocchi and honestly I cannot pick out one flaw in it. It was great. 
I would definitely return to Delfina. Maybe the area isn't as loud on normal occasions (like I said, it was gay pride weekend), but that made it so much more enjoyable. The restaurant itself was great, but the atmosphere of the city was really special, and it enhanced the experience so much.
author: Gee M.

description: Maybe my view of Delfina is skewed by my opinions of when I was younger, because I remember thinking highly of Delfina back in 2004.  It's been 6 years since I've dined here.  Great ambiance, love the neighborhood, but it's not the 5-star place I remember.
author: Marnie S.

description:
I have only consumed absolutely delicious food at Delfina.  I struggle to think of other restaurants I can say that about.

But, the squeezed together tables, noise, and challenges getting a reservation keep me from returning as often as I would like.
author: Gary B.

description: No denying that over the years this restaurant has served me some great food. But is it consistently a five-star joint? No. In fact, I think it may be the most over-rated restaurant in SF. First of all, the service. Even with reservations, I think I've waited at least 20 minutes or more for my table many more times than other restaurants of this caliber. The servers are friendly, knowledgeable but not overly efficient. The noise level doesn't allow for intimate conversation and the overall craziness of the place takes away from the fact that the food is quite good.
author: Brent H.

description: Delfina is my favorite restaurant in SF. I've been going for 10 years and its the restaurant by which I measure all others. The ambience and service is sophisticated and friendly, the food is amazing, and it is a great fine dining value. The only downside is the salt cod is no longer a permanent menu offering. Its also sometimes hard to decide between the otherworldly profiteroles on the menu, and the salted caramel ice cream across the street. I recommend saving room for both. PS - I was fascinated there were even a handful of bad reviews on Yelp and had to read them to find out why. To those unfortunate few, my advice would be to stick to your local Olive Garden.
author: Alex L.

description:
If you're looking for a fantastic Italian in vibrant Mission district, then look no further! When I say Italian, don't think basic pizza or pasta, but more sophisticated (without trying to be over the top) dishes that come from the heart of Italy. Bread from nearby Tartine makes it even better.

Besides great food and wines, the hip atmosphere is awesome and the service impeccable. Don't hesitate to pay Delfina a visit!
author: David M.

description: Delicious and big Insalata Di Campo salad.  The spaghetti and Pappardelle (pork) were both excellent.  We were seated in a corner which gave us some space from others, but had we been there earlier or a different table, it probably would have felt like we were right on top of others.
author: C B.

description: Amazing little find in the Mission. The food is locally fresh and delicious...every morsel just melts in your mouth. We had several appetizers...all very tasty.  Loved the asparagas, polenta, salad, and bread. The butter had salt in it which made my bread taste even yummier.  I love you Delphina's!  Great service, food, and fun energetic atmosphere.   You better make a reservation or you will be waiting a long time to eat.
author: Judi O.

description:
I had long heard about Delfina, but never managed to get reservations, because my wife and I like to decide where to eat a few hours before we dine, and reservations are filled up quick at Delfina.

So it just so happens that we were in the area about a half an hour before Delfina opened, and noticed a line was already starting to form out front, so we thought, what the heck, let's try and get seated at the bar. Lucky for us, we actually got one of the few two person tables in the bar area, near the kitchen where we could see them cook.

The food was excellent, they had an excellent Rose Champagne on the menu for a modest price, watching the team cook in the kitchen was captivating, as they really treat the dishes with respect, and run very smoothly.

The staff was very friendly and attentive, and the ambiance was good. I don't recall it being overly loud, as is often the case with a lot of the smaller restaurants here in SF.

I'll consider changing my rating to five stars after a few more visits, I need to see consistency, and taste more of their menu first.
author: Robert B.

description: One of my top picks when in SF - excellent, house made Italian. Make sure you have a reservation for the restaurant (as opposed to the Pizzeria) well in advance and enjoy an evening of delicious, well-made, fresh, thoughtful food.
author: A R.

description:
Hubby's Review:

My two cents...I know this one's been reviewed to death!  It's a great place to eat.  Food is flavorful and of good quality.  The wine was good although I know nothing of it other than I like to drink it.  Service was prompt and professional.  It's nice to see the owners are still involved in the day to day operation.  Given my background in the restuarant industry (a wretched and sordid affair), I admire the Stolls for their dedication and effort.  They deserved and have worked for the success they are enjoying right now.
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description:
Like this place needs more great reviews. 

God. All I f@#%ing heard about for months was this place. "So and so went to Delfina, and she loved it!" or "This one and that one said it was great" and " We went to SuppenKuchen LAST week and the week before!" and the inevitable "No I don't want another cancun burrito!" 

So finally when my girl won a 100$ gift card, we went. And man, do the rich eat well. And now after a series of promotions and pay raises at work I TOO can experience the joys of eating at Delfina once a month. I TOO can now know what a thirty dollar glass of wine tastes like. I TOO can be that guy who loved Delfina in the story that some other dudes' girl nags some other dude to the point of acquiescence about. 

Cheers Delfina. You're pretentious neighborhood location is trumped by your capacity to prepare and serve delicious cuisine. My girlfriend was so nice to me for days afterwards. I'll be back soon.
author: Farallon Living I.

description:
Dining Date: April 4, 2008
Company: Co-worker Date Night #1 w/ Chantal, Angelica, Estee, Anthony & Michele

Since I am blessed with working in such fabulous company and everyone at work has such a strong affection towards delicious food we decided it would be fitting for us to get together every few weeks and go on a date together at a fabulous restaurant. The first pick was Delfina as it is my co-worker Chantal's home away from home. When I first met her she was eating dinner at Delfina a few times a week. Her love for all things Delfina is admirable and as a nod to her we decided to make it our first stop.

By the time we all met her at Delfina, there was already wine being poured and bread being broken. It was critical that we went on any day except Monday or Tuesday as those are the only days where they don't feature fresh baked bread from neighbor Tartine. Make it a priority for your visit as the Tartine bread is truly a work of culinary art. Soft, moist centers with a crunchy crust quickly absorb and melt the butter you choose to bless it with. Paired with our Prosecco, it was a harmonious flavor explosion of yeasty, sour, buttery and sweet. You could make a whole meal out those three ingredients and I would happily do so any night of the week.

Here is what we ordered:

Antipasti & Contorni: Grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad, Salt cod mantecato with walnut oil and fennel seed flatbread, Warm Castelvetrano olives & the Sardines.

Everything was blow my mind amazing. Honestly, I could write for days about just the appetizers but I will spare all of you and just say that the Castelvetrano olives alone were so good that I felt like the universe stopped for just a moment and everything in my life was absolutely perfect. The calamari were some of the freshest I have ever tasted, the salt cod mantecato was so so salty and good that i wanted to take a bath in it and finally the sardines--oh the sardines. If you think you don't like them, please go and have them at Delfina, it will make you a believer. They are incredibly fresh and are not cured so they don't have the normal pungent fishy flavor you would expect. They are phenomenal.

Secondi: One Halibut dish, One chicken dish, One pork shoulder dish and three orders of hanger steak.

The main dishes brought with them our second bottle of  juicy wine. Silence ensued for about five minutes until everyone was ready to share thoughts and bites. Everyone was very pleased. The only thing I would have like is for my steak to have been cooked a few seconds longer. I am a fan of the perfect medium rare cut of meat but I think my steak may have been a little undercooked and was chewier than I would have liked. Other than that the fries were cooked with fresh rosemary and quite spectacular. The fish dish was delicate and very tasty but my favorite main of the night was the pork shoulder. Perfectly tender and flavorful, lucky for me this dish was seated to the right of me for easy access.

Dolci & Formaggi: Buttermilk panna cotta with caramel and kumquats & the cheese tasting plate paired with glasses of Moscato d'Asti-Sori del Re

I have to say that after the panna cotta at Incanto I was let down a little bit. The styles were pretty different as Delfina uses buttermilk for theirs so the taste is much more yogurty and opposed to light and creamy like a flan which is my preference. Even so, I appreciated the fresh approach and thought the the caramel and kumquats were very nice addition. The cheeses were all delicious and made me wish that I could enjoy a cheese plate with every one of my meals. My favorite dessert was definitely the glass of  Moscato. It was light and sweet and did not have that syrupy consistency that I dislike in so many dessert wines. It made me a total fan and now I order Moscato as often as I can.

As you can see, I still ended up writing for days about Delfina because it is not only a great restaurant but also a perfect example of of how the food movement in San Francisco has been taken to new heights. For that same reason, Delfina has a huge following and without a reservation you'll definitely be waiting for a table. I don't say this often but it is definitely worth the wait.

Note (upon request from fellow yelper Lily):  Why 4 stars and not 5 you say--well, I love my steaks and my hanger steak wasn't quite as awesome as I was expecting. I already have my next date planned and I am sure the 5th star will follow, stay tuned...
author: Sugey G.

description:
The moment we entered Delfina, we knew we're in for a good treat!  The restaurant environment was bright, "airy", and very down-to-earth.  Part of the restaurant has this long "bench-style" seats which became quite uncomfortable for the "behind" after 2 hours.  But the food made it all worthwhile.

Service was 5 stars!  Our server was pleasant, helpful, and knowledgeable.  He never rushed us, he took the time to explain the menu, made recommendations - he was just great!  I can tell he loves his job.  I think he's name is Matthew.
