description: Delfina really lives up to the hype. My dining companion swore it was the best meal she'd ever had in her life. Service is also excellent. Definitely make reservations though, as waiting in the street is never fun.
author: Nick M.

description: I've been here so many times. It's impossible to get in last minute but it's so worth the wait and well worth the reservation. Fabulous food. A little noisy though.
author: Kem K.

description: Love this place!  The food is great, fairly priced and the service is friendly, knowledgeable and really makes you feel comfortable. We keep coming back over and over because it's such a delight.  And they are open late on friday and saturday, making it possible to drop in late sometimes without a reservations.  Other times we can usually get a table in the bar without too much of a wait.  Go and go often.
author: Kaye K.

description:
I have eaten Italian food across the city, and South Bay.

This is the best italian restaurant in the bay area.

Perfect food.
Perfect service.

Nothing else to say.
author: John S.

description: 3 and a half stars.  This hurts me because I used to LOOOVE Delfina... but it seems like it has slipped a bit in the past few years.  The food was not as amazing as it used to be... some dishes were even just ok.  I do like the atmosphere though it can be a little loud.  They finally added valet parking too, a huge plus.
author: Mary S.

description: Consistently one of the best meals in the city. Top class service without being formal, incredibly fresh, seasonal ingredients, awesome wine list (with some very good bargains), good people watching. What more can I say? Last night the two standout dishes for me were the delta asparagus and the wood-oven calamari. I wish I could cook this well. My only lament is gone are the days when the restaurant was a well kept  Mission secret. We used to be able to call up and say we lived in the neighborhood and get primo reservations. Oh well, at least everything else has stayed the same.
author: Reality Check S.

description:
I may need an intervention. A 30-day gift certificate to Promises. I admit, I have a problem. My name is Haley, and I am a pre-dining order crafter.

You who share this same disorder may well know but may refuse to admit what this sad addiction entails. The second one pre-dining order crafter clicks "reserve" on open table (and sometimes even before) he or she rushes to the restuarant's web site to hit the bottle. You do not pass go, you don't collect $200, you will spare no one in your path until you reach it - the dinner menu. A heavenly glow shines down from your internet browser to light your way as you peruse the items of your potential feast. You methodically determine what appetizers your group will share and what meal you will coax each diner in your party to order, so you and you alone will eat the perfect dinner. Pre-crafting seems foolproof only until you reach said dining establishment to find their online menu hasn't been updated since the opening and there is a selection of new items for you to feast your eyes and belly upon. But don't fret! If said menu is Delfina's you're in for a treat, either way.

However, I must say Delfina was not an easy craft. The menu seemed short and somewhat lacking. I couldnt determine an entree that I had my heart set on. I placed my order like i place my bets, eyes closed, the waitress/dealer staring impatiently, until one perfect culinary selection/monetary value comes to me DING DING DING.

The sausage appetizer was good not great. The mushroom salad was delightful. The home-made pasta (oxtail capeletti and duck taglietelle) was unbeatable and the sauces melted in your mouth. The sage butter sauce on the capeletti was the perfect lubricant for me to stuff those tasty flavor bombs down my throat. The bread gets points for the salt-topped-butter that reminded me of my Salt House experience.  

Instead of silencing my sweet tooth with dessert, we went 
back and tried what we'd been eyeing nearby all along, the rosemary fries, and hail (rose)Mary they were perfect. I'm already itching to go back. Not to mention I've already pre-crafted my order for Pizzaria Delfina next door.
author: Haley M.

description: i totally dig the place.  i dont live within 500 miles but i constantly send people here.  its a good mix in spot....always a packed house, upper range of good food, fun fun vibe.  drinks flow, service makes sure of that.....not a top 20 place as far as food, but a top place that will make a group of friends or a date night happy.  i dont go here enough.
author: Dustin S.

description: I keep going back to this place, their pizza is addicting.  In fact, I think imma have dinner there tonight!
author: anna p.

description: Call weeks in advance to dine on fine food that leaves you satiated.  Duck, being the heavy meat that it is, was cooked delicately in a pomegranate sauce.  The petrale sole was perfect - melting gently in your mouth.  Clean, sophisticated, fine-dining food.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
this place doesn't need any more reviews.  last night was my first visit.  three things stood out for me:

1. the server was incredibly helpful, knowledgeable, attentive, and stylish.  couldn't ask for anything more.

2. the green olives are off the hook amazing and i've never had those olives before, with that sweet olive oil taste - the salted butter with the bread equally awesome.

3. the jewish style artichoke starter was a new experience and delicious, original, and interesting.

yes, its crowded.  yes, its a small space.  yes, its san francisco.  make a reservation if you have to, or go at an off time or on an off night.  (or know someone who knows someone)  best meal i've had in my 8 nights in SF.  not too casual, not too fancy.  great attention to detail and real quality food.  loved it.

: )
author: Brent F.

description: Best pasta I have ever had. I got the spaghetti, it had a tomato sauce with basil and other herbs. The noodles were cooked perfectly and melted in your mouth. The portion was just right.
author: Melissa S.

description: I love Delfina. I find that the food is always balanced in flavor. The only thing that lack is the service, which is very good, but not that professional, example, I saw a server merry two bottles of wine, while facing the dinning room and chatting it up with the bartender.
author: johnny s.

description: Delfina's is worth the wait. I went with a group of foodies and we ordered a little bit of everything. It's really the best way to sample all the dishes. We were very, very happy with just about everything. The decor is simple, the restaurant small and tightly packed. Everyone was dressed casually, the atmosphere was lively. Our server was incredibly knowledgeable and prompt. We ordered 4 apps, 2 pasta starters, and 4 meat entrees. The stretched mozzarella was so delicate and smooth. The pasta was al dente and perfectly balanced with mint and artichokes. Even the lamb spaghetti was rich but not overly so. I had the braised oxtail and everyone agreed it was the best entree - full of flavor, rich, and tender. We even had 4 desserts and loved the strawberries with basil. So good. Buono appetito!
author: TaDao V.

description:
Good food or not, what's the point in having a reservation at this place? 
This place is all hype! My husband and I reserved a table for two to celebrate our anniversary. We were seated at a very cold steel table under a window in a row of tables. My husband let me sit inside and he unfortunately was forced to sit under a wall phone. This, placed strategically at the rear of my husband's seat, it turns out was the hostess desk. We had to speak to each other between rings and through the voices of all of the staff who congregated there. At one point a hostess reached over and fumbled with some light switches directly behind my wine glass, moving it over to the side, too! We stayed because it took us an hour to park the car and I did not know the area well enough to venture out and find another restaurant. Our streetclothed waitress was knowledgeable but rushed and often flagged down. When my meal arrived it was pepperflaked all over and I am allergic. Needless to say it did not mention spicy on the menu. Of course in sending it back my husband's food got cold and I waited foreeeever for the replacement, with no apologies. My husbands ribollita was not. The chef needs to take a trip back to cooking school if he's going to attempt authentic Tuscan food, Which by the way we have. Just because their namesake in Italy serves ribollita this way doesn't change the fact the it is not true ribollita. Delfina in Italy modified the recipe for the locals who knew better. When I see a true deal on the menu that's what I expect or call it something else, DUH! The ribollita is a definite soup when all is said and done and my husband said it tasted like a browned salty vegetable cake. For the one star..The salmon was very good. So much for the food. I would not go back. I'd rather spend the same money at a REAL Italian restaurant and get table clothed privacy to boot!
author: rosanna m.

description:
I think Delfina could have potential for most people.. everyone I was with enjoyed their meals.. however, as a vegetarian or vegan you have literally no options. It's actually rare to find a place in the city that has so little to offer a vegetarian/vegan, especially in the mission. For appetizer I ended up with a plain salad. As in the white/inside of lettuce, not leafs, and olive oil with lemon. It had a beautiful appearance, but not the salad taste I would have liked. Also on the menu as a vegan option were fries- thankfully they were delicious, or I would have gone hungry.
The polenta cannot be done vegan, nor can the risotto.. so I had the pasta. The pasta was freshly made, obvious at first bite and cooked perfectly al dente. 
Yes, it was good.. and it's a cute little place, but pricey for what you got, how limited a veg. is on options, and how impossible it is to get reservations there! Glad I tried it, but over-rated.
author: Megan C.

description: Just so you all know.. I am talking about the Pizzeria....WARM OLIVES!!!  order them... enjoy them... don't forget...  WARM OLIVES!!  The pizza is thin crust and quite enjoyable.  I always have a glass of wine with my meal whenever I go and even though the wait can be rather extensive (bring a warm coat) it is really a fun place to go with a small group of friends (do not go if you have ALOT of people).  They also do take out so you can order to go which is nice to know!  The waitresses are really friendly and I like how you sign your own name up on a chalk (not dry erase) board in order to wait for a table.  Sitting at a table is nice but sitting at the Bar can be fun too because you can see into the kitchen.    Head over before you get hungry so by the time your order comes through you are the perfect level of hungry!
author: Kylie L.

description:
Delfina... delfina... where do I start... 

Having looked forward to this reservation for weeks I had no intention of ordering a reasonable amount of food. My eyes are always bigger then my stomach and I gave them the authority to totally take over. We started off with the bread from Tartine that needs to be specially requested. I was close to passing on the bread in an attempt to save precious room for other dishes... this would have been a big mistake. It is crucial that you order the bread; if you have been to Tartine you should understand that this is no ordinary bread. To accompany this so called bread, we had the grilled calamari; hands down my favorite dish of the night and the best calamari I've ever had - big statement, I know, but I am 100% confident in this. I felt the same way about the spaghetti, it totally revolutionized the way I feel about this once boring dish. Whether it is simplicity at its best or if the tomato plum sauce has some sort of secret ingredient that makes it the king of all spaghettis (msg perhaps?)... the outside world may never know. In addition to the spaghetti and calamari, we ordered the sea bass, chard, and olive oil mashed potatoes. The sea bass was the only dish I was slightly disappointed with... I loved the sauce and the way they prepared it, however I got a bad piece of fish and a good section of it was gray and tasted off, very disappointing. Last but not least, we had the profiteroles with espresso gelato. So rich, both sweet and bitter, and so difficult to eat after having already stuffed my face the way I did but too good to leave a morsel behind. 
I had to shimmy my newly fat ass between the jam packed tables to get out the door and I plan to be shimmying it back in as soon as possible. 

P.s. All of this was for the bargain price of $100. Fine dining at a reasonable price; doesn't get better then that.
author: Taylor E.

description: I didn't like Delfina as much as I thought I would. It was a bit too cramped/crowded/loud for me. The service was great. The food was good, but nothing super special. The hangar steak was very good, but did have an awful lot of sauce on it. The duck had about three forkfuls of meat on it, and it was nearly impossible to get it off the bone. Some of the food was too salty. Overall it was a good meal, but just didn't live up to my high expectations. If I go back, it will be for pasta, and that's it. I am looking forward to trying the pizzeria, though.
author: Monika M.

description: Love love love the spaghetti.  If you are alone, go sit at the bar.  The staff is fantastic and everything tastes good.  The wine list is amazing.  The lighting is perfect.  And the prices are very reasonable.
author: Amme P.

description: Crowded little place that is IMPOSSIBLE to park anywhere close to.. However, the service is friendly.  The food is good.  I had a bib lettuce salad and my date had their version of a Caesar.  Both were good, though the main theme throughout all of the dishes (and even the butter) was a bit too much salt.  I had the steak for dinner, which I thought was very good and my date had the scallops, which she said was good, but nothing special.  We had a side dish of spaghetti and coming from an East Coast Italian guy, I would say it's probably the best pasta I've had on the West Coast in 6 years.
author: Michael P.

description: I finally went here last week when my 'rents were in town, and we were mighty pleased.  Great service, amazing soup and pasta, and fun environment.  One thing that was kinda crazy: There were 2 items on our bill that were wonky.  The prices didn't jive with the menu prices.  Luckily my dinner companion, a.k.a Veronica Mars, noticed the discrepancies and pointed them out to our server.  Kinda bizarro.  Also, as much as I loved my spaghetti (which I did-frankly it was amazing), I was really disappointed in the lack of vegetarian options.  This is San Francisco, people!  If the menu had been more vegetarian friendly, I would have dished out the 5th star.  Alas . . .
author: Lacy T.

description:
scene from the movie, manhattan: 
party guest: I finally had an orgasm, and my doctor said it was the wrong kind. 
isaac davis: You had the wrong kind? I've never had the wrong kind, ever. My worst one was right on the money. 
that's how i feel about delfina.  i had one little side dish that didn't quite meet up to the delfina standards but it was still amazing.
the worst moment i had - was right on the money (and orgasmic, of course)
author: Mary C.

description:
It's insane how good this place is, and how busy it always is...

everything was fabulous but I'm in love with the sweetbreads. it's not easy to make a good sweetbread dish but this was perfection. I cleaned my plate, literally, with the help of a nice chunk of tartine bread...and bless the staff, no one tried to take the plate away from me before I was done.
author: Gina S.

description: The food here is great, to me not terribly authentic Italian (Oliveto, Incanto, A16 do a way better job at that), maybe Italian with a bit of a Cali twist, but terrible acoustics and can get cramped. They once seated 5 of us at a very small table with very little elbow room to spare and we had reservations a few weeks in advance (it was my birthday dinner to top it off). Menu selection can sometimes be limited depending on your mood. Add to the fact that parking is a bit heinous around this area, I won't be returning for a bit.
author: Ken K.

description:
This is based on my 2nd experience in Delfina..

For appertizer, the two of us shared their amaizng grilled calamari.. I was very happy that it still tastes good like last time! =).. definitely a must try at delfina.. alot better than their sardine!

I was looking forward to eating the hand & straw pasta.. I had it when I first tried this restaurant and it was amazing!! However, they don't have it right now :(..

So I ordered their rosemary tagliatelle, which was recommended by our server..  well, it was ok.. nothing special i should say.. quite disappointed right here.. why can't they continuously have the hand& straw, like the roasted chicken :(

We also tried their roasted liberty duck, wasnt impressed.. it was so hard tgo cut through the meat and we could hardly taste the sauce.. even with the extra that they gave us.. the roasted cherries helped though

For the dessert, we had their chocolate budino, and it was good.. but not heavenly or anything..

a-OK this time..
author: Cherish S.

description:
* I'm a wordy reviewer --- apologies in advance *
Last night was Roomie's bday dinner at Delfina.
I'll start with the positives:
Cherry.  Bellini.  Sweet Mother Mary those things are tasty.
Sauvignon Blanc --- two bottles was it?  Mmmm.
The food.  There were five of us which is wicked perfect for sharing tons of things on the menu.
We started with the very last order of the Fried Squash Blossoms, stuffed with ricotta and basil.  Cheesy, salty, sweet and deep fried.  How all vegetables should be served.  The batter was super light and really let the delicacy of the squash blossoms come through, while adding the perfect amount of crunch.
We shared several dishes after that:
The Linguine with Petrale Sole --- salty and tomatoey and soley.  It was tasty stuff.
Chicken & Pancetta Ravioli with black summer truffles --- DELISH.  The flavor was fantastic though I found the texture of the filling to be a bit gritty.  This dish was a hit overall.
Grilled Hawaiian Ahi --- cooked to perfection, seared on the outside and raw in the middle.  The spring onions added a great compliment to the ahi with salsa verde.  The farro was a nice change of starch and was cooked perfectly --- just a touch al dente. 
Roasted Fulton Valley Chicken --- Wow.  The chicken was perfectly seasoned and the sauce was divine.  The chicken was moist and succulent and perfect.  The mashed Yukon golds were average, but when combined with the sauce on the chicken plate, I couldn't stop eating them.
Finally we shared the Niman Ranch Flatiron Steak.  Again, perfectly cooked at medium rare, the sauce was perfect, and the fries --- while not as golden brown and crispy as I like, were awesomely seasoned with salt and rosemary.  This one was gone as soon as they set it down.  I was lucky to get any seeing as it was on the other end of the table.
For dessert we may have forced the Bittersweet Scharffen Berger Chocolate Cake down the birthday girl's throat, but don't feel too bad as I helped her by eating almost half of it myself.  Holy lord --- it came out HOT (and I mean like, I burned my mouth on it hot) surrounded by a little moat of crme Anglaise.  All that was missing was the lava center that I adore so much in those "molten chocolate cake" thingies.
The negatives:
The tables ARE very close together.  And the bar type seating in the center is sort of odd since it seemed like the people there were passing judgement on our cackles and shrieks, ready to pound their gavels at any second if someone said something off color.  They're practically on top of your head and they look directly down on to you.  Not so bad when the restaurant was busy and every seat was taken and it was loud.  Not so good when we were among the last people there, and the one lone guy was sitting right above my head laughing at our jokes that he couldn't help but hear.  Creepy.
Our waitress.  Wow.  I wish I had better things to say, and alas, her tip did NOT reflect her suckitude in the least since so many of us are ex service industry folk who tend to overtip.  We were seated at 8.  She took our drink orders at 8:30 and dropped them off shortly thereafter.  We didn't see her again to order appetizers until 9.  Half an hour between visits?  She wasn't even anywhere to be seen on the floor for us to grab her for drink refills or to place orders.   She and the other server were GREAT about bringing us all small plates since they knew we were sharing all the entrees, but the attitude overall sucked.  The icing on the birthday girl's yummy chocolatey cake was when we jokingly asked if she was going to sing and her response was, "This isn't Bennigan's.  This is Delfina."  Indeed.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I recently revisited this place 5 years after the first time I came here.

Not much has changed. And that's a good thing. I was satisfied then and I am satisfied now. The fish is still amazing just as before. I had the sole with dried tomatoes and olives, shared the octopus, mussels, and chickpea appetizer with a friend, and snagged my own dessert which consisted of cream puffs with some jam and pastry cream. I also snagged bites of my friends' desserts. (of course) I'm a sucker for chocolate, so the molten chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream is always a winner...unless you really suck at making desserts.

The only ridiculous thing is how hard it is to get a reservation. I mean, 5 years ago, it wasn't this difficult. But I guess for the excellent service and good food, it's no surprize. And after a couple of bottles of wine, it's all good.
author: bloopie s.

description:
after hearing so much about this place, we finally got to get a taste and i must say that i was underwhelmed.  let's start off w/ what i didn't like.  my entree was the rosemary tagliatelle with guinea hen ragu and vin santo and overall it was decent.  the rosemary was definitely evident in the dish but the flavors were all too over the place and the dish lacked focus and nothing was given a chance to shine.  a dash of fresh ground pepper helped the dish a bit.  the wife had the rigatoncini alla norma with bellwether ricotta which was nothing more than over-glorified penne pasta.  our friends had the tagliatelle that i had gotten and the fulton valley range chicken.  the chicken from the sounds of it was just alright.

so on to the good.  the grilled calamari appetizer w/ white bean salad was outstanding.  i really wish i had more of this as it was totally flavorful and everything i want in a calamari dish!  the wine that we got, lagrein "steinraffler" 2003, was awesome.  our waitress was very nice and quite knowledgeable about the wine menu, though our first impression of her is that she had no clue about the wine list.  she did quite a sell job on some of the dishes and was overall very attentive to us.

would i go back?  yeah, cuz there is enough of other intriguing things on the menu to warrant another trip but not any time soon.
author: Swarup B.

description:
this place is amazing!!!  we went here a while back so i cannot recall everything we ordered- but i do remember that with every bite we kept looking at each other going 'oh my god this is good!'.  the menu changes frequently so what we had is likely not on it anymore- but i am sure that what they have now is just as good.

our server- janine- was really good.  she was knowledgeable and genuine (unlike some servers who seem to be acting like they care about your questions/concerns or even their job!).  she really made the experience even better.

the space is classy and homey at the same time.  we had a corner table in the back so we could see the entire restaurant.  we did have to wait about 10 minutes for our reservation and there really isn't much space to wait inside when the place is packed and/or it's cold outside.  but 10 minutes is not so bad.  i prefer to be sat immediately- especially when we made the reservation a month in advance (which is what you have to do to get it on a friday night).  if i could give half stars maybe i would give them 4 1/2.  but the food is so good that i think 5 is really more accurate.

i definitely would go back here in a heartbeat.  the only thing is we don't typically arrange our dinner reservations a month in advance :(  the sister pizzeria next door is supposed to be great as well- a lot more low key and mainly pizza on the menu- and they take walk ins.  but i am not the biggest pizza person- so the restaurant is where it's at for me.
author: Harmony R.

description: I have heard the hype about this place for a while and decided to give it a try this past Friday. I had an awesome experience. The waiter was excellent, the menu was creative, and the food tasted darn good.
author: Howie M.

description: Never disappointed! My first choice out in SF every-time!  Not pretentious at all, great quality, creative, yet simple and fresh food.  Wine is unique italian choices that don't kill your budget.  Its all perfect.
author: Leslie M.

description:
The waiting staff at Delfina has poor hygiene. They smell like rotten pabst and sweat.

I date you to put that on a t-shirt.
author: Carlos C.

description: Come here and eat: Grilled fresh calamari, Spaghetti (seriously, even though it's just spaghetti), Pork Sugo with Pappardelle (EAT THIS FOR REALZ), black pepper panna cotta.  Awesome.  That's all.
author: M L.

description:
I went here expecting A LOT considering it's always hailed as one of the best eats in town.  I was surprisingly unimpressed with the food quality, presentation, and creativity.  
They were out of 3 of the 4 things that I wanted to eat which was a bummer.  I ended up with their butternut squash soup, which was quite tasty, although heavy on the cream.  I also had their roasted chicken which was pretty blah...it didn't come with vegetables or anything, just a big dollop of whipped mashed potatoes on the side (which tasted fake...and believe me, I'm a freaking mashed potato connoisseur).
The Scharffenberger Chocolate Cake was rich & yummy though - as was the Wild Mint tea, which is one of the best mint tea's I've ever had.
I went with 5 girlfriends and it was super crowded and noisy.  The space itself is really gorgeous and simple.  The chairs were uncomfortable though.
I will likely give this place another shot, maybe with a smaller group and on a less crowded night.
author: Stephanie W.

description: This is my go-to place for special occasions.  Birthday, Delfina.  Anniversary, Delfina.  Saturday, Delfina.  I love everything on the menu, but most of all the scharfenberger chocolate dessert with a gooey center.  Nothing beats that stream of chocolate running out of the cake when you slice your fork through it.  I wouldn't be surprised if the name 'Delfina' was the new 'Jennifer' around San Franciscan elementary schools in a few years.
author: Rob U.

description: Yummy food. Great staff. Great desserts ---- not nearly enough dinner options for vegetarians, but still an enjoyable restaurant.
author: n s.

description:
Delfina obviously does not need another review, but I want to write one anyway!  The first time I came here was about a year and a half ago, and only got one course.  I remember it was really great, but I'm glad I got the chance to come here for a second time and really see what all the fuss is about.
First, our server was great.  She was attentive, but not annoying, and had the perfect answer for everthing.  There were four of us and we decided to get a bunch of dishes and share everything.  For salads we got the grilled calamari and some other salad with shaved parmesan on top.  It was a toss up on which was better that round.  For the first course we got three pasta dishes:  short-rib dumplings, mint tagliatelle, and another pasta with shrimp.  Again, all were fantastic, but I really enjoyed the unique taste of the mint one.  I would totally eat that for an entree any day.  Speaking of entrees, we ordered the sole, chicken, quail, and pork shoulder.  The sole was the weakling, still good, but it was in an "aqua pazza" broth and it was too much liquid for us.  I never thought the chicken would be my favorite, but it was the most delicious chicken I've ever tasted!!  Really moist, the juice was delicious, and the skin was hard to resist!  For dessert we got the chocolate profiteroles and we wanted the Scharffenberger chocolate cake but they were unfortunately all out.  Instead, they brought us (on the house, might I add!) this really amazing pumpkin squash tart with sage gelato, as well as a dish of vanilla gelato topped with...get this...olive oil and sea salt! Who knew it was a winning combination?!  All in all it was one of the best meals I've ever had in SF :)
author: Michelle L.

description: Best polenta ever. Dreamy spaghetti. Great service.
author: Crank Y.

description: Loved this place for the atmosphere for the food, for staying late.  Will be back again and again.
author: Dima B.

description:
Been slacking on my reviews, my sorry (kinda like my bad)...

Called a good two weeks in advance after previous attempts at not being able to score a seat at Delfina on a weekend night. So two weeks should be plenty of time for a week night and I can pick any time I want.

5:30 or 9:30? Well there goes that plan!

Got a 9:30 reservation which is a good time to chow down.

Parking is a bear down in this neck of the Mission or is it the Castro? Really nice area. Ended up taking public transpo. If you do drive park at a lot at Valencia and 18th, $8 and they close at 11 pm, which sucks but not to bad!

Place was packed and very happening. Promptly seated at a very cool table with a metal top and wooden backed benches. The wait staff was seemingly all beautiful women. More than often I was caught looking and not paying attention to the people I came with, thankfully that list did not include my SO.

Menu is small and simple and is not what I would call Italian. Place sounds Italian and has a few dishes that are Italian, like pasta. Guess you would classify this joint as California New Modern Italian or some bs.

Basic fact: Food here is very good, well cooked and presented in a great manner. Recommend a starter salad, small but filling and the flat iron steak with fries. A dish you would find more at a French Bistro.

Service was A+, water was always being filled and the wine recommendation was SPOT on for the dishes we had. Great bottle of red, forgot the name already!

The bread is what I would come back for! Hot and served right away. The lighter bread is made there and the darker crust is made down the street at Tartane (spelling?).

Would recommend sitting inside, as the outside is more a covered patio and not all that great.

Next time I will come and sample the pizza next door.
author: David B.

description: The best experience ever...comfy, casual fabulous food, mission atmosphere upgraded but not stuffy, anything is a sure thing at this fine restaurant that is a SF staple...LOVED IT especially the pork chop that is on the menu all to rarely!!!
author: Carol L.

description: One of my favorite restaurants. Even their 'standby' menu items are thoughtfully prepared - don't miss the ribollita.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
really?  do i really need to add another review?  oh YES, yes i do.

the dining experience at delfina this evening with mom was fantastic.  i quickly got over the early 5:30p reservation and left feeling buoyant and delighted.  our waitress was attentive, smiling, and ready (even excited!) with recommendations and advice.  she also seemed really happy to help us taste and discover which wines we'd like the best.

food-wise . . . the bread was good and the butter with salt was, well, mom said she could just eat the butter on its own.  we shared the insalata di campo, a divine combination of radicchio, frisee, and arugula with walnuts, pancetta, parmigiano, and balsamic vinaigrette.  mom enjoyed the fulton valley chicken with king trumpet mushrooms and olive oil mashed potatoes (YUM).  i loved the mint tagliatelle with chanterelles and creme fraiche.  the homemade pasta was delicate yet hearty enough for the sauce, and the portion perfect.

and then there was dessert.  i don't usually order dessert because i'm not a sweets person, but i couldn't resist the warm tcho chocolate torta with olive oil gelato and maldon sea salt.  and i am so glad i ordered it.  phenomenal.  amazing.  sublime.

i may regret living so close to this restaurant . . . and can't wait to return!
author: Pam M.

description: Was thrilled to get a last minute reservation for a sunday night but the food did not impress I am afraid.  Starters brussels sprouts with honey and hazelnuts were fabulous and the sunchokes, my new favorite tubers were still slightly raw in the middle.  Slanted Door just proved the only proper way to cook these special Jerusalem artichokes is to bake or broil them and they were peeled and shaped into  potatoe-like nuggets! (I was aghast) seriously.  Duck was too salty and pasta with nettles was more like a carbonara and I think missing alot of the described ingredients on the menu.  Dessert, the citrus panna cotta was unexpectedly good.  Mix of mature crowd that night.  Still prefer my pizza place next door.
author: Patty J.

description: We ate at Delfina this past weekend after waiting 3 weeks to get our Saturday evening reservation. Let me tell you, it was well worth the wait!!! This was some of the best Italian in the city, and it wasn't extravagantly priced. All of their dishes were really creative and we loved the different spin they put on Italian food. For wine we started with an Italian pinot noir type grape that we thought was fabulous. I forget which ones we had but they were available by the glass and they were exactly what wine should be like, not overly fruity but very complex & tasty. For first courses we had a fresh porcini salad that was unbelievably fresh. The wood roasting taste was a little strong but so different for a salad I thought it was great. We also tried the gnocchi with ragu and both components were absolutely amazing. Gnocchi was so tender and cooked perfectly, and the ragu sauce had so much flavor. For entrees we tried the salmon, which probably was some of the best I've had. It was cooked in a grape leaf with corn on top and the moisture, flavor, and color were perfect. Very well done!! We also had the roast chicken with potato mash,  one of the best 19$ meals in SF!! So moist and it was bursting with flavor. We had a dessert, I actually forget which one and it was only average, but we had very high expectations by this point. The restaurant is fairly small so now I understand why it is so difficult to get a reservation, but it is definitely worth the effort. The service was great as well, we will surely be coming back to Delfina!!!!  Really the only negative is the parking situation, it's impossible so going to have to cab it.
author: Kate N.

description:
Two distinct memories from my dinner on Feb 22, 2009 at Delfina:

~The food was so outrageously good that I closed my eyes through most bites so that I could concentrate fully on our meal.  
~Throughout dinner I repeatedly told my husband that the only thing bad about this experience was that I wouldn't be able to give it six stars on Yelp.

The food blew my mind.  So did our server's fabulous mustache.  Outta sight!
author: C H.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  It feels like we have waited years to get a reservation here.  Seriously.  We have called multiple times over the past few years and have never been able to get in on a couple of weeks notice.  So with the economy being what it is, I thought I would give it a try for my husband's birthday.  We were so elated to score a 6:30 PM reservation on a Tuesday night!

There was nothing truly bad about our meal but I expected so much more.  I would give it 3.5 stars if I could.  We had a salt cod brandade app with fennel-sprinkled flatbread.  This was actually very tasty.  Though I wouldn't recommend it on a date as the flatbread is crispy, crunchy...messy.  Our two mains - a panzotti (ravioli) with a filling of greens and a light walnut cream sauce, and (skirt?) steak with fries ranged from okay to very good.  

The sauce with the steak was pretty salty and the meat had a strange gaminess to it.  The quality wasn't what I would expect from a restaurant of this reputation.  The panzotti was much better, but also a bit on the salty side.  We also had a side of polenta, which was super disappointing.  It actually had very little salt, was somewhat bland and had semi-coagulated Talegio cheese on top.  This was probably the most disappointing in both flavor and texture.  Oddly enough, the salt cod seemed to be the only dish that got the salt just right.

The service was fine, but unremarkable.  It didn't compare to the amazing service we had at Nopa a few weeks ago where every single person oozed attentiveness and warmth.

The people at the table next to us really seemed to enjoy their pastas...maybe that's what we need to try next time.  Although honestly, I am not sure we are that motivated to give it a second chance with all the other fantastic SF eateries.  Sigh....
author: Mona P.

description: Ok pizza, good design concept...really too tight a space to sit in for any length of time. Not worth a second try!
author: s c.

description: This restaurant was good but not great. Ordered a Bardolino glass of red wine which was great! Portions overall were small. We had the grilled calamari appetizer which was just alright. My boyfriend ordered the pork sugo parpardelle which was awesome!!! Great sweet flavor although not much meat in he dish. I ordered the tagliatelle with mint and mushrooms which was just ok. For desert we had the chocolate budino which was vey nice! Should have maybe ordered the spaghetti which people have raved about...
author: Karina M.

description: wow, i had the BEST SPAGHETTI at delfina. it was amazing. simple and fresh ingredients. you could taste hints of lemon, red pepper, garlic and basil after each bite. i can't wait to go back and eat it again!! the PANNA COTTA was also delicious. full review & photos - http://bit.ly/nnnH1L
author: Shalina P.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!  This has become a bi-monthly tradition for my boyfriend and I.  We've been here on two occasions through two menu changes and we've been awed and satisfied both times.  The service is very friendly and quick, the food is always unique with rich flavors and everything is presented impeccably.  The only downside I can think of is the wait.  Though I only go on weekends, there is always a 30-45 minute wait.  But I assure you, it's well worth it.
author: An N.

description: Close your eyes, point to the menu and pick your entrée. You can't miss. Delfina does it right. From the table bread to dessert, Delfina is the perfect dinning experience. This restaurant is on its way to becoming a San Francisco staple.
author: Caleb A.

description: This place is amazing, and an amazing deal for the price... which is probably why it is so hard to get a reservation here. It seems like almost every time we call they say they can only take us at 4pm or 10pm... but maybe *we* are the problem since we can never seem to plan ahead. The food is really fantastic, and the service and wine selection are great.
author: Alex J.

description: As my boyfriend's dad put it last night, "God, I hate this place.  They deliver every damn time."  I had the Mixed Grill (Quail, Chicken Liver, Wild Boar w/ grilled polenta) last night, my bf had the pork belly w/ octopus and cockles and his dad had the steak w/ frites.  It was ALL amazing, the food served at just the perfect time and we brought our own wine.  Delicious!
author: Freckles D.

description: Came here with my sister when she visited and as I expected everything was quite tasty. Everything tasted authentic and very well put together. The funny thing is my sister and her boyfriend did not like it but I also expected that. They don't eat out at fine restaurants and their idea of good Italian food is the Olive Garden..... ;-)
author: Rolo A.

description: Food was alright, nothing to rave over.  Did I order the wrong thing?  Of course the day after I am perplexed on *just* why I had to wait 30 days for a reservation.  I hope I am missing somethingI
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
If you are heading to Delfina's in San Francisco's Mission District, do not confuse it with the Delfina's Pizzeria next door, which we did not try but hear is also amazing. We visited at night and sat at a corner table with a perfect view of the open kitchen. The waitress was helpful and knowledgeable with the menu and wine selection. After deciding on our poison of choice we started with the grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad cooked to perfection. 
The lighting here is dim and romantic, many couples surrounded us in the tight seating venue, not uncomfortably tight though. 
If you take another look around you will almost find everyone is eating the house favorite, spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini, which my friend had. I went for the al dente chicken tortellini, which was heavenly divine. Portions are just right leaving some room for desert but though tempted we worked on what was left of our wine. I would without doubt revisit this fine Italian venue when in town, "That's Amore."
author: Yeleny S.

description: I've been to Delfina over 5 times in the past 10 years that I've lived in this great city and they still hold the key to running a great unpretentious italian restaurant. The food has never disappointed as with a simple spaghetti marinara or squid ink risotto to pork sugo and polenta. The look, layout, and staff have always been fun and inviting. My biggest disappointment is that I can't get a friggin table there cause it's always packed. Love Delfina, Love Italian, Love SF, Hate not getting what I want!
author: illy P.

description: i think my expectations were too high. the wine was good. the chard was excellent. the other dishes were forgetful.
author: Rosalee R.

description: Simple is remarkably hard to pull off, especially since the essential part of simplicity is making it seem effortless.  I've slowly watched delfina stutter-step, falter, and finally become a dottering old fool, reminscing of great ald times while doing an increasingly sloppy and belabored job doing all the things that it had done so right and so easily in days past.  Do restaurants age like people, or is it just the complacency of the people working there?  I don't know, but SF's must go to italian neighborhood joint just joined the cemetary of restaurants nevermore to be visited again.
author: snoopy s.

description:
reservations 3 months in advance? are you kidding me?? yeah right. i was shocked when i called to make one for friday night.

however, the woman who answered so graciously suggested to come when they open and eat at the bar, which really means you can eat at what seemed like 1 of 3 tables. this was just great!

so we got the sauteed calamari, served with white beans, olives and the entire squid - very good, but only 4 squid  - get it anyway!

also the darker bread they served was excellent

for entrees got the special of day which was a artichoke pasta, very delicate in flavor, and i recommend it

also got the petrale sole pasta which was horrendously, not that bad, but overly salted, enough to make your tongue hurt after one bite. sent that ish back and got the walnut sauce ravioli dish thing which was just right

for desert got the chocolate torta with olive oil ice cream. very very rich, like bill gates only in chocolate.  would have been nice if ice cream was doubled. 

prompt and considerate service.

i liked the large bottle of water they let you refill your cups with, it reminds me of something posh. 

and the bathroom water provides boiling hot water to wash your hands. i like that :)
author: Porkers T.

description: Delfina made a weekend spent doing Taxes almost bearable! FH and I and I met a dear friend and her date here for dinner. They were headed to a show after dinner so we made it there right at 5:40pm for dinner. It was not too crowded, easy to maneuver in the restaurant and we got super lucky and managed to park right in front ! Had the calamari, butter nut squash tortellini and braised short ribs. The food was great, wine and beer selection good, and service was excellent. Our waiter was super cute and super attentive, over all a great night out. A little pricey for rustic Italian food but nice modern ambiance and laid back atmosphere make it a fun place for a couple date since it wasn't too loud to hear ourselves converse. Also, try the nettle soup - a shade of green I have yet to see in nature!
author: Rosy H.

description: Delfina makes me feel like a grown up. The man who gets my heart will take me there weekly. Yummy roasted chicken.
author: Kezia P.

description:
Oh. My. Gawwwwh.  

I have absolutely NOTHING bad to say about this place!  After having gone to Pizzeria Delfina, I had high expectations, but Delfina went above and beyond.  I came here for my birthday on Saturday and it was packed.  We called ahead to make reservations (on the off chance that they'd have a cancellation on the day-of) but of course they were full til 10pm.  Instead we opted to come down and put our name in.  Had a glass of wine in the bar-area and didn't wait more than 20 min for a great table.  

We split a bottle of chianti (DELICIOUS) and started with the calamari and white beans.  I'm not a calamari fan but my partner raved about it.  I tried the white beans and they were fantastic.  A delicious plate of crusty breads was brought to the table w/ some authentic olive oil for dipping.  Our server (I think his name was Adam) was INCREDIBLY attentive, funny and knowledgeable.  Although all of his tables were full and he was running around like crazy, he never let the hectic pace show.  I ordered the roasted chicken w/ Yukon gold mashed potatoes and Roya Trumet mushrooms and my date had the Strawberry Hill hangar steak w/ fries.  The chicken was cooked to absolute perfection.  It was a half chicken and every part of it was done perfectly.  It wasn't overwhelmed by too many spices or sauces, just basted in a simple broth.  The potatoes were to die for, too.  The hangar steak was marinated in something great and the fries were perfectly crispy.  Myer lemon tart to finish off the night and we left completely satisfied!  

Be sure to make a reservation to avoid having to wait, but if you can't, the ambience and staff will make you feel welcome anyway.  

LOVE LOVE LOVE.
author: Kathleen B.

description: We shared the Gioia Burrata, Insalata di Campo, and calamari for appetizers. We shared the Five Dot Ranch Brisket, Rosemary Tagliatelle with guinea hen, and flat pasta with shrimp. For dessert, we shared the Profiteroles. All were delicious, particurly the calamari, and Tagliatelle. Highly recommended!
author: Joshua S.

description: The food here is consistently good, even after all these years. The chicken and the steak get all the accolades but what brings me back here is the grilled calamari & bean salad and the lovely assorted cheeses for desert.
author: Reza E.

description: Like this place for its atmosphere, friendly service and the food off course. We tried the chilled asparagus (with prosecco zabaglione and thyme breadcrumbs), crab meat spaghetti and some halibut. Out of the three dishes the asparagus and the spaghetti were mind blowing!! The prosecco zabaglione on the asparagus was heavenly and such a pleasure to the palette. We unfortunately didn't get to try any dessert given how full we were -- which calls for another trip! Overall a lovely experience.
author: sandhya ..

description:
what's so great about this place? it's definitely not the food - solid but nothing special and the portions are borderline offensive. it can't be the drinks - no full bar. i guess it could be the ambience - it was comfortable and clean. possibly the service - all the servers were attentive and kinda hot. hmmm...actually, what i enjoyed most about my meal at delfina was my window seat, which allowed me to endlessly people-watch the patrons of delfina pizzeria next door. 

to be completely fair, i dont really have anything against delfina or "nice" restaurants in the mission, so my rating may be inaccurate, but it's just really difficult for me to justify spending $$$$$ on a meal  when i could walk a couple blocks over, spend $ on a burrito or tacos and be 10 times as satisfied.
author: Kevin C.

description: So far my favorite restaurant in the city. Unpretentious northern Italian fare impeccably prepared with friendly, unobtrusive service. Always a safe bet, if you can get a reservation. If not, and it's just you and a friend, try getting a seat at the bar. Won't always work, but it's worth a shot.
author: Wilson M.

description: Favorite! Good looking, cracked on servers, tasty wines, every kind of little animal made into food, I love it! Went recently and had rabbit sugo gnocchi. Love the fries with eyes. Nettle soup is greenalicious!
author: Krismet C.

description: After hearing so much hype on Delfina, I decided to go there for my birthday dinner.  I am glad I did.  Aside from the fact that they ran out of the dish I was going to order (it was 10pm when we had a reservation), everything else was spot on!  The service was amazing as well.  The chicory salad with poached egg was delicious, not to mention my favorite part of the meal, dessert.  There buttermilk panna cotta with blood oranges was amazing!  The decor is really fresh and their art is fun and different.  Working at a restaurant myself, I can be pretty critical on service.  Our server was very helpful and knew what he was doing.  I would recommend this place and I would definitely be going back in the near future.
author: Samantha R.

description: Exceptional food!  The service was poopy though.  Once the food was served, the waiter never returned.  We drank all of our water, our tea and then there wasn't anyone around to bring a refill...then we waited for 30 minutes for our check.  It was a bad ending to an otherwise delicious meal.
author: Irving B.

description: Delfina was absolutely fantastic.  From the service to the food everything was perfect.  I really enjoyed the grilled calamari and the flat bread.  The pork ribs were cooked just right.  The meat fell nicely of the bone.  Definitely a place to return to.
author: Christina C.

description: I have gone to this place on a few occasions within the past few months and loved it everytime.  It can be pricey so expect to spend.  $50 a person should suffice, just incase that person's hungry.  I recommend the fulton valley chicken with yukon mashed potatoes, smoked salmon appetizer, panna cotta dessert, white bean w/ calamari appetizer, the steak is alright but still very good.  As I mentioned, this place is pricey so "expect to spend".  Good for special occasion dining, despite the fact that it's in the mission district with all the homeys.
author: Jack N.

description: Let me start off by saying that the food here is great! I ordered a mixed greens salad, and my boyfriend ordered French fries (appetizers) and they were both good. My main dish was a fennel pasta. It was, I believe, a fettuccine like pasta filled with fennel and topped with a fennel puree. It was their one, out of three vegetarian dishes- one of them being vegan. It was good, but not exciting. As a vegan now, there is a lot to be desired. As I said though, their food was great, but there should be a lot more variety I think. I want to thank our waitress, who was amazing. I am sorry that I forgot her name, but she was very helpful, kind and patient. My boyfriend and I enjoyed our experience and we even hugged her before we left. It loses one star because i feel that it has the potential to offer a bit more, so I think it should.
author: Federico V.

description: First timer walk-ins, great bread and butter, wonderful grilled asparagus salad but skimpy, perfectly al dente and savory pasta dishes and fabulous strawberry torte with  a teeny weeny scoop of gelato. The service left a bit to be desired, not quite attentive enough. Noisy, frenetic and cafeteria like for a place that is striving to be haute cuisine. Eighty bucks including tip. No alcohol.
author: Eileen M.

description:
two drinks, one appetizer (5 asparagaus w/ two small crostini slices and a spoonful of cheese), one side-spaghetti, 2 main dishes equals $118.  chew on that for a little and you'll find that your eating here to satisfy your taste buds not your hunger.  I don't mind paying what I payed for for food that makes my mouth scream..YES! YES! give me MORE!  but my tongue was like "e'... this is ok but not anything to get all wet over".  I would pay $70 max for what Delfina had to offer but $118!  Man, I've had superb dining at other places for that amount.  I'd save your dough and try another place that is really worth the price tag.

It is true- the service was pretty good and the waitress new her stuff with wine and was very good at what she did so she gets stars.

place was crowded and took 1.5 hours to be seated so I suggest reservations.

if you have a lot of money to blow then try it out- just to check it off you list of happening spots, but if you want food that is great and 99% cheaper go down the street to Pancho Villa's Taqueria!  

losses two stars for food not worth the price...gains three points for the service and vibe.
author: omelocs o.

description: Maybe 4 1/2 stars.  My daughter and I walked in on a Thurs. evening and had no trouble getting two seats at the counter.  That gave us a birds-eye view of the entire room.  Service was fine.  I started with the Delfina peach bellini, she had wine (can't recall which).  Then we shared the mozzarella, heirloom tomatoes, basil oil antipasto and the escarole salad with roasted grapes (a nice touch), gorgonzola and almonds.  All were delicious.  I had the paccheri (large pasta) with chunks of blue-nosed seabass while my daughter had the gnocchi al ragu.  Both were ample, fresh and tasty.  Dessert was lemon verbena buttermilk panna cotta with raspberries for me and chocolate torte with olive oil gelato and maldon sea salt.  Everything was fine...the unique touches added to the flavor and style of the meal rather than merely add-ons for effect.  I'd recommend it and definitely go back.
author: Bonnie G.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE - LOVE THE PIZZA - SO YUMMY! But know ahead of time that there is a SUPER LONG WAIT. I have only gone to the pizzaria (sorry if i misspelled) side because I always crave their pizza and they don't serve it at the regular restaurant. But you have to wait to be seated (last time we went it was an hour) then after you order it's a good 40 mins for your food...def get an appetizer and some wine. It's cool you can order wine and chill on the sidewalk while you wait...but its usually super crowded so only go if you're willing to deal with it. IT IS TOTALLY WORTH IT. I am now starting to crave their pizza...so yummy. For me and my husband one pizza and an appetizer works....but the pizza's are a tad small...in between a small and a medium...so you might wanna try getting 2 pizza's if you're really hungry or more if you have a bigger group ;)
author: Kimberly R.

description: Took the family to Delfina for a birthday dinner.  Very disappointing.  Not the Delfina I remember from several years back.  The ribollita, shrimp porchetta, calamari with warm white beans, and salad were tasty but the entrees (Paccheri alla Amalfitana, Hanger Steak, Risotto, and Spagetti) were desperately uninspiring.  Felt like the chef has gotten tired and the dishes stale.  The hanger steak was ordered medium rare and arrived seared on the outside and cold inside.  We sent it back and it was only marginally better and slathered with additional sauce.  Of course, that diner had to watch and wait while the rest of us ate our meals.  The steak was stringy/chewy as well.  Finally, the waiter's obsequiousness was off the charts.  He wished me Happy Birthday so many times I felt like went from 60 to 70 in an hour!  Delfina has squandered its reputation.  Used to recommend it to SF visitors.... no more.
author: Mark H.

description:
people are probably going to hunt me down and kill me for this, but i'm going to say it anyway. delfina is just OK. i said it. no lightening has struck my unappreciative ass down yet. i must deserve to live. 

we arrived early and had some beer and wine at the bar before our friends showed up. the bartender was nice, not super attentive, but still nice. we had some yummy warm olives while we waited. i will say that i appreciated that our table was ready before our ressie, but they never rushed us to sit down. it was still ready when we were half an hour later. for a place this in demand, they really respect the reservation and don't try to sneak more folks in. 

starters:
snap peas: very good.  i really liked these. they had a great mild sauce and fresh flavor.
salt cod: this was underwhelming. it was baked in a little souffle cup and came with some crispy flatbread. for being salt cod it could have used a lil more salt. we actually added some on our own. 

entrees: 
steak frites: the frites were amazing. my friend approved of her steak, but didn't rave about it. 
quail with polenta and fennel sausage: LOVED that sausage and creamy polenta. the husband said the quail was a bit fatty. that's not good.
lamb with black olives and white beans:  this was prepared perfectly medium rare, great mellow flavor. i was glad for the olives, they added that extra something. 

dessert: 
we shared the scharffenberger chocolate cake, really lovely and melty in the middle. 

yes, i would definitely eat here again. it's good comforting italian food and i believe in that. though i have to say i didn't think the waitresses were all that hot, as i read in a previous review. they were ok. no angelina jolies. but whatever. we had a good time and the food was good. next time i will try a pasta. if you're in the mood for meat you have to go to range.
author: rachel p.

description: Calamari app was awesome as was my salmon. The portions were perfect and the place was really cozy. It gets super busy but I def. enjoyed the food. The dessert was a nice way to complete the meal. Was fully satisfied by the time I was done (but I couldn't help stopping by Bi-rite up the street given we were parked right in front of it :)
author: shadi m.

description: ummmm, ummmm good. I just love this place. Happy staff, causal environment, fabulous food. It's hard to get a reservation but if you're patient it's worth putting your name on the wait list. Plus it gives you time to get a glass from their great wine list. And if you just can't wait any longer, you can always go nextdoor and grab the tasty food at the pizza place.
author: dava g.

description: I likey.  Good food, but small menu and not great for big groups.  Go with a date!
author: Drew G.

description: My absolute favorite restaurant in the city.  Every meal I've had there (and I've had many) was sublime.  You really cannot go wrong with anything on their menu--all time favorites include their spaghetti, parpardelle with pork sugo, dungeness crab with endive and grapefruit, Berkshire pork shoulder with farro-nata, and the Tuscan short-ribs.  My husband loves their french fries and fried spring onions as well.  And desserts are incredible--their panna cotta and gelato is out of this world, and the chocolate cake is to die for.  I can't think of any other restaurant in the city that makes me so very happy.
author: Sharyn F.

description: Maybe I'm being too critical but I wasn't blown away by this place.  Although I must admit their spaghetti is pretty damn good.  It is so simple, yet so amazingly good.  Not sure if the food is worth the hype, wait, and prices, but if you do go here, stick with the pasta dishes!
author: YumCha L.

description: I've been eating at Delfina for over a decade now and have found this to be the *only* consistently excellent restaurant in the city.  I know, I know there are so many incredible places to eat... Yet still, a chef leaves and the place no longer retains the magic.  Not the case here.  I was there when they opened and am happy to say that I've never had a bad experience in over eleven years now.  The wait staff is amazing.  They seem to have an almost magical quality and have given guidance in their wine list that is almost scary.  They are that good.  If I could choose one place to eat before I die it would unquestionably be Delfina.
author: Don A.

description: I've eaten here twice, the first time in 2001 or so and I remember the food as fantastic. The second time was a couple months ago. My bf and I had been trying to get in for a while (I don't like to make reservations but live nearby) so I was excited to finally eat there. By the end of the evening I was wondering what all the fuss was about. I had some kind of chicken thing, he had pot roast. Both were unremarkable. I was like: I can make this at home, why did I pay $40 for this? Maybe they had an off day or somethign. But I think really Delfina has reached that point in the restaurant lifecycle where it's overhyped and not so great but people keep going because of the reputation.
author: Amy T.

description: Yes, it's hard to get a reservation, but it's worth it.  Great food, nice wine selection, and nice non-stuffy atmosphere.  Looking forward to a return visit!
author: Tania S.

description: Okay, you know when you hear how great a movie is and then you go to see it finally and you're disappointed?  That's how I thought it would go with Delfina but folks, the hype is true.  This was a perfect meal and not just that I had the best Halibut this new fish eater has ever had, but because the whole experience was amazing.  The timing was impeccable and that's important to me when you're eating out.  We had plenty of time between the courses to enjoy our bottle of wine without ever feeling rushed or hungry.  It was a great flow.  The space is small yes, but it was intimate without being crowded or too noisy.  See where I'm going here?  The waitress was friendly but not nosy, the food was rich and light at the same time.  Imagine you're Goldilocks and Delfina is just right...that's what makes this place perfect.
author: Rachel C.

description: Love LOVE Love this place. Beats out a lot of the overrated junk in this city. Just be prepared to wait around outside for a while. Once you're in, you will be happy.
author: Chris S.

description: Oooh so delicious. Every single thing was orgasm-amazing. A little too pricey (for me) to be able to go very often, but totally worth it for a treat. The profiteroles were.... man.... there's not even a word to describe how unbeLIEVably good they were. I'm getting hot just thinking about them.
author: Cary M.

description: I think Delfina has AMAZING food! The people there are super nice and welcoming.Even though it is a bit pricy,  it's well worth it for the food and service!
author: Lily B.

description: On a recent visit to Delfina I was left feeling as though something has shifted.  At one time Delfina was my favorite restaurant in SF.  It seems there popularity and the demand for reservations has changed Delfina.  They've crammed more tables in to meet the growing demand and the servers are out of touch.  Our wine arrived with the second course and the server took forever to acknowledge that we had sat.  The food was good.  Just good.  I can honestly say everything was executed properly but was left feeling let down.
author: Anne D.

description: Thrilling, thrilling meal, from the first bite to the last.  If I could,  I would give this place six stars.  One of the best meals I've had in SF, or anywhere for that matter.  This menu was packed to the breaking point with hot course after hot course.  The bitter green salad had me oohing and aghhhing with each suprising bite.  The grilled salmon w/ sweet corn succotash stopped me in my tracks, the culinary equivalent of walking by Matthew McConaughey jogging shirtless.  The chocolate cake, maybe the best I've had, finished the meal in fine style.  What a simple, yet completely profound dining experience.  Worth every penny.
author: Matt D.

description: Delfina doesn't need my review, but I love it.
author: Seth B.

description: I love delfina.  The service is always impeccable.  Their simple pastas, their calamari dish, their fresh stretched mozzarella . . . ahh, so tasty.  I only wish it was easier to get reservations there!!
author: Annie F.

description: Great restaurant!  Very small space and gets crowded very quickly.  Service is knowledgeable and friendly.  We had excellent pasta dishes and the calamari and ricotta appetizers were tasty and creative.  Sides were just okay.  Our waiter had great wine pairing suggestions.  The pomegranate bellini was also a hit.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Oh man, this place is great.

It is expensive. (I was treated =) But I would say it's worth it. 

The portions are the right size for me. The flavor of everything was perfect. I had an asparagus salad, ravioli, and dessert.

It's difficult to get a reservation--the place is popular for a good reason.
author: Anna J.

description: Too much hype for its own good.  Don't get me wrong, i think the spaghetti is great, however i don't think its worth the price. Its a trendy spot that charges a premium.   It's one of those place i would just go once, try a variety of apps and entrees, just to say that i've been there and done that.  I have no reason to go back. Im more than happy to go to the pizza spot next door.
author: Jared K.

description: This is our favorite place in SF at this point.  Everything about it is excellent, the only difficulty is getting reservations within a week or so.  The food and atmosphere is perfect for a high quality yet somewhat casual meal.
author: Shawn C.

description: Everything was pretty much delicious. I like their grilled calamri and trofie with pesto the best...their roasted chicken was great too...OoOo ..n especially their buttermilk panna cotta is a must try!.....Very fresh n tasty!
author: stephanie n.

description: One of my favorite restaurants!  Been there 5 times and can't wait to return. The staff is always really great and the food tasty--not incredibly original, but is prepared to perfection.  It can get pricey, but for a special night is worth it.
author: Candy Z.

description: Possibly the most redundant review on here, but it was great.  Apparently it was the SF weekly or SFBG's best restaurant last year in the reader poll.  I'm not surprised.
author: Alex T.

description:
I give it a 2.5 actually, but they get the additional 0.5 for the service.

Average and overpriced food. Didn't impress us. There are much better choices in SF.

We ordered:
- tagliatelle with duck giblets: this was quite good, but nothing amazing
- bigoli with sardines: avoid this one
- cacciucco lovornese: 25$ for 4 mussels and two clams, a bite of fish and lots and lots of salt
- profiteroles: blah, too much of the same, too heavy, not refined
- fresh mint stracciatella: voted best choice of the evening

Won't be coming back...
author: bart a.

description:
salty food
bad service - 
long wait

did not enjoy the experience
surly managers

will not come back again
author: ed f.

description:
When thinking about how many stars I wanted to give, I felt like it should be five, but, for some reason I just can't, which makes me feel guilty because I gave Nopa five stars and I feel this place is at least as good, if not better. Ok, after that useless introduction, our meal was awesome on Friday night. I called almost two weeks ahead and they only had a 5:30 or 9:30 reservation available, so we went at 9:30 for my husband's birthday. 
They have a nice selection of Italian wines, I ordered the Franciacorta, which I don't see on wine lists too often. We started with the Anchovies, which were AWESOME, not the stereotypical, overly strong, fishy, salty taste AT ALL. Then we split the Oxtail Risotto, which was also quite good and I've had there before. I think that is where Five Star doubt started to creep in, the Risotto is very good but I can't help thinking it, at times, tastes similar to risotto you might make at home out of a box and the reason it tastes so good is all the preservatives and saturated fat that it contains. 
Then we had two main entrees. I had the Abalone and my husband had the Hanger Steak. The Abalone was really, really good, if not a tad overcooked. The Hanger Steak was awesome (we ordered it rare and it was cooked perfectly). I was so full by then that I didn't eat much of the entrees. 
I had to order dessert. We had the ScharfenBerger Chocolate Torta with Olive Oil Gelato. I ordered it mostly because of the Olive Oil gelato, which we had last time we were there (a year before, again on my husband's birthday) and I have been dreaming about ever since. But, maybe I built it up too much, because even though it was an AMAZING dessert, it was not as amazing as my memory of it. Sigh. 
Overall it was a wonderful birthday experience. I like the atmosphere, the music, the service was OUTSTANDING. So perhaps my first experience of Delfina (which I'm sure I would have given Five Stars) was too good and I was brought back down to reality for my second experience, resulting in only Four Stars.
author: Kathleen Y.

description:
This is as good as a meal can get in the city, but you must always expect a long wait ahead if you do not make a reservation. And if  you crave a great gastronomic experience head down the street towards valencia to grab cocktails and appetizers (specifically the spicy clams with chorizo) at Range while you wait for a table to open at delfina. Make it a progressive dining night! 

So after a great drink and a small snack we headed back to Delfina to first indulge in freshly baked bread from tartine across the street and sip a refreshing glass of wine (they have quite an extensive wine list both local and international- great selection). And you must order their homemade pastas - the basic spaghetti is so memorable in its simplicity, one of the best around. if you want some more excitement in your pasta they offer half orders of every pasta, so you can get a taste of all their great concepts. 

As much as I loved the pasta, the highlight of the meal was the desert. Molten chocolate cake with olive oil gelato and sea salt is incredible. sweet and salty - just the perfect combination. I want to go back simply for that taste I still have lurking in my mouth.
author: Wesley E.

description: This has to be one of favorite places to have dinner in the city! It could just be for an anni, birthday or date night.  Last time we dined there- it was gay pride- I figured that would work in our schedule to check out the dyke march then walk over to Delfina.  We showed up a little tipsy and way hungry for our 10pm reso. But we were notified that they were a little behind due to it being gay pride?!  We were seated at 10:45 and now sleepy and hungry- they comp'd our wine, immediately brought over frites and pasta! So, they totally saved themselves...dinner was good as usual:)
author: Valarie A.

description:
I'm here more than any other rest in the city.  Best place the Mission has to offer.  

If you generally think italian is boring and tired (if not comfortable), you need to hit up delfina.  There pasta dishes are memorable.  Best thing I've had there is a black cuttlefish risotto.  Those things are adorable under the sea but damn good in Deflina's capable hands.  

Highlight for me is sitting at the long bar that faces the main dining area.  It's great for people watching, you can't help but at some point start up a conversation with those you are eating over.  And, you can meander through a three hour meal without a lot of pressure from the servers to turn your seats - which I have felt when sitting in the main room.  They're much more hands off with the bar patrons.
author: Chris A.

description: This is my second time at Delfina. The food was absolutely ingenious and fantastic. Our reservation was 20 minutes delay. But, our witstaff was really affable. She apologized and bought us 2 free drinks while we were waiting. I had the halibut salad and herb chicken for main course. It was delicioso and mouthwatering. The best racy food you could ever die for. On the other hand, the wine list was moderate but potable. The atmosphere definately gave us a joy of bonhomie. I strongly recommand this restaurant.
author: Michael K.

description: Yes, it's that good. Neighborhoody ambiance belies delicious northern Italian and an excellent wine list.  Best to bring only dates outfitted with ample self-confidence since the waitstaff can be intimidatingly hot.
author: Gabriel S.

description: I would come here every Friday if I lived in these parts.
author: sarah k.

description: Simple Italian food at its best!  Delfina continue to execute things right after all these years.  One quick note: dinner reservation seemed easier recently, so pay them a visit if you have not already.
author: J S.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I would go there anytime with anyone for any reason. I don't know what I could write about this place that hasn't been already said.
author: Charles H.

description: so this restaurant is definately better than the average restaurant, but it doesn't blow my socks off.  I had the polenta, which was good warm and gooey, and the seafood stew, which was ok, and the proflierates, which i didn't think were super special.  don't get me wrong, i see why all the cool cats dig this place, i just don't think it's superfab
author: Chrammy D.

description:
I haven't been here for a long time so I was excited to come back!  But what happenned to the grilled calamari appetizer - I thought that was a signature dish.  Bring it back!  
We had the 
Carpaccio - so yummy with the salty bits of fried capers
Roasted Fulton Valley chicken - really good, but chicken can only be so good 
Papardelle with duck sugo- good but I had this at Sociale only a few nights before and I like their version somehat better
Paccheri with bluenose bass al'Amalfitana - can't tell you what that all means but this pasta dish was so----  good.  I'm not really used to little bits of fish with pasta but the flaovrs in this were just right.
Panna cotta - I find most panna cottas kinda boring but Delfina's verison is really good
The food here is solid but I wish the pasta portions were a bit larger.  I'd order another appetizer next time.  I also wish they had another 2 or 3 options. And the table next to us said they tried for 3 months to get a reservation- not sure I'd go through that trouble but Delfina is definitely worth a visit..
author: Amina B.

description: This place was good. It lives up to the hype. The ingredients are fresh, simple and delicious.  Why this place and Velvet Cantina are rated the same is a mystery to me. However, It irritates me and deepens my dislike for hipsters who don't eat, but rather, judge places on their hipster appeal.  Who knows what that's based on but whatever the criteria it rates Velvet Cantina and this place the same.  so sad.
author: mazzy s.

description: We had to call a couple of weeks in advance in order to make a Saturday night reservation.  I thought it was definitely worth the wait.  The food was really good and the service was awesome.  I really like how they have seasonal menus so each time  I come, the menu is always different.
author: Jen L.

description:
yum. yum yum yum yum yum.  every last bite and morsel is delicious contentment, the kind of comforting food which makes you feel loved, sing holiday songs, close your eyes, wiggle your toes...and forget your ex.  or in this case, forget that you're having dinner with an ex!

it's really that good!!  my favorite italian spot in sf, and now i can't wait to go to italy!

menu (in layman's terms)
a lovely, fruity zin (that didn't make me sleepy), bread, turnips, grape salad, mint and mushroom pasta dish, red cream sauce shrimp pasta scrap dish, and a strawberry shortcake-like thing for dessert.  the only disappointment was the dessert, but maybe i was just too full to enjoy it by that time.
author: Dee C.

description: i'm in love with delfina.  we stopped in for a late dinner last week and were amazed by the offerings. Our server was kelly and she was great--very attentive w/o being overbearing.  she didn't try to oversell us on food and seemed to know her stuff.  we ordered the chicken liver crostini, Puntarelle alla Romana (anchovy-flavored salad), brussel sprouts with pancetta, and spaghetti with squid ink.  the spaghetti was awesome but we could have still enjoyed it without the uni on top.  overall, great food and great service.
author: T S.

description: Don't know if it was a bad day or what, but the service took forever, they were out of most dishes on the menu, and couldn't seem to get anything right (bringing the wrong dish which was the 3rd option anyway).  Would be willing to try again, but not at the end of the evening like this time.
author: Blair S.

description:
A friend and I were wandering around the neighborhood looking for a place to eat and stumbled into Delfina. It was a lot nicer than we were looking for, but they had 2 seats at their bar available at 7 on a Sat night, so we couldn't say no (would have been a 3-hour wait for a table). I've had their pizza before (as a New Yorker, it's the only edible pizza I've found yet in SF), but didn't know much about the main restaurant.

The staff was extremely friendly and gave us no attitude about wandering into such a restaurant on a Sat night w/o a reservation. Service was timely and attentive -- we never felt rushed, nor did we wait.

The menu is a little intimidating with the many courses and advanced culinary vocab (and we aren't inexperienced eaters when it comes to fine dining), but our waitress was extremely friendly and suggested options and a structure.

Per her suggestion, we decided to share 4 dishes -- an appetizer, two pastas, and an entree.

Beef carpaccio appetizer was wonderful. Nothing to write home about, but certainly tasty. The spaghetti pasta was also extremely good, although not especially remarkable.

But then came the squash tortelli. All I can say is: Wow. Absolutely delicious pasta with buttery sauce gave way to sweet squash taste -- a perfect combination and sequence of flavors. Hands down one of the single best dishes I have ever tasted. Seriously.

The duck entree was also spectacular. The most tender and flavorful duck I've ever had.

Portion sizes were also ample, which is more than you can say for a lot of pricy restaurants.

Yes, it cost $70 per person (all-in), but we shared a bottle of wine and those 4 courses and left completely full and satisfied.
