Perhaps it was stumbling upon such a meal that made it so special, or maybe the friendliness of the staff and comfort of the ambience, or maybe just the sheer taste and quality of the food -- but it was a perfect experience all around and worth every penny.

Whether for just a meal with a good friend, a romantic evening, or a celebratory occasion, I HIGHLY recommend Delfina. But you're probably better off getting a reservation than doing what we did -- wouldn't try my luck and wander in on a Saturday night again!
author: Evan K.

description:
It was a dark and stormy night.....  But, it really was!

     After taking in the new Pissarro exhibit at the PoLO (Don't get me started on impressionism, but the organ concert was outstanding), my dining companions and I were doing the S.F. dining two-step.  First available reservations at our other choice were 8:30, and of course, Delfina's were long gone.   However, we figured we would head straight for Delfina and hope our dining Karma was as good as usual.  If nothing else, at least we could sit at the counter/bar.  

     As is wont to happen, we were just finishing going over the day's menu with our server when a table opened up for us.  Moving down, we were delivered from the care of one very capable server to another.  It is worth noting, everyone we interacted with from the Hosts to the servers, to the chef was affable, professional, and extremely accommodating.

     Our game of musical chairs completed, we commenced to the meal.  My dining companions are of the preference (and I know this is annoying to the kitchen at times) of ordering one course, then deciding on the second.  I should add, this isn't out of fickleness, but rather to avoid the disappointment of having a poor service cause one dish to pile up on top of another, leaving one feeling rushed and leaving food to sit either on the table or in the window.  Again, our courteous server was able to appease with the accommodation that she would be happy to pace our meal to assure a leisurely dining experience.  True to her word, we enjoyed impeccable food, presented in a perfectly choreographed sequence of dishes.

     While our dining party does enjoy wine, there are often personal preferences which make ordering a bottle impractical.  Delfina has respectable, if not particularly encyclopedic by-the-glass offerings which change, at least between the visits we have made.  What I found particularly helpful was our server's unsolicited offer to "taste us on a few things" when we asked her for some insight to what they were pouring that evening.  We settled on a couple of Italian reds, which were both pleasing, although actually the "lesser" selection we found more to our liking.

    One of my favorite experiences at Delfina is enjoying the explanations, freely given, of how something is prepared, where it is sourced, and what the ingredients are.  Delfina's food is excellent because it is top quality ingredients, expertly prepared: ingredients + technique.  Our server eloquently demonstrated this principle by ticking off the seven (yes, 7) ingredients in the spaghetti, while confiding that she had been unable to reproduce that bowl of pasta magic at home (I sympathize, but the quest continues).  On another visit, the chef took the time to explain, in detail, how he prepares kale dish, transforming that bitter green into something miraculous.

    As they do every night, they began with the country bread from Tartine bakery just down the block, and a cuboid tub of butter (unsalted on request).  Personally, I prefer no start to a meal more than freshly made, good bread, torn by hand from the loaf, with sweet, lightly salted butter.  Truly, Delfina obliges.

  First Course - The little gem lettuce salad was pleasant, but dressed with too much blue cheese for my taste.  The octopus was tender, sauteed simply in olive oil, and served over ceci (garbanzos) in a light tomato and seafood based sauce.  The slight chew of the octopus paired beautifully with the creamy tenderness of the ceci, contrasted with a well buttered grilled slice of bread.  Beans were adeptly incorporated in several dishes in our meal.  Our other mollusk of the evening, the calamari, was quickly grilled and lightly seasoned with oil, garlic, salt and pepper, yielding a pleasant, subtle charcoal flavor and a soft, fresh texture.  Served atop a warm white bean salad that was understated, but added a little sweetness and herbaceous to the dish.

     Entrees - The spaghetti was simple, and elegant.  Seven ingredients (see above), which were greater than the sum of their parts.  Dried, Italian spaghetti was cooked al dente and served with a reduced sauce of tomatoes, olive oil, garlic, basil, and just a hint of red   pepper flakes.  It was unassuming, and delicious (although one of our diners felt the pasta was a little too al dente).  The Bollito Misto, consisting of a cheek, a tongue, and a sausage, while still enjoyable, was the least preferred.  The meats were cooked until tender, but not noticeably seasoned, leaving a flavor mostly reminiscent of boiled meat.  The highlight was the bass.  The fish was perfectly cooked: salty, crispy skinned, with flesh that flaked but remained moist.  The large filet was served on top of butter beans, pale savory, and creamy.  We also enjoyed the brussel sprouts, lightly charred from a hard sear, salty with the barest hint of anchovy.

     We were too full to even consider dessert.  Ah, maybe next time.
author: Michael L.

description: I almost feel stupid writing a Delfina review, but this place can't get better. except it would be nice if they always had a place... I hate making reservations with the common folk.
author: J B.

description: I had the lettuce gem salad and wild boar ragu.  My friend had a pasta dish with two types of pasta (one green and one yellow) with english peas, some sort of cured meat, and a raw egg yolk on top which is punctured in front of you and mixed into your pasta by the waitress.  All were pretty tasty and I would definitely be up to go again.
author: Jo W.

description: I immediately like the vibe / ambiance of this place.  And the wine / food was fabuous.  Although I didn't pay for dinner, I would say it is a bit on the pricey side... but deliciously worth it.
author: Myra M.

description: Tramping all over the Mission for the afternoon makes you hun-gry! I came to Delfina a little past 6 p.m. and was seated at the bar (my choice as I was told they don't have tables for 1). Before I actually sat down, I visited their facilites, and when I returned to the bar my place setting was complete, with bread and a carafe of water. I thought that was very welcoming. Also, many times in restaurants when you're walking through the  servers plow through as if they are more important than the customer, which I get because their work is hard work. But, at Delfina they all prioritized my movements.A small thing, but noticeable. Jeanine was my server and she was terrific. From where I sat I could watch the salad makers and the cooks down the line with the care they take in their craft. I started with insalata di campo. As David D. said, a great salad. I normally don't care for frisee, removing it from the salad altogether. But I noticed that Delfina does something unique. Instead of lumping a frisee in the salad, it is torn into smaller bites---and I liked it! I ordered the spaghetti--very simple but flavorful. How do they do it? No meat, not much sauce but still so good. I had two wines--a chianti and a sangiovese--both very good. I was full, but knew that a place like this would turn out terrific desserts. Jeanine told me about their lemon crostada---I couldn't turn down lemon! The crust was light and sweet topped with luscious lemony curd. delightful with an espresso. I wanted to save half of the dessert for later and Jeanine graciously boxed it up. As wonderful as this place is on a first visit,I just can't imagine how it could be as magically perfect the next time.
author: M F.

description: There was a hair baked into the pizza I ordered. Disgusting.
author: Julia E.

description:
Amazing dining experience. Authentic and robust, the flavors soar.
The wait staff is always friendly and informed. Hands down the BEST place to eat for Italian in SF. My husband and I are regulars, and have been for the last 7 years. Delfina has never disappointed. If you love real food and real people, this place is a must!
author: J S.

description: Both the pizzeria and the restaurant are as good as it gets... and I am usually hard to impress.  Seriously, I couldn't stop thinking about the food for weeks.  In fact, I want it right now... so good.
author: Christa B.

description: Delfina! Goddess of Panna Cotta. My taste buds dance around your light. I'm not a dessert person, but the Panna Cotta at this place is magic. It's a drug, it's in the brain, I'm addicted.
author: Nga H.

description: Yum yum yum. I went here for dinner with my girlfriends and we walked away full and absolutely impressed.  Surprisingly, dinner wasn't as expensive as we anticipated (probably because we didn't drink that much...).  The raviolis were delicious.  Great use of seasonal ingredients.  The praise and reputation Delfina has earned it totally justifiable!
author: Heather C.

description: I'm somewhat of a regular here, and have been going for years. I've had great meals here and sometimes just good ones, but they are always satifying, mostly because the cooking is humble, with an honesty that really allows the ingredients to shine.  I love the gorgeous and sometimes surly girls who work here, probably because they are always sweet to me, and besides, it's probably the only place in the city that you can see so many hot lesbians in the same room.
author: Stellah D.

description:
This place is alright, but I didn't think it was anything astounding. To begin with, I was there with a friend who is a total foodie but really doesn't like seafood, and there was hardly anything on the menu that didn't include seafood. Overall, the menu was interesting, and that's basically how I would sum up my meal. The menu is separated into about 4 categories (apps, sides, entrees, and maybe one other) and I wanted to select an item from at least 2 of the categories, but not many of the dishes sounded like they would compliment each other. It was very odd.  As for what I did order, I admit I didn't order a huge variety, but of the things I did try I thought they were underwhelming. It was also quite loud inside, and our server was clearly unamused that we weren't there to spend a couple hundred on a full course meal, despite the fact that we were sitting at the counter. So anyway, I got the tomato soup for starters. It was fine, but tasted like a great fresh marinara sauce without any pasta--I was able to use the last piece of free bread to eat with about a third of it which greatly improved it, and I really think it's a soup in dire need of some kind of carb accompaniment. I also had the polenta, and I was sad about how boring it was. Polenta is usually a creamy, simple comfort-type food, and this polenta didn't fit that bill at all. It was bland, and tasted like they took plain polenta, melted an incompatible cheese on top, and charged me $8 for a serving of tasteless mush not much bigger than the palm of my hand. I appreciate simple, well-done, fresh food, but this was honestly pretty lame. The guy next to me got chicken and mashed potatoes that smelled amazing though, so I guess based on smell alone I'd get that if I ever went back.

I've heard they have a pizza place (next door maybe?) that is better. Maybe I'll try that perhaps since this is so close to where I live, but honestly, I expected much better quality and value than what I got here. I think there are restaurants in SF serving all kinds of better Italian food (modern, traditional, etc.) at better values. Even in the much-maligned Little Italy there is a restaurant I love called Panta Rei that I'd rather spend my money at. Delfina just didn't make much sense to me and given the hype I really expected more.
author: Allison G.

description: I've had this place in my yelp bookmarks now for three years. Everyone I've talked too has told me that Delfina is outstanding. So, I was excited to finally check it out. The service here is great, absolutely great. They are very attentive to your dining experience. I expected the menu  to consist of many Italian dishes but, was shocked to see more of a rustic European selection instead. The food was good but, the service was better. The roasted duck with apricot glaze was good and their pasta dishes are put together very well. The desert menu is average. The profiteroles and pane cota good too. One of the nice things about this place is the serve Ritual coffee.
author: Marco M.

description: I adore this place - the staff, the ambiance, the bars, the big picture windows, and the best grilled squid - perfect. We had a perfect half bottle of wine, kicking myself that I did not write it down.  And a white shrimp pasta that was a little too fishy on first blush, but pasta made up for it. I suspect they used a fish stock in sauce. But overall I completely adore this place, and love that you can easily have a quick bit at the bar, and still have it feel intimate and special.
author: I. V.

description: Excellent food, great atmosphere, but prepare to pay for it.  I think I would choose the Pizzeria over the restaurant next time around.
author: Debbie Y.

description: When I have to pick an upscale place in the city to take out-of-town guests to, I always think of Delfina.  It's just plain yummy, with unusual offerings.  I had the most divine celery root soup here (I'd never even heard of celery root before then), they have decent wine, and my companions enjoy the espresso.
author: Rachel R.

description: It's a great place go to when you only want to hear only every 3rd word spoken at the table. The food is still good, the service is still surly, the bar stools are still uncomfortable.
author: Rene D.

description: Wonderful place, great food, but the bean appetizer gave us a rather salty story to tell later that night.
author: Allison L.

description: Excellent quality food, and even better service.  All their staff treat every customer as their own table, and they all check to see if any customer needs anything.  Amazing team work.  I had their soup, salmon dish, and ice cream desert.  All were great.  Only downside is the place is tiny, and there is no privacy.  Basically you are sharing a table with people on tables next to you.  If you like making friends and sharing your conversations with stranges, then this is the place for you.  However, if you prefer the least bit of privacy, then you may feel uncomfortable having other tables so close by.
author: V J.

description: One of the best restaurants in San Francisco. Everything is divine. The decor is clean, modern and elegant and the service good. Get reservations and take a cab/bus if coming on a weekend.
author: Sara W.

description: We went to Delfina Saturday evening prior to "Wicked".  We advised the server at the beginning of our meal we had theater tickets and she accomodated us to ensure we got out of there with time to spare without feeling rushed.  Besides that which was so important, the meal and wine were outstanding!  We started with the anchoives and the halibut crudo, wow they were both so delicious.  We did a split Panzenela salad which was also good but had a different twist with the bread portion.  It was bread crumbs soaked in oil/vinegar and then layered into the salad.  Not my first choice of delivery but creative and good.  I had the Oxtails with polenta and my wife had the steak.  Both were good by the Oxtails were the highlight!  We can't wait to go back.  The service was top notch and the staff was fun and beautiful!  5 stars!!
author: Ted D.

description: My all time fav in SF! Walk-ins at bar ok, groups need reservations weeks in advance. Their new pizza place opens in Spring 05!
author: Stephanie F.

description: Delfina's all female waitstaff barely make an effort and despite reviews to the contrary, it's been this way since they opened in 1998. (I recently asked and was told there are two men working the front of house, but I have yet to see them.) The food is tastey and reasonably priced, but it's not worth the trouble getting a reservation weeks in advance. I doubt I'll be back anytime soon - well, at least until Craig opens his pizzeria, presumably next door.
author: Philip M.

description: I was a bit disappointed with this restaurant. I heard so many good things and the wait was really long! I had the chicken and rabbit with polenta for my entree. It was good, but nothing special. My date had the seafood stew, a typical entree. The grill fennel was quite tasty. I thought the it was a little overpriced for what we ate. Overall, not worth the wait or price.
author: Denise L.

description:
had a real nice experience here in september.
we made reservation for a friday night at 10pm for my friend's birthday.
it was 4 of us.
our server was really friendly and knowledgeable of both the food and the wine.  she told us what was no longer available on the menu for the night and told us what they had instead of the certain items.
all the food we ordered was really tasty.  nicely balanced flavors.
chicken, rabbit, fish, tripe, desserts...  their menu changes often so i'd definately want to go back again to see what else they have...
author: charlotte s.

description: I went to Delfina last Saturday for a friend's birthday.  The only time available when we called for reservations was at 5:30 PM (we had a party of 6).  At 5:20 PM, there was a long line of people waiting for the restaurant to open.  We were seated immediately - the service was great throughout the night (all dishes were served on time and water glasses were constantly refilled).  We ordered: a bottle of wine, two orders of calamari, an order of charred corno, each person ordered his/her own entree, apple crostata rustica, panna cotta, and chocolate cake for dessert. I ordered the albacore tuna and got to try the halibut and chicken as well.  Everyone agreed that the food was delicious but it does get pricey if you order wine.  The bill came out to about $70 per person, including tip.  It's a restaurant worth trying out so you know what everyone is raving about.  However, there are also many other restaurants in San Francisco that are just as great.
author: Connie W.

description: Strange.  we have had one good meal here and one terrible meal. Mushy pasta , bland food in general.  Dessert was the best part of the meal.
author: Bleep S.

description:
uh, huh....if you like good eats, get your ass to Defina.  bugger the reviews, just get on down.

yes, parking blows, so heck, phone it in and pick it up to go....

are you kidding me, how awesome is that?
author: david s.

description:
delicious meal! we celebrated christmas a week early...
i have to say everything was so flavorful. 
we started with a salad with pears, which was not what i expected and so much better.
i had the quail over a bed of polenta, the flavors bursted...
he had the lamb... which was also tasty, but i have to say 'mine was better' - sorry babe...

for dessert he had the biscotti & dessert wine and i had a sweet potato tart. it was declicous and wonderful meal!!
author: kiko v.

description: The space is nice, but i think it just alright, great but not excellent. Everyone is raving about the gnocchi, but it is too greasy for my taste, i rather go to Della Santina's Trattoria in Sonoma for it. Of course i know it's too long adrive for gnocchi, haha. I guess the food is consistent and atmosphere is great. It deserves to be one of the most popular restaurants in SF.
author: Angela H.

description: Loved the Grilled fresh calamari with warm white bean salad appetizer and Niman Ranch flatiron steak and French fries! Super yummy!
author: Yan M.

description: Overall the food was great, everyone in my party really enjoyed their dishes. Only one of us was unhappy, a friend ordered a dish that turned out to be WAY to salty which she sent back and it came back too salty again! The restaurant is a little crowded and noisy but has lots of personality.
author: Emily L.

description: I was in Delfina for my birthday and the food was truly amazing. The  only thing that was missing was good service. Our waiter completely forgot about us and it took forever to order and to get food. But in the end the food is definitely worth it.
author: Maria V.

description: Delfina doesn't really need anymore reviews with praises, but for those headed there, you do need to know to order the Dungeness crab pasta they have on their menu right now.  Oh how I wish there was more it it here right now!
author: Mazi S.

description: Excellent place to sit al fresco on a warm night (with your dog even). They have a simple menu with 3 specials daily: antipasto, entree & dessert. We shared a pizza margarita, comes with a side of fresh shaved parm, off the vine oregano, and crushed red peppers. Wine list is intriguing since I'm a total novice on Italian vino, I had a great recommendation from Yolanda, the rock star server. Also shared the roasted beets with ricotta ensalada and broccoli rabe. Very satisfying meal and ambiance.
author: Colleen B.

description:
I love this place.  Delfina is one of the few really popular restaurants that I don't think is over-hyped.  Every time I've been there, the food has been outstanding.  This is the place that I generally bring out -of-towners who I deem deserving.  My favorite starter is the grilled calamari.  The dish is served with some beans and greens and is always on the menu.  Pastas are changed every so often, but if they have anything with rabbit ragu, you gotta get it.  I've tried several of the entrees from lamb to duck to cioppino and everything has always been excellent.  Desserts are consistently good too.  I'm a big fan of the panna cotta and chocolate cake.  
My only complaints:
It's difficult to get a reservation for a good time on a Friday or Saturday night so I would advise booking over a week in advance if that's your plan.  Also, sometimes you can end up waiting up to 20 minutes even if you have a reservation.
author: Saw T.

description: I've never ever had a disappointing meal here.  Delfina defines simple, fresh Italian cuisine.  The menu is forever changing, as most everything is based on what is seasonally available.  The pastas are always cooked to perfection, and I've enjoyed both the fish dishes and the more meaty fare equally well!  Eat here!  Just do it!
author: Amy C.

description: You know those rare meals when you are with crazy foodies who know the chef and the owner and the sous chef and all sorts of things you'd never order (like tripe n' shit) keeping showing up for free as a 'gift from the kitchen' and you eat so much you ache from it and probably drink to much fantastic wine too and your crazy foodie friends are genuine and lovely and you really share an experience?  Well to me, that is Delfina, and boy do I feel lucky.  Yay me (and all the foodies and friends and family too)!
author: Val G.

description: This place is hectic, but worth the wait!  Everything I had was delicious, and the service was good.  The only thing was that I felt a little crammed in, but whatever, when the food is that good, I don't mind eating standing up or crouched in a corner if I have too!
author: Jennifer H.

description: We haven't dined at Delfina for several years now  and recenlty we decided to go here for dinner and my review still stands- food continues to be amazing.  I also forgot how wonderful the service was considering that many SF restaurants have fallen short in this department.  This restaurant deserves 10 stars!!
author: Belle M.

description: Magnifique! One of the best Italian meals I have had in a long time.  I would definitely recommend.  A good atmosphere, excellent service and great food.  What more can you ask for?!
author: Kimberly-Alexis N.

description: We went on a weekday night and the place was packed. This is certainly an indicator of the quality of the food, which was indeed quite delicious, but also meant that the timeliness of service was not phenomenal. Eat here if you have a lot of time on your hands, go early to ensure a table, and prepare for a good meal thats worth the wait. The restaurant has a great atmosphere and chances its menu everyday.
author: Jack Z.

description: My appetizer (pressed ricotta, peppers and a crostini) was really good. They were out of the obvious desired veggie choice so I was stuck with spaghetti. I asked to sub the rosemary pasta from the beef ragu instead of the spaghetti noodles (If I wanted to eat spaghetti, I would stay at home). The dish was ok, a very powerful tomato sauce, but nothing special. I was a bit peeved that they charged us the price beef ragu for subbing the noodles (I could understand adding a few bucks, but not $6 for a noodle substituion...). The appetizer was nice and I am sure I would have had a better meal if I ate meat, hence the 3 stars. But the spaghetti entrée on its own would only merit 1 or 2 stars.
author: Sue M.

description:
given all the hype, i was hoping for a 5 star experience all around.  

food was 3.5 stars (heavy sauces, skimped on crab in the salad, okay desserts), price/ value was a 3 star, and friendliness of reservations and wait staff a 5 star....thus with my complex algorithms, i give it a 4 star (rounding up). certainly didn't live up to my expectations that had been beat into me over years of hype...
author: Greg A.

description: I really wanted to LOVE this place, but to be honest...I think it's pretty overrated.  The house made mozzerella didn't taste much different than what you can buy next door at Bi Rite, and my skate was pretty standard, nothing made me want to come back...except wine, and the atmoshpere.
author: Sarah D.

description: Casual, reasonable, dependable-San Francisco could use a few more restaurants in this formula.  Eat at the bar and avoid the reservation disaster.
author: Beth V.

description: I love this place.  we had our wedding anniversary dinner here and hope to go back every year.  staff is very friendly and down to earth, the food is amazing, the atmosphere is great and the price is awesome!  we had 3 course dinner with wine for about 100 bucks.
author: Rio K.

description: I will give you that sometimes the service leaves a lot to be desired, and I will give you that there are things on the menu I look at and wonder why the chef thought that sounded appetizing, but this restaurant and its kitchen do amazing work and it's always a pleasure going.  And when the menu is good -- and it can be insanely good -- it's a spectacular experience.  If you can't get a rezzie, don't fear -- just pop your head in and sit at the bar, seats usually open up pretty quickly.
author: amanda g.

description: The salads are fresh, the service is exquisite, but the entrees vary from delicious to decent
author: Seiji C.

description: The best italian restaurant in SF.  It's my fav...hands down.  Everything is good on the menu.  Call for reservations is a must.
author: Julia H.

description: I don't agree about the dress code as "dressy", this place as I remember was fairly casual (think normal date outfit). The Panna Cotta is amazing, and the service very knowlegable. I don't remember what I ate, just that it was outstanding. Don't miss this place.
author: Carson H.

description: Delfina, as all the previous Yelpers wrote, is a wonderful restaurant.  But their excellence is attributable to more than just the culinary experience.  My dining mate and I ordered a bottle of rose that didn't taste anything like what we expected, and the waitress was attentive and kind enough to take the bottle away and provide different drinks that were more to our palate's liking.  Bravo to Delfina!
author: Helen C.

description:
excellent food! knowledgeable servers!

HORRENDOUS crowd - pretentious and rude.
author: Erika Y.

description:
yeah, it's expensive.  neener neener.

that said, delfina is the most consistently delicious restaurant in SF.  that said,  the house of hula is filled with foodies and we've hit all the "best" places in the city...but we always come back to delfina.  delfina always delivers and delivers well:  food is fantastic, servers are delightfully quirky and incredibly helpful, the menu is a seasonal surprise and the wine list is divine.

i have to disagree with the person who said it was "trendy."  we've been going to delfina for six years and, though it's occasionally filled with the pseudo-glam set, we tend to see neighbors and friends each time we go.
author: nic f.

description: I really like this restaurant but is nearly impossible to just go there on a whine. I've also notice that I can't seem to keep track on whether the week is pork week or beef week.  I've been trying to go during beef week with w/ Rey but we can't seem to get the dates right.  I'm very pleased that they have half bottle wines.
author: May A.

description: The girls here do it right.  The service is amazing!  And the food is always fresh and yummy.  Delfina serves up a great dining experience -- casual yet special.  The pasta dishes are my fave along with the fresh Mozzarella starter, and the octopus starter when they have it.
author: Tina T.

description: I've eaten lunch here a couple times now and hope to eat dinner (need to make a reservation), sometime soon. The pizzas are really yummy (anything with their homemade sausage), the meatballs are good, salad can be a little bitter, but overall yum. Takes awhile to get seated, I think ordering takeout is the best, and next time I want to try their calzones!
author: Rachel R.

description: Our waitress was great! She was very attentive to us as it was our first time. The portions were a bit on the smaller side for my liking but it was all very yummy. A little on the pricey side, but it was a pleasant experience overall.
author: Susana M.

description: Love this place!!!! The best Italian ever. Everytime I take my wife here I think she falls in love with me all over again. It's that good.
author: Anthony B.

description: Had a great dinner here with the boy when we first moved to the bay area.  I love the type of food (boy would say it was "my flavors" - whatever that means).  Anyway - I definitely recommend it!
author: Jenn K.

description:
Everyone seems to love this place. I'm not entirely sure why. I'm going to have to go with Bonnie B. on this one and just say "meh."

It's not that the food was bad or the service was terrible (even though every piece of the meal, from the complementary water to the main course to the bill, were brought to our table by a different person), but does anyone actually believe that Delfina is Italian food?

The menu seemed to lack variety. I looked at the thing and just thought, "that's it?" The halibut I got was good, but not $26 good. The meal overall was tasty, but not $100 tasty. Not to mention reading the menu made me feel like an idiot because I am not a food snob and had no idea what half the words meant.

Go to Delfina Pizzeria next door instead.
author: Alexis C.

description: Good service, good beer. We didn't try the wine because we are not in the mood but tons of ppl order the wine...The portion of the dish is little bit small but i guess you are not suppose to be full by entree. Therefore we ordered dessert. Dessert is ok not really recommended. But the fries is pretty special, a hint of ginger makes the fries taste fresh and not too oily.
author: Shin T.

description: Five stars are not enough...should have more stars!  Perfection!  Hands down my favorite Italian restaurant in SF.  Service is excellent.  Vegetable dishes made from fresh, local produce.  Bread from next door.  I try to take all my friends there when possible.  The pasta in tomatoe sauce is incomparable and my favorite. Such a simple dish, and so extraordinary.
author: Felice K.

description:
3.5

like most, wanted to eat here for while but reservations are difficult; unfortunately it's popularity is not justified, 

i will say it does have an elegance to the dishes but really can find same quality of food in more than dozens of places in the city without the hassle of reservations, better prices; also found the portion sizes to be small, cannot get away with just entree, or pasta.
author: Peter L.

description: My friend and I embarked on a mission to try this restaurant, as it is supposedly the best Italian restaurant in the city.  We were not disappointed.  The spaghetti was wonderful with a hint of olive oil.  The break was tasty - fresh from Tartine.  The gnocchi was soft and with all the right spices of garlic and seasoning.  We topped off our dinner with a Scharffenberger chocolate cake which was crispy and warm on the outside and gooey in the inside.  Heavenly!
author: Joanna S.

description: YUMMY!  One of my favorite restaurants in the City.  Just getting a reservation at 7 pm on a Saturday makes me feel like I've defied the Fates and became the master of my own destiny!  The Insalata del Campo is to die for.  The flat iron steak and the chicken are great too.
author: Julie H.

description: When you're good you're good.  I can't say enough about this place.  The food is sublime.  Never overdone.  Fresh, simple, seasonal ingredients perfectly combined.  Great waitsaff that actually know about the food they are serving and are knowledgeable about wine as well.  Host with no attitude even if you call on Friday for a Friday reservation.  Divine.  Oh and even a chocolate lover will swoon over the panna cotta ... a must have dessert.
author: Ingrid C. L.

description:
i guess i could start eating dinner at 10 pm from now on...or i could just go in for the pannacotta.
not a whole lot for vegetarians to choose from though.
i need at least a 2nd visit before giving 5 stars.
author: Adrienne Y.

description:
Simple, well prepared food. I wish they had more on their menu or it changed more often, but it's a dependable restaurant. Reservations are recommended otherwise you may have to wait a while at this dinky restaurant or eat at one of the walk in tables or countertop. 

I recommend the roasted chicken and the tripe all fiorentina.
author: Cary W.

description:
personaly i don't see what all the buzz is about. it is loud and cramped. the waitress was a bitch. the food was so-so. the tripe good (needed alot of salt) and the quail was boring. the prices were also way to high. 

the pizzeria menu looks good although walking by i noticed that the pizzas are quite small. barely enough for one person
author: nate C.

description:
The food: excellent! For starters we had the calamari dish and the mozzarella with what seemed like pickled vegetables and peppers dish.  For me the calamari was fishy, but for Zbikh it was delicious and he couldn't get enough of it, esp. the beans that came with it.  The mozzarella was milky and together with the thinly sliced pickled zucchinis gave a fusion of tempered flavor.  The main entres: I had the short rib- which by the description from our server was true to form- it fell right off the bone.  It had just the right amount of fat to make it juicy, the tomato based sauce was tangy and full of body, and the polenta that accompanied was warm, buttery, and not too cheesy- which made the whole dish pretty close to perfect.  Other dishes at our table was the flank skirt steak- which again to Zbikh who ordered it, it was done to the T- tender and tasty, I on the other hand thought it was a little rubbery.  My other friend ordered the chicken with Yukon potatoes and she was happy.  For desert: the profiteroles were a hit and the buttermilk panna cota was light and delicate.

The service: the host was genial and seated us fairly quickly.  Our server was delightful- she was accommodating without being pushy.  With a 10:00pm reservation, we were her last table and so she let us relax and moved with our pace.  She was well informed about the dishes and took our playfulness at asking her all kinds of questions from the pertinent to the silly with stride.  We liked her a lot.

Why didn't Delfina get 5 stars?  The decor and layout.  The decor had a trite industrial feel- they had buttoned padding like blankets that resembled blankets movers use to safe-guard furniture.  The seating was too close together, I don't like rubbing elbows with total strangers especially while I'm dining- heck that's why I don't use public transportation.  

Overall experience:  As Delfina has been rated as one of the top eateries in SF- a pretty big statement as we have a gazillion restaurants- WE were satisfied with our meal.  We thought we received great service and yummy food for a decent price.
author: J S.

description: Let me start at the end. I seriously just had the best gnocchi ever! Could just as well have been M&M's the way it melted in by mouth! Even the greens (nettles?) were awesome (they tasted like roasted garlic or maybe truffle oil).  The Arugula salad was incredible and I don't even like arugula! I also had the spaghetti which was perfect and made me appreciate al dente like I never have before. Lastly but firstly was the crostini appetizer which was filling enough for a whole meal, luckily everything else was so good that I didn't stop there. (btw, don't try cutting the crostini into portions or else you will have them all over you or your date. Just bite into portions). Anyway the food was so good it deserves 5 stars, however I was starving when I walked in and had to wait too long for even some bread.
author: John S.

description: The food is fabulous - you can count on anything you order being delicious. The desserts are always amazing too - so save room to share at least two! (I recommend the cheese plate).
author: Bridget W.

description:
to my way of thinking, Delfina is an instantly classic, affordable San Franciscan restaurant in the same company as places like Range.  if you woke up from a coma and found yourself sitting at a table here, you'd know you were in SF,  and you'd be very, very lucky because Delfina is a challenge when it comes to booking a table.

5 of us for an early sunday in late spring made for a delightful evening.  perfect food.  appetizers/salads: salted cod, insalata del campo, anchovies.  entrees: pork shoulder (wow!), bucatini, agnolotti and halibut (double wow!)  desserts: profiteroles all around.

the prices are right on the border of spectacularly cheap for the quality.  service hits a perfect note.  food is crazy good.
author: Geoffrey W.

description: It's not like Delfina needs more praise, but it was deeeelicious!!!
author: Elina R.

description:
all i can say is this: flavor explosions.  this place wins the award for best food i've had in san francisco.  to go into too much detail would lessen the simple greatness that delfina deserves.  i know the menu changes, but here is what my group had, and i recommend every single dish:

warm marinated olives
ensalata di campo
snap peas and mushrooms
french fries (seriously, great!)
fresh bread (wonderful, and free!)

halibut with potatoes and artichoke hearts
pork loin scallopini (truly incredible)
gnocchi with stuff

chocolate cake with vanilla creme anglais
profiteroles with espresso ice cream and fudge
prosecco float with sorbet
panna cotta


all were wonderful. the consensus was that this was one of the best meals everyone had ever had - and trust me, the food experience at my table was substantial.  overall, a great food experience.  if you can afford it (i generally can't), eat here as much as possible.
author: jeremy f.

description: Quite possible my most favorite restaurant in the city. Delfina present very approachable food matched with excellent service. Eating at the bar can be really interesting as you'll see how much hustle goes on in the kitchen. I'm still trying to duplicate the salt cod brandade at home but haven't been able to do it as well as Delfina does.
author: Clodel G.

description: I'm deeply conflicted about giving Delfina any less than five stars, b/c I have without doubt had some of the best Italian food of my LIFE here.  That said, our last time here things seemed a bit "off".  Starters were great as always - the warm white beans and grilled calamari are always incredible - but the pasta courses and main dish seemed underwhelming, somehow less mind blowingly orgasmic than usual.  Perhaps it's a bit unfair since I remember being blown away by this place in times past, and the food, however good, suffers unjustly in comparison with those halcyon, untouchable, impossible memories.  I'll be back regardless - that damn calamari is, per Robert Palmer, simply irresistible.
author: Enriquito A.

description:
I lived next door to this place for a year.  The food is outstanding, no doubt.  That's why you come here.

The service can be downright surly, and can be inconsistent on busy nights (which, unfortunately, is almost every night).  The wait staff tends has a high count of uber-trendy hipsters dressed in black.  They think highly of themselves, to say the very least.

They really pack in the tables, so you can be elbow-to-elbow with your neighbors very often.
author: Chris F.

description: One of the top restaurants in the city... and not priced as such.  Book ahead as it is hard to get in!
author: Kurosh H.

description: Yum, yum, yum!  This place is so freaking good.  Every single thing we ordered was fantastic.  My mother-in-law did not stop talking about the pasta for a week!  I had the salmon, which was perfect.  The suggested glass of shiraz was also perfect and was fantastic paired with my meal.  The server was very friendly and on top of it the entire time.  I also love that it was a Friday night and they had no problem seating three of us.  I will be back to try more!!
author: Rise G.

description:
i've frequently loved dining at delfina. it is the quintessential san francisco restaurant: cosy and confined, with a décor that relies on simplicity and elegance, while offering a small menu where each item is given ample attention and often exceeds expectations.

sometimes, it is best to make a spontaneous visit in order to savour just one dish -- tops two -- together with a glass of wine.

tonight, we opted for the sardines seared in olive oil and sage. excellent, delicate, salty, mouthwatering. perfect.
author: christian svanes k.

description: Overrated "uber" trying too hard to be an alternative hot spot. Service was ok, at best.  Waited 20-25 minutes for our appetizers - olives and calamari! I had the seefood stew, which was your run of the mill.  My wife had the ahi, which was ok.  Overall over priced and over hyped. But if you use"uber" more than once a week then this is the spot for you.
author: Abraham Y.

description: Delfina used to be one of my absolute favorite restaurants. I loved eating there which I did dozens of times. I haven't been in a year and a half so it came as a big disappointment when I recently revisited the place with my partner to celebrate our anniversary. Things started out great, our table was waiting when we arrived. We were greeted warmly and generally throughout the night the service was good except that it took an inordinately long time to be offered the opportunity to have a glass of wine. For the first glass of wine we each had the Prosecco, I got a reasonable pour but my poor partner got only about 2/3rds of the amount of wine that I did. The same thing happened later when we each ordered a glass of red wine. I received about 6 ounces and he only got about 4 ounces even though his was almost twice as expensive as mine. Again, I felt bad for him. The food was not as good as it had been in the past. I had the grilled calamari and beans. I received two calamari while the table next to us (3 inches away) received the same dish with three calamari. The beans were kind of dry and not as plentiful or flavorful as they were in the past when I have ordered the same dish. And the calamari tentacles were burned which made them inedible. There is nothing worse than the taste of burned calamari. Our main dishes were good as was my partner's desert. But my desert, the chocolate torta, was a big disappointment. I used to love the warm chocolate cake they served with cream anglaise. The chocolate torta which seems to have taken its place was basically a round chocolate brownie. It was very dry and had a funny taste like it had been left uncovered in a refrigerator for a couple of days. The promised caramel sauce was just a smudge on the plate. I should have skipped desert and just has ice cream at Bi Rite. Overall, prices are up, they no longer give you those wonderful olives, they charge that annoying health fee on your bill and you have to ask for bread. Alas, Delfina no longer seems worth the cost. It is very sad to see such a good restaurant slip. Oh well...
author: Lee D.

description: did not meet my expectations. i went here once with a friend and my parents. we only got pasta, so this is basically a review of the pasta. i can't speak of the non-pasta entres. of the four pastas we ordered, the only one i really liked was the spaghetti. The spaghetti was awesome; noodles perfectly done and sauce very yummy with plenty of delicious oil! i had the wild boar with penne type pasta. it was pretty good. the other two were not as good and i would not recommend them. one was a chicken ravioli type thing and the other was tagliatelli sp? the atmosphere was cool. i really like the skylights. the wait staff was fine. in conclusion get the spaghetti.
author: Geoff B.

description: Mushroom pizza was awesome. The wait can be long even if you make a reservation.
author: Samantha K.

description: Great food - the pasta is out of this world.  Among other things, we had the simple spaghetti with tomato sauce and it was one of the best pasta dishes I've ever had!  My only problem was that it was so loud we had to hunch across the table to talk and couldn't hear our waitress.  I guess that contributes to the casual feel, but if I'm spending what it costs me for a week's worth of groceries on one meal, I want to be able to talk about it!  And rubbing elbows with the people at the table next to you doesn't make it very romantic, though you do get to see what they order.  (also, the guy who complained about them not bringing him bread didn't look carefully at his menu - it says right there you have to ask for it!)
author: Justine O.

description: outstanding italian cuisine!  menu changes daily and they have a wonderful wine selection.  parking is a pain in the butt but the restaurant is fantastic!
author: Laurens V.

description: SIMPLY the best Italian in the West Coast.. Every time I'm in SF, I make it a point to eat here!! If I'm in town for a few nights, I might make reservations here for both, it's that good.. The service, price, and freshness of the food, is TOO GOOD TO MISS.. The pastas are to die for....
author: Gleanlife G.

description: Did not live up to the hype but was still very good Italian food.  However, this place is nothing special.  Most of the dishes you can easily make in your own kitchen.  The prices are pretty unreasonable for the quality and creativity of the dishes.
author: Daniel B.

description: I've been here a few times and it's always been consistent service. The squid appetizer is to die for, and so are the other seafood entrees. Their desserts are awesome - try the semifreddo and you'll go home with a very happy tummy...
author: Tami Y.

description: I thought the food was great and reasonably priced. the all female waitstaff was cool. Best french fries I think I've ever had.   With all that said, with reservations, still had to wait about 30 minutes to be seated and service definitely did not match the write-ups I've read.
author: Amy H.

description: I've been here several times, and the wait to get a reservation has been worth it every time. The food is always outstanding. They keep it simple so the flavors really come through. The staff is very knowledgeable about the food and the wine.
author: Micki S.

description: Great food at a reasonable price. The atmosphere is good but the food is what makes this place awesome. There is a wait for seating food and service at times but well worth it. Anyway isn't that why you get a bottle of wine with dinner?
author: Brian M.

description: Good?  Yes.  A one month waiting list for a reservation?  Not worth it!  The Chicken here is the best in the city, blowing past even Zuma.  If you can sit outside then you are in for a real treat.  The staff is friendly and very helpful.  The inside is a bit cramped and they certainly are trying to make the most out of every square inch of space they have.  You will see people sitting in not so comfortable places just to get some of that chicken grease all over thier fingers and chins.  The Bathrooms are Unisex and are modern, clean and cool.
author: Pele N.

description:
love love love this restaurant. if it were a boy, i'd love to marry it (and have it feed feed feed me)

there are lots of fabulous places to eat in the city, but this has to be the best bang for your buck. top 10 at least. it's not cheap, but the quality is superb.

the ambiance is lively and despite the fact that it's almost always packed, surprisingly the noise level is not above 2.5 bombs (out of 5)-- i can always carry on conversation with friends. the service has always been stellar as well, i agree with sugar b.-- not saccharine sweet service but attentive and spot on (my favorite waitress is the one with the shootingstar wrist tats). and of course the food and presentation-- nothing to complain about on that front whatsoever! AND parking is usually not too bad. what a combo.

the only downside is that last-minute reservations are difficult. call a couple of weeks in advance to get prime dinner hours over the wkend.
author: AlfiHatesFlea S.

description:
mashed potatoes were fine, but definitely not mind blowing like everyone else has said.  the pork was very unique and definitely tasty if you're ready for one of the richest dishes you've eaten. salad and bread were great (bread is a great barometer for a restaurant) and ive had the pizza here before and its also quite good.

no hot waitresses though. not sure what the other yelper was referring to. overall solid, but there are better places in sf (and in the mission).
author: Nick T.

description: Just one of those Italian restaurants where everyone is guaranteed to have a good meal. No matter what else you order, do yourself a favor and get the spaghetti--always perfectly al dente and cooked in the sauce. The menu changes frequently, but the ingredients are always fresh and the service is impeccable. You should not pass on the desserts, esp the panna cotta and profiteroles. Reservations are highly recommended any evening, but definitely on the weekends (at least one week in advance).
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
Yes, I like. Notice you can tell so much about a place from the first call you make to the restaurant/reservations desk. The woman was so incredibly nice and friendly. Wonderful service. I took my picky picky father, who ended up loving the place - this is saying a lot. He is a picky Spanish man who has had amazing food for like 60 + years. He had the ribs - which he was also not able to finish, which again, is out of character. I had a dish I didn't care for and they gladly and openly took it away and offered another dish free of charge. The soup was incredible, as was the salad. the spinach on the side was a little plate of orgasmic heaven. And the home-made bread? What? Home-made. Yes, it was incredible. Not to mention the fantastic ambience. It was so beautifully lit, great space, nice vibe, great location. So pleasing. And it really felt like you could go smartly dressed or dressed down a bit in some workout clothing. How fantastic is that? it's fabulous. thanks Delfina!
this is a place that would be good on a regular basis. what is the con here: parking.
author: Jess P.

description: My absolute favorite restaurant. The atmosphere is lively, the wait staff is the friendliest I have ever encountered, and the food is always amazing. I always leave in a good mood.
author: Sarah N.

description: If your visiting friends are foodies, treat them to a delectable meal at this rustic Italian classic in the Mission. Every dish is mouth wateringly delicious, even at 10:30pm. Other Yelpers complained about the service but if they wanted fast food they should have gone to The Olive Garden or Burger King. Our server was helpful and awesome: she reserved the last lamb of the night for me and had explanations and suggestions about the dessert menu.  You're here to experience the food. One star off for the atmosphere (crowded, loud and low lit) and the fact that they turn making a dinner reservation into a chore.
author: Jessica M.

description: I really don't know why people like this place. I mean..the ambiance is nice..maybe I was just expecting a lot more. I can't cook, but i'm sure I can make something 10 times better than what I got the day I came here for dinner. I got the spaghetti and it did NOT satisfy me at all. It tasted undercooked and the sauce was nothing special. Maybe it's just the spaghetti, but I was hoping it'd taste better considering this is such a talked about restaurant.
author: Cris L.

description: delfina, delfina, it was on my list of restaurants to try going on year 2.  Either due to no available reservation or that I simply didnt remember to think of this restaurant at the time of need, we didnt get to go.  But finally after making a last minute reservation be it early 5pm due to someone's cancellation, I tried this place and it was great.  Light fresh cherry bellini as an appertif, then with steamed octopus so tender as appetizer, and with the pork chop as entree (not greasy but juicy instead) it was fabulous.
author: anita c.

description: This place is wonderful but it is becoming a little bit of a scene. I don't want to see and be seen, I just want to eat good food. The roast chicken is fantastic and I order it everytime we go. The service has always been good. A few times I've gotten in by just walking up and have lucked out when they've had cancellations.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
A solid 4 stars.  

I had the anchovy pizza.  Considering how much closer it is to me than North Beach, I'll definitely be hitting this place up.  Being next to Tartine's and Bi-Rite Creamery helps alot too. :)

The lines get pretty long.  My friend and I were lucky enough to get a spot at the counter for dinner.
author: Chris C.

description: This place is well worth the early and/or late reservation.  Their appetizers were wonderful, the service was friendly and the prices were fair for what you received.
author: Ani N.

description: This is the place were you go when you're Italian and you don't feel like cooking tonight.  Always delicious, fresh, authentic and memorable.  The pizzeria next door is also fantastic.
author: michael p.

description:
this will be a short review for now...

but i went there for my Mom's birthday dinner (table for 4). it took about 2.5 week to get the time and date I wanted, which is pretty good since they book up quiet fast. 

Service: Had a carrot top (hair only) waiter, which provided excellent service. It was knowledgeable with the food and knew how to give us the proper space we needed, instead of being a sales type of waiter that bugs us every 2 minutes. He did get a lil warmer feeling as the night went on..

Food: Started with this Crispo type of Dish (three pieces of sliced bread w/ spread on top). The pate was exquisite and the bean spread was awesome. For dinner I had the goat.. tasted like lamb with a hint of mint. Besides it being very delicious it does has a similar taste and texture to lamb. Prepared beautifully and would highly recommend. From what the waiter said .. its going to by in the New York Times.

Overall: great time + good service + great wine selection..
author: Jon N.

description:
What a Disappointment to finally meet  Delfina
I always wanted to try this place.  Their reviews and recommendations from friends and magazines created anticipation for this dining experience.  As I was trying to understand my mediocre entree, I was wondering if there is something wrong with my palate as the dining rooms was full, them I observed that no one was eating with a smile and perhaps some of the other patrons were busy with the same thoughts. 
Flavor: Salt and Pepper were forgotten back inside the kitchen.
Service: Kind and friendly, but slow in response to patrons needs.
Portions: Small portions for the price which reflects on  the management and ownership of maximizing their profits, this especially for the bread, and olive oil, if you have dined here, you know what my point is.
Perhaps, I waited too long and Delfina has changed and become the type of restaurant that you want to avoid.
author: Bela M.

description:
after an aborted attempt to shop at zoe's bikini for an upcoming trip to Cabo (is that shop EVER open?), me and the girlie decided to not make the trip to the low-property value district of SF a total waste.  so kicking aside the syringes and the used condoms, we parked near Capp street and 18th and wanted to venture into Delphina's.  When i first started working in SF, back when i still lived in L.A., this was one of the very first restaurants that i ever went to.  this was maybe ten years ago and i was going to the HOT, NEW restaurants in SF even back then.  well, i did like the place but i didn't have facial hair, a leather jacket, nor a visible tattoo so i didn't think they would let me back into the Mission.  anyway, i liked it but hadn't been back since. 10 years later, supposedly it's still one of the 'hot/cool' spots so , okay, let's check it out.  we're stuck, we got a parking spot, we've already gotten used to the smell in the MIssion, why not?  

amazing.  the place is still buzzing and busy even on a MONDAY night. they were full ! ? what?  monday?  that's just stupid. anyway. they did have a table by the kitchen which was really not bad at all.  no one bumped us, we could get our waiter any time we wanted.  it was pretty cool.  the girlie, if she wears leather and stands in the rain is about 92 pounds and has the stomach the size of a peanut.  so i got tired of wishing we didn't order so much so i went with the option of 2 appetizers and sharing one entree.  this was a good idea.

it just so happened that we picked 2 very light salads (the caprese and another green salad) and a light, Sand Dab, entree.  the sand dabs were awesome.  the girlie took them off the bone while i yapped about my super-exciting story of how i bought my house against all odds.  we shared a half bottle of champagne (it was a MONDAY, after all).  points to Delphina for having a half bottle of champagne but half point off for only have a $48 option.   

the salads and single entree were light enough to get the panna cotta dessert - very nice!  and a dessert wine - too sweet!  

all in all, servcie was excellent - probably because of our table by the kitchen.  the food was very good. the champagne and dessert wine were solid.  the girlie was cute as ever so 4.4 stars rounding down to 4.  taking some points off for small selection and not a ton of options for light appetizers and entrees.
author: dan h.

description: Not 'wowed' for the price you pay.  Everything was good, but nothing was great.  I feel wowed by most things I eat at Beretta and also at Alembic, while spending half the money I just spent at Delfina.
author: Tom Z.

description:
We went to Delfina a couple of weeks ago and had a very good experience. Their reputation as a solid Italian restaurant in the city is very justified. 

The octopus salad was probably the stand out item there. I don't normally choose octopus out of the menu, but had read about this appetizer so decided to give it a try. It definitely was well worth. Very fresh, and very creative with a lemon-infused sauce.

We decided to sample the pasta, so we ordered gnocchi with a ragu sauce (the gnocchi was very soft, the sauce was flavorful, but it didn't taste as fresh as it could have); we also had ravioli with prosciutto, and that dish had a hand-made, very fresh feel. 

The final dish was spaghetti which was perfectly al dente, but it reminded me of a similar textured spaghetti dish I had at A16 a month prior. The A16 version very creatively incorporated mint, and the surprising flavor won me over. The Delfina version, by comparison, seemed more common. That is actually how I would sum up my Delfina experience: solid, it delivers on expectations, but it is not as inventive as A16. It did not surprise me, and it didn't delight me. 

The service was also slow, but the bread excellent. I would go back next time I want to eat Italian, and can't get a table at A16.
author: A W.

description: Pretty good restaurant but I feel it is a little tiny bit overrated especially the wine list isnot at 5 stars level. The Nero d'avola was mediocre.
author: stephan c.

description: Warm marinated olives with bread, salad, hanger steak with real steak frites...awesome. And yes yes of course the panna cotta was legendary. I'm just not sure if I'm feeling the whole very expensive-casually dressed-rushed service-modern decor-rustic Italian-in the Mission thing.
author: Abbie B.

description:
This place is really tasty. And the Tartine bread is just the most fabulous thing ever. It really detracted from the rest of the food. I was speechless after the first bite.

I had the spaghetti which was the most flavorful I've ever had, a truly beautiful experience. My husband got a fish special (swordfish?). There were two large pieces but one wasn't cooked all the way through.

This place is expensive so be prepared to pay $50 with no apps or drinks. Service is good, atmosphere is crowded.
author: Sarah J.

description: I came from Los Angeles and several people in the food industry here referred us to Delfina. When my boyfriend and I sat down, I will be honest, we were a bit disappointed by the decor- very 90s, cluttered with mediocre art on the walls, and mirrors all around (really only belong in a French bistro.)  We had a glass of Carmignano that was so good, we decided to buy the bottle- reasonable for the good quality at $50. However, the waitress did not let us know it would clash with our food- which it did. We ordered 3 courses and shared each. We started with a warm chicory salad with homemade croutons, whic was absolutely delicious, but it got our hopes up too high for the next 2 courses. The mint tagliatelle with chanterelles and nettles sounded incredible, but came out bland and clashed horribly with our wine. Next, we had a braised beef with polenta, pomegranate sauce and pine nuts. The flavors were good, not great and the meat was overcooked, making us feel cheated because it cost nearly $40! We ordered a side of turnips and greens. There were very few turnips and, again, very bland... For close to $200, I felt it was really NOT worth it. I can see how Delfina might have been an influential place, for its fine food in a casual atmosphere- emblematic of California cuisine- but the place is just dated now and the food mediocre. I gave it three stars because our waitress gave us fine service- she was subtle and intuitive- just perfect. If I do return, I will just order a bowl of pasta (the heartier pasta dishes looked good) and share a bottle of wine (the sommelier must be good, judging by our Carmignano.) However, I will stay away from the main courses (overpriced) and the sides (bland.) Or perhaps I don't need to revisit the restaurant- the pizzeria next door looked hipper and is less expensive.
author: NORA L.

description: By far my favorite restaurant in the city. We celebrated a "significant" birthday here not too long ago. We were seated right on time for our 7:30pm reservation. The service was out of this world and my family was in awe of the food.  The little gem salad (with egg) was phenomenal as was the grilled calamari, warm olives, and crab linguine.  I wish I lived closer I would eat here every night if I could...
author: Win S.

description: A great place there to take a date. My fiance took me there when we were first dating and got major points from me!
author: Crisa M.

description: The best special occasion or date place ever! Simple, delicious, smart dishes, nice wines by the glass (good if I'm the only one drinking it...), homey but refined feeling. As an ex waitress, this place actually seems like a nice place to work too!
author: Bethanne S.

description: It's not easy to get a reservation, but they do handle walk-in customers well. The menu changes daily, ingredients are fresh, and flawlessly prepared. And it's a value -- it's not nearly as expensive as many restaurants with not-so-good food. Delfina is one of the best places in town for an amazing meal.
author: tout le monde a.

description: Excellent food!! best creative Italian restaurant in San Fran. love it! Nothing to compain, excellent all around.
author: D P.

description:
laura b. (up there) is tres populaire. Yep. She is like the head Yelp or something and we're all her evil minions. Flailing away trying to write decent reviews for you to read. Sob.

Anyways, I mention laura since I was here and was eagerly waiting for the cute waitstaff.  They were there all right. Geez.

Oh yeah, the fud. Delicious. I liked the scallops but be wary if you're not into sushi. It was practically raw. Thinly sliced and terribly delicious. I also had the hanger steak and I substituted mashed potatoes for fries. I got the fries but no mashed. When I finally got my waitress' attention (it was busy), the mash came out a little later it was holy god amazing. Yum! I wish i could sit in a tub of it and eat my way out. (Not a good visual, eh?)  My steak was awesome too since I love my steaks rare and they actually served it to me rare. Thank God! I just wish they would offer a better cut of meat.

That's about it. Great ambiance, great service, awesome food, just about perfect. Since the Slanted Door left our area for that faraway place known as touristville, it's nice to have an option for a grown up meal. Thank you Delfina, I kiss you.

p.s. the country bread from tartine's was about the best bread I have ever eaten in my life. Oh. My. God.
author: Tracy Y.

description: Dining at Delfina is like dieing and going to Gourmet Heaven.  OMG... the crusty sourdough bread with an incredible bite is served first and the dining experience begins. I plant my boodie at the bar and order my favorite entree "tripe alla Fiorentina" made to perfection as if I were in Italy.  I've had fresh buffalo mozzarella before, but never as yummy as here.  The waitress said they pull their own.  How cool is that?  Love love love the service.  The servers know their stuff.  It helps when you're in a dilemma on what to order.  The homemade chocolate/mint gelato accompanied by chocolate shortbread cookies was a great way to end the meal.  Buon appetito!
author: Lizzie L.

description:
Absolutely one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  The food is fantastic with the freshest and best-quality ingredients.  Definitely authentic (not one of those with Californian influence on over half of their menu).  Wines are all well chosen .... I've had many bad Italian wines elsewhere but not here.  I would say that their desserts are not phenomenal though. People praise their panna cotta. It's good but not impressive. 

Overall, service is great.  My experience with the maitre d' and the servers have been always pleasant.  One star was taken away because it's just way too hard to make a reservation (it's not a big place).  However, if you can go to the restaurant at 5 pm or don't mind eating at the bar (first-come-first-served), there is still hope.

One final note:  It's obvious that most of their customers truly like and enjoy the food there.  (Instead of seeing some customers at restaurant sbeing rude, with a bad attitude, and having unrealistic expectations.)  Very satifying for me to know this, as this makes the atmosphere so much more comfortable.
author: mavisp p.

description: As long as you aren't expecting to be seated right away, this is a great place to satiate your taste buds!!  Grab a glass of wine and chat with a friend while you people watch...  The food is incredible and the people watching never ending!
author: Jules S.

description: Crazy good...bordering ridiculous!  Everything on the menu is great, but have you ever had the chicken?  I know, not the sexiest thing on a restaurant menu, but this chicken is exceptional.  Let's not forget the other great things like, the location (I walk), to the service (very helpful and knowledgeable), to the energy (place is always hopping).  The food seems so simple, but when you take the first bite, you know how much went into making it the perfect dish!  Enjoy...
author: John A.

description: A friend and I came here for dinner and it was good stuff.  We had the Salt Cod Mantecato and Tomato and Mozz salad for appetizers.  Both were great, the tomatoes were heirloom and very fresh.  The Cod was like a spread and came with spicy flatcrackers - yummy.  We shared entrees and got half portions of the Gnocchi, Spaghetti and Rabbit Penne, all were impressive - I liked the Gnocchi the best and my friend, the Rabbit.  The service was good, although we missed the cute waiter guy that everyone was gushing about on Yelp.  I loved the people to the left and right of us, they were a walking advertisement for the food, talking about the flavors and presentations very happily and enthusiastically.  We didn't eat dessert here, thinking that we would go to the bakery down the street afterwards (too bad it was closed).
author: Lisa B.

description: I don't get all the hype. The food is fine but nothing special, which was sad because I chose the place for a special occasion. My gf and I shared three dishes and I'm not going to remember the names, so I'm sorry. The first was beans flavored with tomato and bacon. The beans were mushy but the flavor was good, so we deemed it okay. Unfortunately it turned out to be the highlight of the meal. We got the roast duck with figs, which was fine but the polenta that came with it was boring. The final thing was a pasta dish with pork and peppers. It was bad--the peppers totally took over. I'd been to Delfina once long before and figured that my lack of enthusiasm that time could have been a fluke. Not going to make that mistake again.
author: haley b.

description:
I'm giving it two stars based on Yelp's suggested translation of their star system. Two stars = "Meh, I've experienced better." 

So, I liked my Delfina experience, generally -- we had starters, salads, entrees, desserts and wine. All were good, except for my entree and the server's recommendation for my daughter's entree.  My daughter's entree  was their spaghetti dish -- it was very good BUT, despite our server's assurance that the dish was not spicy at all, was WAY TOO SPICY and thus inedible!  

My entree -- three small, overcooked scallops for $27! 

Okay, they were supposedly "Sea of Cortez Diver Scallops" -- can someone tell me, please, if there is something particularly rare, exotic, special about this type of scallop? Perhaps I was just unaware that I was eating the scallop equivalent of precious caviar? 

Whatever the case, the price for the dish seemed terribly mismatched and left me disappointed.
author: k n.

description: You know how when people keep raving about a movie and you finally see it and your expectations are so high that it would be near impossible to fulfill them? That's kind of how it was with Delfina. I finally ate there, and it was good, but it was not phenomenal. The service was wonderful, and it was loud but not more than most restaurants in SF.  The food was good but I was not bowled over. I wouldn't go out of my way to make reservations to eat here again. The back open space looked wonderful though.
author: Helen K.

description:
We had been wanting to go to Delfina for a year but never worked out.  And, perhaps it was because of the hype, but we found it to be highly overrated.  We ordered salad, the spaghetti, chard, sea bass and the lamb.  Salad and chard were fine.  Spaghetti was good, just know that it will be very spicy, but the main courses completely missed the mark.  The sea bass (which was a substitute on the date of this review for another fish that I cannot remember) was barely edible...and I never-ever say that.  It tasted like a frozen half-fried fish served with a spoonful of mayo.  The carrots were pickled way to much...tasting like I took a swig of vinegar.  The lamb (which I ordered) was extremely fatty and just not "wowing" coming from the reviews below.

My take...this is a restaurant for the marina crowd who wants to get some culture in the mission.  There are dozens of better restaurants.  Try Alamo Square grill...though it is french so dinner will take a good 2 hours, the food is much better and so are the prices.  Or, for the same price try Perbaca (sp?) that just opened in the financial district and finally Zyriab (sp) which is on divis and fell that wows me every time I go in.  Or, if you really need Italian, I wish I could remember the name but it is near Hyde and Pacific and the name changed a year ago...someone help me out if you can.

Overall, just bland dining and not worth the hype.  We won't be going back.  Though I will give credit where credit is due and our server was very knowledgeable and very attentive so those reviews are spot on.
author: Christopher C.

description: Why use any other words? Delfina is SF's best restaurant. Period.
author: Chris G.

description:
My mother was in town this weekend.  So after a meal at Boulevard on Friday, we decided to try Delfina on Saturday.  I can honestly say that it was better in nearly every way.  Aside from the beautiful view and incredible building that houses Boulevard, it topped it in every category.

We started with a bottle of wine.  I can't remember what it was, but the server helped us choose, and this was the only slight disappointment.  A fairly boring Italian red.  But not bad.

We then had a salad and monterey bay sardines.  The salad was great, and the sardines were as well.  I expected small sardines to put on the bread, but it was a huge one.  Lots of little bones, and really oily, but up there with the best spanish mackerel in my book.

For our entrees, I had the special of the night, some kind of Greek fish cooked whole.  It was absolutely incredible.  They presented it, then took it back to the kitchen for a long deboning process.  I almost offered to do it myself, but I'm glad they did, as it looked like quite a bony fish.  When it came back, it was easy to eat, moist, fresh, and with a really unique and nice flavor.  My mom had the chicken, which was local and organic, and she said it was excellent as well.

Also, don't leave here without trying the fries and potatoes!  I wish I could go back just to have a plate of fries, but I imagine the servers would hate me for that.  haha

Top notch meal.  This place lived up to its reputation.
author: Jeff W.

description: Wow! Not only good food, but great service! The chard was so amazing we had to order another side of it! I had the snail appetizer for dinner, my friends had the baked chicken and pork belly. Man, can they bake a chicken.... And though I found the belly a bit fat, it was belly... and, ohhhhh so yummy! Panicotta for dessert was like heaven on a spoon. You have to go! But make a rezy or get there early, cuz the lines are long....
author: Avonelle T.

description: Delicious pasta and amazing desert. I love how their menu changes so you can always be pleasantly surprised, like at Chez Panisse. I just wish it wasnt so hard to get a table there.
author: Kat G.

description:
What's there to say that hasn't been said already? 
Food, Wine, Dessert, all delicious.

Go Now. Love it. 

Try to sit out back. It's a very romantic space.
author: A L.

description: Fabulous food.  A little on the heavy side, but very flavorful.  It tends to get a bit loud inside, but it's overall a great place to enjoy some great food.  Service is awesome, parking is tough.  But well worth it.  Make sure you check this place out.  My fiance and I frequent this place on the weekends.  MMMM.
author: Heather B.

description: My husband and I went there on a Friday night with no reservation. We put our names on the list and were told it would be 45 minutes to an hour - which meant that we would eat at 10:30 pm. We ordered 2 glasses of wine and sat on the bench outside. Twenty minutes later we were seated at the bar table and wonderfully attended to by one of the hottest guys in SF. He was friendly, knowledgeable, and had a great sense of humor. The food was wonderful - we split 5 dishes (appetizers and side dishes) that were fantastically prepared. We didn't order any of the main courses since they didn't seem as interesting as the other courses. If you keep it light and varied, you'll have a great experience, and without fail - order the fries.
author: adriana E.

description:
Delfina rocks 

I have been to Delfina more than a few times. The last couple of times I went without a reservation and they really went out of their way to get us a table. Everything about their service is excellent, from the friendly, cheerful host to the knowledgeable and attentive wait staff.

And the food? My god, the food!  Last nite I think they said the restaurant was celebraing the pig.  And what's not to celebrate?  I can't remember the name of the dish I had but it was amazing.  Slices of pork from a whole roasted pig with a side of the most unique bread pudding that I've ever had.

Go here.  Wait if you have to.  It's worth it.
author: Jon F.

description: I finally ate here after wanting to try this place for years! The decor and atmosphere are warm, inviting, and convivial - although the noise level can make it challenging to follow conversations. The service is professional and friendly, and staff are knowledgeable  about menu items and the wine list. That said, the food did not blow me away as I expected. The starters - cooked greens, and a version of steak tartare - were too heavily salted. The short rib pasta was tasty, but again not spectacular. The wine - a Barbera - was excellent, however, and so were the French press coffee and the dessert, an extraordinary bay laurel panna cotta served with huckleberries.
author: Irene B.

description: This place is good for pizza and beer, but it is a bit pricey for what you're getting.  I've been looking for good NY style pizza since I moved to SF from Manhattan, and I'm still looking.  But Delfina is the 2nd closest to getting there, at least because of their margherita and the Salsiccio pizza.  The white pizzas, I'd avoid.  Also, generally, I'd say there's way too much crust.   But, for the price tag, it would be a 4-star pizza.  I've gotten better pies in NYC for 2/3 of the price.
author: A J.

description:
Almost tempted to give a 1-star... way overrated... 
Not the best SF food for your $.
