Has a streak to make some amazing dishes once in a while.. (Great city ambiance: We walk by frequently & have been drawn into try out their new daily menu over the past few years. It's just not in the top culinary experiences for SF.) 

Pizzeria Delfina next door is in top league, though.
author: Sri S.

description: it has awesome food . and great service. and there kid friendly . i like the insalata di campo
author: Maudie G.

description: More tank tops per capita than any other top restaurant in the city.  Plus always good conversation with the table over if you and your companion have nothing more to say to each other.  Now if people would just forget about you then we could be friends again.
author: Nate B.

description: Loved it.  Food and wine were both excellent.  Perhaps the best spaghetti I have had in my life.  Given that you have to make reservations a month in advance, this is like the restaurant equivalent of LeBron James when he went pro.  However, like LeBron, this place has got game.  Unlike LeBron, this place has (happily) no lousy ad campaign with Nike that makes me want to boycott all associated products.
author: Dan H.

description:
Server was gracious and went out of his way to explain many of the wines on the wine list. The rose we ended up with was perfect with our meal.

The classic spaghetti and roast chicken which were suggested to us were the low parts of our meal. The best: Dessert --- remarkably flavorful espresso profiteroles, tangy citrus panna cotta, and a perfectly rich chocolate cake. 

Overall, I do not think that Delfina is up to the Hype, but the meal was good and the wine was great.
author: Eric D.

description: 2 out of 3 times I have eaten here within two years I have been disappointed.  1st time - delfina was adequate; 2nd time - truly amazing; 3rd time - downright disappointing!  At 3rd meal, most items were good (not great), but one entree of fish was yuckily undercooked.  (Complimentary panna cotta was a nice gesture to compensate, but what a bland dessert.) Wine is still phenomenal, but the poors are stingy for the pricetag.  Service is adequate - good suggestions on wine and personable folks, but not very prompt.  This place seems to be very overrated.
author: Andrea S.

description: its good-- not amazing. The profiteroles are really good, but rich so make sure to share with the table. I had the nettle pasta which was good. my friend had the rabbit  gnocchi which was better. not really worth the hype though, perbacco has better pasta's. I wasn't too impressed with the menu didn't seem unique.
author: C. G.

description:
One of the finest dining experiences I've ever had and without the pretensions that usually go along with fine dining.  This place has a casual, easy-going and comfortable atmosphere, service that is exceptionally timely and educated and a kitchen that works miracles.

I took my parents here when they came into town for a visit.  We showed up 15 minutes early for our reservation and were shown right to our table.    My folks took a little convincing to order as much food as I wanted, but we ended up having 4 courses, sharing a bunch of things and two nice bottles of wine.  Everything was exceptional.  We had separate bills because I wanted to pay for the wine I picked out, and for the food total was so reasonable, I had to look at it twice to make sure it was correct.  For 3 people to have a 4-course top-notch meal the cost was under $130 dollars.  That might sound like a lot, but for the quality of overall experience, it felt like a bargain.

Highly recommended!
author: henry c.

description:
Let me start at the end.  Love the profiteroles.  Let me repeat, like Pavlov's dog, I start drooling thinking about that coffee ice cream and dark chocolate sauce when I see the restaurant.  Not pretty but the truth.

We have eaten at Delfina at least 15 times in the past couple of years.  Every time we go my partner has the spaghetti.  Every time!  It's simple but he calls it the best he's ever had.  If it's a bit pricey for what it is who's to argue with the pleasure it provides.

Some of the dishes can be intimidating for out-of -town guests.  And truth be told our savvy foodie friends have needed the help of decoder rings a few times as well.

As noted elsewhere, it is difficult to get a reservation and the space can be cramped.  Hey!  Have you ever eaten in a popular restaurant in NYC??

My biggest peeves:

Not taking parties of more than 6.  And having an attitude about it.

Adding a charge to the bill to provide health care benefits for employees.  That could really backfire.  Just raise the prices and be done with it.  Don't play the martyr on a political issue.  If I want that I'll go to a meeting of the SF Board of Supes.
author: Roger C.

description:
Our dinner:

Grilled calamari w/warm white beans - delicious  $9.25
Iceberg lettuce salad with gorgonzola dressing - delicious  $8.50
Chicken-mortadella agnolotti with lemon-chive burro fuso - excellent  $17
Roasted Liberty duck with nebbiolo-roasted cherries and Anson Mills polenta - excellent  $25
Pozzi Farms spring lamb with fresh fava beans and mint - flavorful  $29
Profiteroles - amazing  $8
Flourless Chocolate Cake (forget the name) - very good  $8
2 Syrah - okay  $10 each
1 Chardonnay - okay  $10
1 Capaccino - excellent $3.50

The food is delicious and very expensive.  The combination of flavors and the sauces are superb! But the venue isn't at all comfortable. You're seated at cold, hard, small aluminum tables with no tablecloth. Music plays loudly in the background and it's not 'easy listening.'

The wait staff are good, attentive, some are a bit casual for my taste. Our waitress described 1/2 dozen dishes on the menu as "It's a lot of fun."  For example, nettles salad. Yep, the field weeds that scratch the skin off your legs was on the menu tonight and she described the dish as "A lot of fun."  Rule of thumb: I don't buy weeds when I get a bouquet of flowers and I don't buy weeds when I sit down for a $100+ dinner.

The secondi pasta was excellent; unfortunately, only a small serving was on the plate. $17 is too much for "a taste" of pasta. It was delicious with interesting flavors and a perfect blend of chicken, bacon, lemon, cream, & chives.  To my surprise, it wasn't cooked al dente. No matter. It was very good, just too expensive for such a small portion.

The problem dish was the lamb. It was very flavorful and cooked rare. But the cut of meat sent from the kitchen was uneatable - a lot of fat and grizzle. First bite I couldn't chew it was so grizzly. It found its way to my napkin. The second bite, the same. Third bite, grizzle and fat ... no meat. I couldn't chew it. Again, into the napkin.

I stopped cutting the lamb and sighed, looking at my plate trying to figure out what to do. Fava beans, eat them. They were perfectly cooked and plain excellent. Melt in your mouth delicious! I ate the beans and stared at the plate again. One of the staff must have seen me from the bar area, as he appeared out of nowhere. He asked how everything was (our waitress was somewhere). I  asked him to please get a fork and take a bite of the lamb. I had cut a lot of grizzle and left it on the side of the plate, which he could see.  I pointed to a piece of meat and asked him to please taste it.  He didn't, but assured me the kitchen would. He saw the plate had many cuttings on the side and believed me.  I advised that there was as much unchewed lamb fat and tendon in my napkin as on the plate.  He offered to have the kitchen prepare another plate, a different cut. I declined. The food on the plate should be eatable, and it wasn't. I'm done with the lamb. Thank you.

I asked for the dessert menu. We ordered profiteroles and Delfina's flourless chocolate cake. Amazing. Delicious. Scrumptuous. Hazelnut ice cream, chocolate sauce to-die-for, sliced toasted almonds. And a quiet (subtle) fragrant warm flourless chocolate cake. They even placed a candle on the plate, having noticed the card on the table. Very thoughtful, and I was very, very grateful they didn't sing Happy Birthday.

By the time tax and medical insurance was added to the bill, dinner came to $124 before tip. No charge for the lamb. Given the reputation which Delfina and it's owners, Craig and Anne Stoll, have earned ... I expected more. I just wasn't a bit comfortable or relaxed at this restaurant. The hard surfaces, uncomfortable chairs, loud crummy music left me happy to pay the bill and go. 

I can now say that I've been there, but have no plans to go back.
author: Martin G.

description:
Tasty, tasty, tasty... what more could you ask for than TASTY you ask? How about incredible service, down to earth owners,  some of the best produce in grown in California, house cured meats, generous portions, reasonable prices, elegant simplicity and and Tartine bread with dinner? Yup... that sounds like five stars to me. 
   As hard as it is to get a reservation here don't let that discourage you. The atmosphere is unpretentious and the people who work here are incredibly well versed in their food and wine. Go early and try to snag a seat at the bar or the counter. Otherwise - call ahead and commit to going  on some random date for no special reason at all. This experience is likely to turn the most ordinary and mundane of evenings into something extraordinary and beautiful.
author: Lizzy L.

description:
Look...they just rock. Dishes to die for (the pork...the pasta, the steak with frites...Good Lord)!

Servers are Mission-Flavor Beautiful (boys and girls), and always professional. The brunette hostess went that extra mile to write down the song that was rockin' their stereo (Citizen Cope).

A true gem.
author: Tonya M.

description: First time there early on a rainy Tuesday night last week.  My wife and I absolutely loved it.  Friendly and informed staff.  Excellent service.  Outstanding food across the board.  Exceptional wines.  Totally professional.  Good vibe.  The whole package.  A near perfect upscale but unpretentious neighborhood trattoria.  I can see why this restaurant is a local institution.  Wish I'd stopped by a long time ago.
author: Kirk M.

description: I've been to this restaurant several times in the last 12 months and I have to say, I have not been disappointed.  The food is good. Wine selection has enough offerings to suite the company, the food, the celebration. Servers are friendly and gracious without being intrusive or pushy. Only downside is the crazy parking.  I took the BART the last time and it's only a half mile walk.
author: Fishcalldwanda K.

description: the wait is worth it... it's such a fun place to grab a pizza.. and the pizza is delicious...my favorite is the Prosciutto Pie... the crowd is fun and so are the waiters/waitress.... I like sitting on the stools and watch them make the pizza...
author: Jay S.

description: Very disappointed in this place, apparently they now have two TV Screens showing the game?!?!?! WTF, if I wanted to watch the game I would have gone out to a bar and spent less then what I am spending at Delfina. This is ridiculous especially in upscale places where plates cost over $30. Last thing I want when I'm dropping $300 on a meal is hearing someone scream out the score and cheer on their team. Seriously, if you want to watch the game go to a F#@king bar!! I hope Delfina lowers their prices to accommodate the fans that prefer to watch the game while at dinner at this place. I strongly discourage anyone going to this place and paying their prices while the World Series is going on. Unless you enjoy dropping $300 while having to put up with screaming baseball fans at the other end of the restaurant. So much for a nice romantic dinner out....................
author: Jim G.

description: Absolutely great food. The chicken is my favourite! I can easily say my favourite italian restaurant in SF!
author: T G.

description:
I've heard a lot of buzz about this place.  Never written one of these reviews before, but my waitress said, "If you're so impressed, Yelp me." (What the hell did that mean?)  Well, that sounded like a challenge, and being in the stunt biz, I'm a man always up for one those especially when put forth by a purty lady. 

Here's how it went down... went with one of my surfing ladies who likes herself some red meat.  Since I'd never been I asked our server (who actually smiled when she said hello to us) what she recommended.  That's when she said, "Well, what I would like to see you have is...." Okay, I mean, who says that?!  What waitron ever walked you through your ideal dining evening?  After that, I was like a little purring kitty-cat in her hands. 

She recommended the Niman Ranch carpaccio --- a fresh plate of pounded beef on radicchio sliced thin-style with some parmesan shavings on top and with salty capers just the right amount of S&P.  Also a gem salad with some crunchy cheesy crispy thing and this light anchovy dressing.  We were on our way!  Entrees -- the lady's steak with french fries that had some rosemary and sage.  Our server Alissa did the hard-sell on the braised short ribs, and in that tomato and balsamic sauce they were some tasty, manly goodness.  Dessert was a god-like panna cotta -- usually this guy doesn't like anything with the word "gelatin" in it, but this was some tarty, creamy good shizzle.  Did I mention the wine?  Don't know much about that Italian swill, but our gal asked us what 'made us happy' when drinking.  I loved this woman; she was all about MY NEEDS!  So after 3 options and much-o descriptive-o wine-o talk, she led us to a Sassetti(?) Brunello di Montalcino.  I gotta say, that was the pick of the century, the dried cherry and hint o'chocolate --- it went down real easy.

As for the all the buzz, I was like a bee who'd found its honeycomb!
author: Zephyr C.

description: Hands down- the best restaurant in the City.  Consistently great food, knowledgeable staff, & the fact that I have never been disappointed.  If you are looking for authentic Italian food- this is the place.  I do think they could work on their wine list a bit though,  I haven't been too impressed - but the food all than makes up for it.  Mi raccomando!
author: Jill M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place... but I wasn't that impressed.

It's one of those restaurants that I kept wanting to try and I expected the food to be amazing. But it was just ok. Maybe it was what we ordered. Or maybe it's just me. 

We had several apps and the mozzarella was good, but of the three we ordered, none were particularly memorable.

For my entree, I got the pasta tubes in red sauce with seabass (the italian name escapes me now) The server warned me ahead that the pasta would be very "al dente" and I was ok with that. She was right, it was quite firm, but that wasn't the part that was displeasing. It was just character-less as a dish. It had no joy, no love. Maybe it's rustic and true to life, who knows? But the fish was really just flakes of seabass (seemingly more for flavoring than anything else) and the sauce was very fish-stocky. My husband is a chef for another restaurant in the city and his response was "I can't believe you're actually eating that."

My husband ordered the gnocchi with pork and his was quite good. So... that's a plus. If I went back, I'd probably get that. Or YOU out there... still to dine at Delfina... YOU get that.

We had gelato for dessert. It was gelato-y. I think I would have preferred to just go the cheaper route and have some of the rocky road I had in the freezer at home but, again, maybe that's just me.
author: Annabelle O.

description:
Delfina is probably the best southern Italian food in San Francisco.  It is without pretension and attitude, the service is efficient and the staff is personable and witty. The challenge is getting seated...

Tonight was our 10th time there, and the food just gets better.  Spaghetti is my favorite, along with the salt cod appetizer.

Because the restaurant is so popular (read: prone to crowds) and they offer food service at the bar, the turnover up front is very slow making it an uncomfortable place to park yourself while waiting for your table. Still, once you make it to the restaurant area, it's quite relaxed, with enough space around each table so that you don't feel like you're listening in on your neighbor's conversation.

Highly recommended if you miss the bold flavors of Southern Italian food.
author: Martha S.

description: My absolute favorite Italian rest in SF.  Delfina serves bread from Tartine, which is truly to-die-for.   Their dishes are all superb and the environment is inviting.   I give Delfina 5 stars.  Unfortunately, we're too lazy to make ressies in advance.  :)
author: Ali G.

description:
WORST PLACE EVER
i heard ok reviews about this place so i decided to give it a chance.   Everything was bad from the overpriced seafood to the terrible "im better than you are" glances we got from the staff.  Overall bad restaurant and i was very embarrised (being the host) to bring my close family here!
author: Katie B.

description:
For the third time in my life, Delfina delivered an outstanding meal I won't soon forget.  Overall 4 stars because so crowded, but the food is 5 stars for sheesy!  Tonight I had the hawaiian ahi with meyer lemon conserva, grilled fennel and canellini beans.  Oh. my. god.  Just stellar.  The ahi was perfectly cooked (med rare), grilled flavor, the acidic lemon conserva in a thin layer on top was a perfect bite, the grilled fennel perfectly soft, warm, sweet and very grilled tasting, then the creamy white beans all things together in my mouth was the perfect balance and the best fish dinner I've had in a long time.  the big chunk of ahi was so gawd dang meaty tasting!!  this is totally my favorite dish right now as of three hours ago.  whew.  I feel so much better getting that off my chest.  we also had the artichoke and salad di campo, both fabulous.  my friend had the hanger steak, which she devoured.  skipped dessert for a scoop of salted carmel and coffee toffee from bi-rite instead (5 stars and my first child for this combo)    oh yeah, and a bottle of Costa d'Amalfi "Ravello" (Falanghina, Biancolella) - Marisa Cuomo 2006 Campania - dry, acidic with a salty back wash.  trippy at first but complimented the ahi very well.  

and got a table for 2 at 7:30 on a Wednesday night after calling at 2:10 the same day.  who says it's tough to get in to defina?  not today!

previous visits have resulted in two of my top dishes in the city - the hanger steak when I was eating beef and the porfiteroles, second only to coco500's vacherin (simply heaven on earth).
author: Celia S.

description: It did not live up to the expectations that I read about!  Service was great and the chef even came over to our table to see if we had any questions, but I wasn't that impressed by the food.  I had the halibut which was too salty and buttery.  My boyfirend had the chicken which was really greasy and my sister had the spagetti which is something I could've made at home.  I actually really easy to please when it comes to food, but I probably wouldn't go back.
author: Lauren P.

description:
This is a place that you definitely have to make reservations for and not just do a walk-in.  This will save you a lot of headaches.  

The food's simplicity really accentuated everything wonderful about good food-the textures, the taste, the smell, the visuals.  My partner is not a chicken person, but ordered the roasted chicken and was having a orgasm over the whole experience.  My fish was prepared perfectly.  The food doesn't need to hide behind bells and whistles.  However, the squid and bean salad did not work for me as a whole.  Individually, the parts were great.  Together, the flavors were too confused for me.  

The coffee (french press) tasted like road trip coffee, not pressed (no oils).  Maybe it was just rushed.   

The service was very good overall.  They are very attentive, but not too attentive; however, the food came out a bit to quickly for our tastes.  They didn't give us too much room to breathe between dishes.  I felt like they were really pushing to turn over the tables. 

Prices are very reasonable for the quality of the food;and the portions are good.  We left more than stuffed after doing the standard-appetizer, main, and dessert.
author: may b. g.

description: Every time i go here i find myself surrounded by beautiful waitresses all smiling at me and wanting to help me.  I am constantly amazed by how well the wait staff pares the food and wine for me.  This is my favorite place in sf besides the blue plate.  The nettle pasta blew me away!
author: Dallas C.

description:
holy crap let me tell you right off the bat, it is IMPOSSIBLE to find parking around this place - the bf and i must have driven around for a good 40 minutes trying to find parking - it's sooo ridiculous.

i've been dying to try this place and the boyfriend and i finally came here yesterday for valentines day dinner.  the place was PACKED and i was waitlisted for a reservation but was able to get in.

the decor of this place is pretty cute, tall ceilings, artwork on the wall - really nice light fixtures.  the only thing i didn't like was the weird grey "mattress pad" coverings they had on the wall - not sure what that was for but it was funky. anyways...

we waited maybe 10 minutes for a table to clear up. the tables are pretty close together so i wouldn't advise talking about anything super personal unless you don't mind your neighbors hearing.  right when we were seated we were poured two glasses of water and the frosted glass decanter was left at our table (i really liked the decanter).  bread and butter was also brought out - the butter was packed into a tiny neat cube of butter - it was really cute! 

the bf and i decided to split the hawaiian ahi carpaccio to start (i'm not a big sashimi fan - i can do sushi but not sashimi so much) - the fish was really fresh and the crunch of the fennel was perfect with the dish as was the citrus vinaigrette.  we also split the spaghetti with plum tomatoes - it was cooked PERFECTLY - noodles were al dente and the sauce was delicious!  for our entrees the boyfriend ordered the short ribs and i had the oxtail ravioli - i thought the short ribs were good but my ravioli were SO DANG DELICIOUS!!  the kitchen even brought us out a complimentary swiss chard for making us wait for a table - so nice!  we were going to go to bi-rite down the street for dessert but we ended up ordering the buttermilk panna cotta - which i'm so glad we did because it was SO GOOD.  creamy, a hint of sourness and the blood orange and zest were soooo refreshing.  the kitchen also sent out a complimentary dessert - the "bomb" which was a meringue over cherry and chocolate gelato over a chocolate crisp with house cured cherries - it was really good but really rich - the crisp and the cherries were the best part of that dish.  i would only order that dessert if you're a big meringue fan.

our server was great, very attentive and informative.  the staff here in general are all friendly and very helpful.

as it was valentines day our server put a little dish of those conversation hearts and also included a valentines card with our bill - cute and sweet!

i'll definately be back, i'll just have to remember about the ridiculous parking and plan to come EARLY.
author: Kim-van T.

description: Delicious small plates - string beans with hazelnuts and mushrooms were a particular standout.  Velvety and subtle polenta and cheese side dish, and the panna cotta was fabulous, not too sweet.  Service was very good, efficient and not intrusive.  One star down because it was, like almost everywhere else these days, hot and noisy with intrusive and ugly background music.  I will definitely go again
author: mary s.

description: Ate here in July 2007, my third visit. The meal was as superb as ever. Minor demerit for a server's spill of some entree sauce onto a member of our group, but the food made up for that gaffe.
author: Michael H.

description:
Love Delfina--have been going there since it started in the bar-side of the restaurant. Service among the best in the city. Food is always tasty. However, Craig's vision as a moderately-priced neighborhood place is now being challenged by the costs of doing business in the city. Last week entrees were  $21-$24. Olives are no longer served free (but bread from Tartine is). This just means that after years of hard work building its reputation, Delfina is a destination restaurant for a bit more special occasions. Still, I love the way they run the place.
I guess they deserve it.
author: Valerie T.

description:
one of my favorite restaurants in SF. 
*spicy cauliflower with capers
author: around town e.

description: I hadn't been to Delfina in years so didn't feel good about reviewing it. Finally, Kristen and I went there last night to celebrate our five year anniversary of dating, and what a great way it was to ring in this special occasion. First of all, the staff here is super cool, very friendly, everyone from our host to our busboy to our extremely nice waitress. Our meal was more an experience - there was never at any time a sense of being rushed - so we had a real chance for some great conversation and to linger with our meal. Our waitress helped us select an excellent white wine, the 2004 Pigatto to be exact. We spilt the salt cod mantecato with flatbread, which was pretty good, and the very tasty tomato and bread salad, as appetizers. Kristen went with one of the pastas while I tried their local salmon, both were perfectly prepared, and with a side order of mashed potatoes, pretty near heavenly. For dessert, Kristen went with her favorite panna cotta, which was nice and creamy, while I tried a creamy in its own way sheep's milk cheese. Again, our waitress offtered up nice suggestions for dessert wines to pair against our last course. So while I normally get worked up about places that seem to be all about hype, I think Delfina is one of those cases where they truly deserve it. Reservations are a must, take what you can get!
author: Nish N.

description: I ate there this time last year and am now just getting to writing the review. Unbelievable meal, one of the best I've ever had..and completely reasonable entree and wine prices. Book ahead and get there. Off the beaten path a bit but well worth it. I got the last wild boar ragu of the night! Must've been fate. Visiting foodies, make sure you hit it up.
author: Chris E.

description: delfina is my absolute favorite!!  i have been 3 times and loved loved loved everything!!  this last time, we shared the calamari appetizer which comes with these amazing white beans, and also the dungeness crab salad.  sharing a pasta with your dinner is definitely a must.  they are all fantastic.  for dinner, i had the steak which was perfectly done.  their wine list is great and our service was awesome too.  i seriously think you cant go wrong at delfina, i just love it.  if you are bothered by noisy restaurants, i would recommend asking for a table along the windows, its a little better.
author: Carolyn B.

description: Ate here with the hubby last month and soooooooo good.
author: jennifer j.

description: Completely famished after a rather exhausting day hiking from Stinson Beach to Muir Woods, Sonia, Tom, and I strolled down the block to check out the famous Delfina. I was under the assumption that we would most likely end up next door at the equally esteemed pizzeria as reservations are standard at this upscale San Francisco eatery. However the restaurant gods were with us as miraculously on a Sunday night at 8 pm, sans reservations, we were instantly seated at the bar, pleasantly sipping fresh and fragrant white peach bellinis. A mouthwateringly tempting display of Tartine bread, figs, and and cheese added to the anticipation of the delicious meal to come. While the service was a bit on the slow side, our waiter was friendly and after placing our order we were rewarded with the crack laden famous Tartine bread, fresh and warm with extra creamy butter. Not wanting to fill up too much on the starchy goodness (although if you've read any of my other reviews you probably know that I am perfectly okay with eating bread, and bread only for dinner) we waited patiently for our food to arrive. I had ordered the roast chicken with olive oil mashed potatoes and morel mushrooms while Tom and Sonia went for the classic pasta dishes (capellini with tomato and basil for Sonia and linguine with trumpet mushrooms and a cream sauce for Tom). The roast chicken dish in my opinion, was the winner of the night. The crispy skin encased an extremely tender meat which was seasoned to perfection. The olive oil mashed potatoes were deliciously creamy and smooth while the mushrooms added an earthy and rich dimension to this already heavenly dish. Both pasta dishes were tasty, although I preferred the mushroom linguine over the tomato and basil concoction, soley because it was a novelty. After licking our plates clean, we still had room to share a dessert- the shortbread cookie sandwich filled with marscapone and caramelized nectarines- the perfect finish to a stellar dining experience.
author: Kate A.

description: I like this place a lot because it's so obvious that they put a lot of thoughts into putting their dishes together.  We had a salad and two pastas.  We had the Insalata di Campo.  It came with walnut, pancetta and a very nutty parmigiano.  The nuttiness of the cheese complimented the walnuts, while the crunch of the walnuts gave a similarly complimentary texture to the whole dish with crispy pancetta and cabbage.  Brought together with the bitter greens, it had a very complex layer of flavors.  We also had the Spaghettini Nero.  The squid ink gave it a very pretty look.  The lemon zest was what we tasted first when we put it in our mouth, then the very pleasant ocean-saltiness of the squid ink and uni.  There was also a slight hint of chili, so subtle that it was almost like an aftertaste.  The squid was crunchy and fresh-tasting.  It was our favorite that night.  Finally we had a mint tagliatelle with chanterelle mushroom and creme fraiche.  I was grateful that it wasn't too creamy, and the mint surprisingly went well with this dish.  This was the first of three dishes we had over the weekend that had chanterelle mushroom, but it was the one that we thought where it was the most well used.  It was a four-star dish, just paled a little compared to the spaghettini.  The wait staff was also very nice and attentive.  I just appreciate the thoughts that go into this dish as well as flavors that were new to me.
author: Eric W.

description: Starting in reverse, the Panna Cotta and the Profiteroles were the highlights of our dinner. I wish I could give 4.5 stars. Extra half star for the To-Die-For desserts. We had the hanger steak and the whole fish tai snapper. Hanger steak was mouth-watering. The fish was prepared just right. Then we started with calamari appetizer and the gem salad. We were digging the gorgonzola dressing. Calamari dish is very good. I always order this starter. I should really branch out. Delfina is one of my Go-To places for birthdays and anniversaries. I love the buzz in the energy of this place and the service is also very professional without the pretense. My impression is that Delfina is getting better and better. Though I miss some of the waitstaff from their beginning years that were tattoed and pierced up with crazy hair. Mission cool but still the same professional service.
author: Seymour S.

description:
me and a friend took a day off to spend a day in the beautiful SF to shop, spa and of course EAT! we were starved after our luxurious massage and wanted to end it with a fabulous meal. once you stop frequenting the city, you start getting brainfarts on where to go for good eats! thank goodness for yelp =)! i remembered bookmarking delfina and w/ their fantastic reviews thought it'd be a great time to check it out. even on a weekday it was packed and we were fortunate enough to score a nice patio seating (w/ heat lamps) in the back. after ordering our glasses of wine and chomping on the yummy bread and butter (so yummy, we asked for another), we felt like 2 celeb gf's (think drew barrymore and cameron diaz) on vacation!

the food:
-INSALATA DEL CAMPO (bitter greens, pancetta, walnuts, parmigiano) was your basic decent salad. they were nice enough to split it on 2 plates since we were sharing.
-side of OLIVE OIL MASHED POTATOES - nuff said
-SLOW ROASTED BERKSHIRE PORK SHOULDER W/ SPRING ONIONS was so delich i didn't know what to do w/ myself. my friend was on a beef and pork fast (she's a crazy girl) and so couldn't taste any of it. she LOVES berkshire pork so you can imagine how hard it was for her. when i said i'll order something else, she insisted that i try it because it's too good to pass up. poor her, more for me! =) every bite was HEAVENLY. i don't know how often the menu changes but this is a definite MUST EAT even for non-pork lovers! 
-SWORDFISH so does not meet up to the dish above and was a bit fishy for our taste.
-PROFITEROLES W/ ESPRESSO GELATO W/ WARM CHOCOLATE SAUCE would have been better if the gelato was sweeter, was more on the bitter side.
-SCHARFFENBERGER CHOCOLATE CAKE W/ VANILLA CREME ANGLAISE was rich and perfect way to end our evening.

we seriously stuffed ourselves silly! i would say the service was slower than i liked and from checking out the other reviews, it looks like weekdays are a better bet!
author: Jane Y.

description: Delfina is fantastic.  With 2 young kids and lack of time to prepare, we made a last minute decision to find a nice restaurant to celebrate my husband's 35th birthday.  We've lived in San Francisco for 10 years and have dined at some very fine establishments, but had not yet tried Delfina.  Last night we drove out to the Mission, I made a quick call to Defina, and the wait for dinner was long.  We decided to chance it and go in person.  Ally, who was our first point of contact at Delfina, was so nice and she found a way to seat us for our special occasion despite being booked up.  The service, the food, the ambiance - all was wonderful.  Exceptional food items included the grilled fresh calamari (to die for!!!), the warm Castelvetrano olives, and the linguine with petrale sole.  Delfina - we'll be back and we won't forget our incredible experience all around!  Thank you!!!
author: Julie S.

description: Tier 1 pizza in the city that has no comparison, its unlovely amazing.
author: Carl S.

description: Craig and Annie (the owners) really get it.   This restaurant is always packed every night and for a very good reason.   We eat there regularly (once a month) but thought our experience last night warranted this review.   Walking by at 8 PM and hungry, we decided to see if we could get a table.   While the massive crowds outside were waiting for Delfina PIzzaria, we had a glass of wine and only waited 15 minutes for a seat at the bar.   Dinner reminded us of why we live in the City.   The diversity of the customers, the radiating energy of the restaurant and the consistently delicious food and wine.    From the Tartine bread, to the perfectly balanced Little Gem salad, to the seasoned fries, to the fresh seasonal sweet corn soup, to the meaty short rib stuffed pasta, to the olive oil mashed potatoes, to the bitter chard, to the cheesy polenta.   Our only regret is that we missed the Duck Confit special.   But we watched as those around us savored every bite of their orders.   And the wine list contains such Italian finds as Germano Ettore and others from Piemonte.   At restaurants of this caliber the staff usually becomes haughty and detached yet everyone working at Delfina is always cheerful and attentive!   Service may get a little slow at peak dining times but be patient, the overall experience will leave you happy you live in a City like ours.   Exquisite food, uplifting dining experience and very reasonable prices are why this restaurant has been so successful.   Why don't other restaurants get it?   General managers should dine here more often for inspiration.
author: Roger B.

description: I once read in Fortune magazine that Delfina was the top 50 restaurants in the world. I don't think it is that highly ranked but Delfina is good. Fresh, well prepared and lively place. I had the steak and fries which is very very good. Only problem is parking but one can always park somewhere and take a cab.
author: Joe C.

description: thank you !!!!! it was great . when you can make my wife and daughters (21- 15) Happy with the meal . Service, wine selection and suggestions fantastic . The desert yummy - we love Molly. thanks for the  help  and the great time  . Will be back when in the city
author: chu l.

description: Great food!  Yes, this place is busy all the time - so better make reservations.  Servers are friendly.  Food is priced good - tasty and good portion.  Parking sucks but still coming back to this place!
author: Tomo S.

description: Delfina is definitely moving into my top 5. I'm frustrated and amazed that they continue to be packed, any night of the week. The last 3 times I've been there, I've had to make a reservations 1-2 months in advance. It's crazy how busy they are but once you go, you'll understand why. I tend to not stray from their signature dishes. My bf and I now have our ordering down to a science. We may or may not get a salad but we always get the spaghetti and the fulton valley chicken. The chicken is tender, juicy, and perfectly seasoned. And I know what you're thinking...spaghetti? Really? This is no joke. Don't be fooled by the other pastas even though the papardelle is pretty good. Go straight for the full size order of spaghetti - no sharing! Trust me, I've attempted to share and once you get this plate of goodness in front of you, you don't want to spare one noodle! A portion of my eating pleasure goes to dissecting the spaghetti. How do they make it so good?? I know there are probably about 5 ingredients and I need to know their secret!
author: Josephine H.

description: uncomfortable seating, and when it comes down to it i dont like the kind of italian food places like delfina and a16 serve up, although its not bad. but whatever. its kinda funny here because a lot of people who never get out of the mission end up here as their idea of a fancy dinner, as well as people not from the mission coming here to be like OH see the mission not only has culture, but it has class too! wow, bob, wow.
author: christopher a.

description: Absolutely love Delfina.  I would say this defines San Francisco cuisine.  Everything is SO simple yet delicious.  They use all local produce and make their own pasta.  Every bite is honestly heavenly.  I went with a larger group so we literally got almost everything on the menu since they are small plates.  I left craving more of every dish.  Honestly, as good as it gets!
author: Monique C.

description: When you are paying top dollar you don't expect the staff to be rude.  We came in and asked the hostess if we could have a seat at the bar and have a glass of wine.  She said it was no problem.  There was only one seat available so one of us sat and the other stood.  When the seat next to us became available my other guest sat next to me.  The hostess then said that we could not stay there because she was going to seat a walkin for dinner.  Although, I like that they take reservations for the bar.  This is a treat for anyone who has tried to get a spot at NOPA.  I just feel that Delfina is inconsistent.  She should have told us upfront and we could of put our name in to be seated if that was the policy.
author: Darrell T.

description: Delfina was altogether good.  Our party of three arrived for a nice dinner out on a nice Monday night and were pleased that the restaurant had some energy but wasn't packed to the gills.  My only complaint was really that the hanger steak I ordered was simply undercooked and over-sauced.  I'm not a send-it-back-complainer, and I second-guessed myself because the reddish hue of the generous portion of sauce did a lot to mask the meat's color, so I just went ahead and grinned and bore it.  So that was kind of a damper, but nothing Bi-Rite ice cream across the street couldn't fix!
author: JR S.

description: You know...I've always wanted to try Delfina. I would constantly see a huge crowds waiting to get in whenever I walk by to go to Bi-Rite or Tartine. I was disappointed though. The waiter pretty much ignored us except when my friend started waving her arms around like crazy. Delfina...you've disappointed me. The expectations were much to high. It's like being in love with a celebrity for 10 years, and then you finally get to meet him, and he ends up being an inch shorter than you...in flats. Sigh...
author: Fresca T.

description: My 3rd time at Delfina, and yet another perfect meal! I had to settle for a 10PM reservation on a Friday night, since I only booked it a little more than a week in advance. I was told that you need to book 6-8 weeks in advance for a prime time reservation on the weekend. It wasn't nearly this bad last year at this time of year, though last year I got a Friday at 9PM only 10 days in advance. The maitre d' can be a bit curt on the phone when you're making your reservation, but ignore that and keep your eyes on the prize! The decor isn't all that, but who cares when the food is so good! And now you get to walk past all the losers eating at Pizzeria Delfina next door as you enter Delfina to claim your prized reservation. After circling 15 minutes to find parking, we arrived to happily find that they could seat us 30 minutes early. Led to our seats along the wall underneath the mirror running the length of the restaurant, towards the front windows, we settled into our seats and met our cute waiter. Tables are close and cramped, so be prepared to overhear your neighbors' conversations. A small dish of olives comes to the table, which I love, and then bread and butter. But the reason I come to Delfina in February is the crab dishes. Last year they participated in the Crab Fridays in the Mission program, but it's not running this year. But they had a crab dish available (since it's in season until the end of Feb), and what a spectacular dish it was. Spaghettini and fresh-picked Dungeness crab was absolutely yummy, for $16. My friend and I split it, and when they brought us our 2 plates, we thought they had made a mistake, the portions seemed too much. But upon checking, we learned that they had indeed split the dish. We mopped it up with bread. We could not have been happier. But we were about to become even more so! The menu offered local petrale sole in acqua pazza (capers, oven-dried tomato, olives, and white wine) for two for $39, $24 for one. So we had the two, which a different server deboned for us, and it was so amazingly good. We mopped it up with bread as well. For dessert, I ordered the warm persimmon budino (Italian for pudding) with caramel and mascarpone cream. It was yummy, like a bread pudding, and the persimmon and caramel flavors were exquisite, balanced by the coolness of the cream. A decent portion too, about the size of my palm. Chef Craig Stoll's Tuscan food continues to deserve your accolades, and the effort to get a booking is well-rewarded.
author: Hao L.

description: okay this is one of my most favored restaurants in all of SF.  amazing cuisine - the small plates and pastas are heavenly and while I feel the mains are slightly less reliable and of less economic value they are also quite good too.  a recent trip had me enjoying the grilled calamari and white bean salad and then mint infused tagliatelle with  nettles and lovely mushrooms.  the duck was my main and rather than the sliced breast I got a real part of a duck!  crispy and good.  there was a coconut pineapple dessert - that was as light an an angel's wing.  the wine list is fab and corkage is $18 - and the staff are stellar - class, amazing cuisine - this is still a truly splendid establishment.
author: Eric S.

description: Although they pack em in tight it's a nice atmosphere. If you get claustrophobic eat at the bar. The asparagus salad was amazing. Pasta with petrale sole was amazing. Pansotti with walnut sauce was only ok although the battleaxe liked it. Polenta and chard sides and also the bread were quite good. And we left feeling like we had not been raped as the bill was only 90 bucks
author: Steve P.

description: I came late for my reservation but was still be able to get seated right away, pretty impressed and happy with their services. I love the complimentary bread that they gave, the bread taste like sourdough but with a chewy textures. I couldnt help munching away all the bread with olive oil and balsamic. I ordered the grilled fresh calamari, it was ok not that great. The insalata di campo salad was fresh and light. I ordered half  linguine and clam and half ravioli, they taste pretty normal and standard and lastly i got the short ribs which was soft and melt in the mouth. The food was pretty average until i got the panna cotta which was heavenly! they melt in my mouth and is not too sweet.  I will want to try their pizza place next door because its pretty crowded!
author: fourevindo h.

description: We went recently after 4 years hiatus.  I know they opened their pizzeria next door but I was so disappointed they took it off their menu as a starter.  That was all Grandmom wanted but did not get.  She ordered the roasted duck which was good thank god!  The grilled calamari was excellent. The salads were good but nothing special.  The burrata at Beretta was better than Delfina.  Even the entrees were not as spectacular as I remembered it before their expansion.  Portions were really small for the money.  The spaghetti here was appetizer size at other restaurant and salty.  Service was good and their bread from Tartine bakery was the best.  I may give it another try but with so many great restaurants in the city, it's not worth the hassle of trying to get a reservation for the day and time you want.
author: Shirley Y.

description: Craig and Anne Stoll know how to run a neighborhood restaurant that transcends a neighborhood - it is truly a destination place.  Craig's  food is truly Italian (and I'm the decendant of Neopolitans who, while growing up in NY, ate very little that was not genuine Italian food).  Anne makes sure that the service is always attentive and caring, like an Italian grandmother feeding you in her home.
author: Louise L.

description:
after months of dodging numerous recommendations by friends, we finally braved the line randomly, late on a friday night.  only a 20 min wait.? hmm. the perfect amount of time to run down to luna park for a quick drink!  when we returned, our table was ready as promised, in exactly the amount of time originally quoted. 
the calamari app. was perfection. the beans, tiny and cooked to absolute creaminess without losing structure.  the squid was delicate and perfectly charry, and without the rubberiness or slick finish so often found in such dishes.  the only dish to ever to have beaten it was a grilled version i had in sicily. 
stretched fresh mozz and tomato salad was sent on the house, which was a delight... and holy crap, where did the tomatoes come from?  SO delicious and graden fresh.  the cheese was just lovely. not too heavy, not too stringy. 
the gnocchi was gorgeous. perfectly balanced and with, again, divine tomatoes. though it was flavorful, the texture was not as good as that found at valentina's in bernal.
the roasted chicken was good as well... a plump, generous serving of comfort food.  the mashed potatoes were light and earthy. the mushroom jus was well seasoned but unfortunately lacked any real hutzpah. 
for dessert, we had profiteroles with espresso ice cream.  by that point, it was more an issue of curiosity as to whether the meal could follow through than any actual hunger or room in our stomachs.  they were crispy, creamy, and light, with the ice cream a slightly bitter accompaniment that cut through the heaviness of the pastry.  all in all, an excellent finish.
the wine list was more than reasonable, covering a wide range of paletttes as well as wallets.   our syrah blend went well with every dish we ordered, though it was a little odd that with so attentive of service, no one ever refilled our glasses.
we will gladly go back, likely repeatedly, for their simple and rustic italian fare made with some of the freshest ingredients around.
author: Ariane R.

description: This place is great!  I would definitely go back and recommend it to anyone who is in the mood for some good Italian food, a good atmosphere and excellent service.  Our waitress, Allison, was amazing!  We were not familiar with a lot of the terminology on the menu, so she took the time to explain every question we had and in great detail.  When we asked for her recommendation, she started with the priciest dishes and moved her way to the other price ranges, so you know she wasn't pushing only the expensive stuff on the menu.  She was very pleasant and it was very refreshing to finally experience good service.  The food was great also.  I ordered the braised ox-tail risotto and it was delicious!  Definitely would go back, but next time I want to try the pizzeria next door - I believe it was the same owner, but not sure. Their pizza looked amazing!  Highly recommended for great everything!
author: Theresa P.

description: went there one night after seeing a show at dolores park cafe - was able to avoid the long wait by taking 3min mid-show to skedaddle down there to put our names on the list and then when the show was over we walked the block and went right in. the dinner was great, food was yummy, and their olive oil is memorable.
author: lisa w.

description: We were visiting SF for first time and we passed by Delfina, because of the crowd we saw outside we decided to try the  restaurant. The food was excellent. The service was very professional. I had insalatta di campo, Spaghetti with plum tomatoes, garlic, extra virgin olive oil and peperoncini and as a dessert panna cotta. The food was delicious. I strongly recommend this place.
author: Anna N.

description: First came here years ago and had a wonderful meal with warm service. Came back this past week and was so glad to see that the food is still outstanding and the service is as genuine and outstanding as it was the first time I visited. It's so rare is it to have that kind of consistency.
author: Barbara C.

description: I am not quite sure if this place needs another great review but I have eaten here for years and they still do it right. My friend and I went here last night and I felt the need to point out some excellent items on the menu which if they have them when you go, you should definitely order them. To start, I have three words - black truffle arancini. This little risotto ball with cheese and black truffle was divine! We actually wanted to order more but they had run out and it was only 7:30 PM. I assume many people did what we did - tried them and then ordered more! A guy at the table next to us asked his parents what they liked the best out of the meal and his father said at least 3x the arancini - it was comical! We also had the little gem - delicious with the sieved egg and pt reyes blue cheese. For our mains, we ordered the pork saltimbocca and the papparadelle with duck sugo. Both very good - I am not a huge pork fan but I tried it and it was quite flavorful. I always order pasta here since it is always cooked perfectly and tonight was no different - perfectly al dente and the duck sugo was nice and rich. We also had a side of their brussel sprouts, which I know everyone has now, but theirs is unique in that they sweeten it up with honey and the hazelnuts give the dish a nice crunch. The other must order dish if on the menu other than the black truffle arancini is the meyer lemon panna cotta. I order a lot of panna cotta and theirs is quite special. Just the right amount of lemon taste and the creaminess of the panna cotta is incredible - my friend had to put a stop to me ordering another one! Our waitress (who I must say was fantastic) is a chocolate fan and she says she chooses this dessert even above the chocolate budino. Delfina remains on my list of favorite restaurants in SF!
author: M S.

description: The best medium price italian restaurant in the city!  Start with grilled sardines, grilled calamari, and any soups.  Their pasta are the freshes and the baked ricotta is a special treat.  Paccheri with sea bass, spicy spaghetti are wonderful.  Good gnocchis too, not too starchy or mushy, just right, which is not easy with ghocchi.  Their panna cotta with fruit and berries is a great way to finish a memorable meal.  Don't go on the weekends, too busy.  The weekdays are busy as well, but you should be able to get a seat.
author: Jen M.

description: i dont remember what i had here, but the pasta was fresh, it wasnt super expensive, and the waitstaff was not pretentious and very helpful.  second best italian in the city, only to quince!
author: Robert S.

description:
my boyfriend took me here for our anniversary.  pretty funny that neither of us had ever been, considering the fact that he lives 3 doors down.

although we had a wonderful evening of great wines, appetizers and desserts with very mediocre entrees, i would have given delfina 3 stars instead of 4.  but i have my reasons for the extra star.  im going to spare you the boring food review that everyone wrote and get right to the good stuff.

why the 4th star?  because of the entertainment provided us to that evening.  oh, the DRAMA.

the drama consisted of a very, very drunk couple who fought outside the window by our seat for a good 30 minutes while they waited for their table.  although we obviously could not hear the argument, the fight consisted of the boyfriend doing a lot of scrunchy faced yelling with wild hand motions, and the girlfriend (wearing a demin skirt, flip flops and baseball hat - inappropriate for delfina in my book) looking like she was going to pass out.  once they got inside, the boyfriend immediately ditched the girlfriend, seeking refuge in the bathroom.  the girlfriend decided to "sit" on a barstool and promptly TUMBLED face first to the ground.  she remained sprawled out on the floor of delfina and laid there for a full minute and a half, apologizing profusely, causing quite a scene, and appearing to be in no hurry to get up.  the waitstaff was very accommodating and helped her to her seat, although it was clear that the front of house manager was NOT happy that this was taking place in DELFINA at 9:30pm on a MONDAY.  when the boyfriend returned, the girlfriend tried to act like nothing happened, but the couple left a few minutes later.  

after exiting the restaurant, they resumed their post at the window in front of our seat and fought for another 10 minutes or so until they finally left.

the best part is that about 45 minutes later, after my boyfriend and i had left the restaurant and when we were leaving his apartment to go back to my 'hood for the night, we saw the boyfriend walking back to delfina without the drunk girlfriend.

and that's just the classy kinda place that delfina is.
author: Natalie H.

description: perfect, every time. you can't go wrong ordering any of the specials, and the steak & fries are utterly delicious. the trouble getting reservations is little tiring, but hey, just take everything in stride, and be assured that you'll leave supremely satiated.
author: Jeremy H.

description: Yum, Yum. Chicken is moist and tasty without being saucy. Mash potatoes were light and fluffy. The chop salad was tasty as well. The only negative about this place is you can't ever get reservations, unless its for 10pm! Good if you are a late night diner, but I like to have time to digest my food before I hit the sheets.
author: Mama L.

description: Came here on a recommendation.  Between my wife and I we decided on a four course meal.  We had the mushroom salad, shrimp appetizer, pork pasta dish and the roasted chicken.  Sorry I don't remember the name of the dishes but do remember that I enjoyed every bite of that meal.  Even the bread was great.  Delfina is a small restaurant with so much charm.  The service was great and the interior mood lighting made the dinner seem even more romantic.  One of the best meals I've had.  Now I know why friends frequent SF so often.
author: steve p.

description: Delfinas! Delfinas! Delfinas! is all I've ever heard about this quaint eatery in the heart of San Francisco. Being a native I felt it my duty to try this place out. Finally, after I put in a reservation three months in advance I could check of Delfinas on my list off top restaurants to visit. IIIIKKK!! Bland chicken and plain spaghetti with your average tomato sauce is what I was greeted with. Yuck! I couldn't have been more disappointed. Even the seating was uncomfortable and narrow. I could barely talk to anyone besides the person next to me. I'll never eat there again. Don't get me wrong the pizzeria is a winner (besides the lack of seating and the toppings that leak off the thin crust) but the restaurant is a big ol "wa wa wa..."
author: Alexis G.

description: I was very excited to eat here, given all of the rave reviews. I was a bit disappointed. I like my food pretty salty, but the cod and crisps were way too heavy on the salt. The salad was fresh, but uninspiring. My tuna was _perfectly_ cooked, and tasty. The pasta were also good. Wine list is also solid. Service is friendly, but confused. Other tables dishes arrived etc.  If you're going to spend $200+ for four people, I think you can do much better.
author: Maximilian A.

description: A friend took us to Delfina for dinner because it's pretty "well-known" in the SF area and my husband loves Italian food.  The service was efficient and pretty friendly.  The waitress didn't interrupt us much, which I always appreciate, and filled our water glasses often.  We all started with the cream corn soup, which I would highly recommend.  I had the tagliatelle with bolognese sauce, which was very good.  We didn't order an entree, because we didn't think we were that hungry.  The pasta portions are small; even the "large" spaghetti is pretty small.  Next time, I'd probably order more items--an appetizer, the cream corn soup, a pasta, and an entree.  They clearly expect us to order several courses because the portions are fairly small.  Overall, I'd definitely go again.  We did have a great time there, but in large part because of the company, rather than the food.
author: FY H.

description: Great location (located in the trendy mission district).  Very PRETTY restaurant overall.  Great service.  But my only complaint was the food, it was just okay. I am willing to give this restaurant a second chance, since everything else was perfect!
author: Bella C.

description: I was seriously disappointed in Delfina's. My wine was about as exciting as Kool-aid, the waitress was cooler-than-thou, and the $17 pizza consisted of cheese melted on bread with a sprinkling of arugula and three meager slices of prosciutto. On top of that, they were playing Green Day. Loudly. Go to Delfina's if you want to pay a lot for not too much.
author: Betsy E.

description: i like delfina alot. the pizza is great but tons of places are doing that style of pizza now. i dont really see the big deal about it. i also heard, and this may be rumor, that the owners went to italy, trained with a chef who had the restaurant of the same name and they came back here and created delfina without telling him. idk if its true but o well. when i did go there there was great service and they kept us liquored up which is nice.
author: Lola r.

description: A place that hits the culinary sweet spot everytime.  It's like watching Andy Roddick hit a perfect ace or cross-court winner when you eat here - the flavor and the texutres are spot on.  If you're going during the weekend and want to sit at the bar or counter section, ask for Jolie. She is the best!!
author: Jason K.

description: I'm so tired of people's ridiculous complaints about this place! This chef just won the James Beard award for the food at this restaurant! Look it up, people. This is excellent food, folks, and if you're not "getting it," try a little reflexivity and think about how your pallatte might not be up to Delfina's standards, not the other way around. If you think the spaghetti is bland then you're probably used to over-sauced crap from one of your Marina hang-outs. If you think the chicken is boring (which it's not...it's simple and delicious and artfullly prepared using the best birds and brines) then don't go to a Trattoria and order chicken! Order something a little outside of your pallatte and live a little. No they don't take AMEX (who the hell does?), no they don't bring you free dessert on your birthday (this isn't TGIFridays...hello!), and yes you have to help them pay the Healthy San Francisco Ordinance. Are you so stingy that you can't give a dollar twenty-five of your 50 dollar dinner so that your server can get minimal health care? Restaurant owners aren't rolling in dough...ever. ...And lastly, the ignorant comments about our neighborhood being "crunchy" are just disgusting, racist, classist, snobbery. Shame on you.  I am proud to live, like Delfina, in an a nieghborhood full of different kinds of folks with different socio-economic backgrounds (not all of which can afford to eat at delfina like you), and if it weren't for your snobby segregation over in your neigborhoods, maybe the maldistribution of wealth wouldn't be what it is. If you dont like the waits in the mission, the crowds in the mission, the homeless and marginally-housed folks in the mission, the people of color and queers in the mission, the hipsters in the mission, or the food in the mission, then stay out of the mission! sorry to be not-so-nice...but seriously, ya'll....
author: Jesse H.

description:
divine. 
i haven't used that word in a long time. it used to be used often by me, too often, to describe food that I enjoyed. Fortunately for the word, I stopped using it, and now I can reserve it for those moments that truly transcend previous experiences. 

delfina was divine.

we started off with something bubbly at the bar while we waited.  After we were seated we ordered another round of wine, and ordered a few courses to taste from.  The salad was so beyond perfect I don't know if I should bother describing it, but I will. Bitter greens, pancetta, candied walnuts, thick sheets of parmesean.  I walked by recently and saw it on the menu still, I believe it has a permanent spot as it should. Go for this salad, and you will not be disappointed. Moving on, we had the trio of crositini; chicken liver pate (yum yum), fava bean spread (yummy) and a roasted garlic-lemon spread (good).  The ravioli we shared were stuffed with chicken and pancetta, which was absolutely delicious.  Our main course was the salmon (on recommendation from a friend who had finished his meal as we arrived, thanks anth!)  The salmon was so so good, served on just cut from the cob which was just cut from the stalk corn. WOW.  As if the meal wasn't perfect enough, we had awesome desserts. The buttermilk panna cotta was fantastic (although served with out of season - this was in may when i went- raspberries. why bother!?) The chocolate cake was out of this world.

I cannot wait to go back.  Not cheap, but not expensive. Worth every penny (maybe more, but I won't tell them that)
author: Markell M.

description: This is hugely popular restaurant in the Mission Dolores and last weekend I got to try it. In a nutshell, service is very good, attentive and low key; the food is mediocre. We ordered appetizer of grilled sardines, it took about 40 min to get it (at which point it no longer felt like an appetizer). The real test in my view came with a pasta dish, simple spaghetti with tomato sauce. I am sorry but no Italian would make pasta like that, salty, overcooked and overpowered - I couldn't possibly tell if the pasta was freshly made (as claimed on the menu) or bought from Safeway nearby. The main dish, pork shoulder was ok but not more than that. Having tasted these dishes, it was easy decision to skip the dessert (with Tartine few steps away that is no-brainer). Overall, good place if you don't care for authentic Italian meal.
author: Mikhail K.

description: I've only been once, and it wasn't as good as I'd expected. The waitress told my friend and I that the ribs were sublime. The were just BBQ'd ribs. Didn't fall off the bone, the sauce wasn't unbelievable etc. Just good/decent ribs. We also shared a shrimp appetizer. Was also good, but nothing blew me away. I'll try again.
author: Gym W.

description: four stars for food. five stars for price-performance. starters are always excellent. i had a pork shoulder earlier this month - i can still taste it. reservation lead time for a weekend slot is usually 4-5 weeks.
author: noflaps c.

description: I can't honestly say that the food at Delfina blew us away . . . not that there was anything necessarily wrong with it, just lacked any "wow" factor.  Four stars are for the fantastic service - just the nicest bunch of gals your likely to meet on the restaurant scene in San Fran.  Snaps also for their passion and knowledge around the food and wine that they serve.  I will definitely go back on my next trip to the city.
author: Eleanor S.

description: As good as good Italian gets... best restaurant in the city, imho. The only thing close to it is Dopo in Oakland. Enjoy!
author: Zami Z.

description: Came back on July 11 and had one of my best meals ever here (and I've had hundreds--an average of once a week for the last 7 or so years).   The kitchen was spot on!   First the little gem salad with gorgonzola, sieved egg and radishes, then the mint tagliatelle with porcini mushrooms, then the pork shoulder (so tender it was almost like lamb) with stewed apricots and blue lake beans, followed by an amazing black-and-blue-berry crostata with vanilla yogurt gelato.   The glass of Pinot Nero wasn't bad either!
author: David T.

description: Booked my birthday dinner for two at Delfina and was actually pretty disappointed in the food, though it was probably our fault for ordering the wrong things since everyone else seems to love it--guess we should have asked the server for recommendations.  I got the spagettini with sepia (a type of cuttlefish, kinda like calamari), with sauce made from the sepia's ink, and given what it was, the chefs did an amazing job with it, but it was still a pretty, well, weird dish.  Guess I'm not the most adventurous eater, even when I try to order that way.  My boyfriend got the Niman Ranch steak, and it came so raw it was extremely difficult to chew (or look at).  I've heard this is the authentic Italian way of doing it, but before you order it, keep in mind how it will be cooked.  Salads, gelatos, and wines (recommended by our server) were great, but the main courses disappointed, especially after the great reviews I read.  Also, we were smushed right up next to another table for two--two rather loud women from NYC--which didn't heighten the romance of the evening.  But I'd definitely go back and order differently--simultaneously classy yet low-key atmosphere and great potential if you don't order the way we did.
author: Gina K.

description: If Maggiano's is broad brush (or coarse depending if you're a fan or not) strokes in Italian cuisine, then Delfina is definitely fine and delicate.  We enjoyed the calamari as an appetizer - the beans were so soft and comforting while the calamari was well flavored.  Hint: eat with their yummy bread!  We also tried the chicken liver crostini which was great and I appreciated that they had some pickled onions and olives to curb that fatty taste -- if you wanted it curbed that is!  I loved my wild nettle ravioli: the bits of walnut with the soft ricotta was fabulous.  For dessert, we shared a panna cotta which was silky smooth and a great ending to a fine Italian meal.  So the food is excellent, but perhaps what we most liked is the fact that Delfina is casual and unpretentious.  Collared shirt and jeans are definitely fine and our waiter was helpful and cool.  The food isn't cheap, but not terribly expensive if you're ordering appetizers and pasta.  The only one negative for Delfina is that the place is small so it can get quite loud, so it's not exactly where you go for a nice romantic dinner.  However, if you're in the mood for some fine Italian dining with Bay Area cool, Delfina can't miss.
author: Tim L.

description: Pastas here are amazing.  Wine selection is great, not because of the volume, but the depth of choices and its price points.  Salt Cod is a great starter.  Service is ok, a little rude, almost like we should feel honored to eat at a restaurant where these waitresses are lucky enough to work - but I put that behind me.  We've eaten here a handful of times.  You can tell the Management cares, but again, some of the servers just have attitudes.  I would have given it 5 stars if service was as good as the food.
author: Leslie P.

description: If only I could give half stars; then the wisdom of the crowd would be even more precise. Delfina is certainly one of the best Italian restaurants in the city, and I'd love to give it four and a half stars but, alas... it sits somewhere between the superlative Quince and the very good Perbacco, right around Acquerello territory in the land of New Italian cuisine. I hadn't been here in a few years (I keep getting tempted by their Pizzeria next door), so I started off with a celebratory glass of Prosecco- dry, dulcet, delicioso. Then came the perfectly piquant pomodoro with thick, fresh spaghetti. For my main course, I ordered Berkshire Pork Shoulder- quite tender, lightly sauced, very loin-like (and one of the best pork preparations I've ever had). Finally, I was in the mood for salted caramel ice cream, so we skipped dessert and headed down the block to Bi-Rite Creamery. That just means I'll have to return soon, at least to try what I'm sure will be some truly delightful desserts (yes, alliteration is annoying).
author: Lawrence S.

description: i will spare the details on terrific menu, service, wine list , vibe, etc- because you can read all about it in the dozens of other posts.  i will say that it is always one of the best dinner's i've experienced in a long time and i always look forward to going back.  this place is one of the best restaurants in sf, and my personal favorite.  thanks delfina!
author: Kevin J.

description: We slipped in here Saturday night without a reservation. The service here is wonderful--attentive and very knowledgible about the food and wine. I enjoyed the insalata de campo while my husband had a half portion of ravioli. For my entree I had the hanger steak with french fries--so tasty. My husband had the lamb (very generous portion) and loved it. They do have wine by the half bottle and we had a great zin. We skipped dessert since we were heading to Bi-Rite Creamery, but my husband had the cheese which he enjoyed.
author: K W.

description: Just got home from a pretty fab dinner with my pops.  After hearing so much about it I had to go.  The service, ambiance and food are all stellar.  ALthough the portions seem small they are actually perfect.  The layers of flavors and the delicate balance of ingredients makes each dish succulent to the last bite.  A few things that stand out:  calamari and warm bean appetizer, bittersweet chocolate cake, and of course the famous roast chicken and mashies.  Dad's spaghetti with crab was very good as well.  I can't wait to hit up the pizzeria next door.  Well done Delfina, everything was executed with precision.
author: Jessica K.

description: we came here for our anniversary because i really wanted steak, and it was fantastic. the meat was cooked to perfection with the right amount of sauce, and the fritz were perfectly cut. my hubby got the duck- which was absolutely perfect! it was juicy (yet not fatty), and tender. the ambiance and service are superb as well. honestly, there are no complaints to be made. we're big fans, and can't wait to go back for another meal.
author: SF U.

description: the pizza here is really good. the pizzas are super thin and the breadsticks are good.
author: chloe w.

description: Delfina is simply divine. My family and I have been going there for years and every dish they make is exquiste. My father a picky eater and wine drinker considers this to be one of his favorite restaurants. Our favorite dish is the tomato pasta and the hanger steak. Enjoy!!!!
author: Danielle R.

description: so i finally tried this place out a couple of weeks ago. came here with a friend for some wine and appeteizers. it was pretty full - so we sat at the bar. we asked the bartender / server to recommend an appetizer. he recommended this fried soup thing. the only way i can explain it was it seemed like a poor man's meal of leftovers made into a patty and fried in a pan. it wasn't bad, but it wasn't excellent either. we then decided to split an entree. we went for the roasted fulton valley chicken with yukon gold mashed potatoes and king trumpet mushrooms. i rarely order chicken at restaurants, but this was worth it. i recommend sopping up the juices on the plate with bread. so good! the bartender also recommended some great wine to go with our meal. all around it was a very good experience. i plan on returning in the near future to try some of their other dishes.
author: James J.

description: Yum yum yum. There's a reason this restaurant always tops SF food lists. Chef Craig Stoll's menu is rather small, but is full of amazing always changing dishes... From homemade mozzarella to the best salmon I've ever tasted to divine deserts, this place is a winner. This place is incredibly reasonably priced when you compare the quality of the food to other neighborhood spots for the same price.
author: Michael H.

description: italian style pizza.  uh, yum!!!  they do it a bit fancier than i would prefer, but oh well.  also, if you arrive after 6pm, expect to wait for an hour for a table, and for good reason.  yum.
author: Jason H.

description: yumyumyum. we got appetizers and wine and pizza and it was all very delicious. the only :/ part was that we had to wait - in the street - for like 15 or so minutes before getting a seat (at the food bar, could watch everything being made, that was neat). it was crowded on a tuesday at like 7pm. seemed a little nutso to me, but i still really liked the food. i think we got a margarita pizza. the memory is a little fuzzy after the wine. :)
author: Kathleen D.

description: Had an amazing dinner date here with my hubby last week.  Food was incredible.  Had so much food and wine that I almost popped.  Definitely bringing my parents here for their anniversary in a couple of months.  May come back sooner by myself.  Already craving the pasta that I had.
author: Maryann S.

description: J says: No wonder this place is a perennial fave in SF.  The food was really good!  The little gem salad was so unbelievably fresh and I love that they served the lettuce whole instead of cutting it up into pieces, makes for a much classier presentation.  Then I had the spaghetti with plum tomatoes, it was so simple yet so delicious, with the spaghetti cooked perfectly al dente and the tomato sauce richly coating every strand of pasta.  K had the gorgeous med-rare flank steak which he gobbled down in no time and I pinched a couple of fries off his plate, they were very crispy, even better when soaked in the yummy sauce from the flank steak.  Our friend had the roasted chicken which was moist and tender and the portion was huge.  We got the profiteroles to finish off the meal, what a great choice!  At other restaurants the puff layer is soft and then gets downright soggy but these ones were crispy, so it didn't get mushy even after some of the espresso ice-cream melted on it, ingenious!  We'll be heading back very soon.
author: Jen Ken H.

description: I guess this is another reason why I hate trendy stuff. I mean this place is nice, but it's not that freaking great. I'm not going to die and go to heaven cause I ate here. It was okay, but whatever. I guess it's different if you're a yuppie... in the Mission of all places.
author: Hmmm W.

description: Has anyone else noticed that the quality of the service here is slipping?  Is it just me?  This is my favorite restaurant in the City, both for the food and the thoughtful service.  But the last couple visits, the service has just been...off.   Last Friday it was a timing issue.  We waited forever to be greeted by server and then to order.  After dessert we waited ages, and finally got his attention by waiving as he polished silverware and chatted with a co-worker.  I was really surprised -- Delfina servers are usually so great about the rhythms of a meal and checking-in just as you think you might need something.   We also got a bum steer on wine -- the description by our server didn't match what we got.  We asked for a dry white and got a perfume-y bouquet of flowers.  Our server asked what we thought of them, but he didn't seem to really hear us when we said it wasn't what we expected, or notice the fact that we left wine in our glasses.  I will note that these last couple times I've gone on busy Friday and Saturday nights and we didn't recognize our server from past visits.  Maybe these nights are too hectic for the servers to maintain the excellent service?  Maybe lots of new waitstaff?  Anyway, I hope this phase passes.  Anyone else notice this?
author: Tamalyn t.

description: People sometimes talk about pizza like a religion. I'm not one of those guys. I find it extremely hard to believe that the difference between water on east and west coast is why pizza isn't the same. Whatever. With that said, let me just say this is hands down the best pizza I've ever had. I was in a bad mood, they didn't seat my sister and her boyfriend until I arrived (if you see how small the place is, I guess I could understand but does it really matter if you ORDER for everyone). Yeah, I was in a bad mood but one bite of that margarita pizza (which by the way, it seemed like every table had ordered - must be the specialty) and heaven. My sister gasped about how fresh the mozzarella always is between mouthfuls. We ordered THREE pizzas, I had made a bet for the cost of dinner prior to tasting the pizza that we wouldn't finish them all. Now I'm $70 poorer (yep, wine/beer make it pricey) but have a big smile on my face. Yeah, this place is awesome.
author: Ben H.

description: What can I say about Delfina other than been there many times and am always pleased with the food (I always pick the pasta!) Sometimes the wait staff can be a little erratic with their attentiveness but the place is always packed and the plates are always empty. Bit taken aback with the increase in corkage to $18 as it is still a neighborhood restaurant!
author: dawn w.

description: Fresh food and good times happens at Delfina.  Order the gnocchi.  It melts in your mouth.  Overall, the dishes are consistently yummy.
author: amy l.

description: i can't say a bad word about this place. our server was amazing, our food was perfect and the desert was to die for.
